Academia: Safety Net Or Threat?
LEAD: Trying to identify musical trends in a crazy-quilt culture can be frustrating.

Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
LEAD:  Strawberry's lack of maturity and lackadaisical play both on defense and offense make him expendable.
He definitely should be traded to the American League for a number of quality players, while he still has value.
By trading him, it may help him to grow up and also help the Mets, by showing that even big name stars can be traded.

Echoes of a Princely Past in a Many Layered City

Huge public housing estates in unpainted concrete rise out of the gravelly red soil where cattle still linger, as if no one had informed them that the past was over, fini.

Review/Music; Quartet Opens Shostakovich Project
LEAD: Dmitri Shostakovich was 32 years old and had five symphonies behind him when he completed his first string quartet, in 1938.
At his death in 1975, the symphonies and quartets had reached parity - 15 each.
The cycles complement each other, with the symphonies standing as his more public pronouncements and the quartets as records of his private turmoil.

A Monastery Stay: Expect the Austere
LEAD: NESTLED in the Sabine hills 30 miles north of Rome, the Imperial Abbey at Farfa was the most important monastery of the Carolingian period in Italy.
Writers of the time said it had no equal for its situation, the splendor of its artisans and its importance politically.
Because it had Charlemagne as its protector and owned vast territories in central Italy, Farfa was considered one of the most powerful Benedictine abbeys in Europe and one of the most famous buildings of the Middle Ages.

''Goodbye, Columbus'' won the author the National Book Award at the age of 26.

But it was.
Passages of Christ's body were painted with angular, creamy brushstrokes that appeared to be lifting off the canvas.

Exiled King's Body Returned
LEAD: Thousands of people turned out in Yugoslavia's southern republic of Montenegro today for the return of the remains of their last king, who died in exile in Italy in 1921.
It was the first time a Communist country allowed the return of the remains of a former royal ruler.
The remains of the King, Nikola Petrovic, the Queen, Milena, and their two daughters, Vjera and Ksenija, were carried to the ancient Montenegrin capital of Cetinje, 125 miles south of Belgrade, for reburial.

A Cotswolds Journey: Back Into Time
LEAD: THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF GLOUCESTER-shire is stone country - Cotswold stone, oolitic limestone.
What lies beneath the soil is reflected above in the golden glow of cottages, churches, manor houses, the dry stone walls that snake up the hillsides.
There is no building material to match this limestone: it reflects and absorbs light in a way that perfectly matches the shifting, changing moods of the countryside.

Questing; Adventures And Visions
LEAD: When pilgrims of the Middle Ages saw the spires of the great Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela, they knew that their adventure was at an end.
The goals may be different for today's pilgrims - although Santiago still holds rich rewards - but the pleasure of the traveler's quest remains.
The past rises from the present: houses and landscapes, informed by imagination, are populated by poets and princes, saints and charlatans.

LEAD: It comes to few men to be as successful in films as Burt Reynolds has been.
For five consecutive years, a record bested only by Shirley Temple, he parlayed an easygoing insouciance, a riverboat gambler's charm and a genial bonhomie into a run as the world's No. 1 box-office draw. ''I am a part of film history, and that pleases me no end,'' he says quietly.

San Francisco's Real Mission
LEAD: EACH TIME AMERICA SEALS ME IN A laminate of deadlines and Dow Jones averages, bills due and bills payable, I journey to a place where urgencies fade, colors brighten and all claims on reality begin to look relative.
Just a stroll down the hill - though, like a good Californian, I usually drive - leads me out of my silent, wind-scoured, chillingly pretty neighborhood into a raucous, mouldering, charmingly unscrubbed caldron.

A World of Pottery in Vermont
LEAD: FINE handcrafts, especially pottery, have become a major attraction for visitors to southern Vermont.
Whether the basic plan is to camp out under the summer stars, gaze at the fall foliage, or zoom down a sugar-white ski slope, more and more Vermont vacationers are visiting some of the region's many craft centers and artisans' studios, seeking something to take home that will not merely be a reminder of the trip but also a work of art.

Correction
LEAD: The Personal Finance column last week misstated the rule that determines when the wages of children employed by their parents become subject to Social Security tax.
Because of recent changes in the law, the tax applies to children 18 years of age or older, not to younger children.

He offered two options: clean up the sport or have it abolished.

LEAD: SQUIRRELS are not among my favorite creatures.

No, I have no need for squirrels.

ART VIEW
LEAD: Every museum director dreams of the exemplary acquisition - the one that will appear to have found its way to the museum with a beautiful inevitability.
Almost never, of course, does it happen like that.
But that is how it can look in retrospect, just as when we have watched a golfer hole out in one we forget that, before the little white ball nestled down at the bottom of the hole, luck, wind, weather and a supreme degree of nervous concentration all had a part to play.

Columbia Pictures accepted a $3.4 billion offer from the Japanese electronics giant.
Columbia produces several successful television series but its movie division has lagged.
The biggest attraction for Sony executives, led by the president, Norio Ohga, apparently was the 2,700 films in Columbia's library.

Rose Seeks Some Help
LEAD: After being banished from baseball amid allegations that he violated major league rules by betting on baseball, including making wagers on his own team, Pete Rose has concluded that he has a problem and has sought professional help.


Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
LEAD:  Darryl has proven to be a liability in the field, lazy on the bases, and a poor hitter in both his average and his power when men are on base.
Would the Mets be sacrificing home runs by trading Darryl?
Probably.
But more importantly, would the Mets be a better team with a player in right field who batted, played hard everyday, and who hit better than .260 for a career?


For the Homeless, Public Spaces Are Growing Smaller
LEAD: IN recent years, New York City officials have done little to stop thousands of homeless people from staying in the city's bus and rail terminals, some subway stations and parks.
But lately, as the number of homeless people and the number of complaints about them have continued to rise, the officials seem to have taken a tougher approach.

Three-Day Fair to Open
LEAD: DOZENS of craft artists in 31 states have been polishing, stitching or waiting for their kilns to cool in the last-minute preparations before they pack up for the trek to New Jersey this week.
Despite the prospect of a long, rigorous drive with a van full of fragile glass, comic ceramic pots, jewelry or handmade clothing, nearly 1,000 people applied to show their work at the 13th annual Morristown CraftMarket.

It is a reunion for a family that appeared together for the first time in the 1912 inaugural show of the Greenwich Society of Artists, which was also held at the Bruce.

The Quest for a Pacific Beach
LEAD: UNDER SOME COCONUT PALMS NEAR THE entrance to Manuel Antonio Park, a woman sells juice.
Little capital investment has gone into this business: a booth, a glass juice squeezer for oranges, a machete to cut coconuts constitute the operation.
The woman twists and presses the oranges for me with wholehearted vigor.

Tolstoy's Little Universe
LEAD: THE SERFS ARE GONE FROM YASNAYA POLYANA, BUT birches still sway on this serene piece of Russia that was universe enough for the riotous creativity of Leo Tolstoy.
Here, on his aristocratic family's estate, the writer and moral reformer was born, and here he alternately despaired and then took heart from fallible humanity, reworking its lessons and language into art.

Virgil Thomson, Composer, Critic and Collaborator With Stein, Dies at 92
LEAD: Virgil Thomson, whose homespun, subtly sophisticated compositions and witty but trenchant criticism made him a central figure in American intellectual life for 55 years, died early yesterday in his suite at the Chelsea Hotel in Manhattan.
He was 92 years old, and his health had been in decline for several months.

Working Warily With Japan
LEAD: INSIDE the Austin, Tex., laboratories of Sematech, the research consortium struggling to restore American manufacturing skills in memory chips, the Japanese are distinctly unwelcome.
The clean rooms where chips are fabricated are closed to most foreigners.
When Sematech needed a Nikon repairman to keep a vital piece of equipment running, he was walled off from the rest of the lab.

MISUSE OF THE I.R.S.
LEAD: David Burnham focused on I.R.S. abuses that occurred prior to 1976, the year in which sweeping revisions were made to Section 6103 of the Internal Revenue Code.
The provision as it reads today carries stiff penalties (5 years' imprisonment and a fine of up to $5,000 for each offense) for abuse of the information gathered by the Internal Revenue Service.


Works in Progress; Egging Them On
LEAD: SEA TURTLES ARE LARGELY mysterious creatures.
Because they are pelagic, meaning they live their entire lives in the open ocean, most of what we know about them comes from observing the females, who periodically visit beaches, mainly in warm-water regions, to lay eggs.
There are no estimates as to the extant population, but it is evident, from the numbers of turtles that become casualties in the course of commercial fishing and the loss of their egg-laying habitat to beach development, that they are a dwindling breed.


Food; CAMPFIRE CACHET
LEAD: THE SMELL OF a wood fire on a crisp fall day has a certain allure to a certain set of people, those susceptible to the imagined romance of snuggling indoors near the flames on a chilly night.
Since much of my childhood was endured in a house that relied on wood fires for both cooking and heating, the mystique has always mystified me.

How to DeadenA Live Concert
LEAD: Assuming that music has been around nearly as long as people have been talking, then recordings, which first became available soon after Thomas Edison figured out his wax cylinder in 1877, have been around for just a short blip on the long graph of mankind.
But in that short time, recordings, and the technology that allows them to exist, have radically changed music.

Griffith's 'Intolerance,' Given the Blush of Youth
LEAD: Imagine an elephant as big as a brownstone, rearing back, straight up, on its hind legs.
Place the pachyderm atop a column twice as high again.
The column is on an arch, flanked by scores of stairs.
Multiply by six, surround with stenciled walls taller than Times Square billboards, throw in a few more oversize elephants, sundry 10-foot lions and 5,000 antlike humans on a movie set.

Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday about airline safety included incorrect figures from the National Transportation Safety Board.
In 1979, 354 people were killed in accidents involving large commercial jet flights flown by United States airlines.
This year 277 have been killed.

The project, called Pondside, will include 94 two- and three-bedroom town houses and 96 one- and two-bedroom condominium units around two manmade ponds.

Question Of the Week; Should The Mets Trade Strawberry?
LEAD:  Absolutely not.
Trading away Strawberry would become a blunder similar to the exportation of Nolan Ryan and Tom Seaver.
Darryl is the premier left-handed power hitter in the National League.
He has been plagued by injuries all season which have resulted in a drop of his statistics.
RICHARD S.


Russia's Reborn Splendor
LEAD: WANTON destruction, in wartime, was once a frequent German amusement.
In 1871, for instance, the palace of St.-Cloud, outside Paris, was shelled for the sheer fun of it.
And during World War II, Hitler's army, as it whiled away the siege of Leningrad, destroyed the imperial palaces just outside the city.


Alaska Oil Fund's Dividend Is Second Largest
LEAD: This year, when thousands of people in Alaska felt the effects of the nation's largest oil spill, the state's residents will receive their second largest annual check from Alaska's oil wealth savings account.


FOR WOMEN GOLFERS, LIFE IN THE ROUGH
LEAD: AS THE SKY GROWS PASTEL OVER THE FAIRWAYS, A GROUP OF EX-cited corporate executives at the Beaconsfield Golf Club, outside Montreal, are busily draining their highballs.
Each of them, all men, has paid more than $1,000 to buy a round of golf with a Ladies' Professional Golf Association touring pro.

Hang On To the Old One
LEAD: To the Editor:


TALKING: 'Gazundering'; Soft Market Puts Sellers On the Spot
LEAD: WHEN the housing market is weak, sellers are sometimes forced to accept less for a home than the price stipulated in the sales contract.
Brokers and lawyers say buyers are increasingly chipping away, between the signing of the contract and the closing, in an effort to get the seller to lower the agreed-upon price.


Meal Memorializes AIDS Victim
LEAD: AN unusual new cookbook out this month is donating part of its profits to providing meals for people with AIDS. ''The Open Hand Cookbook'' (Pocket Books, $18.95) is a compilation of menus donated by 60 California chefs.
Edited by Robert C. Schneider, a chef associated with several California restaurants (among them the Hayes Street Grill and the Pier 23 Cafe in San Francisco), the focus is on nourishing meals chefs cook for friends.

LEAD: According to Cindy E. Soehner, her son, Shane, is ''the kind of child who keeps teachers on their toes.'' Sailing Fiji's Far Waters
LEAD: SUNLIGHT COMES THROUGH THE HATCH OF the crew compartment in this 50-foot sailboat - now at anchor in Suva, Fiji - and wakes me at dawn.
I've taken the lower berth, 24 inches across at its widest point.
Through the hull, a few inches from my ear, I hear snapping shrimp crackle softly like popcorn as they graze along the bottom of the sea.

MISUSE OF THE I.R.S.
LEAD: The tax code, like other American products, should become obsolete every five years.
Planned obsolescence would force the writers of the tax code to be concise.
A lawmaker, pressed for time, might write a few pithy pages but would not have the patience to amend a 2,000-page fossil.
DUWASKY SNOW

OBRYCKI'S: PARADISE ENOW
LEAD: Baltimoreans are a real nice bunch of guys, but they have this thing about their old part of town.
Imagine a compulsion to take all visitors to New York through Corona for their dose of urban quaintness.
Nevertheless, the children of the Chesapeake like nothing better than to stroll through this engulfing blockade of row houses, with their multicolored faux brick facing and three-step stoops, beaming as if they were Roosevelt showing off Campobello.

At Home in Tuscany
LEAD: IT all seemed very Italian, renting a house in Tuscany with my husband, our two sons and my mother, all five of us piling in and out of the car wherever we went.
The two women collecting money for the use of the public toilets at Pisa's Campo dei Miracoli thought it was terrific.
They laughed when my husband kept shelling out coins as we straggled in, one by one.

Jamming on the Other Side of Midnight
LEAD: In a television studio in lower midtown Manhattan, where episodes of ''The Phil Silvers Show'' once originated, ''Night Music'' (formerly called ''Sunday Night'') is taping the first show of its second season, scheduled to air tonight in the New York area on Channel 4 at 12:30 A.M.
It is 10 o'clock at night, but the host, David Sanborn, tailored in his trademark black and gray, wears sunglasses during rehearsal.

&gt;Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My screened porch has a concrete slab floor.
For years, I have been painting this floor with an acrylic concrete deck paint, and in April the paint bubbles and lifts in large sections.
I scrape these areas and then repaint the floor, but the bubbling and separating grow worse each year.
Is there a way to correct this?

Colette: Home Of the Heart
LEAD: BENEATH THE STANDARD FRENCH ROAD SIGN FOR ST.-Sauveur-en-Puisaye, in Burgundy, another larger one proclaims with elaborate flourish that this is ''Colette's Country.'' In the village itself, crude hand-lettered wooden arrows point the way to the house where she was born.
Dun-colored signs identify every street but one - there, on fresh royal-blue enamel (blue was her favorite color), a sharp white replica of her signature marks the ''Rue Colette.


Policeman Slain in Santiago
LEAD: Gunmen thought to be leftist extremists ambushed a national police van answering a bogus call for help in San Miguel, a working-class district of Santiago, late Friday, killing a police corporal and wounding a patrolman, the authorities said.
Youths had erected burning street barricades nearby, apparently as a distraction.


WHAT A CHILD IS GIVEN
LEAD: Deborah Franklin's article raises some interesting questions.
She cites numerous instances in which there is evidence that heredity dictates the traits of individuals - including quite minor traits - but she reports that on such fundamental issues as a person's ''niceness'' or the tendency to ''criminality'' heredity does not seem very important.

If You're Thinking of Living in: Grymes Hill
LEAD: WHEN David and Marjorie Hack moved to Staten Island's Grymes Hill in 1979, they couldn't afford anything better than a $65,000 handyman special on the fringe of the decaying, high-crime Stapleton neighborhood.
Now, 10 years and $150,000 later, the 1910 eight-bedroom Victorian is almost completely restored and is valued by brokers at about $420,000.


Design; AS TIME GOES BY
LEAD: MANHATTAN BROWN-stones that have remained single-family houses are a rarity these days, especially those that have retained their original layouts and intricate architectural details.
The rooms in this 1860's house were remodeled, but nearly 80 years ago during the Edwardian era.
In the intervening years, they have been lovingly preserved and purposely decorated to reflect the spirit of the place.

Frans Hals: Unabashed Painter of Portraits
LEAD: If there is a time for everything, the time for Frans Hals came in the middle of the 19th century, some 200 years after he died.
Hals had spent more than five decades as a portraitist in his adopted city of Haarlem, a position not without significance but hardly one that qualified him as eminent.
Painters of grand historical and religious scenes were considered artists of ambition; portraiture was an altogether more lowly endeavor.

Santiago's Golden Legend
LEAD: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA HAS BEEN A lodestar for visitors for more than a thousand years.
The world's first guidebook was written in 1130 by Aimeri Picaud, a French monk, to give information to travelers on their way there.
In the early Middle Ages, between 500,000 and 2 million people came each year.

LEAD: I was encouraged by Deborah Franklin's article ''What a Child Is Given'' (Sept. 3).

I know now that my concern about ''contracting'' her illness was unnecessary, but the emotional scars of growing up in an unstable family remain.

The Taxpayer's Turn to Win a Few
LEAD: The number of rounds in which the taxpayer emerges the victor after battling the Internal Revenue Service are precious few, but lately the Government has been taking it on the chin.

They have won disputes over deductions of home office expenses and personal computer purchases and they were awarded legal fees for litigation that arose because of heavy-handed I.R.S.

Italy's Vin Santo: A Sip of Hospitality
LEAD: IN Tuscany and neighboring Umbria, vin santo is the wine of hospitality.
Whatever the time of day, a guest is offered a small glass of the amber dessert wine. ''It's the wine of hospitality, the wine of friendship and of courtesy,'' explains Giacomo Tachis, winemaker for the 650-year-old Tuscan firm Antinori.

WHAT A CHILD IS GIVEN
LEAD: Unfortunately, the laws concerning secrecy in adoption records have not kept pace with findings in medicine and psychology.
Only two states -Alaska and Kansas - give adult adoptees access to their birth records on demand, and the vast majority of other states have ''sealed records'' laws that effectively prevent reunions between adoptees and their birth families.

Coping in an Italian Castle
LEAD: IT is called Castello di Polgeto, it's near Umbertide in Umbria and we rented its only ground-floor apartment.
With it came our own cherry tree in full fruit, our own owl and cuckoo, our own private garden with two elegant cypresses flanked by a low stone wall.
On one side of the garden stood a small stone barn where the previous owner had wintered his lemon trees; behind us rose a hollow 70-foot tower connected to a wing of the castle by the tower bridge under which we parked our car.

Tax Watch; Family Business In a Legal Tangle
LEAD: FEW provisions of the sweeping overhaul of the nation's tax laws in recent years have prompted as many anguished protests from tax professionals as Section 2036(c), colloquially known as the antifreeze provision.
It is intended to prevent affluent families from escaping gift and estate taxes by using techniques known as estate freezes to transfer family-owned businesses to a younger generation.

Club Sweetens Stroke
LEAD: A new technique for weighting a golf club iron is designed to compensate for off-center hits.
Subtle changes occur in the contour of the club head if it strikes a ball outside the sweet spot, its optimal striking surface.
Wilson Sporting Goods Company of River Grove, Ill., recently introduced its Ultra, an iron made to minimize the microscopic twisting that comes from an imperfect stroke.

LEAD: ICI Americas Inc., a subsidiary of the British chemical giant Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., said it would build a plant in Louisiana to make an environmentally safer alternative to ozone-depleting chloroflourocarbons.
Chloroflourocarbons are used as the cooling agent in refrigerators and air-conditioners and in producing plastic foams and pharmaceuticals.

Phone Debentures Are Priced at Par
LEAD: The Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia offered $100 million of debentures yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The 8 3/8 percent debentures, which have a final maturity date of Oct. 1, 2029, carry a ''put,'' at par, or $100, on Oct. 1, 1999.


Braniff Starts Some Flights
LEAD: With a $49 one-way fare to attract passengers, Braniff Inc. resumed about 20 percent of its 256 daily flights.
The carrier was virtually shut last week as it filed its second bankruptcy reorganization in seven years.


Kangaroos Sets Merger
LEAD: Jumping-Jacks Shoes Inc. reached a preliminary agreement last week to merge with Kangaroos U.S.A.
Inc., a privately held shoe company.
The agreement calls for Jumping-Jacks shareholders to own a 20 percent equity stake in the combined operations, with the rest being owned by Kangaroos shareholders.

LEAD: The House of Representatives approved a 4.9 percent cost-of-living increase in benefits today for some 2.5 million disabled veterans and their survivors.

LEAD: Joseph Fama, the 18-year-old white youth accused of shooting a black teen-ager to death in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, suffered a slight injury under the right eye, apparently at the hands of a guard at the Brooklyn House of Detention last week, authorities said yesterday.


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas rose last week by 11, to 978, Baker Hughes Inc., the oilfield services company, said yesterday.
A year ago, there were 918 rigs in operation.
The weekly rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas, not those producing oil and gas.


CHINA WARNS U. S. ON INTERFERENCE
LEAD: The Chinese Foreign Minister said yesterday that his country's relations with the United States were ''at a crossroads.'' He said relations could improve if America accepted the premise that China has a different political system that should not be criticized.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about the annual animal blessing at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine misidentified the presiding minister.
He was the Right Rev.
Paul Moore Jr., Episcopal Bishop of New York, not Bishop James Parks Morton, Dean of the cathedral.

Sifting Through What Little the Battles Have Left
Two years after the end of the First World War, on the former battlefields of France, there is still grim business at hand.
And business it is: as the nightmare of war recedes, it has been replaced by bustling, impromptu forms of industry that call for their own curious brand of sang-froid.
Those who have undertaken, quite literally, to sift through the rubble do so with patience, fussiness, occasional opportunism, gallows humor and most of the same bureaucratic instincts they might bring to other, less catastrophe-laden lines of work.
It is the only way of bringing the horror to heel.
In the setting near Verdun where Bertrand Tavernier's ''Life and Nothing But'' takes place, the first stages of recovery have produced a constant hum of activity.
Soldiers are everywhere, an international group searching methodically for the dead and resting in the temporary barracks and restaurants that have sprung up to accommodate them.
Relatives of the missing, guided by desperate optimism and not really expecting anything but the worst, have also arrived upon the scene.
All are united by a deliberately short-sighted pragmatism that almost succeeds in making tragedy matter of fact.

How the Blue Jays and the A's Line Up  Toronto Blue Jays  Catchers(average, home runs, r.b.i.)  12Ernie Whitt (.262, 11, 53)  Last remaining player from the Blue Jays' 1976 expansion draft. Left-handed bat makes him the likely starter against Oakland, despite 9-for-57 slump (.158) at finish.  10Pat Borders (.257, 1, 3)  Will serve primarily as Whitt's backup, although he took part in 94 games, had a good season and finished with a small flourish.  Infielders(average, home runs, r.b.i.)  19Fred McGriff 1b (.269, 36, 92)  Season dragged at the end: no home runs since Sept. 4, a 10-for-73 slide. Still, he won the American League home run title and drew 44 walks in the last 42 games. Switched spots in the order with George Bell, batting third to see better pitches to hit.  2Nelson Liriano 2b (.263, 5, 53)  A switch-hitter who will probably start against right-handers. He has a good glove and exceptional speed.  4Manny Lee 2b (.266, 3, 34)  Usually plays against left-handed pitching. He batted .266 from both sides of plate and swung a strong bat in September.  17Kelly Gruber 3b (.290, 18, 73)  His second full season as the regular third baseman. He hit a career-best 18 home runs, tying Bell for second on the club.  1Tony Fernandez ss, (.257, 11, 64)  Defense was typically spectacular: six errors at short in 140 games. Headed for fourth Gold Glove, but also a threat with the bat (a career-high 11 homers) and speed (22 for 28 stolen bases).  Outfielders(average, home runs, r.b.i.)  3Mookie Wilson rf (.298, 2, 17)  Mets couldn't use him, but Blue Jays began to surge when he arrived in July trade. Hit .205 in New York, then close to .300 for Toronto. Gave team an emotional lift.  15Lloyd Moseby cf (.221, 11, 43)  Best years are behind him, but he still helped win Friday's game against Baltimore. Moved into the leadoff spot in the order recently. Team-leading 24 steals.  54Junior Felix lf (.258, 9, 46)  Good glove in right, but he had only four r.b.i. in the final 48 games and only four extra-base hits in the last 38.  Designated Hitter(average, home runs, r.b.i.)  11George Bell (.297, 18, 104)  Bad right elbow took him out of left field and into the d.h. role. Likely to stay there for the post-season. Had 100-plus r.b.i. for the third time in the last four years and 22-game hitting streak in August, the longest in the American League.  Starting Pitchers(record, e.r.a.)  37Dave Stieb rh (17-8, 3.35)  Led the club in victories. Pitched two one-hitters and one two-hitter, and took a perfect game into the ninth against the Yankees in August. Opposing batters hit .219 against him.  30Todd Stottlemyre rh (7-7, 3.88)  Good genes, son of former pitcher Mel. Matured into a fine pitcher after realizing he could not overpower hitters. LEAD: The Supreme Court, turning down an appeal in one of the most closely watched business cases on its docket, refused today to intervene in an Illinois prosecution of a Chicago manufacturer accused of exposing employees to toxic chemicals.

LEAD: NITROGEN deposited in the soil by acid rain and as agricultural fertilizer may be promoting an atmospheric buildup of methane gas, a major contributor to the greenhouse effect, a new study suggests.

Mylan Cites Drug For Rise in Stock
LEAD: Mylan Laboratories Inc., whose stock price has risen more than 20 percent in the last week, said its shares could be gaining because of the positive response to the anti-Parkinson's disease drug, Eldepryl.
The drug is sold by Somerset Pharmaceuticals, which is jointly held by Mylan and the Bolar Pharmaceuticals Company.


Non-Socialists Forming Government in Norway
LEAD: Three moderate non-Socialist political parties agreed today to form a coalition government.
But with fewer seats in Parliament than the Socialist Labor Party, which they would replace, their prospects for maintaining power are widely viewed here as doubtful.


Motorola to Cut 2,500 Workers
LEAD: Motorola Inc. said it would reduce its 105,000-employee work force by 2,500, or 2.4 percent, and take a pretax charge of about $43 million in the third quarter to cover the cost of the voluntary severance program.
The company said the cut of salaried employees would be made mostly from its United States operations and would be effective immediately.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 31 about ''Days of Rage,'' a documentary about the uprisings in the Israeli-occupied territories, referred incorrectly to financial backing of The Journal of Palestine Studies.
In a letter to The Times, Philip Mattar, executive director of the Institute for Palestine Studies, said the journal is underwritten solely by the institute and by Kuwait University, receiving no money from the Palestine Liberation Organization.

Review/Recital; Norwegian Seeks Extremes For the Cello
LEAD: Truls Mork, a cellist from Norway, seems drawn to music that allows him to move between the expressive extremes to which his instrument is best suited.
In the Grieg Sonata (Op. 36), for instance - the high point of his Saturday evening program at Weill Recital Hall - Mr.
Mork and his pianist, Juhani Lagerspetz, played with unbridled energy.


Yugoslav Inflation Soars
LEAD: Yugoslavia's annual inflation rate increased to 1,181 percent in September.
The Bureau of Statistics said inflation had increased by a monthly record of 287.2 percentage points, compared with 893.8 percent in August.
In September 1988, the inflation rate was 217 percent.


Sana Journal; With A Dagger in Its Belt, Yemen Is a State of Mind
LEAD: A Yemeni magazine editor pointed at the handle of the curved dagger thrust into his woven silk waistband and explained its origin by way of a gesture depicting the single horn of a rhinoceros.

LEAD: The Texas Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the state's system for financing public schools is unconstitutional because of ''glaring disparities'' between what rich and poor school districts spend on education.

In an unusual cooperative effort directed by the Defense Department and NASA, scientists and engineers from leading aerospace companies are beginning to overcome daunting problems like finding exotic materials that can withstand temperatures of 3,000 degrees

Ford Prices Raised 4.9%
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company's 1990 model cars will cost an average of 4.9 percent more than comparably equipped 1989 vehicles, the company announced.
Ford said nearly half of the increase came because of Government-required passive safety devices like driver-side air bags or automatic seat belts.
The General Motors Corporation has announced a 3.4 percent average price increase, and the Chrysler Corporation, which will announce its prices within two weeks, has estimated its increase will be about 5 percent.

Consumer Trust Steady
LEAD: Consumer confidence in the American economy was steady in September, after dropping sharply in August, the Conference Board said yesterday in a survey that suggested a recession was unlikely for the immediate future.
The business research group's Consumer Confidence Index totaled 115.4 in September, the same as the previous month.


Our Deposit Insurance Would Startle New Deal
LEAD: To the Editor:


Stock Link By Nintendo
LEAD: Fidelity Investments, a Boston-based private investment mangement company, and the Nintendo Company of Japan, the world's largest video game manufacturer, said yesterday that they would team up to develop, produce and market a home trading system for financial services.


To Get His Museum, Opening in '92
LEAD: More than 700 paintings by Andy Warhol, as well as drawings, prints, photographs, sculptures, films and videotapes, will form the core collection of a museum devoted entirely to the artist's work, to open in 1992 in his hometown, Pittsburgh.


Acting S.E.C. Chairman
LEAD: President Bush today named Edward H. Fleischman, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission since 1986, to be acting head of the panel.
Mr.
Fleischman, 57 years old, a former New York lawyer, will head the S.E.C. while the Senate considers the President's appointment of Richard C. Breeden, a White House aide, as permanent chairman.


Man Held in Crashes And Machete Attack
LEAD: A 39-year-old attacked a woman with a machete yesterday and hit two pedestrians with his car before slamming into a police station house, the police said.
The police said the man, Sergio Vega of 1535 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, was drugged, apparently on cocaine.


Girl's Mother Doubted Assault Report, Study Says
LEAD: School officials delayed informing the police of reports of a sexual assault against a retarded 17-year-old by a group of athletes because her parents declined to file a criminal complaint, a Board of Education report said today.


Kellogg Expects Lower Earnings
LEAD: The Kellogg Company said it expects its third-quarter earnings to be lower than in the corresponding period last year because of increasing competition for ready-to-eat oat bran cereal.
The announcement caused a sharp fall today in the company's stock, which lost $2.25 to close at $71.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.


By Design; Illusions of Youth
LEAD: There is a good reason so many heads of gray hair become blond.
Or why hair styles that stop at the chin line are better than those that fall to the shoulder.
These two are just a few of the illusionary tricks that trim time off a woman's age.

LEAD: The Houghton Mifflin Company, one of the few remaining independent American book publishers, announced yesterday that it intends to purchase Victor Gollancz, a 60-year-old privately held British publishing house.
Terms of the deal were not disclosed.


Visa Applicants Deluge Embassy in Moscow
LEAD: People lined up for blocks outside the American Embassy here today and snapped up more than 30,000 visa applications as new emigration rules went into effect.


Construction Spending Up For August
LEAD: The Government said today that construction spending had made its biggest monthly advance of the year in August.
The gain was in Government and nonresidential building, while single-family housing continued to sag.

Blaming Others for Collapse of PTL, Bakker Completes Testimony
LEAD: Jim Bakker finished a day and a half of testimony at his fraud and conspiracy trial today by blaming his fellow evangelist Jerry Falwell, who took over the Bakker ministry, for its collapse.


Witold Rowicki, 75, Polish Conductor, Dies
LEAD: Witold Rowicki, who founded the Warsaw National Philharmonic Orchestra and was its conductor for nearly 25 years, died on Sunday, the official Polish press agency reported today.
He was 75 years old.


A Divorce Settlement Forces Out Founder
LEAD: As part of a divorce settlement, George E. Johnson, chairman and founder of the Johnson Products Company, resigned yesterday and transferred control of the company to his former wife, Joan B. Johnson, the company's board announced.
Their son, Eric G. Johnson, was named chief executive.


U.S. Cites New York In Sludge Dumping
LEAD: A Federal complaint has been issued against New York City for spilling sewage sludge into the East River.
The complaint, seeking $100,000 in civil penalties, was announced yesterday by the Environmental Protection Agency, which said the city dumped 328,000 gallons of sludge into the river on Sept 22.


Groups to Consider Proposals to N.C.A.A.
LEAD: With three months remaining before the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention, the N.C.A.A.'s Presidents' Commission will meet in Kansas City beginning today to approve legislation it will propose to the convention.


Coelho to Join Banking Firm
LEAD: Tony Coelho, the former United States Representative from California who resigned in June amid accusations of financial impropriety, said today that he was becoming a partner at Wertheim Schroder &amp; Company, an investment banking firm.


Corrections
LEAD: A brief report in Business Day on Thursday about fines paid by two banks to the Federal Reserve Board for improper recording of deposits reversed the amounts.
The National Bank of Greece paid a $125,000 fine.


Dollar Up in Quiet Trading Despite Central Bank Sales
LEAD: The dollar rose in quiet trading yesterday, resisting continued selling by central banks.
Gold prices were mixed. ''Trading was dominated by profit taking, with central bank intervention less effective,'' said Ronald Holzer, a currency broker with the Harris Trust and Savings Bank.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Sept. 25 about a rally of 10,000 Ukrainians in Kiev mistranslated the banner shown.
It called, in Ukrainian and Yiddish, for official restoration of ethnic and regional languages.


Japanese Get Music Stake
LEAD: A Japanese media group will pay about $150 million to buy a stake of just over 25 percent in the London-based Virgin Music Group, the world's sixth-largest record company, Virgin's managing director, Ken Berry, said today.


Conservative Picked for Kenya
LEAD: President Bush today announced his intention to nominate a conservative journalist, Smith Hempstone Jr., to be Ambassador to Kenya.
Mr.
Hempstone, 60 years old, a former executive editor of The Washington Times, wrote a syndicated column for that newspaper until his retirement a month ago.
In the 1960's, he worked as a foreign correspondent in Africa and Latin America for The Chicago Daily News.


Jean Grambs, Teacher And Author, 70, Dies
LEAD: Jean Grambs, a professor of human development at the College of Education at the University of Maryland at College Park until her retirement last year, died after suffering a heart attack Saturday at her home in College Park.
She was 70 years old.


Leona B. Hill, Advertising Executive, 79
LEAD: Leona Bowman Hill, an advertising executive and founder of The Fashion Newsletter, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at New York Hospital.
She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Robert Felheim, 85, Ex-Brokerage Partner
LEAD: Robert J. Felheim, a retired partner of Neuberger &amp; Berman, a brokerage and money-management concern, died Friday at New York Hospital.
He was 85 years old and lived in Singer Island, Fla.

LEAD: After two weeks of complicated, cryptic and sometimes obscure testimony, a jury here is preparing to decide whether the journalist Seymour M. Hersh libeled a former Prime Minister of India, Morarji Desai, when he described him as a paid informer for the Central Intelligence Agency.


Bulls Sign King, Their Top Choice
LEAD: Stacey King, a No. 1 draft choice who is expected to provide more inside scoring and rebounding to complement Michael Jordan's outside play, signed a contract with the Chicago Bulls yesterday.
No terms were disclosed.
King is the first of the top six choices drafted last spring to come to terms.

LEAD: Alice T. McGillion, the New York City Police Department's chief spokeswoman, was named yesterday to the No. 2 police post, first deputy commissioner, making her the highest-ranking woman ever in the department.


SCI Television In Loan Default
LEAD: SCI Television Inc. said yesterday that as expected it had defaulted on a $153 million principal payment that it owes a group of bank lenders, led by the Bankers Trust Company, and would also have to skip interest payments due Oct. 15 on two ''junk bond'' issues.

LEAD: Already reeling from an apparent fraud at its United States unit that has cost almost $300 million, the British military contractor Ferranti today lost about a third of its market value when its shares resumed trading on the London Stock Exchange.

LEAD: New-home sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent in August but remained above 750,000 for the second consecutive month, as buyers took advantage of lower interest rates, the Government reported today.

LEAD: With a strike deadline hours away, four New York City area hospitals, including Beth Israel Medical Center, broke ranks with industry negotiators and reached separate union agreements late last night, officials involved in the negotiations said.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marketers Study Start Of a Network
LEAD: A new television network, created and programmed by the nation's largest marketing companies, is one of several ideas marketers are studying to combat rising network television costs and declining audience shares, a top advertising executive said today.


Drexel Consolidation
LEAD: In response to a dropoff in the number of the firm's employees, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has decided to consolidate its New York operations into its main headquarters on Broad Street, the firm said yesterday.
Drexel currently occupies 1.5 million square feet of office space in four downtown locations in New York, of which 400,000 will be vacated in a year and a half.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sudler &amp; Hennessey Provides Hospice Spots
LEAD: Sudler &amp; Hennessey, a subsidiary of Young &amp; Rubicam, has decided that the best way to face death is matter of factly.
That is the tone of a campaign developed by the agency as a pro bono project for the National Hospice Organization.
The organization is a nationwide association of hospices, which provide services to terminally ill patients.

Minority Students Walk Out Over a Teacher's Remarks
LEAD: Hundreds of black and Hispanic students, incensed by a history teacher's remark that they deemed racist, walked out of classes in a Brooklyn high school yesterday morning, smashing display cabinets and forcing the school to close early, the police and school officials said.


Market Place; Banking 'Frenzy' Seizes California
LEAD: STOCKS of independent California banks that have previously gone without much notice are being bid up.
The recent acquisition of four banks anticipates a shift in California state law that will allow banks in other states to enter California banking, beginning Jan. 1, 1991, either through acquisition or by opening offices, if that bank's home state has a reciprocal law.

LEAD: Last Thursday the House approved a two-year cut in the tax rate on capital gains - increases in the value of stocks, bonds and real estate - to less than 20 percent.
The decision was wrong.
Profoundly wrong.
It's now up to the Senate to preserve some semblance of conscience and reason, and reverse the


Bridge
LEAD: Good players who want to become even better will have a rare opportunity later this month.
One of the country's top player-theorists, Marty Bergen, will give a free lecture at 6 P.M. at the Manhattan Club, 23 West 73rd Street.
His subject will be competitive bidding, on which he has written extensively.

LEAD: Poland's new Government ordered an investigation today into crimes committed during the era of hard-line Communist rule in the 1940's and 1950's.

LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it expected a small operating profit in the quarter that ended last Saturday.

Manuel Antonio Noriega, to the top of the list of world figures they wanted to see removed from action.
Only Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya came as close to getting under Washington's political skin.

LEAD: Tina Sasser, a single mother of two, earns $17,000 a year as an admitting clerk at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.
She joined the last strike, five years ago, and she is prepared to walk out again.
But as the deadline loomed, she found it hard to think about anything but her bills.

Japan Acts On Apple And Canon
LEAD: In a rare crackdown on high prices, Government investigators here searched the offices of Apple Computer Japan and a unit of Canon Inc. today, seeking evidence that importers selling Macintosh computers at deep discounts are being driven out of the market.

LEAD: A senior official of New York City's Department of Correction has resigned and four others have been penalized in an investigation into charges that the department had told pregnant correction officers to have abortions or resign.

LEAD: In a major shift in policy, a Federal panel of experts has recommended that less prenatal care be provided to the 1.6 million pregnant women whose fetuses are at no apparent risk of health problems and that more be given to women whose fetuses are at risk.

He couldn't be more wrong.

Little Independence For Baltic Nations
LEAD: To the Editor:


Mets Say Farewell to Carter and Hernandez and to an Era
LEAD: The Mets closed one era and two careers yesterday when they said farewell to their 35-year-old co-captains, Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez, and sent them into the free-agent market with thanks and blessings.


French Weapons Trade
LEAD: The French Defense Ministry said Monday that the value of export orders booked by French weapons manufacturers had increased by 30 percent last year, to $6 billion.
The ministry said 53 percent of the orders were for aeronautical equipment, 36 percent for land-based equipment and 11 percent for naval equipment.


5 Million Pounds of Butter Melted in Warehouse Blaze
LEAD: Firefighters sloshed through five inches of melted butter Monday in battling a warehouse fire that burned out of control for nearly 21 hours.


U.S. Loses Key Player
LEAD: Hugo Perez, the star midfielder of the United States national soccer team, tore a groin muscle in a match last Friday and will miss this Sunday's World Cup qualifying match in Guatemala.
Perez, 25 years old, was born in El Salvador and is considered the top American player.


Overwork Led to Spill, Tanker Captain Says
LEAD: The captain whose tanker spilled 289,000 gallons of oil off Newport in June said today that he had gone 36 hours with little sleep, had no lookout and was overworked and distracted at the time of the accident.


Bundling Campaign Money: Giuliani Is the Big Beneficiary
LEAD: Thirty-two intermediaries representing the last vestiges of big money in the New York City mayoral election have funneled $685,000 into Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign in the last four months, making him the biggest single beneficiary of a process known as bundling.


U.S. Created Coup Conditions, Panamanian Asserts at U.N.
LEAD: The President of the Panamanian Government, who is loyal to General Manuel Antonio Noriega, blamed the United States today for creating conditions that led to the coup attempt in his country.


Japan Gets Import Plea
LEAD: A group of Southeast Asian countries today urged Japan to buy more of their products, dismantle trade barriers and spread technological expertise around the region.
The Association of South East Asian Nations, which consists of Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Brunei and Indonesia, said Tokyo had an important role in insuring political stability in the region, but it also had to fulfill its promise to help poorer countries develop.


S.E.C. Shuns Role In B.A.T. Takeover
LEAD: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has concluded that the commission had no power to regulate Sir James Goldsmith's bid for B.A.T.
Industries, Richard Breeden, the candidate for S.E.C. chairman, said.
Mr.
Breeden's outlined the staff's position in a 108-page response to questions from the Senate Banking Committee, which is considering his nomination.


Lessons
LEAD: President Bush may or may not be able to create a ''kinder, gentler'' nation, but he has already created a kinder, gentler Federal education policy.


Mack Sentenced
LEAD: Kevin Mack, a Cleveland Browns running back who was selected for the National Football League Pro Bowl in 1985 and 1987, was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison after pleading guilty to having used cocaine.
Judge Richard McMonagle, of Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court in Cleveland, sentenced Mack to the Mansfield Reformatory, a Cuyahoga County assistant prosecutor, Frank


Prices of Treasury Issues Rise
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities rose in lethargic trading yesterday, helped by a rise in the dollar in overseas markets.
The move in the dollar prompted some overseas buying, but dealers in New York said most domestic customers showed little interest once trading shifted to the United States.


Dollar Rises as Intervention By Central Banks Slackens
LEAD: The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday despite continued dollar-selling by central banks.
Gold prices declined.
News that the Government of Panama might have been overthrown in a coup also gave the dollar a slight kick, currency traders said.
United States Government officials later reported that the coup had failed.

LEAD: Berenice Abbott, the dean of American photographers and one who has always inveighed against visual prettification, lives in a lovely house nestled beside a tree-lined lake in this remote swath of central Maine, But Miss Abbott, who is 91 years old, shrugs off any suggestion of contradiction between the picture-postcard setting of her present life and her feisty days in the 1920's and 30's.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; R. J. Reynolds Settles
LEAD: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company agreed yesterday not to misrepresent the results of a study linking smoking and heart disease in the tobacco company's future advertisements, settling a false advertising claim brought by the Federal Trade Commission.
The F.T.C. said a Reynolds ad falsely contended that the study had proved smoking was not as hazardous as commonly believed.

LEAD: Though there are movie stars who regard classic roles as a careerlong mission instead of a one-shot summer vacation - Kevin Kline and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio among them -New York audiences have lately seen too many Hollywood visitors treat Shakespeare like a cheap tart.
These are the stars who milk the Bard for all the self-serving publicity he's worth during rehearsal, then turn their backs on him by self-indulgently goofing their way through his plays in performance.

Marjorie C. Vietor
LEAD: Marjorie C. Vietor, an organizer of the Red Cross Blood Donor Service in Manhattan in World War II, died in her sleep on Sept. 21 at Lawrence (Mass.) General Hospital.
She was 97 years old and moved in 1984 to Needham, Mass., from Woodbury, Conn., where she had lived for many years.

LEAD: GLENN BERNBAUM, owner of Mortimer's Restaurant, gave a party last night.
He had 75th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues cleared, put up six contiguous tents and charged 1,000 guests $250 each to sip donated champagne and nibble chili con carne in pastry shells.
He called his party Fete de Famille IV.

LEAD: To The Living Section:


Custody Case Heard in Egypt
LEAD: An American woman was told today that she would have to wait another month before an Egyptian court would rule on the disputed custody of her two children.
The court met in closed session to hear competing pleas from Barbara Mezo, who lives in Brooklyn, and her Egyptian mother-in-law for custody of 7-year-old Mohammed and 4-year-old Leila.

Pacers Add a Guard
LEAD: Looking for a quick guard, the Indiana Pacers yesterday signed the 6-foot Rickey Green, an 11-year veteran who spent most of his career with the Utah Jazz.
Green, 35 years old, was taken from Utah in the 1988 expansion draft by the Charlotte Hornets.
He was waived by Charlotte in February, and played the rest of the season with the Milwaukee Bucks.

LEAD: Julio Cesar Chavez of Mexico will meet Meldrick Taylor, a 1984 Olympic gold medalist, on March 17 in a title matchup of two undefeated fighters.
The fight, for Chavez's World Boxing Council superlightweight crown and Taylor's International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title, will be at the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel.

Help the Horses
LEAD: Mayor Koch has a chance - his last - to go down in history as the Mayor who liberated New York City's carriage horses.
He can do that by signing a measure that has already passed the City Council by a vote of 31 to 3.
It would protect carriage horses from having to work when it is very hot, very cold, very humid or for more than eight hours at a stretch.

LEAD: A 30-year-old worker in a heating plant near Leipzig said his rickety Trabant automobile, carrying his wife and two children, crept across the border from East Germany to Czechoslovakia at 3:45 P.M. today, one of the last before East Berlin closed itself off from the last country to which its citizens could travel with relative freedom.

LEAD: Under pressure from Congress, the Bush Administration has for the first time stated that the Central Intelligence Agency will not engage in any secret activities to influence the outcome of the Nicaraguan elections scheduled for February, members of Congress and Administration officials said today.

That agreement doesn't end the legislative struggle.

Boat Hits Pipeline in Gulf; 3 Are Killed and 7 Missing
LEAD: A 160-foot fishing boat struck a gas pipeline in the Gulf of Mexico, setting off an explosion that killed three people and injured at least four, the Coast Guard said.
At least seven people were missing. ''It was just a boom and big ball of fire went up into the air about 300 feet,'' said Allen Willett, a helicopter pilot who takes drilling crews to rigs.

A Grand (Slam) Opening for Clark and Giants
LEAD: The San Francisco Giants brought the act to 75-year-old Wrigley Field and shattered the Chicago Cubs tonight, 11-3, to win the opening game of the playoff for the National League pennant.
And most of the shattering was done by the power tandem of Will Clark and Kevin Mitchell.


Milton Goldman, Vice President Of Theatrical Agency, Dies at 75
LEAD: Milton Goldman, a prominent theatrical agent, died of heart failure in his sleep yesterday in Manhattan in his Sutton Place home.
He was 75 years old.


Vehicle Sales Rose 8.7% in Late September
LEAD: Late-September sales of North American-made cars and light trucks rose 8.7 percent, the companies reported today, but for the 12-month model year ended Sept. 30, domestic and overseas auto makers reported a 1.9 percent drop in the daily selling rate.
Dealers sold 48,669 vehicles a day in the 1989 model year, compared with 49,603 a year earlier.

LEAD: As Sam Sianis sat in his place of work, a white cloth apron tied around his waist as he spoke near the counter where cheeseburgers were being served, his easy smile suggested that he is too kind a man to inform a giddy city that its baseball team is doomed.


Graham Chapman, 48, Comedy Troupe Founder
LEAD: Graham Chapman, a Cambridge-educated physician who decided to specialize in comedy and who helped to found Monty Python's Flying Circus, died of throat cancer yesterday at a hospital near his home in England.
He was 48 years old.


GREATER U.N. ROLE URGED BY SOVIETS
LEAD: The Soviet Union outlined a set of proposals today that are intended to give the United Nations a greater role in preventing conflicts, including the creation of a chain of ''war risk reduction centers'' around the world.


Man Guilty in Accident That Killed Officer
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was found guilty of criminally negligent homicide yesterday in the fatal shooting of a police officer by a sergeant last year.


Tyson Gets Extension
LEAD: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight boxing champion, will be allowed to perform a community-service sentence for speeding after the original 60-day deadline date.
Judge Stephen Safranko agreed yesterday in Albany to let Tyson conduct three youth clinics on Monday, two days after the deadline set Aug. 7 by the judge.


Short Brothers To Bombardier
LEAD: The British Government signed over the state-owned aircraft and guided missile maker Short Brothers P.L.C. to Bombardier, a Canadian company.
Bombardier, which makes subway rolling stock and small passenger jets, paid $:30 million, or $48 million, for Short Brothers.
The Government gave the Montreal company $:780 million, or $1.25 billion, to assist in the takeover.

LEAD: This weekend the congress of the Latvian Popular Front will meet to assert its intent to bring about a fully independent nation.
No more veiled talk about ''economic sovereignty'' or confederation with the Soviet Union - the magic word is independence, the state of nationhood stolen from the Latvians 50 years ago in a pact between Stalin and Hitler.

Esselte Seeking Office Supply Unit
LEAD: Esselte A.B. of Sweden said it was negotiating to buy the remaining 22 percent stake it does not own in its Esselte Business Systems Inc. unit, an office supply company in Garden City, L.I.
The company, which did not make a formal bid, said it would pay about $40 a share for Esselte Business.
The stock of Esselte Business jumped $5.125 yesterday, to $43, on the New York Stock Exchange.


Drug Boss Tells Of Giving Order To Kill 'My Girl'
LEAD: Lorenzo (Fat Cat) Nichols, an admitted major drug dealer, testified at his secret pleading last week that he had ordered his former girlfriend killed because she stole money from him and then ''spent it on a dude,'' according to court papers unsealed yesterday.


Ford Is Recalling 70,000 Cars
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has recalled about 70,000 1988 Ford Taurus, Mercury Sable and Lincoln Continental cars to repair a potential power-steering problem.
Ford announced the recall Tuesday, saying it would replace a power-steering pump pulley on cars with 3.8-liter engines.
The pulleys could come off, causing a loss of power steering, the company said.

Farm Co-op Income Up
LEAD: The Agriculture Department said today that the net income of farm cooperatives last year rose to nearly $1.7 billion, continuing a rebound from the sharp declines of the mid-1980's.
Combined business volume of cooperatives in 1988 was reported at $66.3 billion, up 10.3 percent from $60.2 billion in 1987.

LEAD: Marcel Dionne, the veteran center who was told Tuesday that he would not play for the Rangers this season, has no plans to retire and intends to collect his $595,000 salary for the final year of his contract, his agent said yesterday.

LEAD: Thousands of East Germans flocked to stations and junctions along the railroad line taking their compatriots from Prague to West Germany today in hopes of sneaking aboard.
Conditions became so hectic that the police had to clear the Dresden terminal by force and the doors of trains were sealed from the outside to block them.

Democrat Wins in Mississippi
LEAD: In a Mississippi Congressional district that has been Republican for nearly 17 years, a Democrat placed first in a special election Tuesday, earning a spot in a runoff on Oct. 17.


Review/Dance; Noh and Kyogen Specialties By Companies From Tokyo
LEAD: Two companies from Tokyo offered a sampling of classic Japanese theater on Tuesday night at the Lila Acheson Wallace Theater of the Japan Society.
The Kita Noh Theater, which traces itself back to a theater school founded in the 16th century, appeared in two examples of the refined theatrical form called Noh.


New Conran's President To Lead U.S. Expansion
LEAD: Conran's, a home-furnishings chain, is planning an expansion in the United States over three years with an altered name, Conran's Habitat, and a new president, Ray Brunner.


Campaign Trail; Police Union Puts Off Mayoral Endorsement
LEAD: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association put off endorsing a mayoral candidate yesterday, prolonging the battle between David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani for the blessing of the city's most influential law-enforcement union.


Philadelphia Electric Sells $175 Million Bond Offering
LEAD: The Philadelphia Electric Company yesterday offered $175 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds at competitive bid.


Plan to Let Builder Buy Part of 61st St. Is Blocked
LEAD: Facing almost certain rejection by the New York City Planning Commission, the developers of a proposed luxury apartment tower on Amsterdam Avenue yesterday withdrew their request to buy part of West 61st Street to gain extra development rights for their skyscraper.


The New York City Election, 1989: CAMPAIGN OBSERVATIONS; Tough Politics or Race Baiting?
LEAD: The political rhetoric emanating from Rudolph Giuliani's mayoral campaign has become so dissonant and contentious that it calls for sorting out.
Right after the primary election, Mr.
Giuliani began to focus attention on David Dinkins's ties to Jesse Jackson.
That brought the issue of race to the center of this campaign, and raised questions about whether Mr.


Fama Bail Appeal Denied
LEAD: An appeals panel refused yesterday to set bail for Joseph Fama, the teen-ager accused of shooting Yusuf K. Hawkins in the Besonhurst section of Brooklyn on Aug. 23.
The five judges of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court said in a unanimous ruling that defense lawyers offered no compelling reasons to overrule two judges who had refused to set bail.

Sensible Restraint on Panama
LEAD: Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military strongman for the last six years, had his closest call yet on Tuesday.
While rival elements of his Panamanian Defense Forces shot it out, more than 10,000 U.S. military personnel stood minutes away, on full alert, but apparently ordered to stay out of the fight.


I.R.A. Kills Man, Calling Him A Protestant Militia Trooper
LEAD: Two gunmen fatally wounded a man several yards from a primary school in north Belfast today, and the Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for the attack.

Student Seized With Gun at High School in Bronx
LEAD: A student at Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx was arrested yesterday after menacing two school officials with a loaded .357-magnum revolver in the school's hallways, the police said.


Shuttle Date Is Confirmed
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today confirmed Oct. 12 as the launching date for the space shuttle Atlantis, which is scheduled to carry aloft a nuclear-powered probe for man's closest look at Jupiter.
Federal District Judge Oliver Gasch will hear arguments in Washington next Tuesday on a legal challenge in which a coalition of anti-nuclear groups has asked to postpone the flight until the risks associated with launching the probe are made clear.

I.B.M. Head Is Optimistic
LEAD: The chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, John F. Akers, said today that the recent forecasts of lower-than-expected third-quarter profits at the computer company did not reflect doubts about its long-term growth.


From Tiffany, Jewels of a Different Kind
LEAD: Walking into the Renwick Gallery right now is like walking into a rainbow: a visitor is enveloped in the glowing colors of a lush exhibition of the masterworks of Louis Comfort Tiffany, which opened Friday.
Many of the 65 objects on display, including windows, lamps, glassware and jewelry, come from private collections and have never before been on public view.


Calendar: Gardens and Other Fall Sights
LEAD: Nine Days of Flowers, Planting Fields Arboretum, Planting Fields Road, Oyster Bay, L.I.; 516-922-9207 (weekends, 516-922-9201).


The Silver And Black Head Coach
LEAD: Ken Stabler had suddenly been leveled by one of the Browns' pass-rushers.
John Madden hurried onto the field in Cleveland that day in 1977 to check the health of his quarterback, and then the Oakland Raiders' coach began hollering angrily at the perpetrator.
After a few words, the Browns' pass-rusher took a few ominous steps toward Madden until Art Shell, the Raiders' huge All-Pro offensive tackle, spoke up.


Michael Choukas, 87, a Propaganda Expert
LEAD: Michael Eugene Choukas, an expert on the uses of propaganda who taught sociology at Dartmouth College for 30 years, died Monday at the Hanover Terrace Health Care Facility in New Hampshire.
He was 87 years old and lived in Portsmouth, N.H.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Adjusting a Drain Stopper  Q.The ''pop up'' stopper in our bathtub drain barely opens, so water drains very slowly when the lever is flipped to the ''drain'' position.
With my fingers, I can lift the stopper about 1/4 inch.
What adjustment can I make to make the stopper open higher and thus provide a larger opening?


Review/Music; Ruhrworks, a Mixed Series Of Works From Germany
LEAD: Goethe House and the Ruhr Cultural Foundation are presenting Ruhrworks, a series that will run through January, focusing on what appears to be a thriving arts world in West Germany's industrial region.
The festival includes music, dance, art and photography exhibitions, films and lectures, with events set in performing spaces, libraries and churches all over New York


Two Arab Guerrillas Slain by Israeli Patrol
LEAD: Two Palestinian guerrillas were shot and killed late Tuesday night by Israeli soldiers on a routine patrol in the self-declared Israeli security zone just a few hundred feet from the northern border, an Israeli Army spokesman said today.


The Editorial Notebook; America's Japan Problem
LEAD: Akio Morita, co-founder of the consumer electronics giant Sony, is widely known in the United States.
He is admired as an astoundingly successful entrepreneur, and he represents the perseverance and ingenuity with which Japan has re-created its industrial vigor.
As a mark of that strength, his company last week made a $3.4 billion offer for Columbia


New Jersey Seizes School District In Jersey City, Citing Total Failure
LEAD: New Jersey seized control of Jersey City's troubled public schools today, saying ''total educational failure'' in the state's second-largest city had deprived its 28,000 students of their constitutional right to a ''thorough and efficient education.''


Cadence to Buy Gateway Design
LEAD: Cadence Design Systems Inc. agreed to buy the Gateway Design Automation Corporation of Lowell, Mass., for stock valued at more than $72 million.
Cadence, a growing supplier of software for the design of integrated circuits, reported sales of $67.1 million last year.


Many Elderly Fear Loss of Program That Helps Pays Cost of Long Illness
LEAD: As the House voted to kill a program intended to protect the elderly from ruinous medical bills, residents of several retirement homes here continued to express the fears that inspired the plan in the first place.

Blood Cells Linked to Smokers' Lung Illness
LEAD: Doctors have found that tiny cells called neutrophils tend to collect in the lungs of active smokers, and are then free to slowly destroy the lungs.


Cuomo Says Drug Unit Encouraged Fraud
LEAD: The agency that administers drug abuse programs in New York has been so eager to expand treatment in the state that it has spent money haphazardly and encouraged fraud, a report released today by Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo's office said.

LEAD: PART of the pleasure of owning a home is the freedom to do it over.
But given today's soft residential real-estate market, anyone contemplating a home-improvement project - and an eventual sale - had best proceed with caution.
With housing prices soft, what buyers are looking for now is ''the architectural equivalent of the basic black dress: adaptable, subtle and always correct,'' said Frederick Peters, an executive vice president with Albert Ashforth &amp; Company in


Private Adoptions Aided By Expanding Network
LEAD: Couples who circumvent public and private agencies to adopt a baby independently have become part of an increasingly self-protective institution with its own advocacy groups, its own protocol and its own lawyers.


Bulova Seeking to Take The Watch Beyond Time
LEAD: The Bulova Corporation has a new face, indeed a variety of new faces -15 original one-inch-square geometric designs by Victor Vasarely, the French painter who is known as the father of ''Op Art.''


New England Bank in Pledge
LEAD: The Bank of New England said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Federal banking regulators after the end of the second quarter promising to strengthen its real estate lending procedures.


Lebanese Hijacker Given a 30-Year Sentence
LEAD: A Lebanese hijacker who was lured into American custody two years ago was sentenced today to 30 years in prison for the seizure of a Jordanian airliner in Beirut with two Americans aboard.


Corrections
LEAD: The caption of an Associated Press picture in Business Day on Tuesday about the sale of the Zenith Electronics Corporation's computer business to Groupe Bull misidentified a Bull executive.
He was Michel Bloch, executive vice president for strategy and planning, not Francis Lorentz, the chairman.


Lottery Redone to Aid Weak Teams
LEAD: The National Basketball Association's board of governors, meeting in Manhattan yesterday, unanimously adopted an adjustment to the draft lottery that will give teams with the worst records a better chance of getting one of the three top choices.


MAYNARD JACKSON WINS IN ATLANTA
LEAD: Maynard H. Jackson rode through downtown Atlanta Tuesday in an Election Day motorcade that resembled an inaugural procession more than a last-minute campaign appearance.


Elizabeth Murrell-Fax, A Social Worker, 66
LEAD: Elizabeth V. Murrell-Fax, a social worker and former director of the Forest Neighborhood House in the South Bronx, died of cancer Tuesday in La Guardia Hospital in Queens.
She was 78 years old and lived in Queens.


How the House Voted on Move to Kill Medicare Expansion
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 360 to 66 by which the House of Representatives today voted to repeal the Medicare program insuring against financial catastrophe from high medical bills.
A ''yes'' vote is a vote to repeal the program.
Voting ''yes'' were 196 Democrats and 164 Republicans.
Voting ''no'' were 56 Democrats and 10 Republicans.


Stolen Cartoon Art Is Found In an Office on Park Avenue
LEAD: Westchester County officials have recovered 44 more pieces of cartoon art that were stolen from the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye, an assistant district attorney said today.


Peugeot Talks Canceled
LEAD: Efforts to settle a month-old strike at France's biggest car maker, Peugeot, suffered a setback today when workers refused to end a sit-in at their plant and the management canceled talks.
Union sources said the strikers voted, 434 to 283, against ending the 10-day occupation of a foundry at the company's Mulhouse plant in eastern France.


Dylan Thomas's Light
LEAD: To the Editor:


Testing Time for 2 Devils
LEAD: Of all the buildings in the National Hockey League, the Spectrum in Philadelphia has been the most hostile place for Soviet hockey players.


Skinner Backs Preview Of Airline Takeovers
LEAD: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that it would be more effective for his department to review airline takeovers in advance, as would be required by proposed legislation, than retroactively, as it did recently in the case of Northwest Airlines.


Seidman Admission On Bailout
LEAD: A top Federal regulator confirmed today what private economists had been saying for some time: The $50 billion that Congress approved in August to liquidate and sell off hundreds of ailing savings and loan associations over three years could be inadequate to cover the losses at the institutions.


Corrections
LEAD: The ranking of Division I college soccer teams of Sports Pages yesterday was incorrect.
The teams listed were those of the Soccer America poll, not those of the Intercollegiate Soccer Association of America.
The correct poll appears today on page B26.


Egypt Reportedly Lists 12 Palestinians for Talks
LEAD: Egypt, backed by the P.L.O., has put forward the names of 12 Palestinians to sit at the negotiating table in peace talks between Palestinians and Israelis, Palestinians here said today.

LEAD: Guest artists - Cynthia Gregory, Fernando Bujones, Leslie Carothers and Marin Boieru - brought special excitement to the production of ''Giselle'' that Connecticut Ballet Theater danced tonight at the Performing Arts Center of the State University College here.
At the same time, they fitted harmoniously into the action.


Panel Backs S.E.C. Choice
LEAD: Richard C. Breeden, President Bush's nominee to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, was unanimously recommended today by the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Navratilova Bounces Back: Martina Navratilova lost the first three games but bounced back to beat Tine Scheuer-Larsen of Denmark, 7-5, 6-3, yesterday and clinch a quarterfinal berth for the top-seeded United States in the Federation Cup women's tournament in Tokyo.
The American team swept past Denmark, 3-0.


Bucks Hire Lee Rose
LEAD: Lee Rose, who was an assistant coach with the Nets last season, yesterday was named director of player personnel for the Milwaukee Bucks.
The 52-year-old Rose, who also spent two years as an assistant with San Antonio and 19 years as a college head coach, will replace Bob Zuffelato, who left the Bucks to become an assistant with the Minnesota Timberwolves.

LEAD: The Justice Department today filed lawsuits against Detroit, Phoenix, San Antonio and El Paso, charging failure to control industrial discharges of toxic wastes into their sewage treatment systems.

LEAD: Physicians treating high blood pressure say there is now such an abundance of effective medications that they can often fine-tune the choice of drug to the particular health needs of a patient.

LEAD: The Mets said today that Frank Cashen had finally reached Davey Johnson by telephone and opened a dialogue that would decide whether Johnson returned as manager next year.

When Work Means Bring the Kids
LEAD: It is 10 P.M. and the lights are low.
The toys, the high chairs, the diapers, the bottles, the crayons and the face paint have been stored for the night.
Danny Ross, 3 years old, Ryan Moulton, 5, and Ryan's brother Jake, 3, are relaxing on canvas cots watching ''Sesame Street'' on videotape.
Kristyna Jaquin, 2, is sound asleep beside them.


Senate Debates Bill Outlawing Flag Burning
LEAD: The Senate tonight stopped just short of passing a statute outlawing flag burning, legislation that many Democrats hoped would defuse the drive for a constitutional amendment to protect the flag.

LEAD: A FRIEND recently recalled how, when she was 11 years old, her parents told her she would spend the sixth grade in a class for gifted children instead of continuing at her old elementary school.
They expected their daughter, who had always been at the top of her class and who was generally bored with her schoolwork, to be elated.

LEAD: If you can't win a political argument on the merits, attack your opponent as a Communist.
It is an old Washington tactic.
But I have not seen it used as crudely in years as it has just been by Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah.

LEAD: With the highest tides in a decade threatening coastal communities already flooded by Hurricane Hugo, South Carolina began scraping beaches with bulldozers today to rebuild 65 miles of protective sand dunes washed away by the storm.


Overlooked Natives Amid the Exotica
LEAD: A COUPLE of years ago a friend in the nursery business sent me several perennials - two daisies and an aster - he had just imported from West Germany and wished to test for winter-hardiness in various regions of the United States.
These three not only got through the winter splendidly but also proved to be indispensable for the late-season garden.

Review/Theater; Cocteau Repertory in Wilde's 'Earnest'
LEAD: There are few more enjoyable evenings in the theater than to accompany those Oscar Wilde dandies John Worthing and Algernon Moncrieff as they pursue, both in town and the country, love and earnestness.
In ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' which is being presented by the Jean Cocteau Repertory company, Wilde uses his epigrams like a rapier, slashing his way through Mayfair drawing rooms and Hertfordshire gardens and leaving the cloak of hypocrisy that covered Victorian manners in tatters of laughter.

LEAD: THE nation's independent money managers slightly outperformed the overall stock market over the last 12 months, but trailed the market just a bit for the first three quarters of this year, according to statistics released yesterday.


Review/Dance; Graham Reinvents Her 'American Document'
LEAD: The truths the Founding Fathers held self-evident were anything but that in 1938 when European Fascism claimed the future for itself - and Martha Graham was impelled to create ''American Document,'' an experimental work that used the Declaration of Independence and the Emancipation Proclamation among its spoken texts.


An Unloved Loner and How He Is Used, in 'Mr. Hire'
When the body of a young woman is found lying in a thicket in a Paris suburb, murdered, it appears, by a holdup man who panicked, the police inspector first checks out Mr.
Hire (Michel Blanc), mostly because nobody likes him.
Mr.
Hire once served a six-month sentence for indecent exposure.
He also changed his name to Hire from Hirevitch, but neither fact would seem to justify the policeman's interest in him as a robbery-murder suspect.
The only excuse is profound suspicion of someone alien.
