Rebuilding Begins For Youthful Islanders
LEAD: In five years, the Islanders dropped from the elite of the National Hockey League to the third-best team in a three-team market.


Personal Health
LEAD: Every day 20 million Americans take pills to lower their blood pressure.
And if some physicians had their way, most of the remaining 38 million Americans who have high blood pressure would be similarly medicated, taking one or more pills every day for the rest of their lives to ward off strokes, heart attacks and kidney disease.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Sept. 26 about a debate between candidates for governor of New Jersey misstated the site in some copies.
It was Monmouth College.


Navy Punishes Four for Iowa's Deficiencies
LEAD: The Navy said today that mild punishment had been administered to the captain of the battleship Iowa, two of his subordinate officers and a master chief petty officer for training and safety deficiencies uncovered in the investigation of the gun turret explosion that took 47 lives.


Death Toll Spurring Spanish Draft Resistance
LEAD: When the grim figures are announced each year, the Spanish Defense Ministry invariably tries to blame bad driving and personal problems for the large number of young Spaniards who die or commit suicide while doing military service.

LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The Administration will regulate international money transfers by U.S. banks, the Treasury said, in an attempt to curb the laundering of drug profits.
The Government will open a financial crimes center next month in Virginia to supply information on money laundering to several Federal agencies.

LEAD: Yields of money market mutual funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report rose modestly during the week ended yesterday.

Israel Foreign Debt Dips
LEAD: Israel's foreign debts totaled $24.1 billion at the end of June, down $900 million from the March figure, a Bank of Israel spokesman said today.
He said 90 percent of the decrease was because of repayments by the Government and private sector, while the rest was a result of the dollar's rise in the second quarter.

LEAD: Tonight at 11:30, Channel 2 gets closer to the drug scene than many viewers may find comfortable.
Mike Taibbi, the reporter, spent weeks in a neighborhood in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, which had 3,200 arrests in a recent 90-day period.
Smoking crack and shooting heroin are apparently the main activities for many residents.

Less AIDS From Blood Transfusions
LEAD: The odds of getting an AIDS infection from a typical blood transfusion were just 1 in 28,000 two years ago, and the risk is dropping by more than 30 percent a year as fewer AIDS carriers donate blood, a study says.


Trains To Be Cut In Canada
LEAD: The Canadian Government said today that it would cut passenger train service by more than 50 percent nationwide, touching off bitter protests in a country that was stitched together by railroads in the 19th century and where trains and the people who ride them are the stuff of national folklore.


Corrections
LEAD: The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misstated part of a consent agreement between the Department of Transportation and Wings Holdings, the new owner of Northwest Airlines.
Under its terms, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines will retain a seat on Northwest's board, not relinquish it.
But that director must abstain from decisions involving ''sensitive competitive and international aviation matters.

LEAD: Even as the racing world mourns the death of Secretariat, it will turn its attention tomorrow to the colt who is on the verge of completing the most impressive 3-year-old campaign since Secretariat's 1973 Triple Crown season.


Growth in Ireland Seen
LEAD: Ireland is expected to have sustained economic growth in the next five years with inflation less than 4 percent, according to a survey of 13 leading economists published today.
The poll of the economists from leading banks and stockbroking firms forecasts that gross national product will grow by 4.9 percent in 1989, 4 percent in 1990 and 3.5 percent from 1991 to 1993.

LEAD: An interesting, if narrow, account of Western culture could be written through the history of its musical instruments.

That was popularly and reverently known as progress.

How to Slow the East German Exodus
LEAD: East Germans keep heading west.
And Bush Administration officials now say they would like the flow of refugees to slow, but that it's up to East Germany to do so by reforming itself economically and politically.
Preferring East Germans to stay home sounds harsh, but it's sound policy.
And only a country worth living in, not a socialist workhouse, will keep them there.

The drug is a potential $500 million product that will stop generic rivals as patients switch from Pfizer's Procardia drug, analysts said.

Early Retirements Hurt University in Connecticut

Record on Borrowing Can Help Trump's Bid
LEAD: Donald J. Trump brings a strong staff and a solid record of repaying bank debts to his $7.1 billion bid for the AMR Corporation, but he suffers from an image as a corporate raider who may not be seriously interested in completing a transaction.


Film Festival;; 'Sweetie,' a Wry Comedy By New Australian Director
After directing only four shorts, Jane Campion, a 34-year-old New Zealand-born director, makes a spectacular feature-film debut with ''Sweetie,'' a movie quite unlike any other you're likely to see until the next Campion comes along.
Among other things, it's a love (and hate) story about two sisters who, put together, might make one presentable personality.
''Sweetie'' looks like a small movie, and in every measurable way it is, but it possesses remarkable strength and tenacity.
It is funny, though one doesn't often laugh at it, and sad, without ever asking for tears.
Instead, it demands that it be taken on its own spare terms without regard to the sentimental conventions of other movies.
At its best, it is audaciously unreasonable.


U.S. Cautions Europe On Protectionist Moves
LEAD: The Bush Administration warned today that it might have to re-examine its support for European Community efforts to forge a single market by the end of 1992 if Europeans continued taking actions that discriminated against the United States.
Officials cited a recent television directive calling for majority European content in programming and policies that favor European computer chips.

LTV Steel is part of the LTV Corporation, the Dallas-based steel and energy company that has been in bankruptcy since in 1986.

Sports People: MARATHON; New York City Entrant
LEAD: Pat Petersen, the top American finisher in the event in 1984 and 1985, has entered this year's New York City Marathon, which will be held Nov. 5.
Petersen was seventh in the London Marathon last April in 2 hours 10 minutes 4 seconds, the best time by an American since 1983.


In New York, Topsy-Turvy Justice
LEAD: In Supreme Court in Brooklyn, a defendant was recently convicted of first-degree assault for having intentionally and horribly disfigured a man by dousing him with gasoline and setting him on fire.
At the same time, in an adjacent courtroom, two young men were convicted of first-degree robbery for having stolen money at knifepoint from a cab driver, whom they left shaken but unhurt.


Federal Investigation Begins Into Fishing Boat Explosion
LEAD: A team of Federal investigators today began work to determine the cause of an explosion touched off when a fishing boat struck a submerged pipeline.

LEAD: Continuing to outstrip his opponent in raising funds, David N. Dinkins collected three times as much as Rudolph W. Giuliani in the latest filing period, according to financial reports released yesterday by the candidates.


Marina Woroniecka Viets, War Hero, 61
LEAD: Marina Woroniecka Viets, who won the Polish Army's highest military decoration as a 17-year-old in the Warsaw uprising in World War II, died of lymphoma Sept. 25 at Loudoun Memorial Hospital in Leesburg, Va.
She was 61 years old and lived in Middleburg, Va.


Scandals Bring Hard Times For Nation's TV Evangelists
LEAD: The ethical and financial problems of the nation's television evangelists have cost them contributions and followers.


BMW Price Cuts
LEAD: BMW of North America Inc. said it would lower its 1990 car prices on certain American models by as much as 9.3 percent.
The company said it was lowering the price of its 1990 model 735i to $49,000, from $54,000 in 1989.
The smallest price decrease, 4.9 percent, will be on the 535i model, which will sell in 1990 for $41,500.


Review/Art; 31 Years of Color and Shape In a Kenneth Noland Show
LEAD: There was a time in the 1960's when it seemed that the whole of painting would go Kenneth Noland's way.
What more did we need than those limpid, weightless and perfectly sprung constructions?
There seemed at that time to be no emotional need that could not be satisfied by the chevron, the diamond, the irregularly shaped canvas and, as of 1967, the long, narrow, horizontal striped images that stretched out forever.

C.
Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General of the United States, will address such issues as AIDS, the escalating cost of health care, and care for the elderly, the network said.

LEAD: Lounging in a bathrobe and speaking conversationally, the actress Mary Shultz recalls the story of David and Bathsheba.
She tells it as her own story, as the victim of a king who seduced her and had her husband killed.
As she explains in David Greenspan's ''II Samuel ll, Etc.'' (at Home for Contemporary Theater and Art), she was a woman completely without choice.

But curtailing the program also means that millions will lose.
In the wake of the defeat, those losers deserve attention.

It has orders totaling 2.6 million tons of corn and 100,000 tons of soybean meal.

Ashland Pays Iran
LEAD: Ashland Oil Inc. said it had paid the National Iranian Oil Company $325 million and would charge the payment against results for the year ended Sept. 30.
The payment was made under an agreement announced last month that settled all disputes and litigation between the two companies, Ashland said.
The Iranian company had been seeking $768 million because an Ashland unit had refused to pay for crude oil in 1979.

An Elegy to Balanchine, The Choreographer of Lives
''Dancing for Mr.
B: Six Balanchine Ballerinas'' is as graceful, taut and fiercely controlled as the dancers who are its subjects.
In the opening scene, Darci Kistler - at 25 years of age the youngest of them - recalls that as an adolescent she read that Balanchine selected a perfume for each of his dancers. ''I thought it was wonderful that there was a man who cared that much,'' she says, setting the tone for Anne Belle's and Deborah Dickson's documentary.
This is not a study of the great choreographer and the guiding spirit behind the New York City Ballet, but a portrait of women who feel privileged to have been shaped by him.
Balanchine formed everything from the trajectory of their careers to the elongation of the leg muscles that helped create his dancers' characteristic lithe bodies.
And though he died in 1983, at the age of 79, he hovers over this film like some omnipotent ghost, still choreographing his dancers' responses, still hindering any impulse to chafe against his control.

It is also a mountain of contradictions and anomalies.
Except at the beginning, it is not in B minor but mostly in D major.
It was composed, not as one work, but as four separate ones, each with its own title page.

Frederick Wiseman's 'Near Death'
A half-dozen young medical professionals gather around the bed of an old woman, a stroke victim who cannot speak and can communicate only by means of the faintest movements.
They want to discuss the possibility of removing her breathing tube and the machine to which it is connected.
Does she understand what the consequences of this may be?
Is she prepared for the worst?
Is she worried about the way her death may affect her devoted husband?
The woman attempts to answer this barrage of difficult questions by weakly signaling yes or no, but she is soon exhausted.
She indicates that she would like the conversation to stop.


Dinkins's '86 Letter to Pierce Helped Save Housing Funds
LEAD: A 1986 letter from Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan to Samuel R. Pierce, then the Federal Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, helped New York City retain $8 million in Federal housing money that it might otherwise have lost.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1989
LEAD:  The Economy


Suspect in Deaths of Elderly
LEAD: Olian Small, 36 years old, has been charged with attempting a murder last April by tying a knot in the oxygen tube of Helen Ada Potter, an 81-year-old patient at a nursing home where he worked.
She died four days later, the authorities said, and Mr.
Small was arrested Wednesday evening after he was indicted.


Poland Details Economic Change
LEAD: Poland's new Government announced detailed plans today to convert the country to a market economy, warning of tight money, bankruptcy and unemployment along the way but promising to soften the pain with unemployment benefits.


Bridge
LEAD: There are times in bidding when good becomes bad, and vice versa.
An example of the latter occurs when a player who has passed originally has a fit with the opening bidder.
A jump shift in a new suit normally conveys that message: a player should not jump simply because his hand was almost worth an opening.


Venezuelan Debt Payment
LEAD: Venezuela has brought its public sector debt up to date by paying more than $900 million in overdue interest to foreign banks, paving the way for talks on a refinancing plan, a spokesman for the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday.


With Puck Bouncing Their Way, Rangers Win Season Opener
LEAD: When it was over tonight, the Rangers, in near unanimous humility, smiled and talked about luck and what it was like to enjoy some after all.
They had beaten the Jets, 4-1, to open the season, and their locker room was full of quiet laughter.


C.F.T.C. Bars Restitution Bid
LEAD: Federal futures regulators voted down a proposal today that would have allowed them to force dishonest brokers and traders to pay restitution to the customers they had cheated.


Ad Agency Indicted in Bribe Case
LEAD: In the first criminal indictment of an advertising agency under Federal racketeering laws, Young &amp; Rubicam was charged yesterday with bribing Jamaican officials with almost $1 million to obtain the Jamaica Tourist Board's advertising account in 1981.

Jane Austen's Siblings
LEAD: To the Editor:


LaRouche Conviction Challenged in Appeal
LEAD: The tax and mail fraud conspiracy conviction of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. was challenged today in a Federal appellate court as resulting from a rush prosecution that violated his right to due process.


Judge Orders Crowded Jail to Release 173 Suspects
LEAD: Authorities began freeing 173 criminal suspects from the overcrowded Essex County Jail today under a Federal judge's novel order using taxpayers' funds as bail money.

LEAD: An article in Sports Pages on Thursday about university presidents asking for limitations on college sports misidentified the co-sponsor of a bill that would require all colleges to disclose graduation rates for athletes.
Representative Ed Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, was the co-sponsor with Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New

Defendant Acquitted of Rape; 'She Asked for It,' Juror Says
LEAD: Members of a jury here say they acquitted a man of rape because the woman's clothing suggested she had ''asked for it.''


Dow Up 11.96, to 2,785.52, on Job Data
LEAD: Buoyed by an unexpected increase in unemployment for September and a sharp decline in factory jobs, blue-chip stocks rose to another record yesterday.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Detectors, No Sprinklers  The nursing home fire that killed nine people in Norfolk, Va., was started by a cigarette or match that ignited a foam mattress, the fire chief said.


Five Exchanges Weighing Move To Jersey City
LEAD: The five commodity exchanges in New York, outgrowing their space in the World Trade Center, are considering moving to Jersey City and are talking to municipal officials on both sides of the Hudson River to see which could provide a better package of tax breaks and other inducements.


Offer Is Begun For Lionel Corp.
LEAD: Robert Toussie, the New York investor, began a hostile $145 million tender offer for the Lionel Corporation, the toy retailer that reorganized and emerged from bankruptcy in 1985.
Robert I. Toussie L.P. said it had begun an offer of $8 a share in cash for up to 11.9 million of Lionel's common shares.


Child Is Killed in Car Accident
LEAD: A 15-month-old Brooklyn boy died last night from injuries suffered when his father backed over him with the family car, the police said.
The child, Joseph Mandel, was apparently playing in the driveway of his home at 736 East Third Street in the Borough Park section.
His father, Samson, did not see him as he was backing his 1977 Pontiac station wagon out of the driveway, a police spokesman, Sgt.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Flavor of Dried Herbs
LEAD: With the arrival of autumn, the herb garden begins to lose life, and many cooks rely on dried herbs from now until spring.
The flavor of some dried herbs is more intense, so they should be substituted in smaller quantities.
Other dried herbs lose much of their character.
Basil, chervil, coriander leaves and parsley are much better fresh than dried.


U.S. Sees Israeli Stance as Temporary
LEAD: Administration officials said today that they view the Israeli Cabinet's rejection of an Egyptian invitation for talks with Palestinians in Cairo as a temporary setback and are moving ahead with efforts to organize such a dialogue.


We Need Many More Computer Scientists
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Harsh Lessons of Retailing
LEAD: Nine store chains, including some of the most glittering names in American retailing, have been put up for sale in recent months in what is proving to be a powerful lesson on what can happen when companies with high expectations enter a volatile industry on the verge of a slowdown.


Deal May Bring Permanent Cut In the Gains Tax
LEAD: With the blessing of President Bush, the Senate tonight worked toward a deal that may well give Mr.
Bush the permanent reduction in the capital gains tax that he promised in the 1988 campaign.


Two Personal Essays
LEAD: The personal essay is a dangerous form, prone to banality or overreaching.
Fred Marx's ''Dreams From China'' and Ralph Arlyck's ''Current Events,'' the first-person films that will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 6:30, show traces of both problems.
They are extremely sincere but slight films, not cogent enough to deal with the huge subjects they tackle, and not formally innovative enough to make up for that lack of substance.


Miss Donahue Wed to C. R. C. Kingzett
LEAD: Madeleine Anne Donahue, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Theodore P. Donahue of New York, Litchfield, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Christopher Richard Colin Kingzett, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Richard Kingzett of London and Cirencester, Gloucestershire, England.
The Rev.
Richard Foley officiated at the Farm Street Roman Catholic Church in London.


ISRAELIS REJECT CAIRO'S PROPOSAL ON MIDEAST TALKS
LEAD: The Israeli Government today rejected an Egyptian proposal to convene preliminary Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo as a way of breaking the deadlock in stalled efforts toward peace.


Patents; Self-Cleaning Hot Tub
LEAD: Murray Altman, owner of a Jacuzzi manufacturing company in Sylmar, Calif., has patented a self-cleaning hot tub.
The tub contains a perforated tube that can spray water down the sides.
Controlled by a microprocessor, which starts a cleaning cycle after the tub has been drained, the tube first sprays cold water for 30 seconds, then sprays water containing a mixture of detergent, disinfectant and anti-spotting agents for 75 seconds.


Holiday On Monday
LEAD: Columbus Day will be observed on Monday.
Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Government offices: Closed.
Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only.
Main post office at 33d St. and Eighth Ave. open.
Banks: Option to close.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Traffic Safety
LEAD: Busy parents with busy children too often live life on a treadmill.
The children need to be transported between home and school and after-school programs in a seemingly never-ending cycle of daily activities that often compete with the parents' own obligations.


Nursing Home Blaze in Which 9 Died Is Believed Due to a Careless Smoker (Associated Press)
LEAD: A fire that killed 9 people at a nursing home here and sent nearly 100 to the hospital was caused by a discarded match or cigarette that ignited a rubber mattress, Norfolk's Fire Chief said today.


U.N. Condemns Israel's Tactics in Arab Revolt
LEAD: The General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to condemn Israel for its repression of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.


Civil Rights Panel Rebukes Its Chairman
LEAD: The United States Civil Rights Commission today rebuked its chairman for deciding to appear at a symposium on homosexuality sponsored by an evangelical Christian group.


The Hospital Pact Sets No Pattern
LEAD: The new contract settlement negotiated between New York City hospitals and the hospital workers' union is costly to the industry, but fair to the workers.
It provides 7.5 percent increases in each of the first two years and 5 percent in the third, with a $500 cash bonus to each worker in 1991.
That's a generous wage package, so generous that the leaders of the city's municipal unions will inevitably try to use it as the model for their negotiations with City Hall next year.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in SportsMonday on the success of the Oakland Athletics this season omitted one of the teams on which four pitchers won at least 20 games each in the same season.
The Chicago White Sox accomplished it in 1920.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Easy Goer Tries for 5th
LEAD: Easy Goer will try for his fifth successive Grade I stakes victory, and make his final start of the year in New York, in the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup today at Belmont Park.


Big Wilson Dies at 65; Ex-NBC Disk Jockey
LEAD: Malcolm John Wilson Jr., a radio personality known as Big Wilson, died after a heart attack Thursday at a hotel in Selma, N.C.
He had observed his 65th birthday this week and was touring the country with his wife, Jody.


Lord Einstein Paying WPP $7 Million
LEAD: Lord Einstein O'Neill &amp; Partners, an advertising agency founded by American executives rebelling against their British parent company, the WPP Group P.L.C., agreed yesterday to pay $7 million to WPP.


'Mighty Casey' Opera
LEAD: The American Chamber Opera Company will present ''The Mighty Casey,'' an opera by William Schuman based on the poem by E. L. Thayer, at 8 o'clock tonight at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street.
The fully staged production is to be conducted by Douglas Anderson.
Tickets are $15.
Information: 781-0857.


Michael Williams, 74, Cardiologist in Harlem
LEAD: Dr.
Michael D. Williams, a cardiologist who practiced in Harlem for more than 40 years, died of complications of heart disease yesterday at the St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Medical Center.
He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Harsud Journal; Water, Water Everywhere? Many Now Say 'No!'
LEAD: Here in the remote Narmada River valley, in hamlets that most Indians have never heard of, a new and growing national environmental movement has drawn its battle line against large-scale development in India.

Questions Are Raised About Thornburgh's Travels
LEAD: Two months after Justice Department budget officials limited official travel to conventions, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and five aides flew to a Bar Association convention in Honolulu in August aboard an otherwise empty Government Boeing 727.


Plane Crash Kills 4 Aboard
LEAD: A single-engine plane, buffeted by turbulent air, crashed short of the runway at Palm Springs Regional Airport Thursday evening, killing all four people on board.
The identities of the victims were not made known.
The Federal Aviation Administration and the Riverside County coroner are investigating.


Sony Donates $3 Million
LEAD: The Sony Corporation of Japan has donated $3 million to the University of Illinois to endow a research and teaching position in electrical and computer engineering.
The grant is Sony's largest single gift to a American academic institution.
The position is to be named in honor of John Bardeen, an Illinois faculty member.


Bonds Soar on Signs of Weaker Economy
LEAD: Prices of Treasury and corporate securities soared and yields fell yesterday as the Government's latest employment data indicated a further weakening of the economy.
Unemployment rose by one-tenth of 1 percent, to 5.2 percent of the labor force in September, and there was a decline in factory jobs in a broad range of industries.

McNeil, Calming Down, Says He Will Be Ready
LEAD: It has rarely happened before in professional football or any other big league sport: a player accidentally injures another and is so despondent that he is unable to continue in the game.

LEAD: Evergreen Airways, a new international carrier based in Taiwan, has signed deals with two American jet manufacturers to buy as many as 26 jets worth more than $3.2 billion, the manufacturers said today.

First Things First
LEAD: To the Editor:


New York's Ships
LEAD: ''New York-Built Ships,'' an exhibition on the history of shipbuilding in Manhattan, will be on view through Jan. 2 at the South Street Seaport Museum, 213 Water Street.
Models, carvings, paintings, photographs and other items from various museum collections are included in the show, which focuses on the city's prominence as an international shipbuilding center in the first half of the 19th century.


Windows
LEAD: To the Editor:


Unfinished Business With Canada
LEAD: Nine months after the United States-Canada free-trade agreement began chipping away at tariffs and trade barriers, trade relations between the world's two busiest trading partners have slipped once again to their accustomed place on the policy makers' back burner.


The Heat Is On; Fuel-Saving Pointers
LEAD: During the heating season, which began last week and runs through May 31, New York City requires that indoor temperatures in multifamily buildings always be at least 55 degrees and that when outside temperatures drop below 55, indoor readings must be at least 68 between 6 A.M. and 10 P.M.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Sept. 17 about Seoul misidentified a building on the grounds of the 14th-century Kyongbok Palace.
It was the Korean National Folklore Museum, which was built in 1972, not the palace itself.


6 Payment-Free Months; Hard Sell for a Soft Market
LEAD: Say you've built a development that people like and can afford, but because the market is soft and they are having trouble selling their current homes, they can't afford to buy one of yours.
What can you do?
A Rockland County developer believes he has solved the problem: He is offering to meet a buyer's mortgage payments - up to $2,000 a month for half a year - once that buyer moves in.


Where the Season Shines Brightest; Cezanne, Dali, Giulio Romano
LEAD: FALL is in many ways the best time to go to Europe for major exhibitions.
Unmotivated visitors are fewer.
The hotels are less full, likewise, though it is a good idea to watch out for the trade fairs, conventions and other municipal promotions that begin in late September.

Republicans and Democrats in the Senate report progress in bargaining over a date to vote on reduction of the capital gains tax.
Both sides were seeking tactical advantages and avoiding a filibuster.

Thomas E. Dewey Thruway system.

LEAD: A wrongful death case under New York law is treated differently from a similar case under Connecticut law and from the way cases are treated in other states.

Men's Transitional Coats: Light, Warm and Stylish
LEAD: Blustery, unpredictable fall weather calls for a transition coat, something between an overcoat and a raincoat.
Such a garment should take a man from a rainy train platform in the morning to a sunny lunchtime walk to a chill, dark evening after working late.
Preferably, of course, in style.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Lendl Wins Final: Ivan Lendl overcame problems with his first serve yesterday and defeated Miroslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 4-6, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4, to win the Stuttgart tournament in West Germany.
The match took 3 hours 14 minutes.
Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, broke Mecir twice to win the first set, then started missing his first serves.

LEAD: When Mia Dillon, wearing a voluminous dress, makes her first entrance in ''The Aunts,'' it is immediately clear to everyone in the theater that her character is supposed to be pregnant - to everyone, that is, except the other characters on stage.
For unexplained reasons, the young woman's two aunts are oblivious to her condition.

Translated by Franklin Philip. (Basic Books, $10.95.) LEAD: With the weight of 49 losses in Columbia's last 51 games resting on its shoulders, the Lions' defense lined up for a fourth-down play yesterday with the ball inches from its goal line and less than two minutes remaining in the game.
If Columbia could hold, it would mean a victory over Penn, an Ivy League co-champion last year.

In the West, The Verdict on Soviet Psychiatry Is Still Out
LEAD: DURING the last two years, the Soviet Union has carried out changes in the practice of psychiatry, hoping to persuade the World Psychiatric Association to allow it to rejoin the organization.
It left the group in 1983 to avoid almost certain expulsion because of charges that political and religious dissidents were being confined in mental hospitals.

STAMPS
LEAD: In the days before income taxes - yes, there was such a time - the United States Government raised money through a wide range of excise taxes and collected the money by selling revenue stamps.
Just as postage stamps show payment for a government service, so revenue stamps show payment for a tax.

Ribbon Speakers Have The Virtue of Clarity
LEAD: Perhaps it is the ultimately fantastic notion of an inanimate object making music.
Perhaps it is the challenge of constructing a device that imitates all musical instruments and any human voice.
At any rate, there is something about loudspeakers that stirs the engineering mind and results in a perennial parade of novel and frequently offbeat designs.

LEAD: WHEN the Soviet parliament decided last week to ban strikes in key industries, it was just a modest display of what liberal commentators here call ''the strong hand syndrome'' - the yearning for something to control the disorders Mikhail S. Gorbachev has loosed in the land.
More draconian proposals are in store, as the country sweats out the unnerving side effects of a little liberty.

Friendship Can Be Earned at the Expense of Miss Manners

A Completist Turns His Piano Talent To a Piano Legend
LEAD: Gunnar Johansen is not one of the headliners, but he is a highly respected pianist whose lack of public appearance has been a matter of choice.
In 1939 he was named artist-in-residence at the University of Wisconsin, the first musician in any American university to be so honored.
He settled in.
In his home he installed a battery of the most up-to-date recording equipment, and instead of giving concerts he made a series of records that has put most of his contemporaries to shame.


HOME OWNERSHIP FOUND TO DECLINE
LEAD: Home ownership declined in the 1980's for the first time since World War II, Senator Lloyd Bentsen said today, citing high prices and high interest rates.

The Saving Grace of Chicken Livers
LEAD: THERE are two ways to buy chicken livers.
The expedient method is to purchase the necessary quantity from the butcher or supermarket.
The other way is to collect them from the whole chickens you buy, freezing them until you have enough for a recipe.


Food; Apple Polishing
LEAD: BLACK GILLIFLOWER, WHITE WINTER PEARMAIN, Esopus Spitzenburg, St.
Edmund's Pippin . . . the names of these old apples trip off my tongue with pleasure.
Now affectionately called antique apples, many of the varieties that were grown before the Civil War are being revived.
Alas, they are not as beautiful as their names; the fruit is small, irregular - all right, it must be said - just plain quirky.

LEAD: ''THIS garage is the inside of my brain,'' said Mundy Hepburn, gliding his arm through the air.

Directing 101: George Abbott on What Works
LEAD: George Abbott believes a director wastes his time in rehearsal when he talks endlessly to an actor about who his mother was, what did she want, what does he want and why it has led him up to this moment when he asks for the salt.
Instead he prefers that the director get on with it and tell the actor, ''C'mon, Johnny, just pass the salt.

LEAD: AS trees in the rest of Westchester begin to display their fall colors, the trees on Kenilworth Lane here remain leafless, their stark limbs an eerie black.
The swimming pools and tennis courts once shaded by the trees are empty, and the gardens under them sprout shriveled zucchini and brown string beans.

Trimming the Fat From School Costs
LEAD: As a parent of three school-age children, I read with trepidation Irving Gerber's Opinion article.

While districts may be top-heavy with administrators, budget cuts go right to the children.

An Allowance For Wit and Human Foible
LEAD: Four days ago the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden unceremoniously passed its 15th anniversary.
The circular building, resembling a giant doughnut, has always seemed an oddity amid the neo-Classical and Modernist boxes lining Washington's National Mall.
But whatever might be said against the architect Gordon Bunshaft's design - and curators struggling to hang paintings on curved walls have had things to say over the years - his conception underscored one essential characteristic of the museum.


Children Who Set Fires Prompt a Conference
LEAD: EVERY three weeks, on average, firemen in some Westchester community are called to extinquish a blaze caused by children.
While about half of those fires result from the curiosity of children playing with matches, psychologists say the other half are the work of young arsonists, bent on deliberate, intentional and repeated destruction.

That question pertains crucially to the Equity Library Theater's revival of the show, in which the director Adrienne Weiss has unwisely cast members of the ensemble as homeless people and punks in the street scenes.

America Tackles The Pesticide Crisis
LEAD: JIM KNUTZON IS SITTING IN THE restaurant of the Hilton Hotel in Pleas-anton, Calif., near Oakland, solemnly regarding the plate of swordfish smothered in sauteed vegetables just set before him.
With his head bowed, he delivers what might be construed as a modern-day meditation.
Knutzon, a former pesticide salesman who now advises farmers on pesticide alternatives, expresses the hope that people across America will soon be able to sit down to meals that are free of toxic pesticide residues.

THE A.C.L.U.'S POLICIES
LEAD: There are many things wrong with the American Civil Liberties Union, and Jeffrey T. Leeds has pointed to some of them, as well as to what is right about its policies (''The A.C.L.U. - Impeccable Judgments or Tainted Policies?'' Sept. 10).
But its chief weakness, as I see it, is its insistence that a general principle, whether it deals with free speech or due process, should be applied to all cases - without regard for the consequences.

Forgotten Harvest
LEAD: It is harvest time for squirrels in the city, and the other morning one of them was out foraging acorns in Washington Square Park.
With an acorn in its jaws, it dug a little hole in the turf, pushed the acorn in, patted dirt over it and then brushed some grass over the spot as if to conceal it.
It did the same with the second acorn and was working on a third when a pair of poodles came along and chased it up a tree.

Is Political Humor Politic?
LEAD: Do we need political humor?
I usually answer that question with the smart-alecky response, ''I certainly do - I have bills to pay.'' The humorist Tom Lehrer gave up his practice years ago with the proclamation that political satire died the moment Henry Kissinger received the Nobel Peace Prize, and my endeavors as a satirist are often threatened by the verbatim statements of public figures.

LEAD:  TOTAL BASEBALL.

LEAD: The Big Apple Circus celebrates the Wild West, from Oct. 26 to Jan 7 in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center.
The show includes feats on the trapeze and on horseback, calf-roping, gun-slinging and whip-cracking.
Tickets are $40 to $10.
Information: 391-0767.

A 'Tough Cookie' Makes Nets Debut
LEAD: Last season, for the first time in 32 years, Bill Fitch did not coach basketball.
He played golf.
He traveled.
He read books.
He spent more time with his friends.


Soviets Urge Stronger Role for World Court
LEAD: In what it calls a move to strengthen international law, the Soviet Union has called for a treaty that would oblige signing countries to submit drawn-out disputes to the International Court of Justice in The Hague for binding arbitration.

LEAD: John B. Layton, police chief of Washington in a turbulent five years of strained race relations and rising crime in the 1960's, died of a pulmonary embolism Thursday at Washington Adventist Hospital.
He was 77 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump offered $7.5 billion for AMR, the parent of American Airlines.

Trump would pursue a hostile takeover against AMR's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, one of the most fiercely independent executives in the airline business.


Tainted Hand Of Criticism?
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bastille Opera Manager
LEAD: Georges-Francois Hirsch, the general director of the Theatre des Champs-Elysees in Paris, has been named general administrator of the Opera Bastille, the administrative council of the opera has announced.
Mr.
Hirsch, whose nomination was proposed by Pierre Berge, the council's president, is to take over the post immediately, but will remain as head of the Champ-Elysees theater until the end of the 1989-90 season.


Loose or Broken Banisters
LEAD: Bannisters, or staircase posts and railings, are as much a safety feature as they are a decorative element.
This makes repairing loose or broken bannisters important, but also somewhat complicated, because fasteners are usually hidden.


Rethinking the Convenience Store
LEAD: For convenience stores, these should be the golden years.
First, supermarkets all but killed off corner groceries.
Then the supermarkets themselves consolidated into sprawling, remote megastores.
The convenience store chains, the field wide open, eagerly expanded across the nation.


Streetscapes: 17th Street Off Union Square; 10 Houses With Collective Charm
LEAD: IT is hard to pinpoint exactly what is special about the old houses on the south side of East 17th Street between Union Square and Irving Place.
The individual buildings are not outstanding and most are a bit neglected, even shabby.


There's a Small Hotel; Paris: Comfort and good coffee
LEAD: CHOOSING a hotel in Paris is like choosing a restaurant: there are a great many options.
One of the great charms of Paris is the abundance of hotels, of every size and price category.
There are generally one or two hotels on every block, as much a part of the scenery as the charcuterie, or the boulangerie, or the corner bistro.


FASHION DESIGNER
LEAD: ''When designers start out, they tend to work too hard to make a statement,'' Randy Kemper said. ''I tend to go for clothes that look elegant and sleek and have as few seams as they need to make them work.''

Searching for Incentives To Entice Polluters
LEAD: As Congress last week discussed the renewal of the Clean Air Act, it wrestled with expanded use of an unusual concept in pollution control: letting industries buy and sell the right to emit pollutants, with companies deciding among themselves how to share the work that the Government wants done.
Under President Bush's proposal, this flexibility would extend to automobiles.

There's a Small Hotel; Rome: Charm and efficiency
LEAD: THE hotel scene in Rome used to be simple.
If you wanted luxury and pampering, you paid a lot of money and, in most cases, you got them; if charm and atmosphere counted more than recapturing abroad all the comforts of home, you could find that too (and at a price that was affordable), and if you just wanted a clean place to spend a night, which you never expected to come back to again, that too was an uncomplicated affair.

The Cancer War: A Major Advance
LEAD: IN SEPTEMBER OF 1984 DR.
RON-ald H. Spiro told Robert A. Pfeiffer that he had a large tumor at the base of his tongue, right next to the vocal cords in his larynx, that had already spread to some lymph nodes in his neck.
The standard treatment for such tumors was an extensive operation that involved removing the entire larynx, or voice box.

She, too, was an ''outsider'' and was told that criminal prosecution was impossible.

THE SHRINK ON THE COUCH
LEAD: Barbara Hey has some uneducated theories about psychotherapy (''The Shrink on the Couch,'' April 16).
First of all, a good therapy depends as much on the patient as it does on the therapist.
A brilliant therapist cannot ''cure'' a resistant patient, and a patient who wants to be cured more than anything else could probably do so with a less-than-brilliant therapist.

Reward for Tarpley
LEAD: A week after being promoted from sixth man to starter, Roy Tarpley has gotten a contract worthy of his new status with the Dallas Mavericks.
Tarpley, who had two years to go on a contract scheduled to pay him $560,000 this season and $660,000 the next, signed a three-year extension that will bring him a bit more, an average of $2.6 million a year for the last three years, The Dallas Morning News reported.

The Saving Grace of Chicken Livers
LEAD: THERE are two ways to buy chicken livers.
The expedient method is to purchase the necessary quantity from the butcher or supermarket.
The other way is to collect them from the whole chickens you buy, freezing them until you have enough for a recipe.

FIGHTING AIDS ALL THE WAY
LEAD: AS A HEART MONITOR BEEPED AT MY side and an automatic blood-pressure machine quietly inflated and deflated, the nurse started the infusion.
Doctors and more nurses hovered nearby.
The drug dripping into my vein was dideoxyinosine, or DDI.
Thus, on July 22 of this year, I became one of about 100 people in the United States to receive what was being described in the press as a ''promising'' new AIDS drug.

My ''love affair'' actually led to the divorce of a husband!
I found myself putting my all-important walking loop ahead of putting hubby's potatoes in the oven.
Walking simply came first, and still does.

THE A.C.L.U.'S POLICIES
LEAD: The A.C.L.U. supports restrictions against the production of child pornography.
However, it opposes legal strictures against the distribution of child pornography.
An analogy might be that it is illegal to produce cocaine, but if law enforcement is evaded at the production stage, it should be perfectly legal to sell cocaine.

Subtle Ways to Eat Your Cake and Have It Too
LEAD: Commodities or not commodities - this is one of the big contemporary art questions of the moment.
When does art that sets out to satirize the commercial side of art making cross the line and become just another pretty collectible?
More and more often, it seems.
What does it mean when artists who intend to be subversive turn out irresistible objects, seeming to embrace or otherwise take advantage of the very thing they would criticize?

AROUND THE GARDEN
LEAD: For This Week: Bulb planting begins as catalogue orders start to arrive; if the bulbs cannot be put in the ground for several days, store in a cool, dry place so they do not start to sprout in warm temperatures.

Exploring the New-Look Louvre
LEAD: IT started out as a fortress in the 14th century; then, when the times became less dangerous, it was converted into a palace; finally, with the fall of the monarchy, it became a museum, the first of its kind in Europe.
Now, at the behest of a President with a passion for building, it is going through yet another series of radical changes: enlarged, reorganized, with a new entrance pavilion, it has become in many ways a new museum.

How the Japanese Saw the Arrival of the West
LEAD: IN a way, Lincoln Kirstein was anticipating camp when he began collecting Japanese prints in the 1930's.
Not for him the Utamaros and Hiroshiges favored by connoisseurs; his rebellious spirit was attracted to the woodcuts turned out for popular consumption on cheap paper in colors that, after the introduction of aniline dyes, seem tawdry - even today.

LEAD: IN Ireland the harp is better known as an icon than as a musical instrument.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. The family room in our house is directly above the basement.
In warm weather, this room has a musty odor, especially when the humidity is high.
We use a dehumidifier and ventilate the room, but it has not helped much.
We had the carpet shampooed, and this relieved the problem temporarily.
How can we get rid of the odor?


I Need Some Repairs
LEAD: MY person is in need of mending along with my house and car.
We're running neck and neck, falling apart simultaneously.
My old Buick-friend is no more.
It has spluttered, squeaked and coughed its way to its dotage; it has hiccupped, wheezed and sometimes purred its way to decrepitude.
For a car 26 years old it is over the hill in spades.

OUR MOST NOTORIOUS SCULPTOR
LEAD: Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, is a scenic place.

Of Cats and Frogs And Lessons
LEAD: I was truly impressed with Maggie McCool's pro-animal position until I read of her 16 cats (''A Lesson Refused and a Lesson Learned,'' Aug. 27).
The photograph of her with one of her cats showed no evidence of a bell or other device that would warn prey of a cat's presence.
Apparently, Ms.
McCool's animal advocacy extends only to creatures she favors, e.g., frogs, but not to those whose deaths she may not notice.


WARHOL FACES THE BIG SCREEN INSTEAD OF THE SILKSCREEN
LEAD: Documentaries thrive on public television, but they rarely entice audiences to movie theaters.

LEAD: AFTER Washington stops arguing about the extent to which President Bush fumbled last week's attempt by Panamanian troops to oust Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Administration will have to think about where American policy goes from here.

Question Of the Week; Who Should Be Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
LEAD: With apologies to Pedro Guerrero, can a New Yorker not but imagine one of their outfielders with around 50 home runs and 130 runs batted in!
National League most valuable player: Kevin Mitchell.


Catalogue Companies Should Not Sell Names
LEAD: For Patrick J. O'Connor's information (''No Innocent Victims of Direct Mail,'' letters, Aug. 20) I wrote over two months ago to the Direct Marketing Association to ask that my and my husband's names be removed from mailing lists.


The Arts Endowment: Still in Trouble
LEAD: THE struggle in Congress over how much control it should have over the National Endowment for the Arts seems as unlikely to reach a quick resolution as a Wagnerian opera.
Although the endowment appears to have avoided being saddled with the Helms amendment, which would have prohibited the financing of ''obscene or indecent'' art as well as that which ''denigrates the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion or nonreligion,'' the debate over publicly financed art has just begun.


NEW FIGHTS OVER SPOILING YOUR BABY
LEAD: Marie Winn's article ''New Fights Over Spoiling Your Baby'' (April 16) states the widely held misconception that infants are only able to communicate by screaming.
Numerous scientific observations document what sensitive parents and professionals can easily observe: babies have a rich and eloquent vocabulary of expression, gesture and gaze.


Campus Life: Oglethorpe; Proposed Sale Of Greek Row Upsets Students
LEAD: Squarely in the path of a real-estate development juggernaut, Oglethorpe University has put 15 acres of property, including the school's Greek row, up for sale - and at least a few students are upset about it.


Swedish Dance Tries To Reclaim Its International Standing
LEAD: We haven't heard much about dance in Sweden since 1982, when a dancer in that country's foremost experimental troupe, the Cullberg Ballet, bared her breasts onstage in front of some other visitors at the Brooklyn Academy of Music - the King and Queen of Sweden.


COMMUNIST PARTY IN HUNGARY VOTES FOR RADICAL SHIFT
LEAD: The Hungarian Communist Party voted today to transform itself into a socialist party and said it would strive to bridge the gulf between doctrinaire Marxism and European democratic socialism.


The End of Pegasus
LEAD: Television has provided the world with many remarkable images over the years, but none more beautiful than that of a horse named Secretariat winning the Belmont Stakes.

LEAD: Scott Scesney completed 20 of 31 passes for 326 yards and three touchdowns as undefeated St.
John's held off Pace, 28-21, in the Liberty Conference game yesterday at Finnerty Field, Pleasantville, N.Y.

Figure in Biggest U.S. Drug Haul Tells Prosecutor of Ring's Scope
LEAD: A man identified as the manager of the Los Angeles warehouse where the Government made the largest cocaine seizure on record has told drug agents that 60 tons of cocaine passed through the warehouse in the last year, a prosecutor said Friday.

Friday the 13th: A Virus Is Lurking
LEAD: A potentially potent computer virus, known variously as Datacrime or the Columbus Day Virus, is programmed to activate itself Thursday in a large number of computer systems in North America, computer security experts say.


Florida State Runs Over Syracuse
LEAD: Terrell Buckley returned a punt 70 yards for a touchdown and LeRoy Butler scored on an 88-yard interception return three minutes later today as Florida State ended Syracuse's home winning streak at 16 games with a 41-10 victory.


Review/Music; A Concert in Celebration Of Rochberg's Electicism
LEAD: Even in the program notes for a concert of his music, George Rochberg is likely to be discussed more for what he represents than for what he is.
Mr.
Rochberg is known, to the extent he is known at all, as the apostate serialist, the composer who decided he loved old music with its melodies and intelligible harmonies and would jolly well write that way whether it was in line with progress and current thinking or not.


Long Way For Leahy
LEAD: Charley Winner was the head coach, Joe Namath was the quarterback, Buddy Ryan ran the linebackers and a Briton named Bobby Howfield was the injured place-kicker when a soccer player named Pat Leahy joined the Jets in 1974.


Skateboard Ramp Removed in Milford
LEAD: SKATEBOARD enthusiasts in Milford, already banned from zipping through the downtown area, have now lost the use of a ramp provided for them behind the city library.


Why Mets Lost: Let Us Count
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Running as a G.O.P. Crime Buster: Can Giuliani Match Dewey?
LEAD: The Republican candidate, a celebrated prosecutor, faced a daunting task.
There were 563,000 registered Democrats in New York City and only 122,000 enrolled Republicans.
He had never run for elective office before, and many wondered whether he could make the transition from intense courtroom pyrotechnics to the more relaxed glad-handing of the campaign trail.

LEAD:  Basketball


Loose or Broken Banisters
LEAD: Bannisters, or staircase posts and railings, are as much a safety feature as they are a decorative element.
This makes repairing loose or broken bannisters important, but also somewhat complicated, because fasteners are usually hidden.


For Yankees, Less Is More
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Great Care Taken In Education Plan
LEAD: The recent article ''Plan to Revamp Special Education Draws Criticism'' provided valuable information to parents of educationally handicapped pupils and special-education professionals.
The article presented a balance of the different points of view expressed by a variety of people.


A KILLING IN MAINE
LEAD: Ironically, on the day your article appeared, more than 3,000 gun enthusiasts attended the 12th annual Bangor Gun Show.
Meanwhile, as hunting season begins, many of us in the Bangor, Me., area will be especially cautious as we venture outdoors near our homes, lest we, too, be mistaken for an animal by some overzealous hunter.


QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are Baseball's Showmen Too Showy?
LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


'Touched by an Angel': Different Views
LEAD: I did not find ''Touched by an Angel'' touching in the least.
In fact, I found it very disturbing.
According to the author, after a short visit with her family, Angel is transformed from a ''street-wise kid with no understanding of our family's values or rules'' into ''just another boy'' - just one ''of our own kids.


A Jazzman's Fountain of Youth
LEAD: In the family of jazz, parents have insulted children nearly as often as embraced them.
For every Coleman Hawkins playing sideman to Thelonious Monk, there was Louis Armstrong denouncing be-bop as ''Chinese music.'' For every Duke Ellington recording duets with John Coltrane, there was Roy Eldridge branding Ornette Coleman a fake.


A Prize Winner for Peace
LEAD: Millions of tourists visit Washington each year and leave without a trace.
But one visitor from Berkeley, Calif. may soon realize her dream of a multi-million dollar garden dedicated to the pursuit of peace.


A Whirl of Parties To Save a Museum And Honor Artists
LEAD: Monday and Tuesday were busy nights last week in New York City.
At Jean-Claude Baker's restaurant, Chez Josephine, on West 42d Street, a dinner on Monday honored Evelyn Anderson, thought to be the last living original cast member of ''La Revue Negre,'' which began Josephine Baker's career in Paris 64 years ago.


Correction
LEAD: The Prospects column on Sept. 24 about the Ford Motor Company's proposed acquisition of a stake in Jaguar referred incorrectly to a comment from Charles M. MacDonald, an executive of the Jaguar Clubs of North America, on the status of Jaguar's racing team.
He said Jaguar sponsors two racing teams, one in the United States and another in Europe.

The Town That Determination Is Building Again
LEAD: FALL in Bantam is not the same this year.
People here have put aside such customary pursuits as apple gathering and leaf peeping as they continue to rebuild from the wreckage of a tornado in July.
Residents still have leaves to rake, but they also have piles of downed trees and uprooted stumps to clear.

LEAD: After a year and a half of negotiations, representatives of the newsstand business and the newspaper industry announced last week their general support for proposed regulations that would govern the size, location and operation of sidewalk newsstands in New York City.

When Verdi Spoke, Everyone Listened
LEAD: On Friday, Nov. 13, 1868, Gioacchino Rossini died at his home in Paris at the age of 76.
Four days later, Giuseppe Verdi, a sincere admirer if not a close personal friend of the great Italian composer, wrote his own publisher, Tito Ricordi: ''In order to honor the memory of Rossini I should like the most outstanding composers of Italy to write a requiem which shall be performed on the anniversary of his death.

IN SHORT
LEAD:  REAL FARM: Encounters With Perception.
By Patricia Tichenor Westfall. (New Chapter Press, $14.95.) ''Real Farm'' is the affecting and frequently humorous memoir of an urbane college professor who fell in love with life on an Iowa farm, while simultaneously falling out of love with her husband, a doctoral student at the University of Iowa to whom she gives the pseudonym Mark in this volume.

Perspectives: New Walk-Ups in Queens; Striving for Style in a Transitional Zone
LEAD: THERE is a corner of the Jamaica Estates section of Queens that is something of a laboratory of housing change.
It is along Highland Avenue, within walking distance of the 169th Street subway station on Hillside Avenue, a busy commercial thoroughfare.
Since the 1920's, a range of housing types, from detached single-family houses to midrise elevator buildings, has been developed in the neighborhood.

LEAD: I HAD JUST RETURNED FROM A business trip to see three prospective clients.
My consulting company was growing, and I was preoccupied with acquiring more office space.
On the way to a meeting with the manager of my building, my knees began to feel weak and the simple act of walking suddenly required concentration.

Turning to the U.S., Again, for Peace Ideas On the Middle East
LEAD: AS Arabs and Israelis have traded talk of peace in recent months, United States diplomacy has seemed to move in the wings, half-player, half-prompter, offering a phrase here, a word there, sometimes a whole chunk of the script.
Now, inexorably, a reluctant Washington is being beckoned on stage.


CAMERA
LEAD: The man behind the counter at the one-hour photo lab handed me my batch of prints and then offered a word of advice: ''Don't use 400-speed film for the desert.
Save it for when the light is low.''


Of Cats and Frogs and Lessons
LEAD: The excellent article ''A Lesson Refused and a Lesson Learned'' revealed the problems faced by a student who objects to using animals as classroom tools.
Sadly, the academic status quo often penalizes those who show the most sensitivity and insight.
Rather than teaching respect for all creatures, classroom dissection and vivisection desensitize students to animal suffering.

LEAD: Secretariat'S death on Wednesday marked the end of a wonderful dream I have been privileged to live.
In my eyes, he was the finest thoroughbred performer of the last 50 years and he certainly provided me with a unique experience.

Community Training
LEAD: It may not be a busman's holiday, but for Mike Tyson, it's going to be hard to tell where training camp leaves off and community service begins.
Tyson, who is preparing to take on the Canadian champion, Razor Ruddock, moved his training camp temporarily from Las Vegas, Nev., to Albany, where he was sentenced to perform community service after pleading guilty to speeding in two incidents last summer.

The prosecutor taps his pen nervously on his files during a Senate hearing.
His language may be American legalese, but his pen taps a 6/8 Latin beat.

LEAD: For a moment, the Jockey Club Gold Cup yesterday looked as if it was going to be a real horse race.
Easy Goer had cruised to the lead round the stretch turn, but Cryptoclearance was making a stirring bid and drawing alongside the leader at the top of the stretch.


Diverse Indian Specialties in Stamford
LEAD: MEERA, Stamford's latest Indian restaurant, is another winning newcomer.
Its look is as cool as its cuisine is hot, and the diverse menu is demystified by careful translations and by a friendly, expeditious Indian staff adroit in English.

But when administrators at Brandeis University offered to print E. L. Doctorow's address to the graduating class of 1989 in the Brandeis Review - and then awkwardly reneged over the summer - they touched off a tempest.

LEAD: A Queens lawyer who operated a collection agency set up with the late Donald R. Manes to gather overdue parking fines for New York City was sentenced on Friday to two years in prison for mail fraud.


Anne Bogart Changes Course At Trinity Rep
LEAD: On a recent autumn night, Anne Bogart sat on the stage of the Trinity Repertory Company, facing a small but lively audience.
Ms.
Bogart had just assumed the theater's artistic directorship and was conducting her first post-performance discussion - a conversation about that night's production of ''No Plays, No Poetry,'' her drama based on the theoretical writings of the German playwright Bertolt Brecht.

Labs for Kenilworth; Enlarging the Medicine Chest
LEAD: New Jersey has long considered itself the ''medicine chest to the nation'' because of the large number of pharmaceutical companies based there.
Schering-Plough Corporation, with headquarters in Madison, is one of them, and the expansion of its research facility in Kenilworth will no doubt help the state hold the title.

Students Punished Over Prank
LEAD: One University of Mississippi student was expelled and four others were suspended Friday for their involvement in a fraternity prank.
The incident occurred Sept. 18, when a Beta Theta Pi member and a pledge were stripped, blindfolded, painted with racial slurs and dropped off at Rust College, a predominantly black school about 25 miles to the north.

VOTES IN CONGRESS
LEAD:  Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York  Senate  1.
Flag Desecration: Vote to kill an amendment to a bill outlawing desecration of the flag that would have banned only public acts against the flag.
Approved 53 to 47, Oct. 5.  2.
Flag Desecration: Vote on final passage of a bill that would make it a crime subject to a penalty of one-year in prison and a $1,000 fine to mutilate, deface, burn or physically defile any United States flag.

A KILLING IN MAINE
LEAD: Your article failed to point out that in discharging a firearm within 100 yards of a residential dwelling (i.e., my neighbor's house), the killer of my wife was in violation of Maine hunting regulations.
The implication in your article was that the man was sufficiently distant because he was more than 300 feet from my house.


London
LEAD: Visitors to London this fall will be forgiven if they feel a bit confused about what year this is.
The place looks contemporary enough, with its sleekly gentrified buildings, smartly dressed young people, streets lined with Range Rovers and controversial new glass and metal telephone booths, which have uprooted many of the beloved red boxes of yore.


Trouble Finding Things? Tips on How to Organize
LEAD: TAKE a look around you.
Are you an ''Everything Out''?
Are papers strewn about your desk haphazardly, each related to a different project, each demanding immediate attention, and each destined to end up somewhere other than where you will eventually look for it?


Graduating From the Kitchen Floor
LEAD: ONCE upon a time there was an ordinary housewife who had three children.
She liked the wife part and the mother part must have been pretty good since she had two babies and then adopted a third one.


Where the Season Shines Brightest; Opera from Paris to Bologna
LEAD: FOR an American music lover, the main problem with planning trips abroad specifically for musical purposes is a dearth of reliable, sophisticated information.

Correction
LEAD: The review of Paul West's novel ''Lord Byron's Doctor'' on Sept. 3 misstated the relationship of two members of Byron's circle.
A reader has written to point out that Claire Clairmont and Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley were stepsisters, not half-sisters.


REFERENCE
LEAD:  THE NORTON/GROVE CONCISE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MUSIC.
Edited by Stanley Sadie with Alison Latham. (Norton, $40.) Concise here really means concise.
Information from the 20 volumes of ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'' has been abstracted into bare-bones, succinct entries for this big one-volume reference book.

Fixed Mortgages Down
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.10 percent last week, down from 10.16 percent the previous week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.

Question Box
LEAD:  Mack vs.
McGraw  Q. Did the two legendary baseball managers Connie Mack of the Philadelphia Athletics and John McGraw of the New York Giants ever oppose each other in the World Series?
A.
It happened three times in the 30 years from 1901-30 that Mack and McGraw were managerial contemporaries with their respective American and National League teams, but those three occurrences all took place in the first 13 years.

LEAD: More than 100 pounds of marijuana estimated to be worth at least $25,000 was found today during a raid on a house here, Onondaga County Sheriff's deputies said.

The bill was passed by the Senate last Thursday.

LEAD: Azerbaijani railroad crews defied a national ban on transport strikes today and again stemmed the flow of desperately needed supplies to Armenia, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, said.
There were conflicting reports on how much food, fuel and building supplies were reaching the Armenian republic.

Henrik K. Carlsen, 75, A Heroic Sea Captain
LEAD: Henrik Kurt Carlsen, a sea captain who gained international attention in 1952 for staying stubbornly aboard his crippled freighter for seven days as she slowly sank, died Saturday at his home in Woodbridge.
He was 75 years old.


3 Jewish Students Beaten by Men Yelling Ethnic Slurs in Brooklyn
LEAD: Three Jewish students were attacked outside a fraternity party near the campus of Brooklyn College early yesterday by as many as 20 white men who shouted ethnic slurs at them and beat them with ''fists, feet and beer bottles,'' the police said.

Tales Emigres Tell: Why Life in East Germany Proved Finally Intolerable
LEAD: The thousands of people who have left East Germany in recent weeks have seized opportunities for escape as they arose, first through Hungary and then through Czechoslovakia.
Seen from afar, their flight seemed to be a mass exodus.
But in this West German border city, as the tired travelers disembarked, individual voices testified to often difficult choices; personal dramas emerged from the chorus of cheers.

Stock Market Fail-Safe Plan
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange asked the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday to approve a one-year extension for a system that would halt trading if the market drops sharply.


Campaign Matters; On Running With the Ghost Of La Guardia
LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani declared his candidacy for mayor last May in an Upper East Side Republican club that he identified as the site where Fiorello H. La Guardia began his successful mayoral campaign 56 years before.


Rumors of Saatchi Bid
LEAD: The stock of Saatchi &amp; Saatchi P.L.C. rose several points last Friday on the London and New York stock exchanges amid rumors that the British advertising company might be a takeover target.
Fueled by speculation that an American asset-management company might make a bid for Saatchi, and that a Swiss employment agency was interested in buying some of its consulting operations, Saatchi's stock was the third-most actively traded issue in the London market.


Impact of Harcourt Deal
LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. released a statement on Friday describing the financial impact of its agreement last week to sell Sea World amusement parks to the Anheuser-Busch Companies for $1.1 billion.
Harcourt said that it would gain $550 million from the sale and that the proceeds would allow it to reduce interest costs on its debt by $115 million a year.


How MTV Has Rocked Television Commercials
LEAD: MTV, the cable television rock-music network, is having a profound influence on the way products are advertised on television, advertising professionals say.


Three Military Airmen Killed When Jet Crashes in Atlantic
LEAD: Three Navy airmen were killed on Saturday when they ejected from a military jet that apparently malfunctioned shortly after it took off from an aircraft carrier in the Atlantic Ocean, the Navy said today.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about the Senate's refusal to back repeal of the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act described the Senate's measure incorrectly in some copies.
Unlike the House's, it deals only with Medicare.
It is not part of the deficit-reduction bill.

LEAD: A treadmill has been designed to absorb the impact of running with use of a suspension system in its foot bed.
The machine will be available in January.


Shorter Workweek a Volatile Issue for Germans
LEAD: A hallmark of West German labor negotiations in the 1980's has been a drive by the nation's powerful trade unions to reduce the workweek to 35 hours, from the current average of 38.7, without cutting pay.
With many labor contracts in important industries expiring early next year, the debate has flared anew.

Cargo Boom Causes Plane Shortage
LEAD: Sharp growth in cargo shipments by air is producing a shortage of freighter aircraft around the world.
Companies with freight to ship are having trouble finding planes on short notice, and freight rates have begun to rise.

LEAD: After a tense seven-week standoff that included a church occupation, an embassy takeover and diplomatic maneuvering, the Government of El Salvador has acceded to rebel demands that wounded and disabled guerrillas be evacuated abroad for medical treatment.

Federal Industries will pay 86.5 percent of the cash to W. H. Smith Group and the rest to three Canadian institutional investors.

The commodity, stock and corporate bond markets will be open.

LEAD: Asserting that too many college students graduate with limited exposure to the ''basic landmarks of history and thought,'' the National Endowment for the Humanities urged colleges today to bolster required undergraduate studies.


More Covered By Recycling In New York
LEAD: With New York City's recycling law in effect since July 14, the Sanitation Department reports that more than 600,000 households in the five boroughs are now engaged in the curbside recycling program, in which the department picks up newspapers, magazines and corrugated cardboard.

LEAD: The 1888-89 portrait of Joseph Roulin by Vincent van Gogh, which is one of the most spectacular additions to the Museum of Modern Art in many years, was paid for by the museum through an elaborate deal that involved the sale of seven paintings from its permanent collection.

Gasoline Prices Flatten
LEAD: Abundant oil supplies and volume discounts to sellers virtually halted a rise in retail gasoline prices that had been running contrary to seasonal trends, an industry analyst said Sunday.
The biweekly Lundberg Survey of 12,000 gasoline stations nationwide showed the average price, including taxes, for all grades of gasoline was $109.56 cents a gallon - up only 13-hundredths of a cent per gallon from two weeks earlier.

Centel Agreement
LEAD: The Centel Corporation said it agreed to buy the cellular telephone franchises serving Aiken, S.C., and Augusta, Ga., from the Pond Branch Telephone Company for undisclosed terms.
It said the deal was subject to the approval of minority shareholders and state and Federal regulators.
Centel serves 41 markets and is the 10th-largest cellular company.

LEAD: Most domestic markets for Treasury bills, notes and bonds were closed yesterday in observance of the Columbus Day holiday.
But commodity, stock and corporate bond markets were open.
In Canada, all financial markets were closed for a national holiday.


Review/Music; Milwaukee Symphony Tests Carnegie Hall
LEAD: The Milwaukee Symphony was on the stage of Carnegie Hall Saturday night, but these visitors from the Midwest seemed almost bit players in the larger drama of Carnegie Hall's acoustics.
The plot has arrived at Act III, Scene 1 - from the celebrated sound of this historical space, to the much criticized acoustical changes that accompanied a major renovation several years ago, and now to August's further modifications, which have included absorbent material applied above and behind the playing area and at the back of the hall.

Bogota Blast Called Accident
LEAD: The explosion that tore through a Bogota bus and killed seven people on Sunday was apparently accidental and not the work of drug traffickers at war with the Colombian Government, the police said today.
Initial police reports said the bus appeared to have been hit by a firebomb.

LEAD: The insurance industry, blamed by New Jersey's Insurance Commissioner for nearly $1 billion in losses by the state's Joint Underwriting Association on policies issued to car drivers, has reviewed the studies on which the Commissioner based his charge and come up with far different conclusions.


Dollar Is Narrowly Mixed; British Pound Moves Lower
LEAD: The dollar was narrowly mixed yesterday in thin holiday trading.
Gold prices were lower.
Currency dealers said trading was subdued and abbreviated because of the Columbus Day and Yom Kippur holidays.
The markets in Hong Kong were also closed for a holiday, while trading in Japan slowed on the eve of a holiday there.

LEAD: Buses carrying bingo players were stoned and shot at during weekend violence at the St.
Regis Indian Reservation, where residents are feuding over the legalization of casino gambling.
One woman was hurt.
The woman, Janet Langley, of Ottawa, Canada, was injured by the rock throwing and treated for cuts at a hospital, officials said.

Compaq Stock Up
LEAD: Shares of the Compaq Computer Corporation soared to an all-time high in heavy trading, but company officials said they were not sure what had inspired the rise.
After a morning of light trading, Compaq's shares soared $6.25 yesterday, to finish at $104.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
It was the third-most-active issue, with more than 1.2 million shares traded.

2d California Desert Quake
LEAD: The second minor earthquake in the Southern California desert in three days was felt in the remote San Jacinto mountain range Sunday, but no damage or injuries were reported.
The midmorning quake measured 3.0 on the Richter scale of ground motion and was centered 23 miles south of Palm Springs, said Robert Finn, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena.

Tyson Trains in Albany As Part of His Sentence
LEAD: As part of his sentence for speeding in the Albany area twice last summer, Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, sparred for a half-hour and signed autographs yesterday morning at a boxing clinic at St.
Joseph's Youth Center in downtown Albany.
In the afternoon, he took part in drug-related talks at the nearby Arbor Hill Community Center.


USX Sells Stakes In South Africa
LEAD: The USX Corporation said it had sold all of its equity interests in South African companies, but it withheld the identity of the buyers and the sale price.
Shareholders had submitted a resolution earlier this year that USX sell its holdings in the racially segregated nation.
They withdrew after management said sale negotiations were under way.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bus to Stores By American Express
LEAD: TO advertisers and retailers, the distance to the consumer often seems to represent a yawning gulf.
So, now and then, they make aggressive moves to bridge that gulf by bringing the shopper to stores that sell the advertised products.

LEAD: The Likud leadership never seems to run out of ways to avoid talks with Palestinians.

By Design; Work Boots, for Play
LEAD: They're the latest steps in the sturdy-footwear fashion movement.
With high-tops that end above the ankle, snug lace-up fronts and thick block heels, this season's new boots qualify as members of the comfort class.
The ones with rounded toes and thickish ripple rubber soles certainly do.


Barry Andrew Kearsley, Stage Manager, 42
LEAD: Barry Andrew Kearsley, stage manager of the Broadway play ''M.
Butterfly,'' died of a heart attack Saturday after collapsing backstage during a performance.
He was 42 years old.


Winning Is Craig's 'Happiest Feeling'
LEAD: Roger Craig rarely displays deep emotion, and even tends to mumble a little bit when his thoughts outrace his words in certain tense situations.


New Toyota Luxury Car
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation introduced a high-performance luxury car today that it calls its new flagship automobile.
The Celsior features a 4,000-cubic-centimeter, eight-cylinder engine with 260 horsepower.

From Milan, a Soft and Shimmery Spring
LEAD: Italian fashion exploded over the weekend, as established manufacturers and newcomers alike tried to stage their spring shows before the start of Yom Kippur.
The spate of presentations around the city, in lofts and workrooms that could hold an audience of up to 1,000 as well as at the Milan Fair, made it perfectly clear that the slick, hard-edged Italian look had turned soft and gentle in the face of spring.


Argentina Pardons Its Demons
LEAD: Argentina's tentative democracy was dealt a cruel, if expected, blow Saturday by President Carlos Saul Menem, in the form of a blanket pardon for accused military officers and suspected leftist terrorists.
His action promises temporary gains, but it undermines Argentina's integrity.


Foundation Seeks Self-Sufficiency for Puerto Rico
LEAD: With help from foundations and United States corporations, a new style of philanthropy is taking root here and scattering seeds through the Caribbean.


Pope, on Delicate Ground, Visits Indonesia
LEAD: Pope John Paul II brought a message of Roman Catholic kinship and loyalty to Indonesia today as he began a diplomatically delicate visit to the world's most populous Muslim country.


U.S.-Soviet-Chinese Teams Will Jointly Attempt Everest
LEAD: Teams from China, the Soviet Union and the United States will attempt to scale Mount Everest together next year to draw attention to international cooperation and problems of the environment.

LEAD: Stock in the USAir Group, owner of the nation's seventh-largest airline, rose sharply yesterday after a published report that its largest shareholder, the money manager Michael H. Steinhardt, wanted the company to increase its share price and might consider a hostile bid.


Budapest Encore: Old Socialist Elected
LEAD: The newly named Hungarian Socialist Party, which as the Communist Party over the weekend abandoned hard-line Marxist dogma, today elected Rezso Nyers, a once and present Socialist, as its President.


Ax Plays Beethoven and Schoenberg
LEAD: Emanuel Ax played the best of Arnold Schoenberg's piano music and a rousing selection of Beethoven's most animated, Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y. It was an exhilarating recital and something of a surprise even to a listener who has always admired Mr.
Ax.
Here, more than I can recall from other occasions, he seemed to have something close to the ideal combination of qualities for the material at hand.

LEAD: Negotiations about a possible merger of operations by the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange have broken off, and officials from the exchanges said yesterday that no agreement was likely to be reached.

LEAD: Nancy Fife never doubted that her husband was scarred in mind and body by his Viet Cong captors and was a war hero. nearly 20 years ago, her sneakers seemed to drive her husband, Robert, berserk.
He told her that his captors wore sneakers when they came to his cage to beat him and urinate on him and that the enemy soldier he strangled to escape was wearing sneakers.
