Chrysler Revises Cash-Back Offer
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation revised the cash-back incentives for its 1990 models.
It raised the incentive on the Dodge Daytona from the $500 offered on 1988-89 models to $750 on 1990 models.
Incentives on the Daytona ES and the LeBaron convertible Premium GT and GTC were increased $250, to $1,000.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about efforts to repeal the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act referred incorrectly to the surtax that helps provide the benefits.
Generally, those of the elderly with incomes of more than $15,000, not $35,000 - calculated by their income tax liability - pay the surtax.

LEAD: For a decade before his election as Manhattan Borough President in 1985, David N. Dinkins was City Clerk, keeper of city records.

Penny Lernoux, 49, a Reporter
LEAD: Penny Lernoux, an author and investigative reporter who specialized in Central and South American affairs, died of lung cancer Sunday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
She was 49 years old and lived in Bogota, Columbia.


Dispute on New President Shatters The Tranquility at Rockefeller U.
LEAD: For decades, Rockefeller University in New York City has been a citadel of basic research in biology and medicine: a place where professor-researchers outnumber students and the ''poetry of science'' (as one of the four Nobel laureates on the faculty puts it) holds sway.


Bridge
LEAD: Half a century ago only 21 players had earned the rank of life master, which then required, and still does, 300 master points.
And in 1940 there were only three additions to the rank.
They would have been astonished to know how that number would grow: there are now 40,729, and of these, 79 are Grand Life Masters, having earned 10,000 points and won at least one major national title.


Change in Medicare Law to Be Costly
LEAD: The moves by Congress to dismantle expanded health benefits for older Americans would shift most of their medical costs back to the patients, to taxpayer-supported programs and, to a lesser extent, to private employers, health care experts and insurance industry spokesmen say.


Price Soars For Black Pearls
LEAD: Heavy Japanese buying sent the price of black pearls soaring at weekend auctions in Tahiti, dealers said today.


Snacking Said to Cut Heart Risk
LEAD: SNACKING throughout the day instead of eating three full meals, can lower cholesterol and reduce the chance of heart disease, a study has found.


Review/Dance; A Look at Words and Music By a West German Troupe
LEAD: It was as if a time capsule had been unearthed and opened on Friday night when Else Klink's Eurythmeum Stuttgart performed at the Triplex Theater of the Borough of Manhattan Community College.
A company of 13 dancers and 6 musicians offered a solemn, reverent look at eurythmics, a system of translating musical and spoken rhythms into physical movement, derived from Francois Delsarte's theories of gesture, and developed and elaborated by Emile Jaques-Dalcroze and Rudolf


New Chain Store Splits Hamlet in Adirondacks
LEAD: A new gasoline station and convenience store in this picturesque Adirondack hamlet is to many longtime residents a welcome addition, offering gas at reasonable prices and another spot to meet the neighbors.
But to Baird Edmonds and two other residents, it is an architectural outrage, the equivalent of visual pollution.

LEAD: An international effort to map the genes of a wide variety of plants and animals, from slime molds to human beings, advanced significantly this week when scientists settled on a common method of identifying the genetic markers distributed on chromosomes.

LEAD: There are skeptics aplenty, but an enthusiastic staff and other supporters are convinced that a forbidding old monolith of a high school in a grim inner-city section here will be transformed into one of the most promising arenas of academic and athletic achievement in the nation.


Hewlett-Packard's New Work Station
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company plans to introduce a computer work station Tuesday that features the Intel Corporation's i486 microprocessor and a circuit design called Extended Industry Standard Architecture, or E.I.S.A.
The design, adopted last year by a group of competitors of the International Business Machines Corporation, is intended to increase the performance of I.B.M.-compatible computers and to compete with I.B.M.


Rig Count Down by 18
LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas in the United States dropped by 18 last week, to 960, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
It was the first decline in six weeks, but the count remained above the 914 rigs working at this time last year.


Ira Hirschmann Is Dead at 88; Executive and Leading Nazi Foe
LEAD: Ira Hirschmann, a business executive, pioneer in radio broadcasts of classical music and political associate of Fiorello H. La Guardia, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 88 years old.

LEAD: Another hate crime in New York City - this time the victims were three Jewish college students - rightly stirs shock and outrage.
It is also cause for frustration.

In her New York debut, in a Saturday matinee at Gould Hall, Miss Kashiwagi presented two pieces that fused traditional and jazz dance.

LEAD: The King of Lesotho, a tiny African kingdom entirely surrounded by South Africa, said today that he was trying to bring together leaders from all sectors of South African society with the cooperation of the South African Government to discuss the nation's political future after apartheid is abolished.


Disney Stock Rise
LEAD: Shares of the Walt Disney Company soared $6.75, to close at $134.625 a share in New York Stock Exchange trading, more than double the price a year ago.
A Disney spokesman declined to comment, but analysts attributed the jump to heavy demand in Europe for newly issued shares of Euro Disneyland, the theme park Disney is developing outside Paris.

Science Watch; Smog on Pluto
LEAD: The latest observations of distant Pluto, the only known planet yet to be visited by spacecraft, reveal what appear to be smoggy hazes in the thin atmosphere over the polar ice caps.
The phenomenon reminds scientists of atmospheric patterns seen over the poles of Mars and in the Los Angeles basin.

Slot Machines for Soviets
LEAD: A small Swedish company has signed a deal to sell 25,000 slot machines to the Soviet Union, the national news agency reported last week.
The company, Bonik A.B., almost went bankrupt after Swedish authorities banned gambling slot machines 10 years ago.
The news agency said Bonik was buying existing machines from across Sweden and adapting the coin slots for rubles before transporting them by truck to various towns in the Soviet Union.

Soybean Meal to Soviets
LEAD: Private exporting companies have sold an additional 150,000 metric tons of United States soybean meal to the Soviet Union for delivery in 1989-90 under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today.
The latest sales increased the purchases of United States soybean meal by Moscow to 250,000 tons for 1989-90.

LEAD: An article on Aug. 20 about the Soviet reaction to Poland's new Government misstated a remark by Fyodor M. Burlatsky, a Soviet newspaper commentator and member of the Supreme Soviet.
As Mr.
Burlatsky has since pointed out, he said the clash of forces from the right and the left could lead to the danger of a military government in the Soviet Union similar to the one installed in Poland in 1981, not to a military government in Poland now.

European Jobless Data
LEAD: The unemployment rate in the 12-nation European Community stood at 9.2 percent in August, unchanged from July, the European Community's statistical agency, Eurostat, said today.
In the eight-month period between January and August, the rate fell to 9.2 percent from 10.1 percent.
Eurostat did not give a figure for the total number of unemployed in August because the Netherlands had not yet sent its data.

Mr.
Castillo said El Diario's owners, Inmobiliaria America Latina Inc., hoped to revive the newspaper, which was begun in May 1987 and had been losing about $80,000 a month.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Dow Jones &amp; Company misstated the performance of the company's business publications in the third quarter of the year.
That division of the company reported a slight gain in operating income compared with the third quarter of 1988, not a sharp drop.
The article also misstated the quarter in which Dow Jones reported one-time gains; those gains were in the third quarter of last year, not the current year.

LEAD: Thanks to two World Series-bound baseball teams, the Bay Area finally has a chance to even old scores.

LEAD: The Data General Corporation, a Westboro-based computer maker, said it would sell its plant in Portsmouth, N.H., and move manufacturing operations to a larger plant in Apex, N.C., in the next year.
The company said it would eliminate 2,200 of 14,200 jobs and that more than 700 people would be affected immediately.

Eating Well
LEAD: NUTRITION information is like mercury: it slips through your fingers whenever you try to capture it.
First the experts tell you to lower your cholesterol; then others question that wisdom.
Next they say polyunsaturated fat should be substituted for saturated fat; then they change their minds.
Use monounsaturated fat instead, they say, and it is all right to eat a little saturated fat.

Topics of The Times; Leapin' Lizards!
LEAD: The Postal Service has taken heavy flak for mislabeling its new 25-cent dinosaur stamp, a drawing of a pair of dinosaurs captioned ''Brontosaurus.'' Furious purists point out that the ''brontosaurus'' is now properly called ''apatosaurus.'' They accuse the stamp's authors of fostering scientific illiteracy, and want the stamps recalled.

LEAD: A worker installing lights in a medical building fell 12 stories and survived today, his plunge broken by an atrium's glass ceiling and by a man sitting near a second-story railing.

LEAD: There's an Oldsmobile, this year's vintage, in the driveway of a suburban New Jersey condominium so new that the air around it remains tinged by the smell of sawdust.

In the foyer, a vigilant gray poodle is pacing, uncertain whether to receive guests who speak English instead of his accustomed Russian with a wag of his tail or a worried growl.

Belgians Raise Rates
LEAD: The Belgian central bank raised short-term interest rates today for the fourth time in two weeks.
Belgium's three-month treasury bill rate, considered the key rate, was raised by a quarter of a point, to 9.55 percent.
The one- and two-month rates were raised to 9.55 percent each from 9.2 and 9.25 percent, respectively.

LEAD: More large companies have agreed to eliminate ozone-destroying chlorofluorocarbons and halon in their worldwide operations, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

Swiss Inflation at 3.4%
LEAD: Switzerland's annual inflation rate rose to 3.4 percent last month, the highest since July 1985, the Federal Statistics Office announced today.
Higher prices for heating oil and vegetables were leading factors in the increase, a news statement said.
The annual inflation rate had remained stable at 3 percent from May through August.

2 Knicks Sit Out
LEAD: Preparing for their preseason opener against the Denver Nuggets tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks had an intra-squad scrimmage last night at their State University training site in Purchase, N. Y. Mark Jackson and Kiki Vandeweghe did not participate.
Jackson has been sidelined for the past three days with muscle soreness in both legs, while Vandeweghe, who arrived in training camp last Friday with back spasms, still has not worked out with the team.

Lebanese Official Cancels Speech to U.N.
LEAD: Lebanon has canceled plans to address the United Nations General Assembly, while King Fahd of Saudi Arabia urged all Lebanese parties today to step up their efforts to reach an agreement in the current peace talks.


Judge Revokes Inmate's Bail After He Is Freed by Mistake
LEAD: A judge revoked bail today for an inmate who was re-arrested after being mistakenly released in a publicly-funded bail program, officials said.


Unisys Introduces Imaging Products
LEAD: The Unisys Corporation introduced two systems that store images of checks and blueprints electronically.
The company's Image Item Processing System will be available in the first quarter of 1990 for $1.5 million to $3 million.
Combined with the software Image Check Processing System, it will allow high-speed image processing of checks for the banking industry.


May Stores To Sell Its Caldor Unit
LEAD: Moving out of discount retailing after 19 years, the May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 118-store Caldor chain and to spin off its 73-store Venture Stores unit.

Harley-Davidson
LEAD: A group led by Malcolm I. Glazer, a businessman, said it had requested Federal permission to increase its stake in the motorcycle manufacturer Harley-Davidson Inc. to 15 percent.
The investor group holds 6.24 percent of Harley's stock.
Harley reiterating its intention to remain independent.
Harley's stock was unchanged yesterday at $40.75 a share on New York Stock Exchange.


Cup Team Named
LEAD: Mark McCumber and Paul Azinger will defend the World Cup championship for the United States next month in Spain.
A total of 32 nations will enter two-player teams in the $1 million tournament, which is scheduled for the Club de Golf Las Brisas in Marbella from Nov. 16-19.
The United States has won the cup 17 times.

Opening the World to a Generation
LEAD: THEY talk on the telephone for hours with the same friends they saw that day at school.
They want to hang out at the mall, to wear the latest style in jeans and sneakers.
They want pierced ears.
Their stereos could be a bit softer and their rooms a bit neater.
Yet their parents could not be happier to see them behaving much as other teen-agers do.

LEAD: Over the last decade the number of students in public schools here has dropped by a third, to 4,212 from 6,441.

People say they do not know where the money goes.

Ms.
Buehl, 45 years old, was editor in chief of Working Mother and Home magazines, and, most recently, a consulting editor at Elle Decor magazine.

I really wanted to work hard - and this is much harder than making a movie.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: WE were up in an attic, three women, opening trunks and tearing the tape off boxes that had been sealed two years earlier.
Dust and the sharp scent of mothballs were tickling our noses, and once in a while one of us would sneeze.
There was no air in this attic and little light, and getting to it meant climbing a series of 2-by-4's nailed to a wall.

LEAD: In a debate that at times turned nasty, the candidates for governor of New Jersey clashed tonight on more than a dozen issues, including their records on abortion and whether teachers or children infected by the AIDS virus should be allowed to continue in the classroom.


CalFed Plans Sale Of Insurance Unit
LEAD: CalFed Inc. agreed to sell its British property-casualty insurance business to an affiliate of John Head &amp; Partners, a New York merchant banking firm, for about $100 million.
The sale of the Anglo American Insurance Company is part of CalFed's strategy to sell its less profitable operations.
CalFed has already sold a number of insurance businesses and its $125 million credit-card portfolio.

Results Plus
LEAD:  GOLF  Jersey Wins Dodge Cup: The New Jersey section of the Professional Golfers Association captured the sixth annual Dodge Challenge Cup over the Met section of the P.G.A. in a one-hole sudden-death playoff yesterday at Rockaway River Country Club at Denville, N.J.
The two eight-player teams were tied at 72 points after a 27-hole format that included best-ball, alternate-shot and singles matches.


Reviews/Music; Dylan Dusts Off His Wit and Rage
LEAD: Bob Dylan looked and sounded closer to his volatile mid-1960's self than he has in years on Tuesday evening at the Beacon Theater, where he played the first concert of a four-night engagement.
By turns grimly triumphant, sarcastic and comically self-parodying, the singer, who is now 48 years old, conveyed much the same mixture of compressed fury and secret knowledge that defined his mystique more than 20 years ago.

Percival Goodman, 85, Synagogue Designer, Dies
LEAD: Percival Goodman, an architect, planner and artist who was one of the nation's leading designers of synagogues, died of lung cancer yesterday at Beth Israel Hospice in New York.
He was 85 years old and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and in a house of his own design in East Hampton, L.I.

Allegheny's Proposals
LEAD: The beleaguered consumer products company Allegheny International Inc. today proposed two alternate reorganization plans, its seventh and eighth since filing for bankruptcy protection in February 1988.
Allegheny is best known for its Sunbeam and Oster lines of appliances.
As with Allegheny's earlier plans, the current ones have opposition.


'Junk Bond' Market Comes Under Selling Pressure
LEAD: The 'junk bond' market came under further selling pressure yesterday, swept with rumors about large blocks of bonds being sold by dealers and investors.
Prices of some large, actively traded issues like RJR Holdings were quoted down a point and a half, or $15 for every $1,000 face amount.

LEAD: The ballyhoo was extreme for the world premiere Tuesday night of Stewart Copeland's opera, ''Holy Blood and Crescent Moon.'' And at the end, this first operatic effort by Stewart Copeland, the drummer of the former rock band the Police, received a standing ovation, with especially fervent cheers from the younger, hipper members of the audience.

LEAD: A 24-year-old Staten Island man was critically injured yesterday when an apparent pipe bomb exploded in his car, the police said.
Vincent Ferro was taken to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan, where he underwent surgery and was listed in critical but stable condition, said a hospital administrator, Sol Torres.


Rights Chief Offers to Quit; White House Has Yet to Act
LEAD: William Barclay Allen has been seeking to resign as chairman of the United States Civil Rights commission, but the White House has yet to accept the resignation, which was first offered five weeks ago, Government officials said today.


Study Cautious on Surgery For Some Small Aneurysms
LEAD: Small bulging weak spots in the main blood vessel in the abdomen do not need to be routinely repaired in most patients, unlike large weak spots, researchers have concluded.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 216 to 206 by which the House of Representatives agreed today to allow the Federal Government to pay for abortions for poor women whose pregnancies result from rape or incest.
A ''yes'' vote is a vote to get rid of the restrictions.
Voting ''yes'' were 175 Democrats and 41 Republicans.

Review/Film; 2 Old Sisters and a Love Interest for One
LEAD: The best that can be said for ''An Unremarkable Life,'' the genteel soap opera opening today at Cinema 2, is that it strikes a blow against prejudice, provincialism, depression, loneliness and fear of the unknown.
The worst to be said is that the blow lands with an awful thud.


Right and Wrong on Student Ignorance
LEAD: The National Endowment for the Humanities reports appalling ignorance among college students about ''basic landmarks of history and thought.'' A survey of 700 college seniors conducted in the spring found that 25 percent did not know that Christopher Columbus came to America before 1500.
And more than 40 percent did not know when the Civil War was fought.


Mister Donut Bids
LEAD: The International Multifoods Corp. said that it had been approached about selling its Mister Donut franchising business and that it was soliciting other offers for the chain.
Mister Donut, the second-largest doughnut chain in North America after Dunkin' Donuts Inc., has 573 shops.
Its estimated sales for this year are $156 million.


Machinists Ask Inquiry On UAL Deal
LEAD: The buyout of the UAL Corporation has taken an important step forward with the overwhelming vote by its pilots to commit $200 million from their pension fund, but the machinists' union, which is opposed to the deal, asked the Labor Department yesterday to examine the transaction to determine whether it is fair.

What Price Luxury? Bigger Deficit
LEAD: As the first luxury models from Japan's two biggest automobile makers reach the United States this fall, each car is adding three times as much to the American trade deficit as the far less expensive vehicle it replaces under the current import-quota agreement.


The Real Columbus Day, at Last
LEAD: Notwithstanding the official U.S. holiday this Monday or New York City's Columbus Day parade last Friday, today is Columbus Day.
It is the 497th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's first landing in the New World, properly celebrated as such in most of Latin America and the Caribbean.

10 Rules To Prevent Boorish Behavior
LEAD: GARDENERS who are content to take pleasure from their own gardens and only theirs live impoverished lives, I believe.
The best gardeners I know regularly visit other gardens.
In return they often invite people to visit theirs.
Knowledge of gardening is dispensed in books (and newspaper columns), but gardens themselves, not words about gardening, are the best teachers of gardening's arts and crafts.

Events this week in Florida and in Washington suggest that the cheering was premature.

LEAD: The Navy's investigation of the explosion that killed 47 sailors in a gun turret of the battleship Iowa last April was ''thorough, complete and expeditious'' and did not malign the character of two sailors on whom the inquiry focused, the Defense Department's inspector general said in a report obtained today.

Police Halt Protest in Taiwan
LEAD: About 2,000 police officers drove demonstrators away from a jail with clubs and water cannons early today and at least 28 people were reported injured.
The protesters demanded the release of a dissident publisher.
Demonstrations outside the Tucheng jail in a Taipei suburb began on Tuesday, Taiwan's National Day, when 10,000 people gathered to demand the immediate release of the publisher, Hsu Hsin Liang..

LEAD: One student was stabbed and six others arrested today in a racially inflamed melee at an Alabama high school, and at least 300 students at Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., were involved in similar fistfights, the authorities and witnesses said.


Companies
LEAD: May Department Stores agreed to sell Caldor and to spin off its Venture Stores unit, ending 19 years of business in discount retailing.
Caldor will be sold to an investor group that includes members of management for $500 million in cash and the assumption of $52 million in debt and lease obligations.

Virtues and Pitfalls of TV Pilots
LEAD: Last month CBS announced a new policy of making pilots for weekly television series.
CBS decided to spread out making pilots over the full year rather than concentrating it in the winter and spring, as all three networks traditionally have.

Reviews/Music; Perle's 'Windows of Order' Has Premiere
LEAD: When a new musical score is introduced to an audience, the accompanying pieces on the program are generally chosen without much concern for historical context.
The audience is seldom encouraged to hear connections between the new piece and anything composed before it.
The Juilliard String Quartet's program on Tuesday evening at the Juilliard Theater may or may not have been so casually planned, but it managed to set off interesting resonances.

Market Place; Shipping Outlook Divides Experts
LEAD: SHIPPING executives are turning to stock markets to finance the creation of new shipping companies as the industry shows signs of recovery from an eight-year slump.
The infusion of cash from Wall Street has contributed to nearly a tripling of second-hand ship prices over the last several years, but industry experts are divided on the long-term outlook for speculation in oceangoing vessels.


Reviews/Music; Icons Who Rock: The Stones Play Shea
LEAD: With planes regularly roaring overhead and sightlines more appropriate for landscape artists than for concertgoers, Shea Stadium isn't the perfect setting for a rock show.
But the Rolling Stones, who opened a six-night engagement on Tuesday, quickly made 66,000 fans feel comfortable.
Four or five songs into its two-and-a-half-hour set, the group dug into the rhythm and proved it could still summon the authority necessary to maintain its status as one of the world's greatest rock-and-roll bands.

LEAD: Leopoldo Galtieri, a former military President sentenced to 12 years in prison for leading Argentina into the disastrous war with Britain for control of the Falkland Islands, was freed today by presidential pardon.


Criticized on AIDS Drug, Maker Will Give It to Some
LEAD: A pharmaceutical company accused of overcharging for a drug that prevents pneumonia in people infected with the AIDS virus says it will give the drug away to the uninsured but will not reduce the price for others.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was shouted down by opposition calls for his resignation today as he tried to address the Indian Parliament at the opening of a special legislative session.


Corrections
LEAD: A brief article by The Associated Press on Aug. 18 about the denial of parole for Elmer (Geronimo) Pratt, a former Black Panther Party leader, referred incorrectly to his use of heroin.
In a California parole hearing, remarks about his drug use dealt with the period before, not after, he was imprisoned for the murder of a woman in 1968.


Delay of at Least 5 Days Seen for Shuttle Mission
LEAD: Technicians began removing a faulty engine control unit from the space shuttle Atlantis today as officials predicted that the craft would be launched no earlier than next Tuesday.

LEAD: Three Brooklyn teen-agers were arrested late Tuesday and charged with assaulting three Jewish students at Brooklyn College in what the police have characterized as an anti-Semitic attack.


Japan Lifts Discount Rate; Dollar Still Gains
LEAD: The Bank of Japan surprised the foreign exchange market here today by abruptly raising its discount rate a half-percentage point in an effort to stem the dollar's surge.
But the increase, announced at midday, had a negligible impact, prompting concerns that central banks are running out of tools for taming the dollar.

LEAD: Many women at or past the age of menopause are worried and confused about taking hormones to replace the ones their ovaries are no longer producing in ''adequate'' amounts.

Exxon Capital
LEAD: The Exxon Capital Corporation is offering $200 million in noncallable capital notes, due in 1994, through Salomon Brothers Inc.

Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. is generating bitter denunciations from civil rights leaders and black officials and resurrecting old divisions among the followers of Dr.
King.


Jail Guard Drug Testing Upheld, 3- 2
LEAD: A plan to randomly test more than 10,000 correction officers in New York City's prisons for drug use was narrowly upheld yesterday by a New York appeals court.


Upbeat Ending to U.N. Talks
LEAD: Members of the 44th United Nations General Assembly ended their annual exchange of views on world problems today.


SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:  Fred Hersch


Review/Theater; Casualties of Officialdom: Language and Truth
LEAD: How do you write a truthful play in which everyone is a liar?
Set it on Capitol Hill, of course.
In ''Mastergate,'' Larry Gelbart's excoriating satire of the Iran-contra hearings, the witnesses before a Congressional committee aspire only to be ''steadfastly evasive and selectively honest,'' and they don't even succeed at that.


Victory Is Upheld
LEAD: The British Boxing Board of Control, meeting in London yesterday, ruled that Tony Wilson could keep his victory over Steve McCarthy on his record, even though Wilson's mother landed the winning blows with her high-heeled shoe in a light-heavyweight bout in Southampton, England, Sept. 21.

LEAD: Praying on a barren plain said to have been a killing field for Government troops, Pope John Paul II admonished Indonesia today to respect human rights in the disputed province of East Timor, where he said ''many innocent people have died.''

South Pole Ozone Is at Lowest Level, Researchers Report
LEAD: The ozone in the stratosphere over the South Pole has equalled the lowest level that scientists have measured, space agency scientists reported today.

PANAMANIAN TELLS OF GOAL OF REBELS
LEAD: A Panamanian sergeant whose commander was slain leading an abortive coup against Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that while the uprising seemed well planned, he and other lower-ranking officers had been informed of it less than an hour before it began.

Not Everybody Wants to Sign a Living Will; Additional Instrument
LEAD: To the Editor:


6th Indicted in Hawkins Death
LEAD: A sixth white defendant, Charles Stressler, was indicted yesterday for murder in connection with what the police have described as the racially motivated slaying of a black teen-ager on Aug. 23 in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.
The victim, Yusuf K. Hawkins, 16 years old, was fatally shot after he and some friends went to the largely white neighborhood to look at a used car that was for sale.


Susan P. Riley, Doctor, Is Wed
LEAD: Dr.
Susan Patricia Riley and Thomas James Fleming Jr. were married yesterday by Justice Ernst H. Rosenberger of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in his chambers in New York.
The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
William Riley of Eltingville, S.I.
The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs.


Editor Resigns Post at U.S. News
LEAD: Roger Rosenblatt, the editor of U.S.
News and World Report for the last 14 months who has continued an active writing career, resigned yesterday.
In his letter of resignation to the chairman and editor in chief, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, who had wanted him to take a more active management role, he cited commuting difficulties.

Our Towns; Gadgets to Fight What Goes Bump In Your Night
LEAD: Melanie Franklin and her husband, Antony Lee, conceived of a security supermarket about two years ago when they were living in an apartment in New York City.


NBC Sought MGM/UA Deal Stake
LEAD: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had expressed an interest in becoming an equity investor in an Australian entertainment concern's proposed buyout of the MGM/UA Communications Company.


Northwest Sets Deal For 90 Boeing Planes
LEAD: Northwest Airlines said today that it had placed orders and taken options for 90 jetliners worth from the Boeing Company worth $5.2 billion.


Kemp Suggests Pierce Testify And Adds, 'I Think He Will'
LEAD: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp suggested today that his predecessor, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., should break his silence and testify before Congress about allegations of political favoritism that Mr.
Kemp said had ''tragically'' stained Mr.
Pierce's reputation.


Ross Reid, 72, Lawyer and Executive, Dies
LEAD: Ross Reid, a lawyer and business executive, died on Monday at New York Hospital after a long illness.
He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Giants Call on Riles For New Hitting Role
LEAD: With Kevin Mitchell back at practice and his one-day excursion home to San Diego being accepted as a ''failure of communication,'' attention at the San Francisco Giants' workout today shifted to the self-effacing but important Ernest Riles.


Msgr. Arthur F. Bukowski, Educator, 83
LEAD: Msgr.
Arthur Francis Bukowski, president of Aquinas College here for 32 years, died Tuesday of heart disease.
He was 83 years old.


Sale of Stamps for $1 Million Sets Record for a U.S. Issue
LEAD: A block of four United States stamps, the ''Inverted Jenny'' on which the plane in the center is upside down, was sold for $1 million last night, the highest price ever paid for an American philatelic item, a spokeswoman for Christie's auction house said.


Soviet Sale By Olivetti
LEAD: Ing.
C.
Olivetti S.p.A. of Italy, which shipped high-technology machine tools to the Soviet Union, said today that the sale had been approved by Italian authorities.


Ford to Sell Its Steel Unit
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had signed a memorandum of understanding to sell its Rouge Steel Company to an investor group.


Panel Proposes To Raise Fares In Taxis 11.5%
LEAD: The Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday recommended raising New York taxicab fares an average of 11.5 percent next year and replacing the night surcharge with one for the rush hours in hopes of encouraging additional cabdrivers to work in the peak hours.


Saatchi Is Getting a New Chief
LEAD: Maurice Saatchi, the co-founder of the Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Company, said yesterday that he would relinquish the position of chief executive in favor of a 43-year-old French executive barely known in the advertising business.


Review/Theater; Feydeau's 'Flea in Her Ear,' at Long Wharf
LEAD: John Tillinger's production of ''A Flea in Her Ear,'' which is opening the 25th season at the Long Wharf Theater, is performed with split-second synchronicity.
The mechanics of the farce never show as the actors and audience are swept away by the sport of the chase - the slammed doors, the revolving beds, the frazzled looks and the mistaken identities that confuse an irate husband with a drunken hotel porter.


Knicks Open With Nuggets
LEAD: With more plays for Patrick Ewing, a more controlled up-tempo game and emphasis on halfcourt defense rather than the press, the Knicks open an eight-game exhibition schedule Friday against the Denver Nuggets at Madison Square Garden.


How to Get Those Bright Colors on Film
LEAD: Photographing the spectacular colors of autumn requires no secret techniques, only a modicum of knowledge about cameras and films.
Even a simple camera that does all the focusing and exposure calculations for you is sufficient, provided its idea of the perfect picture coincides with yours.
And off-the-shelf amateur films are fully capable of rendering all the bright hues and subtle shades of fall, although some do it better than others.

Neighborhood Gangs Line Up for the Series
LEAD: The last time two gangs from the same neighborhood tangled in the World Series, Roger Craig was pitching for one of them.
Now the manager of the San Francisco Giants, Craig was overshadowed in the 1956 Series by his teammates in the Brooklyn Dodgers' lineup and his opponents in the Yankees' lineup.


Reviews/Music; San Francisco Symphony Plays Beethoven's 'Eroica'
LEAD: There is a feeling abroad that pieces like Beethoven's ''Eroica'' symphony, which the San Francisco Symphony brought to Carnegie Hall Tuesday evening, are all but played out - that they have been interpreted so much, played so often, heard so repeatedly that somehow they just don't work any more.
This speculation follows from the fact that lots of musicians and critics find themselves a little bored at a lot of performances of the canonic classics by artists and organizations that should be expected to do them well.


House Votes to Widen Oversight of C.I.A.
LEAD: The House of Representatives voted today to give lawmakers broad access to the Central Intelligence Agency's most private analyses of its own failings.

Mr. de Klerk Earns an Indulgence
LEAD: South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, took two strides this week in pursuit of his ''mandate for change.'' By releasing eight prominent political prisoners and holding ''talks about talks'' with three black leaders of the anti-apartheid movement, he seemed to signal that he was serious about negotiating an end to whites-only rule and finding a formula for enfranchising blacks.


Consolidated Natural Gas
LEAD: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company of Pittsburgh yesterday priced $150 million in sinking fund debentures, due in 2019, through competitive bidding won by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.


U.S.-Soviet Drug Plan
LEAD: Officials of the United States and Soviet Olympic Committees today completed the fine-tuning of their bilateral agreeement to test each other's athletes for drugs, and said testing would start in 1990.


Hancock Team in Race
LEAD: The John Hancock Running and Fitness Clinic staff, which includes eight of the finest marathon runners in the world, will compete in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 5 and will also conduct the first Hancock Running and Fitness clinics in New York next month.


Records Show Unexplained Payments by Dinkins Campaign
LEAD: David N. Dinkins's campaign has failed to provide adequate documentation for a number of expenses, including three payments totaling $9,500 for a ''get out the vote'' drive led by a community organizer, Robert (Sonny) Carson, New York City campaign finance records show.

Top NATO Civilian Sees Role For Both Alliances in 1990's
LEAD: The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said today that he believed the Western alliance and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact would continue to exist for at least a decade more because they could both be useful in a time of dramatic change.


Rival Scientists Decide Universe Is Composed of 3 Types of Matter
LEAD: Using two giant particle accelerators, one in Europe and the other in California, rival teams of scientists have established beyond reasonable doubt that the universe contains no more than three fundamental types of matter.


Aristech Chemical Gets Takeover Bid
LEAD: The Aristech Chemical Corporation said it had received a takeover offer of $25 a share, or a total of about $842 million.
It said the Huntsman Holdings Corporation had proposed that its affiliate, the Banstar Corporation, acquire Aristech in a friendly transaction.
Aristech said its board would make a response ''at the appropriate time.

LEAD: The House of Representatives gave final approval today to legislation that outlaws flag desecration, and Congressional leaders began maneuvering for a greater battle next week over a constitutional amendment to protect the flag.

Rape and Incest: Just 1% of All Abortions
LEAD: For all the symbolic importance of the House of Representatives' move to restore the Federal financing of abortions for poor women when the pregnancy resulted from incest or rape, the practical effect would likely be very limited.


No Tolerance for Hate
LEAD: Hateful words like ''shvartzer'' and ''nigger'' and ''kike'' are still unacceptable and objectionable to most New Yorkers.
But recent reminders that such ugliness has its adherents reinforces a troubling reality about New York: Though blessed with a rich ethnicity, the city is also threatened by deep ethnic and racial animosities.


An Altered Political Climate Suddenly Surrounds Abortion
LEAD: Victories for abortion rights supporters this week in the Florida Legislature and the House of Representatives, plus gains in electoral campaigns in New Jersey and Virginia, have shaken their opponents and emboldened Democratic politicians to challenge President Bush and the Republicans to defend their opposition to abortion.


Review/Film; Pfeiffer and 2 Bridges Brothers in 'The Fabulous Baker Boys'
LEAD: Long after midnight, New Year's Eve: a moment that ''The Fabulous Baker Boys,'' the slow, teasing, rapturously moody romance written and directed by Steve Kloves, has been waiting for.
Every waiter and busboy and reveler has left the hotel nightclub, but the balloons and the confetti remain.
On each empty table, a little lamp casts a deep, warm glow.

LEAD: In his final remarks to the jury in the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia, the chief defense lawyer conceded yesterday that Mr.
Garcia ''made a mistake in judgment'' by borrowing $20,000 from a Wedtech executive and then trying to conceal the loan.

LEAD: Voicing fears that a fast-food restaurant would destroy their neighborhood, about 100 people gathered on a sidewalk on the Upper East Side last night, waving placards that proclaimed, ''Save Our Services'' and ''Fast Food Clogs Arteries.''


J. Rupert Picott Dies; Teacher Advocate, 77
LEAD: J. Rupert Picott, an educator and early civil rights leader, died of prostate cancer Wednesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington.
He was 77 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday announced the terms for licensing the Release 4.0 version of its Unix computer operating system, which is scheduled to be released later this year.


Philips Shipping TV Sets to Japan
LEAD: In a reversal of an electronics trend, the Philips Consumer Electronics Company began shipping American-made television sets to Japan.
Philips plans to export 1,500 sets to Japan this year, ''with significantly increasing exports projected for the 1990's,'' the company said.

LEAD: Six intruders armed with firebombs and tear gas briefly occupied part of the residence of the United States Ambassador early today before the police removed them.

LEAD: Edward P. Moore, a management consultant for many years before his retirement in 1977, died Tuesday at his home in Darien, Conn., after a long illness.
He was 80 years old.

British Aerospace
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it had bought 5.72 million shares of Ferranti International Signal P.L.C., raising its holding in the troubled British military-electronics company to 1.7 percent.
On Tuesday, British Aerospace and Thomson-CSF of France said they were working on a possible rescue of Ferranti and considering the possibility of making a bid.

New York City Opera Cancels Rest of Season
LEAD: The New York City Opera, shut down by a musicians' strike since Sept. 13, yesterday canceled the remaining 40 performances of its fall season at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center.
The entire fall season, scheduled to run through Nov. 19, comprised 70 performances.

Walgreen Executive To Head Operations
LEAD: L. Daniel Jorndt, who joined the Walgreen Company out of college as a pharmacist, has been named to succeed Fred F. Canning as president and chief operating officer of the nation's largest drugstore chain.
Mr.
Canning, who is to retire on Feb. 1, 1990, will remain on Walgreen's board.


Ross F. Nigrelli, 85, an Expert On Disease of Sea Life, Is Dead
LEAD: Dr.
Ross F. Nigrelli, a marine biologist and world-renowned expert on diseases of aquatic creatures, died of complications of a stroke on Oct. 4 at Southhampton (L.I.) Hospital.
He was 85 years old and lived in East Quogue, L.I.


Californians Say Clean Air Pact Will Backfire
LEAD: California officials today denounced the new Congressional agreement to extend California's stringent automobile-emission standards to the rest of the country and called it a bad bargain for the state.


The Finalists Are Named In National Book Awards
LEAD: A first novel, ''The Joy Luck Club,'' by Amy Tan, is among the five finalists for the 1989 National Book Award in fiction, as is ''Billy Bathgate,'' a novel by E. L. Doctorow, who is a previous winner.
The five books nominated for the nonfiction prize are on such public policy issues as the American civil rights movement and the Middle


Coca-Cola Net Up 20.9% in Quarter
LEAD: Helped by strong overseas sales of soft drinks, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that third-quarter profits surged 20.9 percent, to $356 million, or $1.03 a share.
Sales rose 8 percent, to $2.3 billion.

Travelers, St. Paul Settle Texas Suit
LEAD: Two large insurance companies, sued in an antitrust case, have agreed to testify for the state and pay $500,000 in legal costs each, Attorney General Jim Mattox said.
The Travelers Insurance Company and the St.
Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company also agreed to cease certain activities in the settlement agreement.

LEAD: Representative Jim Courter, the Republican candidate for governor, found himself under criticism today for his proposal in the gubernatorial debate on Wednesday to remove teachers and children infected with the AIDS virus from contact with uninfected children in the classroom.


Market Place; A New Concern Over Asset Sales
LEAD: THE ''junk bond'' market, which has been reeling in recent weeks, was dominated by selling pressure again yesterday and it is likely to get worse before it improves, according to Robert M. Steinberg, the head of risk arbitrage at Bear, Stearns &amp; Company.

FOREIGN SERVICE TO HIRE THE BLIND
LEAD: In a policy reversal, the State Department announced today that blind people may serve as Foreign Service officers.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the selection of a new executive director for the United States Olympic Committee misstated the action taken.
Harvey Schiller was recommended for the post by a search committee, but the final selection will be made by the Olympic Committee's executive board.

Lockheed Reports Loss
LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation said today that it lost $32 million in the third quarter after taking a $165 million charge to cover cost overruns on several development contracts.
The loss was $3 million less than the company predicted last week, when it disclosed the write-off.


WHITE HOUSE SEEKS CLOSER CONTACTS IN A PANAMA COUP
LEAD: The White House plans to issue specific guidelines to American military, intelligence and diplomatic officials in Panama so they can provide clearer and more rapid communication with potential coup plotters, a senior official said today.


Corrections
LEAD: On Sept. 23 the obituary of Irving Berlin misstated the number of Academy Awards he won.
As a letter from a reader has pointed out, his only Oscar was for the song ''White Christmas'' from the 1942 film ''Holiday Inn.'' The song ''Cheek to Cheek'' from the 1935 film ''Top Hat'' was nominated for an Oscar, but did not win.

LEAD: The former chief of staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission acknowledged today that for seven months he delayed an inquiry into allegations of drug use and safety problems at the Nine Mile Point nuclear plant in upstate New York, even though he believed they were probably true.

When Sewell Replaced Ray Chapman
LEAD: rrOn the eve of the World Series, Joe Sewell vividly remembers the first one he ever saw, 69 years ago.
He remembers it so well because he played in it.
Joe Sewell is the last living member of the 1920 Cleveland Indians team, which beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in seven games in the Series.
And it is a curious slice of history that in the fifth game he actually assisted in the only unassisted triple play in a World


Inspectors Tripping Up Truck Drivers
LEAD: Bill Lemasters was driving a tractor-trailer south on Van Emburgh Avenue, a narrow country road used by truckers to avoid a weigh station and congestion on nearby Route 17, when he was stopped by township police officers.


Review/Art; The Reinvented Americana Of Robert Gober's Mind
LEAD: Robert Gober's eccentric made-from-scratch objects constitute a kind of revised Americana.
They honor the humbler crafts while raising troubling questions about the culture that values them.
These questions are deeply personal, for almost all of Mr.
Gober's objects allude to the body, often to its most private functions.

2 Bankers Cited In Iraqi Case
LEAD: Two senior officers at the Atlanta branch of Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Italy's largest bank, were accused yesterday of fraud and racketeering in connection with the issuance of more than $2 billion of loan agreements and letters of credit, primarily to banks and Government agencies in Iraq.


California Changes Phone-Rate Structure
LEAD: In a move watched closely by regulators in other states, the California Public Utilities Commission today approved a different way of setting rates for the state's two largest local telephone companies.
The change is intended to provide freer competition in the marketplace.


Huzzahs for Armani's Soft and Slithery Collection
LEAD: Fashion is moving in a softer, gentler direction, and Giorgio Armani has reached the finish line first.
Skipping all the intermediary steps, he threw away shoulder pads, all kinds of inner construction and extraneous details like collars and made clothes that slither over the body in gossamer fabrics.

Silicon Graphics To Buy Back Stock
LEAD: Silicon Graphics Inc. agreed to repurchase 2,360,000 common shares held by the Control Data Corporation.
The shares will be bought for $22.60 each, below the recent market price, for a total of $53.3 million.
The transaction will cut Control Data's holdings in Silicon Graphics to 702,750 shares, or just under 5 percent of the outstanding stock.

LEAD: Katharine Graham, chairman and chief executive officer of The Washington Post, is writing her memoirs, which will be published by Alfred A. Knopf Inc.

Guerrilla Fighting in Sahara
LEAD: Polisario guerrillas killed 190 Moroccans and wounded 150 in fighting on Wednesday in the Western Sahara, a Polisario military communique issued in Algiers said today.
The guerrillas, who are fighting Morocco for independence of Western Sahara, captured six Moroccan bases and observation posts in the Hauza region in the northern Sahara, it added.


Deadly Night: New York Murders Keep Pace
LEAD: A Baptist minister, a doorman walking home and a printer who planned to be married on Saturday were among 11 people slain in New York City during the 12 hours between sundown Wednesday and the following dawn.
The police said it was one of the bloodiest nights the city has seen this year.

'Good Health' Walk And Fitness Event
LEAD: A four-mile ''Good Health'' walk from midtown to lower Manhattan will start a health and fitness event on Sunday sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation and The New York Times Company.
The walk will begin at 1 P.M. at The New York Times Building, 229 West 43d Street, and will wind down Broadway to Battery Park, where a health festival will feature food, entertainment, sports clinics, competitions and prizes; the fair will continue until 4:30 P.M.

Dr. Philip G. Colin, 86, Chemical Engineer
LEAD: Dr.
Philip G. Colin, a chemical engineer who developed industrial processes for many drugs, died of a heart attack on Oct. 5 at his home in San Diego.
He was 86 years old.


Sidewalk Obstacle Course
LEAD: East Side, West Side, forget the light fantastic - just walking on the sidewalks of New York can be like threading through a slalom because of construction equipment and jury-rigged scaffolding.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD: THE ECONOMY  Senate Democratic leaders said they had enough votes to keep a capital gains tax cut out of the deficit-reduction package under consideration.
Republicans conceded that they could not muster the 60 votes needed to add the tax cut to the deficit legislation, but they made it clear they would try to attach the capital gains reduction to other legislation, perhaps by the end of the month.


Up Thoughts for a Down Day
LEAD: People who regard 13 as unlucky - triskaidekaphobes - are especially unnerved by Friday the 13th.
There is always at least one a year, often two and occasionally, 28 times since 1800, three.
Today is the second and last for 1989, and time to shed some light in this dark corner of the calendar.


Restaurants
LEAD: The Meridien hotel chain pioneered the consulting-celebrity-chef strategy in the early 1980's, winging in three-star French chefs like Alain Chapel, Paul Bocuse and Jacques Maximin to oversee its kitchens around the United States.
At Maurice in New York's Hotel Parker Meridien, the imported luminary was Alain Senderens of Lucas-Carton in Paris, followed early this year by Marc Haeberlin of the renowned Auberge de l'Ill in Alsace.

She was 60 years old and lived in Middletown, Conn.
The cause of death was suicide, said her husband, Richard.

Manila Moves To Cut Its Debt
LEAD: The Philippine Government offered Wednesday to buy back some of its commercial bank loans at half price in a bid to reduce its $29 billion foreign debt.
The central bank governor, Jose Fernandez, said Manila was prepared to buy $1.3 billion of the $7.2 billion in medium- and long-term bank debt at 50 cents on the dollar, or a total cost of $650 million.


Undaunted, Giuliani Swims Upstream
LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani smiled stiffly at a subway stop in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn the other day, his arms folded across his waist, waiting for someone to shake his hand.
Deep in the liberal Democratic turf of David N. Dinkins, the Republican mayoral nominee was standing more or less alone.


Spurs Sign Elliott To 5-Year Contract
LEAD: Saying he was ''excited to get it over with,'' Sean Elliott, San Antonio's first-round draft pick in June, signed a five-year contract, reportedly worth $9 million, with the Spurs yesterday.
Elliott, the No. 3 draft choice in the National Basketball Association, has made publicity appearances and attended team meetings, but the 6-foot-8-inch forward from the University of Arizona has yet to work out with the team.(

G.M.'s Van Output
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would move the production of its full-size vans to Flint, Mich., from plants in Lordstown, Ohio, and Scarborough, Ontario.
G.M. and union officials said the move would be completed in late 1991.
The shift will affect about 2,500 workers at the Lordstown plant, which employs a total of 11,500.


Nynex and Unions Seek Mediator in Strike
LEAD: At New York State's urging, Nynex and striking telephone workers agreed yesterday to seek a mediator for their 10-week contract dispute.


With Bird Walking Normally, Celtics Prepare to Walk Tall
LEAD: When the Boston Celtics' two-hour practice ended this morning, Larry Bird still wanted more work.
So he did some extra running on the sidelines with a teammate, Ed Pinckney.


Southnet Venture
LEAD: The Southnet Corporation and Fone America Inc., two long-distance telephone companies, agreed to form a joint venture.
Southnet, based in Tampa, and Fone America, a Nevada company, plan to consolidate and share switching centers, data-processing services, network facilities and billing services.
Terms of the agreement are expected to be completed soon, the companies said.


Conviction in Palme Murder Is Overturned


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Tuesday about the six teen-agers accused of the rape of a jogger in Central Park misattributed assertions about the role of one defendant, Steven Lopez.
It was a co-defendant, Kevin Richardson, who told the authorities that Mr.
Lopez had held the jogger down and struck her with a pipe.

LEAD: The General Electric Company yesterday reported a 16 percent increase in earnings for the third quarter, based on improvements in its financial services, plastics, locomotive and electrical generating equipment operations.


Pinball Scandal Erupts in Japan
LEAD: Both of Japan's biggest political parties found themselves enmeshed in new accusations of influence-peddling today after disclosures that one of Japan's most shadowy entertainment industries - its ubiquitous pinball parlors - contributed roughly $1 million to key politicians.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 470 money market mutual funds increased by $899.9 million, to $349.89 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 141 institutional funds decreased by $21.3 million, to $83.14 billion.
The assets of the 233 general-purpose funds were up by $436.7 million, to $114 billion.

He was 86 years old and lived in the City Island section of the Bronx.

LEAD: If the formlessness and scatological shapes and textures of William Tucker's new sculptures put you off at first (''dinosaur droppings,'' one visitor called them), give them a chance.
The 10 pieces of shifting, rocky matter at the David McKee Gallery in Manhattan and four larger, more boulderlike blocks at the gallery's Brooklyn exhibition space are among the most evocative and ambitious works Mr.

AMR Offer To Pilots Is Reported
LEAD: The chairman of the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, has held talks with the company's pilots' union to consider a buyout in which the company's unions would be offered a large stake, a person on Wall Street familiar with the talks said yesterday.


Say Yes to the Landmarks Compromise
LEAD: New York's Charter Revision Commission, dragged into the protracted battle between the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission and religious institutions, managed to extricate itself with an ambiguous compromise.
That compromise goes to the public as a separate question in November's referendum.
It won't resolve the eternal conflict between preservationists and religious institutions.


Foul Play By Eckersley?
LEAD: A videotape that the Toronto Blue Jays claim shows Dennis Eckers trying to hide something in his trousers in Sunday's playoff game has been sent to the American League president and to the commissioner's office, said General Manager Pat Gillick of Toronto.


Barrett Bows Out
LEAD: J. Patrick Barrett, who failed to get any backing from National Football League owners this week in the voting for commissioner, withdrew his name yesterday from the list of four being considered for the job.
Barrett, chairman of the New York State Republican Committee, said it was apparent that the process of selecting a successor to Pete Rozelle would be a protracted one and that he could not keep his life ''on hold'' any longer.(

Henderson the Run King
LEAD: The child who became the man of perpetual motion grew up not far from the stage that will serve as a backdrop for the opening games of the 86th World Series.
The reminders of Rickey Henderson's youth are scattered all across north Oakland, not so much in the places he played as in the minds of those who watched him.

Review/Film; The Dismay Among Filipinos
LEAD: ''Fight for Us,'' opening today at the Paris Theater, is as much a political gesture as it is a political film.
Produced by French interests in the Philippines, the movie is the outraged response of its director, Lino Brocka, one of the most popular and successful Philippine film makers, to the human-rights abuses that are reported to be continuing in his country.


Edward G. Schumacher, Merchant Mariner, 66
LEAD: Edward G. Schumacher, a former merchant seaman who helped win veteran status for merchant mariners who served in World War II, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Dale City, Va.
He was 66 years old.


Exhibitions Are Planned On Titian And 1492 Art
LEAD: The National Gallery of Art today announced two exhibitions to dramatize the cultural ties between the United States and Italy: a retrospective of the work of Titian and a celebration of the quincentenary of Columbus's first voyage to America.


Bank of New York and Chemical Post Big Losses
LEAD: The Chemical Banking Corporation and the Bank of New York Company announced large third-quarter losses yesterday as they greatly increased the reserves set aside to cover possible losses on loans to third world countries and to domestic businesses.

LEAD: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, passing up a chance to defuse criticism from fellow Federal judges over his handling of a death penalty proposal, urged Congress today to act as quickly as possible on the proposal for speeding Federal court review of death sentences.

Zenith, the world's largest seller of battery-powered laptop computers, said the new Supersport SX laptop could operate for more than three hours on the battery before it needed recharging.

She was 73 years old and lived in Rockville Center, L.I.

LEAD: It is only the second week of competition in the Big Ten Conference, but there have already been suggestions the title may be decided today when Michigan State is the host team in East Lansing, Mich., to Coach Bo Schembechler's Michigan Wolverines.

LEAD: Federal researchers plan to use 15 injured golden eagles in an experiment that could lead to the renewed use of Compound 1080, a highly toxic coyote poison.

Lockheed to Use Italian Jet Design
LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation, in the early stages of competing for a $2 billion Air Force training jet program, said it would use an Italian jet design if it won the contract.
Lockheed said it had an agreement with Aermacchi S.p.A. of Varese, Italy, to use the MB-339 jet tandem-trainer for the United States Air Force's Primary Aircraft Training System program.


Review/Theater; Gorky's 'Summerfolk' in Providence
LEAD: It is clear from her debut as artistic director of the Trinity Repertory Company that Anne Bogart is not satisfied with halfway measures.
Her unorthodox production of Gorky's ''Summerfolk,'' which opened Wednesday night, is an ambitious attempt to reinvent the play as a radical and relevant comedy about the complacency and ennui of the new Russian bourgeoisie.


Jersey Takes Over Failing Schools
LEAD: Citing ''total educational failure,'' the state of New Jersey assumed full responsibility for all 37 schools in Jersey City - the first state takeover of a local school district in memory.
Coming on the heels of a summit meeting where the nation's governors promised improvements in education, the move demonstrates just how far some states will have to go to meet that obligation.


Storm May Cancel a City's Halloween
LEAD: Three weeks after a hurricane battered the Carolina coast, this inland city remains so littered with downed magnolias and willow oaks that officials are asking parents to keep children at home on Halloween.


End for 'Junk Bond' Takeovers?
LEAD: Institutional investors behaved yesterday as if the takeover craze had ended.
Mindful of recent turmoil in the ''junk bond'' market, they grew concerned that corporate acquisitions, which have done much to drive up stock prices in recent years, would grind to a halt because of a lack of credit.


H.U.D. Ousts Administrator In New York
LEAD: An investigation by the Department of Housing and Urban Development has found that its former New York administrator, Geraldine McGann, violated Federal ethical standards in connection with a subsidized housing program in her hometown of Island Park, L.I., but did not use her position to enrich her family or political allies.


Joe Foy, Baseball Player, 46
LEAD: Joe Foy, a third baseman with the 1967 American League champion Boston Red Sox and later a member of the Mets, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in New York.
He was 46 years old.

LEAD: Now that cooler weather is here and children are spending more time indoors it is a good time to see that pull cords for window coverings are safely secured.


U.S. Cites Right to Seize Fugitives Abroad
LEAD: Reversing a nine-year-old policy, the Justice Department has advised the Federal Bureau of Investigation that it may legally seize United States fugitives in foreign countries without the consent of foreign governments, Administration officials said today.


Medigap Policies: Fine for Now
LEAD: The Senate and the House of Representatives have moved to repeal all or part of the Federal program of expanded health insurance for older Americans.
A new measure to replace the 1988 Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act has still to be shaped by a Congressional conference committee, but there seems to be little doubt at this point that most of the benefits will end shortly, along with the income-tax surtax that was to pay for them.

LEAD: Richard F. Uhlmann, a grain dealer who served as president of the Chicago Board of Trade in 1948, died at Highland Park (Ill.) Hospital on Monday after a brief illness.
He was 91 years old.

LEAD: Retail sales rose a moderate five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government said today.
Analysts said the report showed consumer spending was still fairly strong, despite a slowing economy.

LEAD: Merab Kostava, a leading Georgian human rights campaigner and dissident for more than 30 years, was killed today in a car accident, an independent newspaper said.
He was 50 years old.

LEAD: After failing to win creditors' support for a 90-day financing agreement, Alcott &amp; Andrews, the retail chain that specializes in career apparel for women, said it would go out of business.

LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.95 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.

LEAD: Sales of American-built cars fell 12.6 percent in early October after two months of steep discounts by auto makers seeking to clear year-end inventories of 1989 models.

LEAD: The Campaign Matters column on Oct. 5, about the issue of ethnic slurs in the campaign for New Jersey governor, referred incorrectly to a 1986 Federal indictment of a union that had contributed money to some campaigns of Representative James J. Florio.
The indictment accused leaders of roofers Local 30-30B, based in Philadelphia, of having made payments to a number of public officials, including state judges in Pennsylvania.

LEAD: Christian insistence on guarantees of a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon continued to hold up an agreement among Lebanon's factions today, but Arab officials expressed optimism that the sides would agree on a new charter for their nation.

LEAD: One of the four main overhead rotors on the helicopter that crashed on Tuesday in central New Jersey, killing three senior Atlantic City casino executives and two crew members, broke in half in flight because of a series of cracks, Federal investigators said yesterday.

LEAD: After three straight declines, prices at the producer level surged nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, mainly because of increases for energy and motor vehicles.

Syrian Pilot's Escape to Israel Was a 'Very Difficult Mission'
LEAD: The Syrian fighter pilot who defected to Israel in a Soviet jet fighter on Wednesday said today that his flight was ''a very difficult mission'' since he flew at about 800 miles an hour and was only about 100 to 150 feet off the ground.

LEAD: The Golden State Foods Corporation, a privately held food processor and distributor that supplies only McDonald's restaurants, retained Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company to help it explore merger possibilities.
Howard Hansen, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company, said the McDonald's Corporation was an unlikely suitor because it had a policy of not selling supplies or equipment to franchisees.

LEAD: While Japanese companies are buying up Hollywood studios and financing American producers, a group of Japanese businessmen is hoping to invigorate Japan's sluggish film industry by grafting American rhythms and plot structure onto a Japanese movie.


Chrysler Price Rise
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it was raising its 1990 passenger car prices an overall 5 percent from comparably equipped 1989 models.
It attributed 3 percent of the increase to the installation of driver-side supplementary air bag systems as standard equipment on all of its United States-built cars.

LEAD: Grateful Dead concerts are as iffy as blind dates, but the band had a good night tonight, the second concert of a five-night stand at the Brendan Byrne Arena.

LEAD: The ''Messa per Rossini'' that the New York Philharmonic presented under Helmuth Rilling's baton on Thursday evening is a musical camel, an improbable animal designed by a committee.
A collaboration by 13 Italian composers in memory of Rossini, it is a Requiem Mass of gangling proportions instigated by Verdi, who wrote the final section.

LEAD: A ''flight to quality'' sent prices of Treasury securities soaring and yields plunging yesterday.
Dealers said the demand for all Treasury securities surged as stock prices began tumbling in the last 45 minutes of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
But a sharp decline in the dollar tended to take the edge off the price advances.

LEAD: A late wave of selling swept the stock market yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent, to 2,569.26.
In terms of points, the decline was the second largest in history, exceeded only by the 508-point plunge of Oct. 19, 1987, but the decline in percentage terms was not nearly so bad.

British Inflation Rises
LEAD: Retail prices in Britain rose by the steepest amount in five months in September, bringing the annual inflation rate to 7.6 percent, the Government reported today.
The Government said the rise of seven-tenths of a percent in the retail price index for September was the highest monthly increase since April's 1.8 percent.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Raiders placed their former All-Pro running back Marcus Allen on injured reserve yesterday because of a torn knee ligament, and he will not be eligible to return until late November.(AP)

LEAD: Against odds and expectations, what seems like a serious peace plan for Lebanon is being tacked together by aging politicians meeting in the Saudi Arabian resort town of Taif.
Arab League mediators have diligently promoted marathon talks among the surviving members of the Lebanese Parliament, elected in 1972.

Mr.
Ward, whose innovative work contributed sophistication and wit to television cartoons for more than three decades, was best known for his series about a bumbling, deep-voiced moose - Bullwinkle - and his sprightly companion, Rocky, the flying squirrel.

Turner Broadcasting Considering Publishing
LEAD: The Turner Broadcasting System is considering starting a book publishing operation, possibly with one or more foreign partners.
It is also looking into establishing a prize for works of fiction about the environment, according to Turner executives in Atlanta.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Cairo Says Qaddafi to Visit
LEAD: Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, will visit Egypt on Sunday for the first time in 16 years and hold talks with President Hosni Mubarak, Egyptian officials said today.
They said Colonel Qaddafi would meet President Mubarak in Mersa Matruh, a resort on the Mediterranean.


First Chicago Reports Loss
LEAD: Following the example of other leading United States banks, the First Chicago Corporation reported a third-quarter loss today after increasing its reserves for shaky third world loans by $200 million.


Warsaw Sinfonia
LEAD: Yehudi Menuhin will conduct the Warsaw Sinfonia in Mendelssohn's Overture to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Lutoslawski's ''Funeral Music,'' the Haydn Symphony No. 104 and the Bruch Violin Concerto at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall.
Robert McDuffie is to be the soloist in the Bruch.
Tickets are $11 to $20.


SENATE APPROVES $14 BILLION PLAN TO REDUCE DEFICIT
LEAD: The Senate approved a $14 billion plan to reduce the deficit tonight, stripping from it hundreds of extraneous measures including child care assistance and Medicare changes, and putting off a battle over cutting the capital gains tax.


Eckersley Not an Issue
LEAD: Bobby Brown, the president of the American League, said today that the Dennis Eckersley emery-board issue is not an issue with him.


Patents; A Cube Game More Difficult Than Rubik's
LEAD: For people who think Rubik's Cube is too easy to solve, two graduate students patented a new cube puzzle this week that makes the original seem as simple as a picture puzzle.

Bridge
LEAD: An opening no-trump bid with a hand containing a singleton is frowned on by theory and avoided in practice by all but a few eccentrics.
But an overcall of one no-trump is another matter, as on the diagramed deal reported by David Berah from a rubber bridge game at the Cavendish Club.


Chinese Vice Premier Meets Gandhi and Sees Warm Ties
LEAD: The highest-ranking Chinese leader to visit India in nearly 30 years met with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today and declared that a new era of friendship had begun between the two Asian giants.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Arby's 42 largest franchisees formed a group, A. P. Association Inc., to oppose the continued control of the roast-beef sandwich chain by Victor Posner, chairman of DWG Corp., which controls Arby's.


Wall St. Cites Sound Fundamentals
LEAD: Although Wall Street was stunned by the selling wave that swept the stock market in the last hour of trading yesterday, it was not devastated.
Some market participants attributed the 190-point, or 6.9 percent, plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average to overspeculation.


Recital in Brooklyn On a Mighty Wurlitzer
LEAD: Two years after extensive water damage silenced its pipes, a vintage Wurlitzer organ that was a permanent fixture at the Brooklyn Paramount Theater can be heard again this weekend.

LEAD: Richard J. Koehler, the Correction Commissioner of New York City, announced yesterday that he is retiring as commissioner effective Dec. 22.
Mayor Edward I. Koch praised Commissioner Koehler, who began as a police foot patrolman in 1967 for changing the Department of Correction ''all for the better in a quantum way.


Herbert M. Weed, 68, Anaconda Executive
LEAD: Herbert M. Weed, a former vice president of the Anaconda Company, a leading producer of nonferrous metals and uranium, died of a heart attack Tuesday at St.
Joseph's Hospital in Denver.
He was 68 years old and lived in Cherry Hills Village, a Denver suburb.


Pretoria Is Said to Transfer Prisoners
LEAD: The Government was reported today to have moved Walter Sisulu and some other political prisoners to jails near their homes amid speculation that they would be released this weekend.


New York's New School Chief Visits City and Faults System
LEAD: Joseph A. Fernandez visited New York yesterday to start setting up shop as the new schools chancellor, and he immediately offered some blunt challenges to the city's way of running its schools.


Centrust Payouts
LEAD: Centrust Bank of Miami said yesterday that it had been ordered to stop paying dividends on its preferred stock because of financial problems including losses in its holdings of ''junk bonds.'' The order to stop paying dividends came from Federal regulators at the Office of Thrift Supervision.
Federal and state regulators are considering a proposal by Centrust to sell 63 of its branches for $150 million to the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.


The Voronezh Visitors
LEAD: Tass, the Soviet press agency, has reported the landing of an extraterrestrial vehicle in the Russian city of Voronezh.
The creatures who emerged were nine feet tall, with little knobby heads and three eyes.
They had a small robot in tow and went for a ''short promenade about the park,'' Tass reports.


Toronto Journal; Will They Always Get Their Man, Hats or No?
LEAD: Along with the moose and the maple leaf, the scarlet-jacketed Mountie in his light-brown ranger hat has been a Canadian totem.
Now, guardians of the country's traditions are being asked to accept a new image within the force that tamed the Canadian west: the Mountie in a turban.

LEAD: Hyman Solniker, a retired New York City Criminal Court judge, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The public has been well informed, by now, that this World Series between the San Francisco Giants and Oakland Athletics, which begins tonight in Oakland, is the first confined to a single metropolitan area since 1956, when the New York Yankees faced the Brooklyn Dodgers.
But what about the first one?

LEAD: Gerard Gallant of the Detroit Red Wings has been suspended for five games by the National Hockey League for deliberately attempting to injure Garth Butcher, a defenseman for Vancouver, while going out of his way to retaliate in a game last Saturday.
The Red Wings said they would not appeal.(AP)

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about an increase in the Japanese discount rate misidentified the person who said that while the strength of the dollar was a factor in the increase, other factors were equally important.
He was Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, not Susumo Saito of the Credit Suisse Investment Advisory Company.

Plain or Fancy, The Greeks Said It With Metal
LEAD: Greek metalwork - known more through adaptations made by Romans in antiquity and Europeans in the 18th and 19th centuries than through the originals - is far more remarkable in its vigor than are later manifestations.
This can be seen in an exhibition of 38 ancient Greek artifacts, vessels and items of jewelry produced over a period of 600 years, and a companion display of 10 neoclassical urns, candelabra and vases of the 18th and 19th centuries, exhibited at the Michael Ward Gallery, 9 East 93d Street.

Why Gorbachev Doesn't Care to Strike Back
LEAD: ACCORDING to the stereotypes Westerners hold dear, Mikhail S. Gorbachev should now be apoplectic over the hemorrhage of Communist power in Europe.
Poland falls into the clutches of Solidarity.
The Hungarian Communist Party shuns the word Communist, then fractures and quarrels over who gets to keep the bank account.

LEAD: As an attorney in Garden City whose firm has 14 years of bankruptcy experience, I read, with great interest, the article on Sept. 10 on the rise of personal bankruptcy filings on Long Island.

HE DIDN'T LIKE IKE
LEAD: Yes, Truman was a ''take charge'' President.

GARY CASTEEL  Knoxville, Tenn.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles.
Last year, we hired a professional to repaint.
He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint.
Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun.

Correction
LEAD: An illustration on Sept. 24 in The Business World, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about German and Japanese investment in the United States, showed the West German flag upside down.
The top stripe should be black, the middle stripe red and the bottom stripe gold.

From Apples and Pears, Elegant Autumn Desserts
LEAD: NOW is the time of year for the widest choice and highest quality of apples and pears.
The best apples for cooking are those that are not too sweet but that are firm and juicy, with plenty of flavor.
Use hard, crisp McIntosh, semi-sweet Cortlands or tart greening apples.
Bartlett and Bosc pears are both good for cooking and their elegant shape always makes an attractive dessert.

The New Bed and Breakfast
LEAD: FOR just about as long as they have been around, bed and breakfast inns have been synonymous with modesty in lodging.
For a small sum of, say, $25 to $50 a night, even in the early 80's a couple could get the basics: a firm bed, perhaps a shared bath, a hearty meal the next morning and the company of an innkeeper who lived on the premises.

Fischer-Dieskau Recitals
LEAD: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau will give two recitals at Carnegie Hall early next month, one devoted to Schubert and the other to Richard Strauss.
The German baritone's first program, on Nov. 3, will offer poems of Goethe set to music by Schubert; the Strauss recital will take place Nov. 5.
Hartmut Holl will be the accompanist.

LEAD: For This Week: Christmas cactus, jade plant and any other house plants that are lingering outdoors should be moved in, pronto; frost can be expected any time now and these plants could be ruined.

Yet this multiethnic district, about three-fifths the size of Connecticut, is one of the most interesting of the country's 21 regions.
