LEAD: To the Editor:


From Apples and Pears, Elegant Autumn Desserts
LEAD: NOW is the time of year for the widest choice and highest quality of apples and pears.
The best apples for cooking are those that are not too sweet but that are firm and juicy, with plenty of flavor.
Use hard, crisp McIntosh, semi-sweet Cortlands or tart greening apples.
Bartlett and Bosc pears are both good for cooking and their elegant shape always makes an attractive dessert.

Remembering the Relocation Camps
LEAD: MANY Americans have only recently begun to learn the full story of Japanese-American internment by the United States Government during World War II.
Scattered in the county are Japanese-American residents who were among the 110,000 people - the majority American citizens - forced from their West Coast homes into makeshift barracks and confined behind barbed wire for periods up to three years.

LEAD: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles.
Last year, we hired a professional to repaint.
He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint.
Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun.

Woody Allen Counts the Wages of Sin
LEAD: Movies frequently raise questions about the moral structure of the universe, but rarely do they talk about it.
Woody Allen has chosen to talk about it in ''Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' which opened Friday.
Whether God exists, whether reality is pitiless, and religious belief merely wishful thinking, whether justice and love can prevail over might or even over daily routine - these are questions explicitly discussed and assumed to bear on at least one life-or-death decision.

LEAD: As the starting pitchers in last night's World Series opener, Dave Stewart of the Athletics and Scott Garrelts of the Giants were up on a platform Friday answering questions behind a microphone in the Oakland Coliseum interview area.

Stock Traders Expect a Revised UAL Bid With Less Cash
LEAD: Stock traders said yesterday that they expected a revised buyout bid for the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, to be assembled quickly.
But they predicted that the buyout group, which includes the company's pilots union and management, might reduce the value of the bid by substituting securities for part of the cash.

Bones Back Beastly Tale Of Old West
LEAD: A jury of 13 experts who dug up the common grave of five Colorado gold prospectors to find out who killed and ate them has agreed with the verdict handed down more than 100 years ago: Alferd Packer murdered his colleagues while they were marooned in the Rocky Mountains in the vicious winter of 1874.

Child's Play in Paris
LEAD: WITH the birth of our son, Nicky, we said goodbye to our yearly trips to France.
There would be no more lingering over cups of cafe noir, no more walking along the Seine at 4 A.M., holding hands.
Under the heading of what our travel agent calls family vacations, Martin, Nicky and I have danced the Bunny Hop with Roger Rabbit, wrenched our backs on Tilt-a-Whirls, fed smelts to Shamu and been photographed in sepia tones dressed up like Belle Starr and the James gang.

LEAD: The American public as a whole views New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles as the best large cities in the country, but frequent visitors are most enthusiastic about Seattle, Boston and San Diego in addition to San Francisco and New York, according to a Gallup Poll.

Maori Tales Told in Wood In Rotorua, New Zealand
LEAD: FOR the Maori (rhymes with ''dowry'') people of New Zealand, woodcarving is the highest form of art, embodying spiritual concepts that can only be brought to it by craftsmen who have been specially trained: tohunga (skilled man-priest-teacher) whakairo (carver).

Budget Tells Where Priorities Lie
LEAD: IN the next 60 days, Suffolk County will adopt a budget for 1990.
An annual budget is the most important statement of public policy that our elected officials develop as part of their public responsibilities.
It separates intentions and talk from action.
The budget consolidates both fiscal and social policies.

An Energy Glut in the Ground Imperils Ecological Hopes
LEAD: FOSSIL fuel reserves, almost always discussed with the modifier ''dwindling'' attached, are now growing rapidly.
The conventional wisdom of the 1970's was that the world was running out of oil, coal and natural gas.
But in the last three years governments and the companies that do the drilling and mining have found far more than has been extracted.

Her mother has become confused, and she fears being left alone in the house they share.

Six Rescued After Boat Sinks
LEAD: Six men whose fishing boat had sunk 40 hours earlier were rescued by a Coast Guard cutter about 50 miles northwest of Maui on Friday.
The men survived by clinging to a makeshift raft of buoys and nets from their boat, which had sailed from Honolulu on Oct. 3.
They suffered only bruises and dehydration, the Coast Guard said.


From Apples and Pears, Elegant Autumn Desserts
LEAD: NOW is the time of year for the widest choice and highest quality of apples and pears.
The best apples for cooking are those that are not too sweet but that are firm and juicy, with plenty of flavor.
Use hard, crisp McIntosh, semi-sweet Cortlands or tart greening apples.
Bartlett and Bosc pears are both good for cooking and their elegant shape always makes an attractive dessert.


Where the Money Isn't
LEAD: To the Editor:


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles.
Last year, we hired a professional to repaint.
He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint.
Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun.


MUSIC Carlos Kleiber: Genius Wrapped In an Enigma
LEAD: Carlos Kleiber: Enigma, maverick or genius?
Opinions about the most mercurial conductor of his generation range widely: He is unpredictable, unwilling to commit himself to future projects and reticent in dealing with the world at large.
Many artists say they hardly ever give interviews; Mr.
Kleiber has never been known to give one.


Nuclear Test Treaties, Ready to Ratify
LEAD: U.S.-Soviet differences over verification have long stalled ratification of two treaties to limit the size of underground nuclear explosions.
But Moscow proposed a reasonable compromise, leaving each side free to use its own preferred method of monitoring and allowing more on-site visits.
President Bush's acceptance of the offer has broken the deadlock.

WHO MADE IT
LEAD: This has been the decade for home design.
Decorating became a hot topic, and so did those who do it.
Interior designers became celebrities in their own right: Appearing on television and in gossip columns, their faces were often as recognizable as their work.
On these pages are 15 of those who made it in the 80's.


'I Think We're Middle of the Road'
LEAD: GARY M. YOUNG'S portrait of the state of the arts in Connecticut would excite even the most jaded listener.
Last year alone, said Mr.
Young, the executive director of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, the nonprofit arts industry generated $354 million.
In addition, the arts employed 12,300 people and attracted an audience of more than 8.5 million people.


October Turns Ugly Once More
LEAD: Stocks had a dizzying plunge on Friday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping a scary 190.58 points and reviving painful memories of the 1987 stock crash that produced a 508-point plunge on Oct. 19.
Friday's heavy selling wiped out all the gains from an early October rally that, just last Monday, had taken the Dow to a new high of 2,791.41.


Deciding How to Cash In an Annuity
LEAD: For at least a decade, deferred annuities have been popular with investors.
Under these contracts, money you pay to an insurance company builds up, free of current income taxes.
The taxes are deferred until you reclaim your cash.

HOME ENTERTAINMENT: RECENT RELEASES
LEAD:  CLASSICAL  Bach: Lute Suites (BWV 995-97, 1006a)  Sharon Isbin, guitar.
Virgin Classics VC 7 90717-2; CD and cassette.
Sharon Isbin collaborated with the harpsichordist Rosalyn Tureck on the new editions of the four suites heard here, and she plays the music with authority.
Immediately striking are the clarity of her articulation and voicing, and her dramatic, high-contrast approach to dynamics and coloration.

LEAD: WHEN the surf is up on Sydney's beaches in the southern summer, paddling a surfboard into the lineup to catch a wave can bring on an inferiority complex of asphyxiating proportions.

LEAD: THE impending adoption of two black boys with AIDS by a gay white male couple has prompted a debate in New Jersey that turns on issues of race, morality and a growing interest among homosexuals to be parents.


FICTION
LEAD: FREQUENT FLYER.
By Kinky Friedman. (Morrow, $16.95.) Perhaps because a marketing gimmick can be one of the keys to success in writing a series of mysteries, Kinky Friedman is at once the author and the protagonist of his detective novels.
In ''Frequent Flyer,'' his fourth whodunit, Mr.
Friedman's hero, Kinky, a rock musician turned occasional snooper and constant smart mouth, is once again a sort of urban Indiana Jones, operating out of a lower Manhattan loft where he lives in a perpetual haze of cigar smoke with his cat.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''If we need to import this many people then we should make the decision to let them in the front door instead of through the back door in the middle of the night.
What we can't do is say we want a border that's closed to drugs but that is open to people.''
- William T. Veal, deputy
chief of the Border
Patrol's San Diego sector.


High Spirits at the Summit
LEAD: TO celebrate my birthday, some of my family gathered for the weekend at my son's country house in Vermont.
It was a special birthday because it marked the gateway to what we call the golden years.
From now on I can claim discounts on trains and buses and in certain stores.
I am also eligible for a Medicare card with its reassurance of health care.

Martinu Can Now Be More Than a Name
LEAD: The name of the Czechoslovak composer Bohuslav Martinu is well known, but probably relatively few American listeners can claim any real familiarity with his highly individualisticmusic, even though he lived in the United States for a dozen years (1941-53) and composed five of his six symphonies for American orchestras.

LEAD: The business establishment in New York City and liberal and black Democrats outside the city have replaced unions and New York City blacks as the main sources of money for David N. Dinkins's campaign for mayor.

LEAD: In this poor rural town near the Rhode Island border, officials say they have found a solution to their financial woes that would also help clean up much of the Northeast: a power plant that burns 10 million discarded tires a year.

LEAD: In an effort to support the Pentagon's program to develop a new chemical bomb, President Bush has decided to retain the option to produce chemical weapons after a treaty to phase out such arms takes effect, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: IF New York City voters adopt the proposed Charter revision next month, they will be embracing a land-use regulation system that distributes oversight of the processes of urban change broadly.


CLICHES OF THE 80'S
LEAD: Years from now, purveyors of style will easily be able to date rooms decorated in the 1980's.
Indeed, in every decade, certain design trends become not simply signatures of their time but veritable cliches.
The ubiquitous English country style, for example, ushered in an overabundance of clutter and chintz, while the post-modern interior brought back neo-classical columns and busts.


Vicenza
LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed your excellent and informative article on Palladio in the Veneto (''A Palladian Journey in Vicenza,'' Travel, Aug. 13).
Your readers might want to pack along Caroline Constant's ''Palladio Guide,'' which covers all of his built works.
This compact book is an ideal traveling companion for Palladio buffs, and includes maps as well as architectural drawings.

LEAD: Mr.
Freedman left a misimpression that the Board of Examiners did not offer an examination for high school social studies instructors for nearly five years.

East Germany Tries to Keep Soul-Searching in the Party
LEAD: AFTER swirling through the Soviet Union, Poland and Hungary, the Gorbachevian winds of change have turned to huffing and puffing at the formidable bastion of East Germany.
They haven't blown the house down, to be sure, but after a remarkable month of mass flight and mass protest, the Communist leadership is feeling the heat.


Police Recruit Kills Himself
LEAD: A young recruit who worked three years to qualify for the Milwaukee police force shot himself to death at a firing range after failing his final chance at a marksmanship test.
The recruit, Daniel Morales, 21 years old, was firing at the third and final target at the Police Training Academy when he turned his .357 revolver to his head and shot himself, a police spokesman said.

LEAD: AS the political crisis enveloping Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi deepened last week, with newspapers reporting that efforts to cover up kickbacks from a Swedish arms deal reached higher and higher in his administration, there was one place that the hottest topic in this parliamentary democracy was barely discussed at all.


'Smoke on Mountain,' Gospel Musical
LEAD: IF you haven't been hankering after a bluegrass, Bible Belt gospel sort of musical, circa 1938, ''Smoke on the Mountain'' at the McCarter Theater, through next Sunday, isn't likely to challenge your predispositions.


CBS Trims 30 Minutes From 'Pat Sajak Show'
LEAD: CBS announced on Friday that ''The Pat Sajak Show'' would be shortened to one hour beginning on Oct. 30.
The 90-minute program, which was introduced nine months ago to compete with NBC's ''Tonight'' show with Johnny Carson, is currently broadcast weeknights from 11:30 P.M. to 1 A.M.
In its new format, it will end at 12:30 A.M.


Helsinki's Russian Flavors
LEAD: MOST major cities are dotted with restaurants where the locals go when they want something ethnic.
London has its Indian restaurants, Tokyo its Italian spaghetti parlors, and in Paris, Vietnamese food gives the extra kick to the French palate.
In Helsinki, Russian restaurants provide exotic cuisine for natives when they're looking for a change from the tame and often prosaic

LEAD: There is no happier sound to the merchant's ear than that of a constantly ringing cash register.


Review/Music; Baroque Bill By 4 Nations Ensemble
LEAD: The Four Nations Ensemble, an early-instruments band directed by the harpsichordist Andrew Appel, describes the boundaries of its repertory as late Renaissance and Viennese Classics.
For its Wednesday-evening program at Weill Recital Hall, the group tightened its focus slightly on the middle ground, offering Baroque works from Germany, Italy, England and France.


Review/Theater; 'Midsummer Night's Dream'
LEAD: There is, of course, no such thing as a foolproof play, but ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' comes about as close as anything written in the last 400 years.
Shakespeare's confection of farce and fantasy can survive virtually any conceit or time warp visited on it and provide a measure of mirth in at least one of the three plots.


Milford Does Battle With Drugs
LEAD: FED UP with drug abuse and the crimes associated with it, DeForest Smith, a Milford real estate broker, has declared ''all-out war'' against drugs in his city.
He has enlisted the aid of the police department, the schools and the business community, and his efforts have led to a drug-tip hot line that will offer callers cash rewards.

HEARTS AND WRITERS
LEAD: I can't tell you how many times my heart has been jolted by a beautifully written sentence or my life has been affected by the magic of words.
Surely, there must be a reason why doctors such as Anton Chekhov and William Carlos Williams were writers, too.
Clearly, they realized the power of medicine to shock life back into a stopped heart and the power of language to make that same heart stop, for a few seconds, to feel the power of the written word.

Architecture Eases Into the 90's
LEAD: THE MOST IMPORTANT legacy of the 1980's in architecture may not be a design at all, but a book.

Rather, it summed up a whole set of impulses, and gave coherence to a time.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. When we bought our 45-year-old house, it had been freshly painted, but a disk sander had been used on many places, leaving deep swirls on the wood shingles.
Last year, we hired a professional to repaint.
He sanded and applied one coat of oil-based primer, followed by two coats of oil paint.
Now a brown stain is seeping through the paint, especially in areas in direct sun.


From Apples and Pears, Elegant Autumn Desserts
LEAD: NOW is the time of year for the widest choice and highest quality of apples and pears.
The best apples for cooking are those that are not too sweet but that are firm and juicy, with plenty of flavor.
Use hard, crisp McIntosh, semi-sweet Cortlands or tart greening apples.
Bartlett and Bosc pears are both good for cooking and their elegant shape always makes an attractive dessert.

LEAD: Abortion is not the stormy issue in France it is in the United States, which is one reason Claude Chabrol, the French director, has been able to make a movie that deals with it not as a moral dilemma, but as a fact of life.
In ''Story of Women,'' abortion is unpleasant, troublesome, even physically dangerous, but for some women it sometimes is the only choice available.

Repairing Fluorescent Lights
LEAD: FLUORESCENT lights are thrifty.

LESSONS FROM THE 80'S
LEAD: The 1980's have been an extraordinary time for home design.
Many trends have come and gone: The English country style swept the nation with cluttered rooms done in chintz and ribbons.
Post-modern buildings, boasting pediments and oversize columns, began cropping up in all major cities.
Deconstructivism, the hard-edged architectural movement that originated in California, was later immortalized in an exhibition at The Museum of Modern Art in New York City.

Review/Piano; Russian and French Works By Donna Amato, in Debut
LEAD: For the program of her New York debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening, Donna Amato chose Russian and French piano works that revel in chromaticism.
But her approach was often so heavy - either because she prefers a forceful touch or because she misjudged the volume of sound it takes to fill the intimate hall - that the opportunities the music affords for subtle coloristic interplay were often squandered.

And Wendell Young, the Pittsburgh goalie, was unable to stop the puck.

Help for the Parents Of Soccer Aspirants
LEAD: By all reckonings, soccer is a youth-participation giant.
In 1988, the Sports Industry Council of America says, 7.1 million children 12 years old or under played soccer, ranking it second in popularity to basketball, which it trailed by a mere 500,000 children.


Marcos Is Buried 5,000 Miles Away From Home
LEAD: Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former President of the Philippines who was ousted in 1986 and lived here in exile until his death on Sept. 28, was buried today in a flower-covered shed more than 5,000 miles from his homeland.

Oilers Rally To Beat Bears
LEAD: Lorenzo White's 12-yard touchdown run with 1 minute 46 seconds left, after Allen Pinkett had run for 60 yards, lifted the Houston Oilers to a 33-28 victory over the Chicago Bears today.

Professionals Watching the 'Junk Bond' Market
LEAD: Professional investors say they will be watching the ''junk bond'' market closely this morning.
If this $200 billion market of high-yield, high-risk securities continues to suffer sharp selloffs with poor trading liquidity, the stock market is likely to decline further, traders say.

Entire Town in Ohio Is Evacuated in Gas Leak
LEAD: All 6,500 residents of this city were evacuated late Saturday night when a frozen-pizza plant leaked deadly ammonia gas.
The authorities allowed them to return to their homes early today, but people with breathing problems were told to wait.


Abortion Debate Clouds Research on Fetal Tissue
LEAD: Over the objections of two Federal panels that say experiments with fetal tissue hold promise for treating diabetes and Parkinson's disease, the Bush Administration is planning to extend a 19-month-old ban on financing such research.


Council Leader Prepares to Take On No. 2 Role in Ruling New York City
LEAD: Peter F. Vallone is getting ready to become the second most powerful official in the government of New York City.


Classical Stations Do Their Best To Survive
LEAD: Only 41 of nearly 9,000 commercial radio stations in the United States play classical music, and when one of them - KFAC-FM in Los Angeles -was recently sold for $55 million, analysts of the radio industry predicted there would be one less.
Most classical music stations are profitable, they said, but not profitable enough for takeover artists.


Review/Opera; Domingo in Met 'Trittico'
LEAD: There were two major cast changes in the Metropolitan Opera's current run of ''Il Trittico,'' along with a number of minor ones.
Placido Domingo sang Luigi in the first of these three one-act operas, ''Il Tabarro,'' and Juan Pons played the title role in the last, ''Gianni Schicchi.''

LEAD: A Brooklyn teen-age girl whose friendships with black and Hispanic men apparently led to the racially motivated killing of a black youth in the Bensonhurst section has said that death threats have prompted her to go into hiding with a round-the-clock police guard.

Review/Music; Brooklyn Hears Factory Sounds From Germany
LEAD: Pohl Musik brought a remarkable instrument to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night.
The Klangmaschine, invented for the group by Christof Schlager, looks like two ventilator tubes and a large electric fan hooked up to a podium-like control panel; its metallic innards produce enough buzzes, rasps, huffs, clanks, scrapes and siren noises to stand in for a factory.

Intel Reports Profit Drop
LEAD: The Intel Corporation, a semiconductor maker, said Friday that its third-quarter profit fell to about half of the amount of a year ago, depressed by a one-time charge related to the end of a joint venture.

LEAD: With the opening of the 20th Sao Paulo Bienal on Saturday, doors have opened that have previously been closed.
Martin Puryear is the first black artist to represent the United States at a major international art exhibition.
His nine abstract sculptures here form one of the handsomest installations in a show in which the United States shares the spotlight with Latin America and Europe.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Untenable is a dirtier word than slaughtered.
Slaughtered means you have more innings left to play.
Untenable means the game is over.''  -William Silver, a trader on the American Stock Exchange.  [ A1:4. ]


Airman Linked to Soviet Spies
LEAD: The American military authorities in West Berlin said they questioned a United States airman today after he was seen with two Soviet military officers who were trying to obtain military secrets from him.
American officials in West Berlin said the two Soviet officers, both majors, were detained and questioned on Saturday night before being handed over to Soviet officials in East Berlin.


Vitro to Buy Anchor for $820 Million
LEAD: Vitro S.A. and the Anchor Glass Container Corporation announced yesterday that they had signed an agreement for Vitro to acquire Anchor in a deal valued at about $820 million.
The agreement ends a bitter two-month struggle by Anchor to remain independent.

2 Killed in Jet Fighter Crash
LEAD: A military jet on a training mission crashed today at Carswell Air Force Base here, killing the two people on board, a base spokesman said.
The F-16 fighter had flown from Dallas Naval Air Station to Carswell, said the spokesman, First Lieut.
Stephen Norton.
He said there was ammunition aboard but did not elaborate.

Alar Scare Unfounded, Apple Growers Say
LEAD: Fears that New York's 1989 apple crop would take a rotten turn without the help of Alar, a growth-promoting chemical, were largely unfounded, growers and agricultural officials say.

LEAD: The Sogo Company, a Japanese department store concern, is considering acquiring the New York-based retail chain Saks Fifth Avenue, a Sogo spokesman said last week.


U.S. Is Urged to Rejoin Unesco if It Adopts Changes
LEAD: A panel of distinguished Americans has recommended that the United States rejoin the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization if that body adopts changes it is now considering.
The changes were proposed by its new Director General but are being resisted by third-world countries.

J.
Kirk Fitzhugh, a biologist, took place yesterday in New York at the Top of the Tower lounge in the Beekman Tower hotel.

Rights and Wrongs of Blaming Japan
LEAD: Frustration with Japan in the United States and resentment of America in Japan are near the flash point.
Many Americans are upset about recent shifts in the global balance of economic power, shifts that seem to threaten American jobs and international influence.
Yet to put all the blame on Japanese behavior is to deflect attention from important domestic causes.

In the Mud, on Imported Sod, Golf Is Introduced to Moscow
LEAD: They came from another world, pioneers armed with silvery sticks, and on a greensward at the foot of the Lenin Hills today they performed a ritual as alien as the pointy-headed spacelings reportedly sighted last week in the Russian provinces.
They played golf.
On nine fairways snuggled ingeniously amid the high-rise tenements and hastily carpeted with squares of imported sod, they introduced the sport of Scottish kings, American presidents and country-club capitalists.

LEAD: Giant Group, the masonry company controlled by the investor Burt Sugarman, ended negotiations to buy Aspen Airways Inc., a regional airline based in Denver.

The Tools a Writer Used for Building An Industrial Novel
LEAD: In his novel ''Sybil,'' Benjamin Disraeli wrote of a Britain that consisted of two nations ''as ignorant of each other's habits, thoughts and feelings as if they were inhabitants of different planets.'' He had in mind the rich and the poor of the Victorian era; but he might have been talking prophetically about the subtler splits of the 1980's.


As a Student of Hitting, Will Clark Is Phi Betamax Kappa
LEAD: BEFORE the recent National League playoff games, Will Clark studied videotapes of himself batting against the Cubs' pitchers.
Throughout the season, he had checked tapes of every other opposing team's pitchers.
Before the World Series opener Saturday night, the Giants' first baseman watched tapes that his parents and relatives in New Orleans had taken of him swinging against Dave Stewart of the Athletics during a two-game spring-training stop there earlier this year.

Abortion Rebuff Chips At a Governor's Image
LEAD: In the early 1980's, when Gov.
Bob Martinez of Florida was still Mayor Martinez of Tampa, he was regarded as a man of action, the kind of public official who climbed on the tailgate of a city truck to tell striking sanitation workers to return to their jobs or lose them.

LEAD: At the Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J., Pamela R. Esterman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Philip Esterman of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday to Joel G. Burris, a son of Mrs.
Bernard Abrams of South Orange, N.J., and H. Barry Burris of Fort Lee, N.J.
Rabbi Harvey S. Goldman officiated.

Connecticut Campus Reports Bias Incidents
LEAD: Seven incidents of harassment aimed at Jews, Asians, blacks and homosexuals at the University of Connecticut have been reported to campus police since school began 40 days ago, school officials say.
University police and administrators say the number of reports represents an increase over past years.

LEAD: Hours after eight of South Africa's most prominent political prisoners returned home from years in confinement, seven of them called today for the release of Nelson Mandela and said they would continue to work for the banned African National Congress.

Question Box
LEAD:  A Series a Decade  Q, Counting a sports decade as the 10-year span from the zero year to the ninth one, like 1930-39, which major league teams have appeared in the World Series in each decade of the 20th century?
A.
None, because no team has won a pennant in each such decade.
In fact no team has managed to get into the World Series in more than seven of the nine decades since Series play began in 1903.

U.S. Debates Israel Buying I.B.M. Military Computer
LEAD: The United States Government is considering a proposal by the International Business Machines Corporation to sell a powerful computer to Israel for military use, several people in the Administration say.
The sale would be the first of its kind to a country other than a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

LEAD: When some freelance musicians formed Orpheus in 1972, their central belief was that they could perform the chamber-orchestra literature without a conductor.
In 17th- and 18th-century works, and in some light Romantic scores, that can be easy enough, provided the players keep an eye on the concertmaster (and the concertmaster is good with cues).

Tonight at 8, 10 and 12 on cable's TNT (Turner Network Television), the made-for-television movie is ''Cold Sassy Tree.'' The chance juxtaposition illustrates dramatically why the networks, chasing questionable formats, may continue to lose audiences to cable.

Kennedy assumed the mantle of orphan and took the responsibility for the disaster.

Bats Found to Adjust Their Squeaks for Motion
LEAD: IT has long been known that bats find their prey by listening for echoes from their high frequency squeaks.
Now scientists have found that bats alter the frequency of the squeaks they emit so that the echoes return at the frequency to which the bats are most sensitive.

Soviets Give Kin Wallenberg Papers
LEAD: More than 45 years after Raoul Wallenberg disappeared into the Soviet prison system after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, the Soviet authorities gave his family some of his personal belongings: a blue Swedish diplomatic passport embossed with the royal crown, some money and several notebooks.

Closing by Pauley
LEAD: Pauley Petroleum Inc. said it intends to close its Newhall Refining Company refinery at the end of the year, offer the site for sale and lay off about 70 people.
The company said the refinery, in Santa Clarita, Calif., had suffered significant losses in recent years and that the market for its products, including asphalt, fuel oil and jet fuel, was expected to remain weak.

LEAD: The prosecutor in the Iran-contra investigation today accused Attorney General Dick Thornburgh of deliberately sidetracking ''with no legitimate reason'' the criminal case against a former Central Intelligence Agency official.

LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today opened a special inspection of the Comanche Peak nuclear power plant in Texas amid charges that some high-ranking commission officials had covered up problems at the $9 billion plant.

Fighting Fire With Money
LEAD: Two years ago the stock market crashed.
Hysterical analysts warned of economic turmoil reminiscent of the 1930's.
But no such catastrophe occurred, due in large part to timely intervention by the Federal Reserve Board.
Sensibly, the Fed is prepared to step in once more to protect the larger economy of Main Street from the latest debacle on Wall Street.

Critic's Notebook; Was She or Wasn't She? A Diary Of Hemingway's (Probable) Muse.
LEAD: Tracking down details about the real person behind a fictional character is a tantalizing game.
When disguising an actual person, a novelist has to make personality adjustments for the sake of the story.
If the writing is going well, the author stands aside, and with a growing sense of wonder watches as the characters take over, speak for themselves and assume lives of their own.

LEAD: Danilo Kis, a Yugoslav-born writer and essayist whose works blended fact and fiction to describe the horror of the Holocaust and Stalin's forced-labor camps, died of cancer on Sunday, friends said today.
He was 54 years old and had lived in Paris 10 years.

LEAD: You would think a bow would solve everything.
After all, this pretty, perky toss-and-tie of fabric is supposed to be synonymous with femininity.
That is why ties have been used for ages to decorate every possible piece of fashion - accessories, suits, blouses, sweaters, dresses, ball gowns - not to mention the unmentionables underneath.

Kisio Rests, But Not Easily
LEAD: There were games last season, Kelly Kisio realizes now, that he should never have played in.
With one hand cracked in places and his back crying in pain, Kisio pulled on his uniform anyway because he feared he would never be able to shed the guilt if he didn't.

Yeltsin Makes the News Again, but Ruefully
LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick Moscow politician who recently toured the United States, told the police late last month that he had been the victim of an assassination attempt, but later recanted his story, according to a bizarre report today by the Soviet Interior Minister.


Copper Prices Fall Sharply; Grains and Soybeans Rally
LEAD: Copper futures fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, while precious metals gained and grains and soybeans rallied, and energy futures sagged.


Kremlin Leader Lashes at Press, Raising Its Fears
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has sharply rebuked some of the leading practitioners of glasnost, and accused the liberated press of sowing division and discontent.


Carmen Cavallaro, Pianist, 76
LEAD: Carmen Cavallaro, a pianist who performed the sound track for the movie ''The Eddy Duchin Story'' in 1956, died of cancer on Thursday at Mount Carmel East Hospital here.
He was 76 years old and had lived in Columbus for 15 years.

Topics of The Times; Disconnected Thoughts
LEAD: While a Federal Communications Commission study confirms that Americans are spending more and more time on the telephone, a telephone workers' strike has put thousands in the Northeast on hold.
Unable to get installations and repairs, they tell horror stories about business deals lost, love affairs ruined and hours spent weighted down with quarters, in search of a working pay phone.

Market Place; Balancing Stocks With the Futures
LEAD: IF one tag on an item says the price is $2 and another says $1.80, it is hard to know what the real price is.
But few buyers are willing to pay $2, no matter how much they think it is really worth.

I.B.M. Profits, at Low End Of Expectations, Drop 29.7%
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday reported a 29.7 percent decline in earnings for the third quarter of 1989.
The earnings were at the low end of the range that the company indicated it expected in its surprise announcement last month that profits would be sharply lower.


Neighbors in West Use Small Claims Court to Combat Drugs
LEAD: In a novel use of Small Claims Courts to fight drug dealers, residents of Berkeley and San Francisco have won substantial judgments against the owners of two buildings that became hubs of drug-related activity.


U.S. Energy Official Joining First Chicago
LEAD: Martha O. Hesse, chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission for the last three years, has accepted a top post at the First Chicago Corporation and is to be succeeded by Martin Lewis Allday, a Texas lawyer and longtime friend of President Bush.


Arbitrage Losses Put At Up to $100 Million
LEAD: Wall Street traders appear to have weathered the worst market slide in two years, although rough Wall Street estimates suggested yesterday that a handful of arbitrage firms might have lost as much as $100 million or more on two airline stocks.


Both Sides in Illinois Try to Settle Suit on Abortion Standards
LEAD: Barely seven weeks before the United States Supreme Court is to hear arguments on Illinois's abortion clinic regulations, the two sides in the lawsuit began direct negotiations here today aimed at settling the matter out of court.

LEAD: David D. Warren has been named president of the Jordache Jeans division of Jordache Enterprises Inc., filling a post that has been vacant since July.

LEAD:  Birds and Hurricanes  Q. What do birds do in a hurricane?
A.
A number of authorities agree that birds do not get any special storm warnings before a hurricane that allow them to avoid it.

LEAD: Hurricane Jerry was a relatively small, weak storm when it hit shore here Sunday night, and some people decided to take their chances out along the city's sea wall, where 80 mile-an-hour winds whipped the water.

LEAD: What little humor surrounded closing day at Belmont Park yesterday was of the sort heard among men on their way to the gallows.

20-Car Pileup Kills 5 at Lyons
LEAD: Five people were killed and 23 seriously injured early today when 20 cars plowed into a burning truck on a highway in southeastern France.


Motorola Unit Sale
LEAD: Motorola Inc. said it would sell its Tegal Corporation subsidiary to a management group led by Elliott Philofsy, Tegal's president.
Terms were not disclosed.
Tegal, based in Petaluma, Calif., supplies plasma etch and strip systems to the semiconductor industry.
Motorola said financing would be provided by Nazem &amp; Company, a New York investment company.


Gold Monkeys Learn How to Live in Wild In Brazilian Preserve
LEAD: IN a flash of orange fur, a golden lion tamarin suddenly appeared, hopping and swinging easily through the green forest foliage.
Nine others followed, browsing for fruit and insects, keeping balance with foot-long prehensile tails.


Notre Dame Is Atop Times List
LEAD: With a convincing 41-27 victory over Air Force at Falcon Stadium that stretched its winning streak to 18 games, Notre Dame finally reached No. 1 in The New York Times's computerized rating of the nation's top college football teams.

Bond's Companies Sell Mining Stakes
LEAD: Dallhold Investments, a private company owned by the Australian investor Alan Bond, said it was selling a 58 percent stake in Bond International Gold Inc., one of the largest miners of high-quality gold, to Lac Minerals for $333.3 million.


Pro Bono
LEAD: *
Ogilvy &amp; Mather has focused on elephant poaching, asking consumers not to buy ivory products, in a pro bono campaign for the World Wildlife Fund.
The print and television ads emphasize that at the current rate of slaughter, elephants will be extinct in 25 years.
The ads are being broadcast in 22 local markets.


Citibank's Progress On UAL Deal
LEAD: Domestic and international banks have told Citibank that they are willing to lend more money than needed to finance a $6.75 billion leveraged buyout of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, a top Citibank official said last night.

Elephant Is Declared Endangered Species
LEAD: In a move against poaching of African elephants for their ivory, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species added the species to their list.
Ivory hunters have drastically reduced the number of elephants that survive in the wild.

Guber-Peters Has Profit
LEAD: The Guber-Peters Entertainment Company said yesterday that its net income for the three months ended Aug. 31 was $5.8 million, or 50 cents a share, compared with a loss of $6.9 million a year earlier.
Revenue more than doubled, to $10.9 million, compared with $4.6 million a year earlier.
The current figures reflect an extraordinary gain of $2.1 million after taxes from the repurchase at a discount of a $9.9 million principal amount of the company's outstanding convertible debentures.


Pretoria May Be Looking to Freed Blacks for Aid
LEAD: In its treatment of the eight political prisoners released on Sunday, the white minority Government appears to be sending signals that it wants the cooperation of the freed men in promoting some form of negotiations with this country's black majority.


For Artists and Musicians, Creativity Can Mean Illness and Injury
LEAD: RECENT surveys of musicians and artists have revealed virtual epidemics of occupationally induced ills, from crippled hands that practiced too hard to outright poisoning and severe allergies provoked by the materials used to create artworks.

Campaign Trail; Dinkins, in High Hopes, Has Scout for City Hall
LEAD: Last week, David N. Dinkins went to Washington to meet the people he'll need to know if he is elected mayor of New York City.
Yesterday, he raised that ''if'' almost to ''when'' by naming the head of a team to lead his anticipated transition to City Hall.


Christmas Tree Outlook
LEAD: The Agriculture Department is predicting another record season for Christmas tree farmers, despite the preference of many Americans for artificial trees.
A record 34.3 million Christmas trees were sold in 1988, and an Agriculture Department report says the market is expected to exceed 35 million this year.


Quotron's Error on Dow Adds to Jitters
LEAD: Quotron Systems Inc., the nation's leading provider of electronic stock quotes, compounded market jitters among its clients yesterday when its computers incorrectly calculated the Dow Jones industrial average and transmitted that information to customers for at least a half-hour.


Taxes Short Of Forecast, Regan Says
LEAD: Revenues from New York State's major taxes were more than $200 million below projections for the first six months of the fiscal year, according to a report issued today.
The report renewed debate over whether the state can afford a scheduled $400 million tax cut next year.

Review/Television; 'Some Girls' and Teen-Age Pregnancy
LEAD: ''Intercom,'' the soberly inclined PBS series, introduces us tonight to a few of the adolescents who give West Virginia one of the nation's highest rates of unplanned teen-age pregnancy. ''Some Girls,'' at 11:30 P.M. on Channel 13, treats its five subjects as individuals rather than as data, helping us to understand why they are likely to have babies before they have husbands.

LEAD: In an effort to squeeze more waste into giant tanks at a nuclear weapons plant in Washington State, engineers in the 1950's added chemicals that created the risk of an explosion, according to a Government study completed five years ago but not made available until now.

ISI Systems Backs Memotec Deal
LEAD: ISI Systems Inc., a maker of computer software based here, said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by Memotec Data Inc. of Montreal.
The company said Memotec would start a $20-a-share tender offer for all ISI shares held by the public within five days.
The deal is conditioned on receipt of at least 15 percent of ISI's shares not held by the company's chairman and president, Charles C.

LEAD: The Mets completed the Frank Viola trade yesterday, sending Jack Savage, a minor league relief pitcher, to Minnesota.
Savage, 25 years old, was 3-2 with six saves for Class AAA Tidewater of the International League last season.(AP)

Change in Leadership Is Expected in Turkey
LEAD: Turkey seemed headed for new Government leadership today when Prime Minister Turgut Ozal announced that he would run for President in an election that starts in Parliament this week.


Liquor Barn Sold In $40 Million Deal
LEAD: Liquor Barn, which has been under Federal bankruptcy court protection for nearly a year, has been purchased for $40 million by an investor group.
The assets of Liquor Barn Northern California and Liquor Barn Southern California were purchased by LBI Holdings, which plans to operate the 68-outlet chain, the nation's largest liquor retail chain, under the same name with new management.


Democrat Wins a House Seat in Mississippi
LEAD: State Senator Gene Taylor, a Democrat, won an overwhelming victory over his Republican opponent, Tom Anderson, in a special Congressional election today, giving the Democrats all five House seats from the state for the first time in 17 years.

LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization has registered strong objections to the newest United States ideas on Middle East peace, leaving Washington's diplomacy bereft of evident support from either the Israeli Government or Palestinian leaders.

LEAD: People who care for children in day care centers are leaving their jobs in growing numbers and the turnover is hurting the children's development, according to a study released yesterday.

Officer Is Cleared in Shooting
LEAD: A grand jury concluded today that a white Vineland police officer acted properly when he shot and killed a black man whose death sparked two days of rioting and looting by blacks and Hispanics, prosecutors announced.


Broadbeach Sells Its Stake in McGill
LEAD: The private Los Angeles investment firm Broadbeach Associates Inc. has sold all but a small portion of its 7 percent stake in the McGill Manufacturing Company.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group gave no reason for the sale of the shares.
In August, Broadbeach had offered to acquire McGill for $62 a share, or $89.8 million.


Gerber Seeking Day-Care Buyer
LEAD: The Gerber Products Company said it would try to sell Gerber Children's Centers Inc., its child-care subsidiary that owns and operates 115 centers in 12 states.
The centers had revenues of more than $30 million for the year ended last March 31.

It's what fills you up and gives you a feeling of satiety.
So to switch from that you are taking a gamble.

63 Killed by Storms in China
LEAD: A series of three typhoons killed 63 people, and injured 712 in Hainan province in the South China Sea, the official New China News Agency said today.
Fifteen people were reported missing, the agency said.
The typhoons hit the island from Oct. 2 to 13, according to the agency.


Senate Votes, 64 to 35, to Send Money to the Opposition Parties in Nicaraguan
LEAD: In the last gasps of the debate over America's effort to overturn the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua, the Bush Adminstration won Senate approval tonight to send $9 million to assist opposition parties in the election next February and to support international observers.

McDonald's Offers McRib Sandwich
LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation is adding McRib, a pork rib sandwich, to its menu, hoping to sell 80 million in a monthlong trial run.
The sandwich will feature a four-ounce portion of pork from the front shoulder of the hog and should sell for about $1.79, said David Green, McDonald's vice president of marketing.

Review/Music; 'Pictures' by 4 Saxophones
LEAD: Mussorgsky's wonderful ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' are fated to be heard in all sorts of arrangements.
Vladimir Horowitz's embellishment of the keyboard original and Ravel's kaleidoscopic orchestration are the best known, but guitarists, organists and orchestrators reckless enough to invite comparison with Ravel and even rock bands have taken their shot at the work.

Bridge
LEAD:  Suit combinations have a chameleon-like quality: depending on circumstances, there can be half a dozen or more ways to play the same combination.
Beginners who learn just one procedure for a given holding are left with a long way to go on the road to expertise.

LEAD: Five court challenges to the Times Square redevelopment plan were thrown out yesterday, and state officials predicted that construction would begin by early next year.

Alaska to Restrict Tankers Without Approved Cleanup Plans
LEAD: The state of Alaska will bar oil tankers from the port of Valdez next month unless their owners equip them with oil spill cleanup plans approved by the state.

Control Data's New Computer

Editors' Note
LEAD: The Our Towns column yesterday reported on a strike by clerical workers at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I.
It focused on the concerns of clerical workers, almost all of them women, who contended that their salaries were unfairly set far below those of men in maintenance and other jobs comparable to theirs.

Housing Group Must Forfeit $700,000
LEAD: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today it had reversed itself and would order a partnership that includes President Ronald Reagan's former chief campaign lawyer to forfeit nearly $700,000, much of it to be repaid to the Government.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of a production error, some copies of Science Times yesterday omitted page C12, which included the continuation of an article about occupational illness among artists and musicians.
Readers wishing copies may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y.

LEAD: McClatchy Newspapers' net income increased 22.2 percent in its third quarter from the corresponding period last year.

LEAD: Urban community colleges have the potential to improve the quality of life substantially in cities and spread equality of opportunity among their residents, but they need more government money and greater coordination of effort, a new report says.

LEAD: L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that the Government should have moved three years sooner to take disciplinary action against the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.

LEAD: Now that the younger Tony Eason and Doug Flutie have failed their opportunities to hold the starting quarterback job with the faltering New England Patriots (2-4), it is the turn of Steve Grogan, a 36-year-old and 14-year-veteran, to take over and attempt to revive the team's dormant offense.
Grogan, who in the off season underwent surgery to remove a herniated disk from his neck, said: ''If I'm not producing, there are guys on the bench who can play.

LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Company, as expected, reported a loss today, as revenues in its third quarter declined from a year ago.

LEAD: A judge was killed in Medellin today in what an anonymous caller said was ''the first retaliation'' for the extradition of accused drug traffickers to the United States.

Assembly Plant For Subaru-Isuzu
LEAD: Subaru-Isuzu Automotive Inc., formed by two relatively small Japanese auto makers, has formally opened an auto assembly plant.
Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., which owns a 51 percent share of the operation, will produce its Subaru Legacy sedans and station wagons here, while Isuzu Motors Ltd., which owns 49 percent, will turn out pickup trucks and sports utility vehicles.


Anti-Incinerator Stand Brings a Blessing
LEAD: No election issue this year moves the Satmar Hasidic community of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn more than the incinerator the city proposes to put in the nearby Brooklyn Navy Yard.
That was why on Monday night in the middle of the Succoth holidays, David N. Dinkins -who has called for a moratorium on incinerators - found himself enveloped in the community's warm, almost crushing embrace.

And their shows aren't elaborate spectacles, but amiable, scrappy, slightly disheveled concerts that reaffirm the band's perseverance and moxie.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Flames 8, Nordiques 8: Calgary tied a National Hockey League record by scoring two goals, both short-handed, in four seconds and also had three goals in a 27-second span in the third period in Quebec to tie Nordiques.
With the Flames' Gary Roberts off for roughing in the final minute, Calgary (4-1-2) pulled its goaltender, Mike Vernon, and sent five attackers against the Nordiques.

Market Place; 'Witching Hour' Next Street Focus
LEAD: THE witches of Wall Street are gathering for a minor convention this Friday afternoon.
And while forecasting what will happen is perilous at best, the talk among traders is that when all is said and done, the witches will have pushed up prices in major stocks, at least for a period.


EARTHQUAKE IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA

Stevenson in Los Angeles; Allan R. Gold, Andrew Rosenthal and Philip Shenon in Washington; Sandra Blakeslee in Topanga, Calif., and James Barron, Constance L.


A Precedent-Setting Cabernet
LEAD: IN 1974, Stag's Leap Wine Cellars made its first Cask 23, a reserve cabernet sauvignon made only in the best years from outstanding fruit.
The wine became a Napa Valley benchmark because of its quality, and has long been a collector's item.
The 1985 Cask 23 was released Oct. 1, and its price apparently has acquired near-benchmark status.

Probert Gets 3 Months
LEAD: Bob Probert, the former Detroit Red Wing, was sentenced by District Judge Patrick Duggan today to three months in prison and fined $2,000 for smuggling cocaine into the United States from his native Canada.


Pretoria Eases Stand on Talks With Rebel Group
LEAD: The senior official entrusted with organizing multiracial negotiations on South Africa's future today softened the Government's longstanding refusal to talk to the outlawed African National Congress.


A Judicial Dispute Spills Into the Bellevue Murder Trial


Executive Search Finds A New Chief for Zemex
LEAD: The Zemex Corporation, a producer of industrial minerals, metal powders and tin, said yesterday that Gerard E. Wood had been named its new president and chief executive.


Bank Revamping
LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation said it would undertake a retructuring program that includes the sale of 53 branches and the consolidation of a number of departments.
The result will be the loss of 800 jobs throughout New England, the bank said.
The company said it also plans to close loan production offices in Chicago, New York and Philadelphia and to sell $250 million of subordinated debt.


South Korea Offers Plans To Ease U.S. Trade Surplus
LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea told President Bush today that his nation would take significant steps to curb its trade surplus with the United States by the mid-1990's.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: LAMB is the most popular meat in most of the Mediterranean region, including the Middle East and North Africa, so it is no surprise that some of the best lamb recipes come from those regions.
It is not always easy to identify a particular dish as being, say, of Moroccan origin as opposed to Tunisian.


Federal Express Drops Ads
LEAD: The Federal Express Corporation has canceled much of its prime-time advertising on the ABC television network, after a report by ABC News that was sharply critical of it.


Mr. Jaruzelski Smiles
LEAD: Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski, who resigned as Communist Party leader to become President of Poland, speaks enthusiastically now about the coalition entrusted with guiding his country through a profound transformation to freedom.

David Baltimore, the Nobel laureate whose selection as president of Rockefeller University was opposed by many senior faculty members, has accepted the position.

Adults Play Hard At Nongame Games
LEAD: ADULT Americans are spending their leisure time at home playing games at a pace not seen since the 1950's when television was just emerging as a home-entertainment force.
And the games they seem to enjoy playing most are those that play down the competitive element - nongame games, as one expert calls them.


Report Shows No Evidence Waldheim Mistreated British P.O.W.'s
LEAD: A narrowly focused British Defense Ministry report has found no evidence that Kurt Waldheim interrogated British prisoners of war or was responsible for the harsh treatment or execution of British commandos in Greece in 1943 and 1944, when he was an intelligence officer with the German Army.


Rise in Babies Hurt by Drugs Is Predicted
LEAD: If current drug abuse patterns continue, 5 percent of all newborn babies in New York City could require admission to intensive-care wards by 1995, state health officials say.


Profit Up 35.5% At Microsoft
LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday reported strong gains in revenues and earnings at a time when other software companies have reported losses or lower earnings.


Yields Offered by Banks For Deposits Fell in Week
LEAD: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions fell in the week ended yesterday.


Broncos Add Shanahan
LEAD: Mike Shanahan, who was dismissed as coach of the Los Angeles Raiders Oct. 3, has rejoined the Denver Broncos as the quarterbacks coach.
Coach Dan Reeves, who has been coaching the quarterbacks, said he didn't think he had enough time to devote to them anymore.
Before joining the Raiders in 1988, Shanahan was an assistant coach in Denver for four seasons, serving as offensive coordinator.


U.S. Economists Are Ready to Advise the Soviets
LEAD: American officials said today that they were prepared to advise the Soviet Union on how to revive its stagnant economy by decontrolling prices, cutting Government subsidies, encouraging private enterprise and permitting the exchange of rubles for gold and foreign currencies.


Bills' Defense and an Unheralded Passer Foil the Rams
LEAD: For five games, the Buffalo Bills' Blizzard Defense had the strength of a brief flurry.
But Monday night, in a stunning, come-from-behind victory, it froze the high-powered Rams and handed Los Angeles its first loss this season.

Judge and Officer Trade Insults at Murder Trial
LEAD: To the head of the New York court officer's union, Justice James J. Leff of State Supreme Court is a ''psycho'' who should be locked up.
To Justice Leff, the union head, Dennis W. Quirk, is a snoop who was ''aptly named.''


Walter Farley, 74, A Writer of a Series On a Black Stallion
LEAD: Walter Farley, whose 20 ''Black Stallion'' novels about the friendships between horses and children charmed young readers for nearly 50 years, died of heart failure yesterday at a hospital near his home in Venice, Fla.
He was 74 years old and lived in Venice and on a farm near Earlville, Pa.


'Apartment Zero' and Its Strange Tenant
''Apartment Zero,'' opening today at the Eighth Street Playhouse, is set in Buenos Aires in 1988 and is about a young man named Adrian LeDuc who is obsessed by movies.
He runs a movie theater devoted to old American films.
When first met, Adrian is in the projection booth of the Cine York, wiping away a tear as he watches the closing scene of ''A Touch of Evil.''
The apartment he has shared with his mother, now hospitalized and dying of what appears to be terminal neuroticism, is filled with framed 8-by-10 glossies of such stars as Montgomery Clift, Elizabeth Taylor and Charles Laughton.
Adrian relates to life only through films.


Net Rises At Morgan Stanley
LEAD: Largely because of one major deal, the Morgan Stanley Group Inc., the Wall Street investment banking firm, doubled its net income for the third quarter over the corresponding period last year.

Miroslaw Dzielski, 47, Polish Political Leader
LEAD: Miroslaw Dzielski, a Polish political leader who espoused entrepreneurship and market-economy principles in his native country, died of bladder cancer on Sunday at the hospital of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md.
He was 47 years old and lived in Cracow, Poland.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in the New Jersey Weekly last Sunday about the Cranberry Festival in Chatsworth gave an incorrect date for one day of the two-day event.
It is scheduled for Saturday and Sunday, not Friday; the rain dates are Oct. 28 and 29, not Oct. 27.


Eastern Air Is Rebuilding At Fast Pace
LEAD: Top executives of Eastern Airlines said yesterday that because a substantial number of striking workers were returning, they expected the airline to emerge from bankruptcy by early next year at 85 to 90 percent of its former size.


Soviets Abstain in U.N. Vote on Israel
LEAD: The Soviet Union abstained today in a vote to accept the Israeli delegation's credentials instead of joining Arab countries in seeking Israel's expulsion from the General Assembly.


White House Backs Call For C.I.A. Role in Coups
LEAD: The White House today endorsed calls for more latitude for the Central Intelligence Agency in supporting potentially violent efforts to overthrow foreign dictators, joining what is likely to become a heated debate on the issue between Congress and the Executive Branch.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Advertising Fills Deputy Creative Post
LEAD: Grey Advertising yesterday appointed Stephen A. Novick the deputy creative director of its New York office.
Mr.
Novick, 49 years old, an executive vice president who has been the agency's director of broadcast production for 18 years, will report to Richard M. Karp, Grey's head of creative services.


James Kirby Jr., Law Professor, Is Dead at 61
LEAD: James C. Kirby Jr., a law professor who taught at five schools and an expert on legal ethics, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Nashville.
He was 61 years old.
For the last 11 years he had been on the faculty at the University of Tennessee Law School in Knoxville, where he served as acting dean in 1980 and 1981.

LEAD: The nation's trade deficit grew sharply in August, to $10.8 billion, as imports surged to a record and exports showed a small decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation and the GTE Corporation reported sharply higher third-quarter earnings yesterday.
Another telephone company, the Southwestern Bell Corporation, said its profits had fallen, mainly because of one-time factors.


Campaign Trail; Giuliani Combines Street Grit And Glitz

Lessons
LEAD: rrGov.
Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey has a theory: Woodrow Wilson left the presidency of Princeton University to run for governor because he was worn out by academic politics.

Winifred Barnes has joined Wunderman Worldwide as senior vice president and management supervisor.


Rumbling Near Sunset Dashes Vision of Baseball
LEAD: At 5:03 P.M. yesterday, Candlestick Park was filled with the light of the setting sun.
The only rumble was from the 58,000 fans watching the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland Athletics warming up for the third game of the World Series.


Bagels Done the Old Way
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Next Inc. Is Offering Improvements in Its Work Station
LEAD: Next Inc., the company founded in 1986 by Steven P. Jobs, the former chairman of Apple Computer Inc., announced two significant developments yesterday.
It said that it would add an accelerator to its computer work station to resolve complaints about slow performance and that it would offer a lower-cost version of the work station for use on computer networks.


Large Loral Order
LEAD: The Loral Corporation said it had received a $325 million order, the largest in its history, to equip the Turkish Ministry of Defenses fleet of F-16 aircraft with ALQ-178 rapport III electronic countermeasures systems.
The General Dynamics Corporation makes the F-16.
Loral, a New York-based high-technology company specializing in military electronics, said deliveries would run from October 1991 through mid-1995.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Roger Ailes, the Republican media consultant, misattributed a quotation from his 1988 book ''You Are the Message'' (Dow Jones-Irwin).
It was Mr.
Ailes, not President Ronald Reagan, who wrote this passage, referring to what Mr.
Ailes calls ''the like factor'': ''I call it the magic bullet because if your audience likes you, they'll forgive you just about everything else you do wrong.


Viacom to Sell a 50% Stake In Showtime TV Service
LEAD: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 50 percent stake in Showtime, the nation's second-largest pay television service, to Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, for $225 million.

Economic Scene; The Morning Line On the Next Nobel
LEAD: TRYGVE who?

Trygve Haavelmo's critical contributions to the infant discipline of econometrics in the 1940's are now ancient history.

Sunshine Mining's New Silver Supply
LEAD: The Sunshine Mining Company, a silver mining and metal exploration concern, said it would acquire a 45 percent interest in a new silver mine near Libby, Mont., from the privately held Montana Reserves Company for a total of about $90 million.
Sunshine will pay about $38 million in cash and assume $32 million of the mine's existing obligations and a 15-year, $20 million note.

LEAD: New York said today that it had withdrawn from a group of Northeastern states working on a regional plan for disposing of toxic wastes because environmental officials here thought New York was being asked to take too much waste.

Integrated Cancels Talks on Core Sale
LEAD: Integrated Resources Inc. said it had called off talks to sell its core financial businesses to an unidentified buyer, and it raised its estimate of second-quarter losses above the previously announced $600 million mark.
But Integrated said a group of its senior executive officers had advised the company that it intends to make a proposal to buy three of the five principal financial businesses.


Computer Network At NASA Attacked By Rogue Program
LEAD: A rogue computer program attacked a worldwide network of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration on Monday, inflicting no damage but forcing officials to disconnect the network from sensitive military and space systems.

LEAD: We are prepared to provide technical assistance in certain areas of Soviet economic reform. . . .
We want perestroika to succeed. . . .
Such words would have been unutterable in official Washington even a few months ago.
Such thoughts would have been unimaginable just a few years ago.
To Ronald Reagan, the Soviet Union was the evil empire.

A $27 Million Loan by Sotheby's Helped Alan Bond to Buy 'Irises'
LEAD: When Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises'' was sold at auction for $53.9 million in 1987 at Sotheby's in New York, it became the world's most expensive painting.
Now, nearly two years later and on the eve of a new auction season, ''Irises'' has become the center of a controversy over how works of art are promoted and sold in today's marketplace.

Generic Drug Maker Gets Permanent Head
LEAD: Par Pharmaceutical Inc., a generic drug maker that is being investigated by the Government as part of a broad examination of the industry, named Kenneth I. Sawyer yesterday to the posts of president and chief executive.
He had been serving in those jobs on an interim basis since last month.


GORBACHEV SEEKS TO OUST AN EDITOR
LEAD: The editor of the Soviet Union's best-selling newspaper said today that he had been called to Communist Party headquarters and told to resign for publishing a political popularity poll that angered President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.


DELUGE OF CALLS DISRUPTS SERVICE
LEAD: Long-distance telephone communication into the San Francisco area was disrupted last night when millions of people across the country tried to reach relatives and friends after hearing of the earthquake that struck there.

Citicorp Auction
LEAD: Interest rates declined sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper for the second consecutive week, to their lowest in more than two months.
The bank holding company sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.292 percent, down from 8.483 percent.
The rate was the lowest since Aug.


Stock Slide Forces Closing Of a Chicago Options Firm
LEAD: The Fossett Corporation, a medium-sized options trading firm here, is the first firm forced out of business by the plunge in stock prices on Friday.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD:  DEAR DIARY:


Dance Theater of Harlem
LEAD: Dance Theater of Harlem is to perform a three-week season at Davis Hall at City College, Convent Avenue and 133d Street, Friday through Nov. 4.
The troupe will present revivals of ''Fete Noire,'' by Arthur Mitchell, company director; ''The Beloved,'' by Lester Horton; ''Mirage,'' by Billy Wilson, and Frederic Franklin's staging of the second act of ''Swan Lake,'' with new costumes and sets, as well as works by Bronislava Nijinska and John Butler.

Struggle on Manhattan Roof Ends in Officer's Fatal Fall
LEAD: A young police officer struggling with a robbery suspect on a rooftop in midtown Manhattan died early yesterday after he fell into a shaft between buildings and lay there helplessly for more than 40 minutes before rescuers were able to remove him, the police said.


Korean Surplus Estimate
LEAD: A South Korea trade group predicted today that the country's trade surplus would fall this year to $1.69 billion, in contrast to the Government's forecast of $4 billion and last year's $8.89 billion.
Korea Foreign Trade Association officials cited the appreciation of the won by more than 30 percent since 1986, rising labor costs and increases in the prices of overseas raw materials.

LEAD: On his first visit to West Germany in June, Egon Krenz and the members of his delegation spoke knowledgeably of choice foods, fine wines and the privileges of power, three topics most of their compatriots can only dream about.

LEAD: In its first public comment on takeover overtures from Donald J. Trump, the board of the AMR Corporation said today that the company ''has not been, and is not, for sale.''


Talbot Rantoul, 77, Designer and Educator
LEAD: Talbot Rantoul, a carpet designer and former president of the Rhode Island School of Design, died Monday at a nursing home in Providence, R.I.
He was 77 years old and lived in Chilmark, Mass., and Ojai, Calif.


Straining Phone System Survives 20 Million Calls
LEAD: The nation's telecommunications network was flooded Tuesday night by an estimated 20 million attempted telephone calls from people concerned about friends and family after the earthquake in the Bay area.


Second Chance for Deer Management Permits
LEAD: Hunters whose early applications for deer management permits in New York were rejected, may try again if they wish.


Wings Stop Stars
LEAD: Steve Yzerman had two goals and an assist as the Detroit Red Wings beat Minnesota, 4-3, tonight and handed the North Stars their first loss of the season.


Hungary Purges Stalinism From Its Constitution
LEAD: Parliament purged Hungary's Constitution of its Stalinist elements today to create a Western-style basic law for a return to multi-party democracy.

Secondary Stocks Rise; Volume Dips
LEAD: Secondary stocks showed more strength than blue chips yesterday as the market regained stability after last Friday's tumble.
The American Stock Exchange composite index was up 2.91 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 378.07, and the Nasdaq composite index, the primary measure of over-the-counter stock movement, rose 3.35 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 463.28.


Seadrift Journal; In Texas, Shrimpers Lament: 'It's Over'
LEAD: Kathy Yarborough was sitting on a broken chair in the little office at Froggies fish house, smoking cigarettes, chatting with friends and happily letting the afternoon pass.
Then her 2-year-old son, Donny Paul, intruded by announcing his ambition.


Review/Theater; Fighting Trash With Trash In a Nihilistic Puppet Show
LEAD: Almost as soon as the Smiths, a family of six from the Bronx, have been shown a cozy new suburban home in Garden City, L.I., their allergies begin to act up.
First they begin to sneeze.
Soon their quarrelsome twin sons have developed itchy rashes, and before long Grandma is suffering from schizophrenic seizures.

Small University Gains Control Of the Barnes Foundation
LEAD: With the recent election of two new trustees, control of the Barnes Foundation, which owns one of the world's most important collections of late-19th- and early-20th-century art, has passed to Lincoln University, a small, predominantly black liberal-arts college in Oxford, Pa.


Cabaret Convention Ponders a Disturbing Future
LEAD: Is there a place for cabaret in today's age of mass entertainment?
That is the question being pondered this week on the stage of Town Hall, where a Cabaret Convention is holding a series of discussions and gala concerts that will continue through Sunday.


Expert T.L.C. for Linen and Lace
LEAD: FINDING a person skilled at restoring lace and linen is a tough task. ''Young women today don't care to do this,'' said Betty LaCasse, who for most of her 60-plus years has been mending holes in bed linens and re-creating missing lace on wedding veils.

Tapestries Depict Life In Chile
LEAD: ISLA NEGRA, a village on the central Chilean coast, is known on two counts: as the home of the poet and Nobel laureate Pablo Neruda and for the striking tapestries made by its women.
The work of the Bordadoras de Isla Negra (Embroiderers of Isla Negra), executed in brilliantly colored wool yarns on sackcloth, has achieved international recognition.


Review/Chamber Music; 2 Sounds' Common Ground
LEAD: Marin Alsop and her Concordia chamber orchestra usually include classical works inspired by jazz on their programs.
Fred Hersch, a jazz pianist and composer, likes to dabble in the classics.
Mr.
Hersch and his band, and Ms.
Alsop and hers, got together for a Town Hall concert on Sunday afternoon, and found a good deal of common ground, although perhaps not as much as they had hoped.

LEAD: A tough austerity policy this year slowed China's runaway economy, but it will take at least three years to put it back on course, the Government says.
The People's Daily quoted


Lebanese Christians Get Arab League Offer
LEAD: The Arab League commission, mediating an end to the Lebanese civil war in talks in Taif, said today that Christian legislators in Parliament should settle for a commitment by the Arab League to obtain a Syrian troop withdrawal from Lebanon.


A 'Time of Drift' Now for a Quieter Koch
LEAD: Inside City Hall these days there is an unnatural if not unexpected quiet.
Mayor Edward I. Koch still arrives early, but his public schedules are usually short.
And as his weeks in office dwindle and his commissioners announce their departures, the question has become, ''How's he doing?''


Shamir Faulted on Mideast Remarks
LEAD: The Bush Administration, increasingly frustrated by what it calls obstructionist moves by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, publicly criticized him today for making remarks that were disappointing and ''unhelpful'' to the Middle East peace process.


9.1% Stake Held In Enzo Biochem
LEAD: An investment group led by J. Morton Davis, the chairman and sole shareholder of the New York brokerage firm D. H. Blair &amp; Company, said it holds a 9.1 percent stake in Enzo Biochem Inc.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr.
Davis said the group might seek to gain control of Enzo Biochem but that it had no immediate plans to do so.

Parent &amp; child
LEAD: RECENT national surveys estimate that 2 million to 6 million children under the age of 13 regularly care for themselves without adult supervision after school or on weekends.
For almost all parents of such latchkey children - ''children in self-care,'' as some researchers call them - the decision to leave them alone is unwanted but unavoidable.

Hugo's Victims Send Supplies to Bay Area
LEAD: A month after being devastated by Hurricane Hugo, this city began sending relief supplies and assistance today to the residents of the San Franciso area.

Currents; It Isn't Lace at All, It's Painted Furniture
LEAD: PENWORK is an intricate decorating technique that involves painting patterns in white gesso on dark varnishes or black paint.
It reached its peak in England and Scotland in the mid-1820's.
Some of the finest examples of the genre have been assembled in a charming exhibition, ''Penwork, the Triumph of Line,'' which runs through Nov.


Campaign Trail; Dinkins Says His Staff Was Wrong To Vote on Broadcasting Company
LEAD: Claiming a busy schedule, David N. Dinkins decided to forgo scheduled trips to Chicago and Detroit yesterday and instead sent surrogates to fund raisers in his honor in both cities.


Notes Offered By Lockheed
LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation is offering $300 million in notes due 1999 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.

G.E. to Eliminate 450 Appliance Jobs
LEAD: The General Electric Company said it would eliminate about 450 jobs in the next three years in the home laundry manufacturing operations at its major appliance plant here.
G.E. said it would shift some manufacturing work to subcontractors to cut costs.
The affected jobs will be eliminated through attrition.

Market Place; Lessons Learned In 2 Hectic Years
LEAD: TWO years ago today, John J. Phelan Jr. was plunged into a new world of finance, as markets throughout the world crashed in what was the worst day in the history of stock trading.


Knicks Lose To Suns by 9
LEAD: Eddie Johnson scored 18 of his 38 points in the first half to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 115-106 exhibition victory over the Knicks tonight at the University of Dayton Arena.


Fabric of Liberty
LEAD: America's flag will still fly proudly over the Capitol if the Senate votes today against a constitutional amendment that purports to protect Old Glory from desecration.
It will wave for those who see the flag as a symbol of all freedoms - including the freedom to insult it.
And it will salute the bravery of senators who resist this tampering with the Bill of


J. G. Hangin, 68, Professor, Dies
LEAD: John Gombojab Hangin, a university professor in the United States and an expert on Mongolian language and culture, died of heart disease Oct. 9 in Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia, where he was doing research.
He was 68 years old and lived in Bloomington, Ind.


Sovran Reports Rise in Profits
LEAD: The Sovran Financial Corporation, which plans to merge with the Citizens and Southern Corporation to create the nation's 14th-largest banking company, today reported a rise of 11.8 percent in its third-quarter profit.

Commodities Firm Fined
LEAD: A commodities trading firm agreed to pay a $500,000 fine and withdraw from membership in the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to settle charges of improper record-keeping and violating margin requirements, exchange officials said today.

Cuomo Offers Help to Victims
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo offered New York's help today to victims of the earthquake in Northern California.
The Governor said the state would supply equipment and other help if it is needed.


Milton Friedman, 75, a Labor Arbitrator
LEAD: Milton Friedman, a labor-management arbitrator and mediator, died of pneumonia yesterday at University Hospital at the New York University Medical Center.
He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.


East Germany: What Hasn't Changed
LEAD: Erich Honecker, the builder of the Berlin Wall, was ousted as East Germany's boss after it became obvious he symbolized an intolerable status quo in a country clamoring for change.
But the wall still stands; so does the suffocating political and economic system it is meant to protect.

First City to Sell Card Business
LEAD: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that it had agreed in principle to sell its credit card business, First City Bank-Sioux Falls, to the Bank of New York Company for $180 million in cash.

Blue Arrow P.L.C., London, an employment agency, said it would adopt the name of its main operation, Manpower Inc., based in Milwaukee, as part of a move to strengthen its position in the U.S. market.
