WCRS Sets Big Shift to Media Buying
LEAD: THE British advertising company whose holdings include the American agency Della Femina, McNamee WCRS, yesterday substantially withdrew from the advertising business while at the same time acquiring complete control of the largest media-buying company in Europe.

Corrections
LEAD: The Advertising column in Business Day on Oct. 9, about the indictment of Young &amp; Rubicam on charges of bribery to foreign officials, referred incorrectly to a Spanish colloquialism for bribe.
The term is mordida - literally, bite.

Currents; Old Friends, New Shops
LEAD: FOR years Christian Jussel, Garrick Stephenson and Janet Mavec discussed putting their respective East Side antiques shops under one roof.
Starting today they are finally together, on the second floor of the Revlon International Building, 625 Madison Avenue (58th Street).


Wang Loses $62.1 Million
LEAD: Wang Laboratories Inc. today reported a $62.1 million loss for the first quarter, ended Sept. 30, and predicted losses would continue for much of the next year as it restructured in an attempt to bring about a turnaround.

Planners Approve a Lab Atop F.D.R. Drive
LEAD: A proposal by Rockefeller University to build a 12-story biomedical laboratory building over the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive was approved unanimously yesterday by the New York City Planning Commission.


Trinova Will Lay Off 1,500 in Revamping
LEAD: The Trinova Corporation announced today that it would lay off 1,500 employees in its second restructuring in two years.


A Life of Study of the Venerable Bead
LEAD: How many beads does the world's leading bead expert have in the collection he keeps in a tool chest by his bed in the basement of his home here? ''I don't know,'' said the authority, Peter Francis Jr., a puckish 44-year-old. ''Well, maybe half a million.
Certainly not a million.''


Jet 'Prevent-Offense' Isn't a Laughing Matter to Walton
LEAD: Joe Walton, his job secure and in control of a 1-5 Jets team whose defense outscores the offense, tried cracking jokes today.

G.M.'s Chief Sees Market Share Rise
LEAD: Roger B. Smith, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said he expects G.M.'s share of the United States market to rise to more than 40 percent by the turn of the century, up from the current 35.5 percent.

LEAD: The Toronto Maple Leafs, stung by Tom Kurvers's refusal to play for the team, yesterday asked the National Hockey League to look into the trade that they thought gave them the Devils' defenseman in return for a first-round draft pick in 1991.

Mozart Opera To Open Season In Brooklyn
LEAD: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's second opera season will open at the academy's Majestic Theater on March 15 with a production of Mozart's ''Finta Giardiniera'' from the Theatre de la Monnaie in Brussels.
The company is to announce the season today.


2 on S.I. Run a Neck-and-Neck Race
LEAD: Two of Staten Island's most prominent politicians - Ralph J. Lamberti and Representative Guy V. Molinari -are waging a vigorous battle for the office of borough president.


Poetry, Not Chintz, in New York's First French Show House
LEAD: Forget Fine French Furniture, Art Deco and Provencale.
Le Style Francais - the French style - has just landed in town, and it is anything and everything but what you might expect.
The occasion is the French Designer Showhouse, the first to be held in the United States.

Review/Dance; Vivona Troupe Changes Roles, Sexes and Clothes
LEAD: Diane Vivona's ''How to Fit a Square Peg in a Round Hole and Other Stories,'' performed on Saturday night at Playlab, took a carefree look at modern androgyny.
The humor was bright, the cast engaging and the performing accomplished.
But it was only in the next-to-last number that the piece became as focused as one might have expected.


Salvador Peace Talks End Without an Accord
LEAD: The Salvadoran Government and guerrilla commanders ended three days of talks in a convent here today without signing any major agreement.

LEAD: A group of Arab-Americans in New York City say David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign has spurned their offers of help because of exaggerated fears of alienating Jewish voters.

THE CALIFORNIA QUAKE: The Highway Collapse; The Desperate Struggle for Lives Along I-880
LEAD: Disbelieving rescue workers and loved ones converged around crumpled Interstate Highway 880 today, filled with the desperate hope that a few more lives could be saved.
But they could do little.
What they found only confirmed their most horrible first impressions of the unreal sight of one roadway lying upon another.


Panel Clears Two Officers In Strangling
LEAD: A second grand jury has refused to bring any criminal charges against two white police officers in the 1986 death of a black man in Middletown, N.Y., the special state prosecutor handling the case announced today.

NEW MARS FINDINGS FROM SOVIET CRAFT
LEAD: Observations by a Soviet spacecraft reveal that magnetic forces surrounding Mars are controlled by ''winds'' of electrified gases from the Sun, not from magnetism generated by the planet.
The finding could explain why Mars has lost most of its atmosphere over the last billion years.

China's Grain Harvest
LEAD: Despite higher prices and investment, China's grain harvest will fail to match the 1984 record for the fifth straight year, according to an official report issued today.
The Economic Information newspaper said the 1989 harvest would be more than last year's 394 million tons, but would fall short of the record of 407.3 million in 1984 because of natural disasters in the northeast and Inner Mongolia.

LEAD: Another Faberge account defected from Bozell yesterday, as Faberge's parent company shifted a line of hair care products to J. Walter Thompson/New York.
Chesebrough-Pond's, the unit of Unilever N.V. that acquired Faberge last August, switched its men's toiletries products from Bozell to Lintas New York last week.

Review/Theater; Heat on Many Levels, in Sally Nemeth's 'Mill Fire'
LEAD: Three widows stare ominously from behind black tulle veils while the audience files in to Sally Nemeth's play ''Mill Fire'' at the Apple Corps Theater. ''Mill Fire'' is, thankfully, not as grim as the visages of those three women: its young heroine, Marlene, another widow, refuses to grieve in the conventional, quiet mode thought proper in Birmingham, Ala., in 1978.


I.B.M. to Buy Back $1 Billion of Stock
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $1 billion worth of stock.
The program is one of series of similar actions the company has taken since 1986.
A stock buyback program initiated by I.B.M. in September 1988 is still in effect.
Currently, $368 million of the $2 billion originally allocated is still to be spent.


Corrections
LEAD: The Sports of The Times column on Tuesday misidentified the 1955 World Series game in which Roger Craig was the winning pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers against the Yankees.
It was the fifth game, not the third.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Low Water Pressure  Q. Is there a safe, economical way to improve the water pressure in my 75-year-old house?
A.
First, make sure that the water pressure coming into the house is up to par.
You can ask your local water company to check this, or a plumber can put a pressure gauge on the incoming line to make sure the pressure is adequate.

Measuring the Magnitude
LEAD: For every increase of one on the Richter scale, there is a tenfold increase in ground motions, or seismic waves.
The energy released by the earthquake's motion is about 30 times greater for each increase of one on the scale.
There is no maximum or minimum on the scale.
Even earthquakes of less than -2 are routinely measured.

Bernstein and Copland
LEAD: Leonard Bernstein is to conduct the New York Philharmonic this month in four performances of an all-Copland program.
The concerts, at Avery Fisher Hall, will take place today and Saturday at 8 P.M., Friday at 2 P.M. and Oct. 24 at 7:30 P.M.
The works to be played are ''Music for the Theater,'' ''Connotations,'' the Clarinet Concerto and ''El Salon Mexico.

Upsala Calls Time To Fetch Quarterback
LEAD: The established reasons to call a time out in a football game include halting the clock, making a substitution or a strategic decision, even rattling an opponent's field-goal kicker.


President Soft-Pedals Flag Measure
LEAD: After advancing a constitutional amendment as the only certain way to protect the American flag from desecration, President Bush has held back from an all-out effort to save the proposal in the Senate, Congressional and Administration officials said today.

James M. Fulton, 75, Ex-Executive at Merck
LEAD: James M. Fulton, a former executive at Merck &amp; Company in Rahway, N.J., died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in Martha's Vineyard, Mass.
He was 75 years old.


THE CALIFORNIA QUAKE: The Next Day; QUAKE DEAD PUT AT 270, DAMAGE AT A BILLION AS CALIFORNIANS STRIVE TO RESTORE ORDER
LEAD: On the day after the most terrifying night of their lives, Northern Californians today catalogued disasters great and small, counted the dead and comforted the living and began restoring order and civility to their devastated cities and towns.


THE CALIFORNIA QUAKE: Earthquake Engineering; Why the Skyscrapers Just Swayed
LEAD: San Francisco's skyscrapers, which over the last generation have given the gentle bayfront city the look of a modern metropolis, came through the earthquake Tuesday with little or no damage, thanks in large part to tough codes for earthquake resistance enacted in California over the last 15 to 20 years.


Animal Rights Activists Endanger Medical Research
LEAD: To the Editor:


Record Textile Imports
LEAD: United States imports of textiles and apparel totaled more than 1.42 billion square yards in August, a record for any month, the American Textile Manufacturers Institute said Tuesday.
It said the figure was up by 19 percent over August 1988.
In the first eight months of this year, imports were 9.82 billion square yards, a 13 percent rise over last year.


Oklahoma Officers Acquitted Of Conspiring to Kidnap Man
LEAD: A jury in Sherman, Tex., today acquitted two Oklahoma lawmen on charges that they had conspired to kidnap a man they thought was a drug dealer, bring him across state lines and torture him with a curling iron.

Her Hints Are Words To Live By
LEAD: ''FORGIVE the dog toys,'' said Heloise, pointing her manicured finger to the rubber skunk, sea anenome, hamburger and ice-cream bar embedded in the grass.
The visitor certainly did.
After all, this was Heloise.
The 38-year-old household-hints writer, who in 1977 inherited her mother's fabled column, ''Hints from Heloise,'' has been called the ''high priestess of housework'' and ''the maven of the mundane.


Crippled Airliner Lands Safely
LEAD: After losing electrical power, a jetliner with 104 people aboard made an emergency landing at a small unattended airport early today and ran off the runway, burying its tires in the mud.

LEAD: Amnesty International expressed concern today for the safety of about 40 people in East Timor said to have been arrested for taking part in a pro-independence protest in front of Pope John Paul II last week when he visited the disputed Indonesian province.

LEAD: ''A FRIEND who is an artist always came to dinner wearing a wrinkled shirt,'' Angela Cummings said, ''so I decided to make some tableware that looked wrinkled, just to tease him.''

LEAD: As damage estimates from the California earthquake exceeded a billion dollars, hundreds of insurance claims adjusters moved into the area yesterd day to assess the devastation and pay claims.


Emerson String Quartet
LEAD: The Emerson String Quartet, in its only New York appearances this season, will play the late string quartets of Beethoven and Schubert in four concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
The quartet - Eugene Drucker, Philip Setzer, Lawrence Dutton and David Finckel - will play at 8 P.M. today and on Dec.


Seoul Leader Offers Assurances To Congress Over Import Markets
LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea sought to assure Congress today that his nation would open its developing markets to foreign imports quickly and that anti-Americanism in his country was limited to a handful of radicals.


In London, Subway Style Above Ground
LEAD: British fashion seems to be going down the tube - the subway, that is.
At the designer shows and in the offbeat London shops, styles first seen on New York City streets and subways carried the day: hooded shirts and jackets with large graphics, sweat pants, belt packs, knapsacks and chunky leather basketball shoes.

Partners in UAL Buyout Offer Continue to Maneuver
LEAD: Efforts continued yesterday to reassemble a takeover bid for the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, and one partner in the bid, British Airways, said it hoped a new proposal would be forthcoming from its other partners, United's pilots and management.

Garcia Jury Still Deliberates In Extortion and Bribery Trial
LEAD: Deliberations are to continue for the fifth day today in the bribery and extortion trial of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee.


Maryland Under Scrutiny
LEAD: The Maryland men's basketball program, which has spent three years in the shadow of the cocaine-related death of Len Bias, now has to respond to accusations of at least 19 violations by a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation.


Move Seen on Oil Stockpile
LEAD: The Bush Administration will stop buying Mexican oil for the United States emergency stockpile early next year, ending an eight-year supply link aimed in part at aiding the debt-ridden Mexican economy, people close to the situation said today.


New Measure Finds Growing Hardship for Youth
LEAD: The well-being of children in America has declined dramatically since 1970, according to an index that measures aspects of ''social health'' like infant mortality and drug abuse.


A Lesson in Playfulness: School Annexes That Please the Eye
LEAD: THESE days, it is architects who are playing in schoolyards.
Four startling new buildings have sprung up alongside public schools in the Bronx and Brooklyn.
Covered with classical ornament and painted bright colors, they seem to be on loan from Disney World.
Actually, they contain classrooms.


Judge Says Hospital Can Take Queens Baby Off Respirator
LEAD: A baby who has been declared brain dead can be removed from life-support equipment despite his parents' opposition, a judge ruled yesterday.

Adlai S. Hardin Dies; Wood Sculptor Was 88
LEAD: Adlai S. Hardin, a sculptor and former advertising executive, died of complications from a stroke on Monday at the Saybrook Convalescent Hospital in Old Saybrook, Conn.
He was 88 years old.


N.C.A.A. Council Seeks Reforms &lt;
LEAD: In a series of moves that supported calls for reform in intercollegiate sports, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Council today called for year-round, random drug-testing and endorsed mandatory disclosure of graduation rates for student-athletes.


Hunter Sets Sale Of a Subsidiary
LEAD: Hunter Environmental Services Inc. reached a preliminary agreement to sell its environmental consulting and services business for $40 million plus the assumption of debt.
The deal is subject to completion of a definitive agreement, approval by Hunter's stockholders and receipt of all necessary consents.


3 Crushed by Skidding Truck That Hits Jeep in New Jersey
LEAD: Three New York residents were killed today when their vehicle was crushed by a tractor trailer carrying compressed garbage, the state police said.


Democrat Captures Mississippi House Seat    With Mr. Taylor were his wife, Margaret, and son, Gary. (AP)


At Least 18 Dead in Tremor In Rural Area of North China
LEAD: A series of earthquakes rattled northern China late Wednesday and early today, killing at least 18 people and flattening about 8,000 houses in a largely rural area, the authorities said.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Weekend on Friday about foliage and farm stands gave an incorrect telephone number for the Kohlmaier Farm in Hopewell Junction, N.Y.
Its number is (914) 226-5028.


Soviets, Vividly Recalling Earthquake Tragedy in Armenia, Offer Aid to U.S.
LEAD: The Soviet Union offered its condolences and assistance to the United States today because of the California earthquake.


Nine Mile Pt. 2 Nuclear Plant Is Shut by Utility After Leak
LEAD: The Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant was shut at 4:22 A.M. today, when the owner, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, learned of a higher-than-normal leak rate in a drywell in the containment structure, the utility said in a release.


Folklorists See Art In Window Dressing
LEAD: Windows decorated with ceramic vases, swans and Madonnas - a common sight in row-house neighborhoods like South Philadelphia - are being studied by folklorists who consider them to be an urban folk art tradition.

Unocal Thailand
LEAD: Unocal Thailand said today that it plans to spend $2 billion in the next 10 years to develop offshore natural gas fields in the Gulf of Thailand.
A spokesman for the company, a unit of the Unocal Corporation of the United States, said about $1.4 billion would be capital investment and the rest operating costs.

LEAD: Of all the changes in New York City's government proposed by the Charter Revision Commission, none are quite so dramatic as those proposed for the borough presidents.

Net Off 25.3% At Northrop
LEAD: The Northrop Corporation reported today that its third-quarter earnings declined 25.3 percent, to $21.5 million, or 46 cents a share, from $28.8 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier.


From Queens Streets, City Hall Seems Very Distant
LEAD: The voters of Kew Gardens, Queens, have not forgotten the blizzard of 1969.
Manhattan's streets were plowed first, they say.
But in Kew Gardens, a man had to be an Under Secretary General of the United Nations and a Nobel Prize winner to get his street cleared.

Campaign Matters; For Messinger, Making Friends With Old Foes
LEAD: Ruth W. Messinger was running for higher office well before she decided on the particular office - the Manhattan borough presidency, as it turned out - but she does not seem to be waiting for the election to begin her new line of work.


SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK and FIELD; Nebiolo Named Again
LEAD: Primo Nebiolo, who was ousted as president of the Italian track and field federation amid a business scandal, was re-elected president of the Association of Summer Olympic Federations yesterday.


Labs in the Bay Area Escape Damage
LEAD: Safeguards incorporated during construction or added later apparently protected three major laboratories in the San Francisco Bay area from serious damage in the earthquake that struck the area on Tuesday.


Resolution Funding in $4.5 Billion Bond Sale
LEAD: The Resolution Funding Corporation, established by Congress last summer to finance the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, announced yesterday that it would auction $4.5 billion worth of 30-year bonds to the public next Wednesday.


Sam Moore, 85, Writer Of Comedy for Radio
LEAD: Sam Moore, a writer for radio in the 1930's and 1940's on such comedy programs as ''The Great Gildersleeve,'' died of a heart attack on Friday while he was on vacation in France.
He was 85 years old and lived in Blairstown, N.J.


Renault in Dutch Vehicle Venture
LEAD: Renault S.A., the French auto maker, said it had signed a letter of intent to create a joint venture with the Dutch company DAF to make light commercial vehicles.
Renault's vice chairman, Philippe Gras, said the two groups would share research and development costs of around one billion francs.


Brownstones to Tour And Apartments to See
LEAD: Seven for Luck, New Yorker League for Cerebral Palsy, 105 Madison Avenue; 212-683-6700.


The Shock of 6.9
LEAD: The millions of Americans who tuned in to the World Series Tuesday witnessed instead the horror of an intense earthquake.
The San Francisco Bay Area became the scene of terrifying images.
The Bay Bridge with a piece of its top deck down.
A one-mile stretch of the Nimitz Freeway collapsed deck to deck, crushing the cars in between.


Asian Venture Selects A Banker as Chairman
LEAD: Richard A. Melville, an international banking executive, has signed on with a newly formed financial services and merchant banking company that hopes to establish a global business.


Relief Groups Taking Aid
LEAD: Funds to help earthquake victims in California have been set up by the following organizations:  American Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund, P.O.
Box 4691, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10163.
Telephone: 800-453-9000.
Episcopal Church/The Presiding Bishop's Fund for World Relief, The Episcopal Church Center, 815 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y.


Gain at United Technologies
LEAD: The United Technologies Corporation said today that its third-quarter income rose 3 percent on the strength of increased sales for jet engines, air-conditioning systems and elevators.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about nominations for the 1989 National Book Awards misidentified the publisher of ''Barbarian Sentiments: How the American Century Ends,'' by William Pfaff.
It is Hill &amp; Wang, a division of Farrar, Straus &amp; Giroux.


Man Convicted Again For a Murder in 1983
LEAD: A man whose life was twice spared by the State Supreme Court after two separate murder convictions has again been convicted of the 1983 sexual assault and murder of an Asbury Park woman.
The conviction could be used against the man, Marko Bey, 24 years old, when he is resentenced for killing another woman in 1983.


In a Collapsed Building, Heroism and the Promise of a Cup of Coffee
LEAD: ''Don't leave me - I don't want to die in here,'' a woman cried out to a San Francisco firefighter while trapped in a collapsed three-story apartment building about half an hour after the earthquake hit here Tuesday afternoon.


Truck Jams in Overpass, Halting Van Wyck
LEAD: A tractor-trailer struck a pedestrian walkway that crosses over Jewel Avenue and the Van Wyck Expressway in Flushing, Queens, yesterday afternoon, forcing a halt to traffic in the northbound lanes of the expressway, the police said.
There were no reports of injuries.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE MARKETS  Investment bankers postponed two ''junk bond'' offerings totaling more than $1.2 billion because of volatile conditions in the high-risk, high-yield market.
And Kohlberg &amp; Company said Drexel Burnham Lambert, which was ''highly confident'' it could raise $75 million in financing for its buyout of Colorado Prime last summer, was unable to finance the deal through junk bonds.


Fund Yields Are Lower
LEAD: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday.


Dayton Hudson Offer
LEAD: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the big retail chain based here, said today that it had accepted for purchase seven million of its common shares, at $62.875 apiece, in response to its Dutch auction self-tender offer, which expired on Tuesday.
The company said it had received about 7,141,000 shares tendered at that price or below.


Reagan Speculates That Iran May Have Duped U.S. in Arms Deal
LEAD: Former President Ronald Reagan says he wonders now whether the Iran-contra affair that rocked his second term was not ''a setup, a sting operation, by the Iranians.''

LEAD: Copper futures prices slipped yesterday to their lowest point this month on the Commodity Exchange in New York, and some analysts said the market's four-month-old rally appeared to be weakening.


Shuttle Launched After Delay And Galileo Is Sent to Jupiter
LEAD: The space shuttle Atlantis rocketed into orbit today to send the Galileo spacecraft on its planned six-year, 2.5-billion-mile journey to Jupiter.


ETHICS COMMITTEE SCOLDS LAWMAKER
LEAD: The House ethics committee scolded a California Congressman today for sexually harassing women on his staff.


Bell Units' Nets Vary In Quarter
LEAD: Two Bell holding companies, BellSouth and Ameritech, today reported third-quarter earnings in line with Wall Street's expectations, despite significant one-time charges.


The Earthquake So 'Great' a Later One Seems Puny
LEAD: Fires raged out of control for more than three days.
Communications with the outside world were severely restricted.
Coordination between government agencies was at times so poor that Federal troops clashed with roving groups of citizens who had been ordered by the Mayor to guard against looting.


Fetisov's First N.H.L. Goal Helps Devils Defeat Flyers
LEAD: With Vyacheslav Fetisov, the heralded Soviet defenseman, shining brightly for the second consecutive game, and Sean Burke making timely saves, the Devils tonight posted their second straight triumph.


It's Not Over, But It Should Be
LEAD: More than 250 people are dead.
Hundreds of others are broken and bandaged.
Long strips of yellow ''caution'' tape cordons off downtown buildings where piles of shattered window glass have been swept into the gutters.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has awarded $105,000 in grants to three dance troupes - the David Gordon/Pick Up Company, the Hubbard Street Dance Company and the Trisha Brown Company - to participate in its 1989-90 Dance Tour program.
The grants will enable the companies to perform in 39 American cities.

William P. Palmer, 92, Lawyer in Manhattan
LEAD: William P. Palmer, a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer &amp; Wood, died Monday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 92 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.


Review/Art; The Recent Sculptures Of Giacomo Manzu
LEAD: This is - in intention, at any rate -the month of Giacomo Manzu in New York.
On Monday, Francesco Cossiga, the President of Italy, unveiled in the garden facing the United Nations building a 25-foot-high bronze sculpture by Mr.
Manzu that represents a woman holding a child.
The gift of the Italian people to the United Nations, it was commissioned in 1987 by the Italian Government.


Rejection of Case Against Judge Urged
LEAD: The impeachment trial of a Federal judge on charges arising from a bribery case took an unexpected twist today when a Republican Senator who has been active in the matter urged fellow lawmakers to reject the charges and let the judge remain on the bench.


Signs of Big Soviet Purchase Move Corn Prices Higher
LEAD: Signs of a large Soviet purchase of American corn pulled corn futures prices up sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.


PBS Appoints New Programming Chief
LEAD: The Public Broadcasting Service named Jennifer Lawson, the senior programming excutive of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, to the newly created position of executive vice president for national programming and promotion services yesterday.
The PBS position will make Ms.
Lawson, who is 43 years old, the most powerful programming executive in public television.

LEAD: The USX Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to form a joint venture with Kobe Steel Ltd., Japan's fifth-largest steelmaker, to produce rust-resistant steel products, primarily for the automobile industry.

LEAD: CBS became the first network to cancel a new series yesterday, dropping ''The People Next Door'' from its Monday night comedy lineup.

16 Reliving The Terror Of a Quake
LEAD: For 16 children now living in this area and receiving medical treatment, the violent earthquake here was the second shock hurled at them by fate in 10 months.
They also lived, and suffered, through the earthquake that devastated Armenia last Dec. 7.


Rapid Transit In Full Service
LEAD: The Bay Area Rapid Transit system, a vital link between San Francisco and the East Bay, was back in full service today.

Two Airmen Admit a Plot to Sell Jet Engines
LEAD: Two Air Force security guards have pleaded guilty to stealing three F-16 jet engines and selling them to undercover agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.


British Jobless Rate Dips
LEAD: Unemployment in Britain fell to 6 percent in September, its lowest level in nine years, the Government said today.
Unemployment figures, adjusted for seasonal factors, showed a larger than expected fall of 50,400 people, to 1.69 million, the Employment Department said.


Memorial for Bill Barron
LEAD: A memorial service for Bill Barron, the saxophonist, composer and professor of music at Wesleyan University, is to be held at 7 P.M. on Sunday at St.
Peter's Lutheran Church, on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street.


New Currency Studied
LEAD: The Bureau of Engraving and Printing is looking at new designs for currency that would make counterfeiting more difficult.
A bureau research panel is studying various designs, but it will need the approval of the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Bank for any change, a spokeswoman said.
She declined to say whether there had been an increase recently in counterfeiting cases.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''From April to October, the length of a baseball season, may be enough to establish a winner of the World Series.
It's not enough to win the war on drugs in this city or any other city.''  - William J. Bennett, the national drug policy director, in Washington.  [ A1:3. ]

Hasbro Profits Rise
LEAD: The toy company Hasbro Inc. said today that better profit margins and improved performances by its Milton Bradley and Playskool units had helped third-quarter earnings rise 73.1 percent.
The company reported earnings of $31.3 million, or 53 cents a share, compared with $18.08 million, or 31 cents a share, in 1988's third quarter.


School Backs Down on Issue of Black Player
LEAD: An all-white private school has reversed its decision to cancel a football game against a team with a black player, thus avoiding expulsion from the Mississippi Private School Association.

SOME BUSINESSES AND SCHOOLS OPEN
LEAD: Parts of this exhausted and shaken city returned to a tentative sort of normality today, while in the most stricken neighborhoods the stunned good nature of recent days gave way to impatience, anger and fear.


Giants Face Big, Aggressive Chargers
LEAD: A few years ago, the San Diego Chargers were the mad bombers of pro football, with Dan Fouts seemingly passing on every play.
The Chargers who play the Giants on Sunday in San Diego are a different breed, a big team on offense and defense that tries to shove the ball down the throat of the opposition in the style of the Washington Redskins.

Realty Sale By Fogelman
LEAD: Avram B. Fogelman, the beleaguered Memphis real estate developer, yesterday signed a letter of agreement to sell his golf and related resort properties on South Carolina's Hilton Head Island to the Beach Company, a closely held Charleston real estate firm, and Voute, Coats, Stuart &amp; O'Grady L.P., a private investment company.

'Skinhead' Is Sentenced in Slaying of Black
LEAD: A white supremacist ''skinhead'' was sentenced to up to 20 years in prison today for helping to beat a black immigrant to death.


Photographs of Haiti
LEAD: Recent photographs of Haiti by Maggie Steber are on view in Room 408 of the Union Square Gallery, 32 Union Square East, through Nov. 11.
The exhibition focuses on the Caribbean country since the fall of the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier.
Hours are Fridays from 1 to 7 P.M., Saturdays from noon to 5 P.M., and by appointment.


Digital Net Tumbles 32.5%
LEAD: Slow domestic sales and the continued strength of the dollar overseas contributed to a 32.5 percent decline in the Digital Equipment Corporation's earnings for its first quarter ending Sept. 30, the company said yesterday.

Rattling Horns and Green Tomatoes
LEAD: Red sumacs, orange maples, golden aspens, wine-dark ash leaves.
This marvelous sunset range of colors is sometimes given voice by flights of geese breezing southward - in wiggling check-marks or military wedges, cheering one another on with halloos, gabbles, baying barks.

Review/Film; Med School Madness In 'Gross Anatomy'
LEAD: When Joe Slovak (Matthew Modine) gets the news that he has been accepted for medical school, he stuffs the letter in his pocket, strikes a noncommittal pose and ignores the anxious relatives waiting to find out what the letter says.
That's Joe in a nutshell: diffident and jokey, vastly charming but also obnoxiously cavalier.


Market Place; Insurance Stocks Regaining Favor
LEAD: AFTER the largest California earthquake in 80 years, one that could cost the insurance companies hundreds of millions, if not billions, Wall Street has responded by bidding up the price of insurance company stocks.


Kodak Camera
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would introduce a disposable wide-angle-lens camera in the United States.
The Kodak Stretch 35 will cost $12.95 and will take 12 color photographs.
The company introduced the one-time use camera in Europe and Japan earlier this year.
The camera's wide-angle lens will take panoramic photographs.


Seattle to Examine Bridges and Freeways
LEAD: State engineers said today that they would conduct a study to see if some of the old two-tiered bridges and freeways in Seattle, a city with geography and structures similiar to San Francisco's, should be redesigned to meet stricter standards.

Debate Begins on Reducing Budget Deficit
LEAD: House and Senate budget negotiators today began what promises to be a slow process: reconciling major differences in their plans for reducing the fiscal year 1990 budget deficit and repealing $16.1 billion in automatic spending cuts that took effect on Monday.


Toast the Screenwriter, Not the Actor
LEAD: To the Editor:


Police Dig for More Bodies on Missouri Farm
LEAD: Police officers searching for missing transients have already found the bodies of three unidentified men buried on a farm here, and are continuing to dig.


Sam Moore, 85, Writer Of Comedy for Radio
LEAD: Sam Moore, a writer for radio in the 1930's and 1940's on such comedy programs as ''The Great Gildersleeve,'' died of a heart attack last Friday while he was on vacation in France.
He was 85 years old and lived in Blairstown, N.J.

LEAD: Ron Hextall, a holdout this season, will return to practice today with the Philadelphia Flyers, whose 1-5-1 record has them off to their worst start in 20 years.

Review/Film; Wisdom and Innocence on the Eve of War
LEAD: In the Scilly Isles, off the southwest coast of England, there lives a silent hermit who loves birds.
He's known, not surprisingly, as the Birdman.
Here, on the tiny Isle of Bryher on the eve of World War I, the Birdman is the only inhabitant who remembers living on the neighboring Isle of Samson.


McKinney Injured
LEAD: Tamara McKinney, the United States' top female skier, is out for the World Cup season after breaking her left leg in a training spill in Switzerland, Coach Paul Major said yesterday.

Giants Practice at Candlestick With Regrets
LEAD: Two days after an earthquake shook the Bay Area and postponed the third game of the World Series until at least next Tuesday, the San Francisco Giants put on their uniforms at Candlestick Park today for an intrasquad game.
But they seemed almost to be apologizing for playing baseball.

Senate Sends Bush a Bill to Broaden Abortion Aid
LEAD: The Senate sent President Bush a bill today that permits federally financed abortions for poor women who are victims of rape or incest.
Mr.
Bush has said he will veto the measure.

Puerto Rico Bank Merger
LEAD: The Banponce Corporation and the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico agreed today to merge in a deal valued at $324 million, or $56.25 per Banponce share.
The new bank holding company will be called the Banponce Corporation.


Brooklyn Handyman Held in Slayings of 2
LEAD: A part-time handyman was charged late Wednesday in the slaying of a Brooklyn mother and her sister-in-law last month while two young children looked on, the police said.

U.S. Critical on Export
LEAD: Venezuela is subsidizing exports of aluminum sulfate and selling it in the United States at less than fair value, the Commerce Department said today.
It said that if the International Trade Commission finds that the shipments have injured the United States industry, countervailing duties would be imposed.

Ford Will Stop Importing Its German Luxury Sedan
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would discontinue imports of its Scorpio luxury sports sedans from West Germany because of poor sales.
The move would end Ford's attempt to attract buyers of European luxury cars to its Lincoln-Mercury dealerships.


Salvador Epilogue: At Least They're Still Talking
LEAD: The failure of the Salvadoran Government and leftist rebels to reach a single major accord after three days of talks here indicates that any peace agreement may be even harder to negotiate than previously assumed.

LEAD: Ending three days of talks here, Argentina and Britain decided today to resume consular ties and direct air and sea links, clearing the path for substantial normalization of relations, according to a joint statement issued today at the end of three days of talks.

LEAD: A Man in the News article yesterday about Egon Krenz, the new East German leader, referred incorrectly to his native town, Kolberg.

Four Cases of Hepatitis Are Reported at GTE
LEAD: Four employees at GTE Corporation's headquarters, including a cafeteria worker, have been discovered to have hepatitis, and company officials are recommending that everyone who ate in the cafeteria this month have a gamma globulin shot.

Uncovered Short Sales Fall 4.3% on the Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest had dropped 4.3 percent in the four-week period that ended Oct. 13.
Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.


Caterpillar Net Tumbles 43.2%
LEAD: Caterpillar Inc.'s third-quarter earnings tumbled 43.2 percent because of a sales slump that has forced the company to place about 325 employees on indefinite layoff, the company said today.

LEAD: JUST before the sharp recession of 1937, a Wall Street sage, Richard Dana Skinner, said, ''More zeal and energy, more fanatical hope, and more intense anguish have been expended over the past century in efforts to 'forecast' the stock market than in almost any other single line of human action.'' Sam Goldwyn, the fabulous movie producer, put it more succinctly: ''Never make forecasts, especially about the future.

Inflation Outpaces Pay
LEAD: Workers' earnings rose 3.5 percent in the year ended Sept. 30, failing to keep pace with the rate of inflation in the same period, the Labor Department said today.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 473 money market mutual funds surged by $6.07 billion in the latest week to a record $356.1 billion, reflecting investors' moving out of stocks and into more stable investments after the stock market plunge last Friday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

Athletics Still Numb in Aftermath
LEAD: When their meeting was over this afternoon, the Oakland Athletics walked slowly from the clubhouse into the bright sunshine to work out.

Catholics, Condoms and AIDS
LEAD: A draft report by a committee of Catholic bishops strongly rejects the use of condoms to retard the spread of the AIDS virus.
Every religion has the right to set its own doctrine without interference.
But when doctrine affects public health, that's everyone's business.


Roger Mynors, Classical Scholar, 86
LEAD: Sir Roger Mynors, one of Britain's leading classical scholars, was killed Tuesday in a car crash.
He was 86 years old.


Composer's Orchestra
LEAD: The soprano Martina Arroyo will be the soloist with the American Composer's Orchestra in Samuel Barber's ''Andromache's Farewell'' at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon at 3.
Mr.
Barber composed the work for Miss Arroyo, who gave it its premiere at a New York Philharmonic concert in 1962.
The program, which is to be conducted by Dennis Russell Davies, also includes Steve Reich's ''Tehillim'' and the world premieres of William Albright's ''Chasm: Symphonic Fragment'' and Martin Bresnick's ''Pontoosuc.


Blacks Plan Rights March in Chicago
LEAD: It is an unwritten rule of life in Chicago.
Black people do not generally venture into the Bridgeport neighborhood after dark.
Over the years, that rule has been underscored by more than a few beatings and tire-slashings.

A 'Prime' Fund Suspends Sales
LEAD: Officials of the Eaton Vance Prime Rate Reserves Fund said yesterday that they were suspending sales of the popular fund, effective Nov. 1.
The firm is taking the unusual step because its portfolio manager has been unable to invest the almost $1.7 billion of shareholder assets as quickly as the money has come in, they said.

Review/Dance; Some Cows, A Goat and (So to Speak) Real Hoofers
LEAD: There was a lot to watch in ''Can We Dance a Landscape?'' For instance, the cows.
Then came the goat; then the chickens.
The cows appeared first, right when the curtain went up on Wednesday night in the Carey Playhouse of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
They were nice black-and-white cows.
But they were only sculptures, and dancers eventually pushed them offstage.


Adlai S. Hardin Dead; Wood Sculptor Was 88
LEAD: Adlai S. Hardin, a sculptor and former advertising executive, died of complications from a stroke on Monday at the Saybrook Convalescent Hospital in Old Saybrook, Conn.
He was 88 years old.

Camilo Jose Cela Wins Nobel Prize; Spaniard Broke Taboos in the 40's
LEAD: Camilo Jose Cela, regarded as a breaker of literary taboos in the years after the Spanish Civil War, won the Nobel Prize in Literature today.


Ex-Dinkins Worker Says He Used Campaign Money in Vote Effort
LEAD: Robert C. (Sonny) Carson said yesterday that he had used $9,500 from the mayoral campaign of David N. Dinkins for a legitimate get-out-the-vote operation on Primary Day.

Net Off at Media Concern
LEAD: Park Communications Inc., a diversified media company, said this week that after-tax income in the quarter ended Sept. 30 came to $3.86 million, down 2.3 percent from $3.95 million a year earlier.
Earnings per share remained at 19 cents, reflecting the impact of a 3-for-2 stock split.
Revenue for the quarter totaled $39.3 million, up from $39.1 million a year earlier.

Senate's Vote on Flag Move
LEAD: Following is the 51-to-48 roll-call vote by which the Senate failed today to muster the necessary two-thirds vote to approve an amendment to the Constitution protecting the American flag against desecration.
A yes vote was a vote for the amendment; a no vote was a vote against it.
Voting yes were 18 Democrats and 33 Republicans.


Plan Would Reassign Power on Land Use
LEAD: Since land is to New York City what oil is to Houston, it is not surprising that changes in the regulation of land use proposed by the Charter Revision Commission have divided planners, developers, environmentalists and many others.


Dinkins Interview Excerpts About Stock Sale and Taxes
LEAD: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday at The New York Times with David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate for mayor of New York City:  Q. How do you explain that you sold the stock to your son for less than you yourself listed with the state?
A.
You do not mention that repeatedly over the years in the financial disclosure forms filed with the city, that that same stock was listed between, I think, $20,000 and $50,000 or $20,000 and $60,000 or something.


American Express Profit Rose 25.7% in 3d Quarter
LEAD: The American Express Company, the nation's largest financial services company, yesterday reported increases of more than 20 percent in its third-quarter revenue and operating profit, with strong growth in its core business of charge cards.
But it also noted an additional reserve for bad loans at its American Express Bank subsidiary and one-time gains and sluggish growth at its Shearson Lehman


COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: The directors of the Lionel Corporation have rejected an $8-a-share offer from Robert I. Toussie, a New York real estate developer.
The bid is valued at $145 million, including debt.

Note Cites D'Amato H.U.D. Grant Help
LEAD: A 1985 note to a high-ranking Federal housing official said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato was working to obtain a Housing and Urban Development grant for a group headed by a Puerto Rican developer who later became a D'Amato campaign contributor and fund-raiser.


Rowers Aim to Rekindle an Olympic Spirit
LEAD: On a drive down to Philadelphia a couple of weekends ago, Bill Stowe was uneasy.
Stowe, a 49-year-old retired crew coach who is somewhat overweight and out of shape, was about to join other members of the 1964 Olympic eight-oared crew for a venture that he regarded as absurd. ''Crazy,'' he said.
The crew was the last American men's eight to win an Olympic gold medal, something they did in


Amoco Net Slides 39.1%
LEAD: The Amoco Corporation's third-quarter net income tumbled 39.1 percent, to $336 million, or 65 cents a share, from $552 million, or $1.07 a share, in the comparable period in 1988, the giant petroleum company reported yesterday.


Review/Art; Intense Personal Visions Of a Fragile Japanese Artist
LEAD: The 1960's are not so long ago, yet the art history of the period already has its gaps.
One is being filled by the Center for International Contemporary Art, whose inaugural exhibition is a small retrospective of the work of Yayoi Kusama, a Japanese artist active in New York between 1958 and 1972.

LEAD: Elizabeth Firestone Willis, a patron of the arts and a composer, died of heart failure Wednesday at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh.

Social Security Payments To Increase 4.7% Next Year
LEAD: The nation's 38.9 million recipients of Social Security payments will receive a 4.7 percent increase in January, the largest annual cost-of-living adjustment in seven and a half years.


Coke Product Test
LEAD: Coca-Cola Company announced that it would introduce a caffeine-free Coca-Cola Classic in test markets on Monday.
The company said the first test market would be Charlotte, N.C., with others to be named the following week.
The company said a date for national distribution would depend on the test results.

Results Plus
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Red Wings 4, Blues 3: Joe Murphy's unassisted goal with 1 minute 21 seconds remaining remaining capped Detroit's three-goal third-period rally last night in St.
Louis.
Murphy picked up a loose puck near the blue line and beat the rookie goaltender Pat Jablonski to the glove side with a 40-foot shot for his second goal of the game as Detroit (4-4-0) won for the first time on the road.(AP)

MCA Net Down 6.6%
LEAD: MCA Inc. reported today that its third-quarter earnings declined 6.6 percent, to $50.8 million, or 69 cents a share, from $54.3 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier.
The company's revenues increased 12.2 percent, to $918.4 million, from $806.7 million in the period last year.
Despite record revenues, generated partly from box office hits like ''Parenthood'' and ''Uncle Buck,'' earnings dipped because of increased interest expenses caused by higher interest rates and higher average borrowings compared with 1988.


Dr. Peter Dineen, 64, Surgeon and Teacher
LEAD: Dr.
Peter Dineen, a professor and vice chairman of the department of surgery at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan, died of cancer there Tuesday.
He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Review/Theater; Sexual Politics and Tango in 'Dangerous Games'
LEAD: If theater people want to make a spectacle of themselves on a Broadway stage, that is their inalienable right, but whatever happened to the poor audience's right to enjoy a few laughs in the face of such disaster? ''Dangerous Games,'' a new musical misfire at the Nederlander, extinguishes all opportunities for fun by shrouding its inanities in stern sermonettes on sexual politics, dour images from Greek mythology and real-life South American state terrorism.


HomeFed Bank
LEAD: The HomeFed Corporation of San Diego said it had converted its Home Federal Savings and Loan subsidiary to a Federal savings bank, and changed its name to the HomeFed Bank.
The parent company received approval to make the switch last week from the Office of Thrift Supervision.
HomeFed Bank deposits will continue to be insured by the Savings Association Insurance Fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Tragedy's Reservoir
LEAD: Similar stories emerge from natural disasters.
Voices are heard crying in the wreckage.
Someone is saved against all odds.
Someone else expires just as the rescuers arrive.
The pictures are similar, too.
Buildings collapse into playing-card piles.
Pavements are crazed with cracks.
Flames belch from broken gas mains.

Ethics Panel Is Told To Shun Full Inquiry In Gingrich's Case
LEAD: A law firm hired by the House ethics committee to investigate the business dealings of Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, has recommended that the panel conduct no formal investigation, House and other officials said today.


A Sound Course on the Baltics
LEAD: Nothing threatens the improving American-Soviet relations more than potentially explosive nationalism in the Soviet Union, especially in the Baltic States.
If Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia press for independence now, they could undermine Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms or prompt a crackdown.
Either outcome would throw East-West rapprochement into reverse.

LEAD: *

Takeover Offer For A.P. Green
LEAD: East Rock Partners, a private New York investment partnership, has offered to acquire all of the shares of A. P. Green Industries that it does not already control for $40 a share in cash, or a total purchase price of $97.2 million.
Shares of A. P. Green rose $1.875 today, to $38, in the over-the-counter market.

LEAD: The polished brass plate on the door of 43 Eaton Place proclaims that the stately residence is home to the President of the Polish Republic.

Corrections
LEAD: Articles on Wednesday and Thursday about the California earthquake misstated the history of the Marina district of San Francisco.
The district was built on landfill created to make space for the Panama-Pacific International Exposition of 1915, not the Pan-American Pacific Exposition of 1905.


Reviews/Film; Revenge of the Hillbillies
LEAD: ''Next of Kin,'' an appreciably better-than-average revenge drama that opened yesterday at Loew's 84th Street and other theaters, has a taste for novelty.
Its heroes are hillbillies, adrift in the big city.
Its gangster villains run a vending machine concern.
Its final fight to the death takes place in a cemetery, which seems vaguely redundant somehow.


Experts Put Stock Value Higher Than Dinkins Did
LEAD: The communications company at the center of the dispute over David N. Dinkins's stock holdings appears to be a prosperous one, with particularly valuable holdings in radio.
It also owns an interest in a Queens cable franchise and the Apollo Theater.

Review/Music; Refining Tempos in the Mahler Fifth
LEAD: Roughly speaking, there are five ways to decide how fast to play a piece of music.
The first is to follow the composer's metronome markings.
Whether to do so is a thorny question that we are spared in the case of Mahler's Fifth Symphony, which was heard in a tempo-conscious reinterpretation Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Saving for College
LEAD:  There is now a wider choice of college savings plans than ever before.
At least three banks, several states and the Federal Government offer programs that are not subject to the rapid fluctuations of the stock market.
These programs have variable rates tied to various indexes.
They require minimum deposits of $250 to $1,000, and mature in anywhere from 2 to 25 years.

Japanese Steel Export Curb
LEAD: The United States and Japan have agreed to extend Japanese steel export restrictions for 30 more months, the Government announced today.


People Moving Gingerly As They Pick Up Pieces
LEAD: The power is back on today.
The broken pots and televisions and bottles and picture frames have been swept and tossed.
The driveway has been cleared of loose earth.
But Gene Holtan and Elizabeth Sanchez lie awake at night in their Tudor house on Beach Hill, listening to the wind pushing on their creaking chimneys and wonder if life will ever really get back to normal.

THE EARTHQUAKE'S TOLL IN 8 COUNTIES
LEAD:  ALAMEDA: Thirty bodies recovered from collapsed section of Interstate 880.
Maybe 97 to 167 people still missing.
Countywide, 320 injuries reported and $1.3 billion damage.
No water in city of Alameda, near Oakland.
SAN FRANCISCO: Ten deaths; 300 injured.
Mayor's office estimates $2 billion in property losses.

Blackhawks 4, Jets 2: Dirk Graham's short-handed goal in the third period clinched Chicago's victory last night and handed Winnipeg its fifth loss in seven games.(AP)  Sabres 6, Canadians 2: Dave Andreychuk had two goals and an assist and Buffalo erupted for four goals in the third period.


James B. Grant, 71, a Manhattan Lawyer
LEAD: James Benton Grant, a lawyer in Manhattan for 40 years and an avid yachtsman, died of leukemia Thursday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 71 years old and lived in Greenwich.

Intel and Siemens End Biin Venture
LEAD: The Biin Company, a joint venture of the Intel Corporation and Siemens A.G., will be liquidated because no buyer could be found for Biin's manufacturing plant.
Intel and Siemens had sought a buyer for Biin's Hillsboro, Ore., plant because the maker of fault-tolerant computers had failed to find a market for its product, a Biin spokesman, Jess Houdret, said.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1989
LEAD:  Markets


Integrated's Talks On a Sale Resume
LEAD: Integrated Resources Inc. resumed negotiations with an unnamed party to buy its core financial services in an attempt to raise money to help pay off $1.75 billion in debt.
Integrated said Tuesday that the talks had ended.
It said then that a group of its senior executives was considering making an offer.


Kodak in Project On Film Transfer
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and a unit of Britain's Rank Organization P.L.C. are working together to make a high-definition telecine, a machine that transfers film images to video.
Rank Cintel Ltd. is the world's largest producer of conventional telecine machines, which cost between $300,000 and $500,000 each.


Minneapolis Museum Director to Retire
LEAD: Martin Friedman, director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis for 28 years and a prominent figure in the international art world, will retire in November 1990, soon after his 65th birthday.


Editors' Note
LEAD: This is the last Saturday News Quiz.


Roll-Call Vote on Hastings
LEAD: Following is the 69-to-26 roll-call vote by which the Senate today convicted Judge Alcee L. Hastings on Article I of 17 impeachment articles relating to bribery.
A two-thirds vote was required for conviction.
Article I was the main count against Judge Hastings, and a vote for conviction on any single count was sufficient to remove him from office.

Review/Music; An Irish Mix Of Rock Beat And Folk
LEAD: The Waterboys, an Irish group that mixes folk instrumentation and melodies with the raw power of rock, came to the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night and had the audience dancing in the aisles.
The show, which was sold out, was another reminder of exactly how popular folk-based rock has become over the last five years.


Otto Dohrenwend, 90, Investment Broker
LEAD: Otto E. Dohrenwend, a retired New York investment broker, died Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y., after a long illness.
He was 90 years old.

Sir Anthony Quayle, British Actor And Theater Director, Dies at 76
LEAD: Sir Anthony Quayle, a versatile actor and director who helped establish Stratford-on-Avon as a major center of British theater, died of cancer yesterday at his home in London.
He was 76 years old.


Vandeweghe Unlikely to Play in Opener
LEAD: Kiki Vandeweghe, the Knicks forward who has a history of back problems and is now suffering from back spasms, will probably not be ready to play when the National Basketball Association's regular season begins on Nov. 3.

Corrections
LEAD: A chart on Thursday explaining how the magnitude of earthquakes is measured and an article yesterday about a Japanese fund for victims of the California earthquake gave incorrect dates for the Great Kanto Earthquake in central Japan.
It occurred in 1923.


Samuel Pulitzer, 84, A Maker of Neckwear
LEAD: Samuel C. Pulitzer, founder and chief executive officer of the Wemco Corporation of New Orleans, one of the world's biggest manufacturers of neckwear, died of cancer yesterday at Touro Infirmary in New Orleans.
He was 84 years old and lived in New Orleans.

Soviets Show Wallenberg's Jail Card
LEAD: After decades of insisting that they had no evidence or documents about the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat arrested by Soviet troops after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, the Soviet authorities today showed Mr.
Wallenberg's friends and family the card registering him as a prisoner of war in Lubyanka Prison here.

LEAD: The Giants' success against the Chargers in San Diego on Sunday may depend on how well the Giants contain Anthony Miller, the Chargers' swift second-year wide receiver.

Reviews/Music; A Bernstein Celebration of Copland
LEAD: For virtually all of Leonard Bernstein's professional career, the works of Aaron Copland have been woven through the texture of his life.
The two friends and composing colleagues have been the warp and weft of American music for so long that they seem to make up one long-wearing fabric.


World Reaching Out To Boy Who Lost Leg
LEAD: Offers of money, toys and even a new home poured in from many parts of the world today for Julio Berumen, the 6-year-old boy who was rescued from the Interstate 880 wreckage only through amputation of much of his right leg.

LEAD: The stock market yesterday completed its best week in 16 months with a mixed performance, although futures-related buying at the close pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to a small gain.

Brooklyn Man Admits Killing 5-Year-Old Girl

Dun &amp; Bradstreet Up
LEAD: The Dun &amp; Bradstreet Corporation announced this week that its third-quarter earnings rose 15.2 percent despite a drop in revenue.
The business information company said it earned $155.3 million, or 83 cents a share, up from $134.8 million, or 72 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1988.
Revenue declined to $1.04 billion, from $1.07 billion a year earlier.

Nilsson to Give Master Class

Justice Delays Iran-Contra Justice
LEAD: Twice this year, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has intruded in Iran-contra criminal cases to appeal decisions on the use of national secrets as evidence.
Each time, a Federal Court of Appeals has ruled that the independent counsel on Iran-contra matters, Lawrence Walsh, has the unfettered right to represent the Government in court.


Dancing for Graham: Disciple's Story
LEAD: Christine Dakin leans back in her chair, wryly recalling the time she hurried back to ballet class to develop a high battement, or kick, for Martha Graham's pure-dance ''Diversion of Angels.'' The results proved almost too good, soon after in rehearsal. ''I did a battement, hit myself in the head and fell down,'' she said.

THE INNER CITY STOCK TRANSFERS
LEAD:  May 8, 1972: David N. Dinkins buys 50 shares of class A common stock in Inner City Broadcasting Corp. for $5,000, or $100 per share.  1982 and 1983: Mr.
Dinkins acquires 24 more shares at $275 per share.
He receives 10 shares as a dividend.
May 11, 1983: Mr.
Dinkins, in a letter to Governor Cuomo's office, says the asset value of the 84 shares is $1,009,230.60, or $12,014.65 per share.

LEAD: Citing weaker prices for memory chips, Texas Instruments Inc. said today that its net income in the third quarter fell 30.6 percent.


Chicago Exchange Head
LEAD: The chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, Karsten Mahlmann, will seek an unprecedented fourth consecutive term as head of the world's largest commodity futures exchange.
In a three-page letter mailed to Board of Trade members this week, Mr.
Mahlmann said mounting threats to the traditional open-outcry system persuaded him to run for another one-year term.

Patents; Synthetic Blood
LEAD: Motivated in part by the danger of transmitting contagious diseases through blood transfusions, as well as by periodic scarcities in supplies, two chemists have patented a synthetic blood.
The blood consists of hemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying molecule in red blood cells, encapsulated in bubbles that have the consistency of Jell-O.

Taiwan Draws Investors
LEAD: New securities firms and investors are continuing to enter Taiwan's vibrant stock market, the country's Securities and Exchange Comission said today.

Patents; Sewage Sludge Used To Make Bricks and Tile
LEAD: The Fujimi Tile Company of Nagoya, Japan, has patented a method for making ceramic bricks and tile out of sewage sludge.
The process begins by burning the sludge into ash and then mixing the ash with ceramic raw materials, including debris from making conventional tiles, to form a clay that can be molded and baked.

Taiwan-China Trade
LEAD: Political turmoil in China slowed the growth in trade between Taiwan and the mainland in August, the Board of Foreign Trade said today.

LEAD: Insurance companies operate in the shadow of the ''big ones.'' These are the brutal storms and earthquakes that strike every so often, crippling cities and forcing insurers to write out bundles of checks.

Tenderized, 'Cured' Meats With Marinade
LEAD: MARINATING accomplishes many purposes.
It is an excellent method of providing flavor.
It also tenderizes and even cures foods, pickling or ''cooking'' them in acid.
How long a food is left in a marinade depends on what the final product should be as well as the character of the main ingredient.
The following recipes illustrate these points.

LEAD: I have spent the last 33 years with the Huntington School District.
When I began in 1956, we had one superintendent and an assistant superintendent.
There were no therapists or teachers for the blind.
We did have three classes for the ''retarded.'' Classes for the learning disabled, emotionally disturbed and handicapped were unknown.

David Hare Captures His Muse on Stage
LEAD: WHen the British playwright David Hare sat down to write ''The Secret Rapture,'' a strong and striking image came into his head.
It was of a youngish woman sitting quietly in the dark beside the bed in which her father lay dead.
He wasn't altogether sure what she'd do or where she'd go, but he knew at once who would, who must embody the character in the theater: the actress Blair Brown.

The Disorder of Dismantling Apartheid
LEAD: SOUTH AFRICA'S new President, F. W. de Klerk, has been trying to buy time and good will for his promised program of evolutionary changes, but in some ways his efforts are only creating new problems.

A Walk Into the Past and Future
LEAD: I WALK every morning, a habit I acquired after the death of my father.
He followed his daily schedule of walking until the day he died - I remember him going out even during the bombing of Seoul.
I also do it because my doctor told me when I was in for my checkup that my cholesterol level is in the high-risk range.


Review/Theater; Vietnam Veterans Ensemble in 'The Ambassador'
LEAD: In his plays, Slawomir Mrozek mixes art and polemics.
Sometimes, as in ''Tango'' and ''Emigres,'' his sense of theater is as strong as his political awareness.
This is not the case with ''The Ambassador,'' receiving its United States premiere at the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company.
With politics taking precedence, the narrative becomes a thin thread on which to hang the author's inquiry into the nature of dissidence and diplomacy during a time of subversion.

Bereavement
LEAD: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on bereavement fares (Practical Traveler, Sept. 10) was especially timely.
I had to attend a funeral on Labor Day.
After the news of the death on Saturday evening, I telephoned USAir and requested a bereavement fare for a flight the next morning.
The reservations clerk was extremely helpful and said that USAir offered a special fare of $360.

The tights and cat suits are blends of synthetic stretch fibers, cotton and wool.
They fit snugly, enhancing and seeming to extend the figure.

Needlework Stories Tell of Chilean Life
LEAD: THE collection of 71 Chilean arpilleras owned by the William Benton Museum of Art of the University of Connecticut is seldom on display at the red-brick institution on the campus in Storrs.
The bright primitive wall hangings depicting particular events and the hardships of daily life under the Pinochet regime were acquired two years ago to be used as educational tools.

LEAD: ''Dark Meadow,'' a 1946 work that the Martha Graham Dance Company presented last Sunday night at the City Center Theater, is both allegorically complex and ambiguous.

There are mythological motifs borrowed from many cultures, as well as recurrent symbols of sex, martyrdom, death and resurrection.

PASTIMES: Stamps
LEAD: A scrap of blue and red paper sold for $1 million this month.
For the arithmetically minded, this bit of paper, the plate block from the sheet of Inverted Jenny airmail stamps, is 2 1/2 inches square.
Thus the anonymous broadcast executive who bought the block at a Christie's auction paid the equivalent of $23 million a square foot, or $1 trillion dollars an acre.

These options include adopting infants or children from other countries, those with special needs or older children.

I.B.M.'s Urbane New Place in the Sun in Texas
LEAD: The first sign that Solana is not like other suburban office parks is the three 100-foot-tall pylons - one magenta, one purple, one yellow - that stand in the rolling Texas prairie like pieces of a gargantuan building toy left in a thousand-acre backyard.
The pylons announce Solana's presence from a mile down the freeway, and they foretell the nature of its architecture, a series of stucco-clad buildings with intense, rich color and a surprisingly urbane presence.

Noriega Might Stay, But the Canal Will Go On
LEAD: UNDER the Panama Canal treaties, a Panamanian is supposed to take over as administrator of the waterway on Jan. 1.
But in the last few weeks, the Bush Administration has made clear that that will not happen if Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega is still ruling Panama.
Nevertheless, the canal will continue operating regardless of whether General Noriega retains or surrenders power, American officials say.

Tenderized, 'Cured' Meats With Marinade

It is an excellent method of providing flavor.
It also tenderizes and even cures foods, pickling or ''cooking'' them in acid.
How long a food is left in a marinade depends on what the final product should be as well as the character of the main ingredient.

PASTIMES: Coins
LEAD: Flipping through the November auction catalogue of Bowers and Merena, Inc., the auction house in Wolfeboro, N.H., one is struck by the great number and diversity of coins.
They range from New Jersey coppers to counterfeits to medical tokens.
But the last entry, an obscure 1744 Austrian token, has politics, religion and sex, three things that mothers say should never be discussed at dinner.

Bereavement
LEAD: To The Editor: The article on bereavement fares could not have been more timely for my family.
My wife's mother had passed away that morning in Buffalo, and she had already made regular fare reservations to fly there that evening.
After reading your article, my wife called back to USAir and was able to change the reservations for herself and our daughter, resulting in a savings of $172.

LEAD:  TO LIVE LIKE EVERYONE.
By Anatoly Marchenko.
Translated by Paul Goldberg. (Holt, $19.95.) In 1966, Anatoly Marchenko had a brief respite from what was to become a long career as a political prisoner in the Soviet Union.
Before his incarceration in 1958 - he was jailed once in the wake of a workers' brawl and again after a near-escape into Iran - Marchenko had been a young, self-satisfied construction foreman.

Tenderized, 'Cured' Meats With Marinade
LEAD: MARINATING accomplishes many purposes.
It is an excellent method of providing flavor.
It also tenderizes and even cures foods, pickling or ''cooking'' them in acid.
How long a food is left in a marinade depends on what the final product should be as well as the character of the main ingredient.
The following recipes illustrate these points.


New &amp;Noteworthy
LEAD:  OUT OF THIS WORLD, by Graham Swift. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $7.95.) As Harry Beech, an aerial photographer, flies over the English landscape, his daughter lies on a psychoanalyst's couch in Manhattan.
Both try to figure out how their relationship went wrong. ''Not a book the reader is likely to forget, 'Out of This World' deserves to be ranked at the forefront of contemporary literature,'' Linda Gray Sexton said here last year.


An Opera Company In Search of Itself
LEAD: Lazarus rose from the dead only once; the New York City Opera has done it again and again during its 45-year history.
Depending on how an observer scores on the optimism/pessimism scale, the record of narrow escapes from the grave is either a proof of vitality or evidence of incurable sickness.
The company, for all its periodic staggering, has been a survivor in one of art's tougher neighborhoods: popular-priced opera.

'You Are a Dog'
LEAD: They blindfolded him and handcuffed him with his hands behind his back.
Soldiers whispered in his ear, ''You are a dog.'' After putting a cloth in his mouth to keep him from screaming, they burned him with a cigarette on his ear and hand.
Then they took him into a bathroom and made him lie on the tile floor.

A New Leader Carries On An Orchestra's Tradition
LEAD: In the first three decades of the microgroove era, there was no symphonic ensemble more conspicuous in the form of recordings than the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande, which London/Decca seemed to favor for introducing each successive development in the technique of sound recording.
The orchestra, founded in 1918 by Ernest Ansermet, achieved international recognition as a direct result of its recording activity, which kept it so busy at its home base in Geneva that there was little time for touring until relatively recently.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, trying to clear an issue that has cast a shadow on his plans to visit Warsaw next month, said today that West Germany had no territorial claims on Poland.


Life, and Death, in the Fast Lane
LEAD: From skiing to surfing, California is a state of exhilarating extremes, and perils.
Even with respect to risk, Californians cover the spectrum.
A law passed by popular ballot in 1986 requires warning labels on any food whose ingredients have a 1-in-100,000 chance of causing cancer.
Yet, as Tuesday's tremor hammered home, tens of thousands could be killed in the truly major earthquake that might strike at any time.

Hectic Recovery For Stock Prices
LEAD: Stocks came back after the Friday the 13th plunge of 190 points.
Sell orders poured in when the markets opened on Monday and the Dow Jones industrial average had an early 60- point loss but the market turned around within about an hour and the day ended with the Dow up 88 points.
Volume on Monday was 416 million shares, the fourth-busiest day ever.

Gosdin was his songs, which are the work of a specialist - or a man obsessed.

The Fed's New Tool Just Doesn't Work
LEAD: The research staff of the board of Governors of the Federal Reserve has developed what is described as a new method for forecasting inflation.
The announcement of this new construct brought a great deal of publicity.
The equation, which is called P-Star, is a throwback to strict monetarism in its most primitive form.


PASTIMES: Chess
LEAD: The exchange sacrifice is the one offer that players who have sworn off sacrifices will still venture.
That's because so much of the time an exchange sacrifice is really more a kind of positional investment than a bludgeon of attack.


Don't Mess With Gramm-Rudman
LEAD: Pressure is building to revise Gramm-Rudman, the budget-balancing legislation enacted in 1985 and amended in 1987.
Indeed, Congress seems to be on the verge of adopting a pattern of amending the law every two years.
This year the argument for revising the targets will have a new and powerful twist: the need to protect people's retirement checks by segregating the Social Security accounts from the rest of the budget for deficit reduction purposes.

VLAD RYBAKOV  Rego Park, Queens


Why the Road Turned Rocky for 'Old Gringo'
LEAD: When the movie ''Old Gringo'' was being filmed here early in 1988, it seemed to everyone involved to have all the prerequisites for great artistic and commercial success.
In Gregory Peck and Jane Fonda, the film boasted two big names, paired with each other for the first time.
The Carlos Fuentes novel on which the script was based offered a story full of passion, both political and erotic, and intelligence.

IN RESTAURANTS IN NEW York, a synchronized activity begins.
Women open their compacts and swiftly pat noses, cheeks, chins.


Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: Earlier this year my husband and I took a tour of Portugal and Spain.
We enjoyed Portugal and its people.
However, in Seville, we were victims of a purse snatching.
We were aware that we should carry nothing of value on the streets, I needed to carry my sunglasses and medication -- and that's all the thieves got.

Review/Theater; Scenes From Memory In 'Bronx Tale,' a Solo
LEAD: Chazz Palminteri's one-man play ''A Bronx Tale'' is the theatrical equivalent of sprawling streetwise rock songs like Bruce Springsteen's ''Jungleland'' and Billy Joel's ''Scenes From an Italian Restaurant.'' Performing on a set that impressionistically re-creates the corner of 187th Street and Belmont Avenue in 1960, the New York-born actor and writer spins a vivid true story of his own childhood and adolescence when he was taken under the wing of a neighborhood gangster named Little

Mansion Melodies and Mini-Concerts
LEAD: THE pumpkins reach the Old Ferry Dock in Beacon this afternoon, and then resume their sail to other towns along the Hudson.
It is the annual Pumpkin Festival, when huge piles of the gourds are offloaded from the sloop Clearwater each day while its crew is on call for ballad-singing, story-telling and ecological discussions.


The Pendulum Swings Away From Cynicism
LEAD: In the 1980's art has seemed to suffer from a fin-de-siecle anxiety.
The source of that anxiety has been a fundamental skepticism about the possibility of ''making it new.'' Instead of seeming limitless, culture and the world itself have come to be seen as finite, closed systems that have been depleted by overuse.

FICTION
LEAD:  THE DEAD PULL HITTER.
By Alison Gordon. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Mystery buffs who also happen to be baseball fans can enjoy both pastimes at once in ''The Dead Pull Hitter,'' an energetic first novel by the Toronto sportswriter Alison Gordon.
The lineup of Ms.
Gordon's fictional Toronto Titans includes all the archetypes of baseball lore - crafty veterans and insufferable superstars, good-hearted heroes and washed-up sluggers struggling to eke out one more season.


Pipe Organs
LEAD: To the Editor: As a longtime organist, I share Craig R. Whitney's enthusiasm for experiencing various instruments (''Pursuing Pipe Organs of Note,'' Travel, Aug. 13) and, like him, I am well aware that no two pipe organs sound alike.


TOUGH TIMES FOR MR. LEVITTOWN
LEAD: My parents' first house was built by the Levitts, in Levittown, L.I. (''Tough Times for Mr. Levittown,'' by Michael T. Kaufman, Sept. 24).
I look back on it fondly.
It was nicely laid out, had a fireplace and the floors were always warm.
The neighborhood was friendly, with lots of kids to play with.


Reviews/Music; Schiff's Central European Assortment
LEAD: Sometimes the art of program-making rightly usurps the normal pleasures that attend concertgoing.
Sometimes the very intelligence with which an artist has juxtaposed scores on a program seems so arresting that it takes natural precedence over the individual pieces or their performance, however excellent they may be.


Patients Dance Into the Unconscious
LEAD: IN place of a psychiatrist's couch, there is a piano, an easel or just an open room.
In place of lengthy conversations about ego and relationships, patients paint, sing, dance or create a drama about their feelings.
This is therapy?
For thousands of people in Connecticut it is.
Whether frustrated with conventional psychotherapy or simply curious about a different approach, they enlist the help a creative arts therapist who uses dance, drama, art, music or poetry as the basis of psychological treatment.


A Jury Awards $1.3 Million To Parents Whose Son Died
LEAD: The parents of a 12-year-old Waterbury boy who died shortly after his release from Yale-New Haven Hospital, where he was being treated for a heart condition, have been awarded more than $1.3 million by a Superior Court jury.

LEAD: A season-ending men's tournament, in which the winner will get $2 million, has been set up by the International Tennis Federation, which said the $6 million Grand Slam Cup would be the richest tennis tournament in the world.

LEAD: Smiling and waving his right hand, a man was pulled alive this morning from the wreckage of the highway overpass that collapsed in Tuesday's earthquake.

I.R.A. Gunmen Kill an Officer
LEAD: Gunmen ambushed a police car in South Armagh province, killing an officer and wounding another, the police said today.
The Irish Republican Army in South Armagh asserted responsibility for the machine-gun attack in Belleek, about 10 miles north of the border with the Irish Republic.
Constable Michael Marshall, 25 years old, died instantly, the police said.

The good news?

LEAD: While pounding new heel guards onto a man's ailing loafers, Donald Leafloor wrinkled up his nose and talked about the meaning of shoes. ''People get unbelievably attached to their shoes,'' he said. ''They know that their feet will love them if they put on a good pair.
So people have their favorite shoes and they hate to lose them.

Summer Skiing
LEAD: To the Editor: Summertime skiing in South America (Travel Section, Aug. 20) certainly whetted the appetite of this ardent skier.
However, spending $2,000 to $3,000 a couple for a week skiing a South American winter wonderland is a major deterrent, which probably accounts for the paucity of North Americans at their resorts.

Corrections
LEAD: A headline on Sept. 24 about lodgings in Scotland misstated the scope of the listing.
It included the Shetland Islands, not just the Highlands.


Hospitals Ready for Bitter Battle On Rate Increases
LEAD: THE average patient in a Connecticut hospital in the year ending Sept. 30 incurred a bill of $5,872.37.
Under budgets proposed by the state's 34 general hospitals for the current year, that same patient would pay nearly $6,900, an increase of 18.8 percent, and the magnitude of that increase has shocked state officials and the businesses that would pay higher health insurance premiums to support those rates.
