Bereavement
LEAD: To the Editor: On Sept. 9 my father passed away in Maine.
We contacted Continental and told them that we had a death in the family.
They did not offer any special rate, and I had to pay $320 one way to Maine.
The next day your story appeared, so when I returned to Florida I called customer service.

By Barry Rubin. (McGraw-Hill, $18.95.) Throughout World War II, neutral Turkey remained an oasis attracting refugees, political plotters, deserters, profiteers, assassins, international beauties, journalists and spies.

Conjured by Calder
LEAD: ''The intimate world of Alexander Calder'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is as much fun as any exhibition we can hope to see.
But, quite apart from being so much fun, it is also a lesson in life, for Calder had in a high degree the gift of metamorphosis.
The first thing we learn from this exhibition is that in the everyday things around him - a clothespin, a cork, a fishbone, a discarded can of this or that - he saw disinherited ingredients that could be put to magical use.

LEAD: Ever since Jose Canseco lined a grand-slam over the center-field fence at Dodger Stadium in last year's World Series opener, he has had 24 consecutive official Series times at bat without a hit.
For a slugger of his stature, he's in the worst possible slump at the worst possible time.
But when he was told that Marv Owen, a third baseman for the Detroit Tigers more than half a century ago, held the Series record with 31 consecutive hitless times at bat, the Athletics' right fielder smiled.

Pop Musical Cultures Mined and Mingled
LEAD: Border-crossing has become a 1980's rock ritual.
One after another, songwriters become infatuated with some ''exotic'' music, decide to make an album under its influence and collaborate with the top musicians available.
At best, star and collaborators inspire one another to synergistic heights.
Failing that, the star's fans may have their ears opened, and some might seek out the original sources (which are likely to reach more record stores in the wake of a cross-cultural hit album).

IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Cold Spring
LEAD: FOR 93 years, the foundry in Cold Spring - just across the Hudson River from the United States Military Academy at West Point - turned out iron smelted from ore in the nearby hills.
Set up with $25,000 allocated by Congress in 1818 and drawing craftsmen from Ireland, Scotland, Wales and England, it made cannon and cannon balls for the Union Army in the Civil War and parts for the first American locomotive.

The Serendipitous Appeal of Eurailpass
LEAD: WHEN the Eurailpass was introduced by the railroads of Europe in 1959, Americans of our generation instantly recognized our travel ideal in an affordable ticket offering unlimited access for a set period to all the trains that crisscrossed the Continent.
We were young adventurers, about to become children of the 1960's, and we valued the very things that the Eurailpass not only made possible but also celebrated: thrift, spontaneity, simplicity, a sense of camaraderie with other travelers and the opportunity for contact with local people.

Review/Music; Vietnamese Pianist in U.S. Debut
LEAD: A pianist of considerable abilities made his American debut at the 92d Street Y Thursday night.
Dang Thai Son was the winner of the 1980 Chopin Competition in Warsaw, and has garnered various other honors over the past decade.
It was possible to hear something of the consensus-oriented approach we often worry about with competition pianists in his polished, secure, unmannered playing, but there was no mistaking a true and varied command of the instrument and a feeling for musical shapes and pianistic textures that could yet blossom into true interpretative individuality.

LEAD: The Brussels stock exchange computer, which went out of operation early last week, will resume operating on Tuesday, the exchange's chairman, Jean Peterbroeck, said.

How, asks Lewis H. Lapham, the writer and narrator, has American power manifested itself in the 20th century?
Why did it rise so fast in the first half of the century?
What accounts for its slow decline during the second half?

LEAD: Leaders of the 49-nation Commonwealth moved today to tighten financial pressure on South Africa and said Pretoria would face new reprisals in six months if it failed to deliver on promises to dismantle apartheid.
Britain alone dissented.

Edward Diamond of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Martin Sacks, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Sidney Sacks of Dresher, Pa.
Rabbi Helene Ferris officiated.
Mrs.
Diamond-Sacks, who graduated with distinction from the University of Virginia and received a master's of management degree from Northwestern University, is a product manager for the Rorer Corporation, a pharmaceuticals company in Fort Washington, Pa.

LEAD: A busy weekend of prep races failed to winnow many candidates or crown any strong new favorites for the Breeders' Cup races at Gulfstream Park Nov. 4.
When preliminary entries are taken today, the fields for five of the seven cup races are likely to be large and lacking a strong favorite.

LEAD: Acknowledging that New York City faces ''difficult times'' financially, David N. Dinkins, the Democratic mayoral candidate, said yesterday that he would be prepared to cut city spending - except for the Police Department - by 1 percent to reduce a looming budget deficit.

LEAD: In 1980, private citizen George Bush said he opposed Federal funds for abortion except in cases of rape, incest or threats to the mother's life.
In 1984, Vice Presidential candidate George Bush couldn't recall having said that; indeed, he said he opposed exceptions.
A week ago, President George Bush repeated that opposition but left ''room for flexibility.


Nicaraguans Register in Huge Numbers
LEAD: Nicaraguans jammed voter registration stations here today for the fourth consecutive Sunday in what diplomats described as an ''overwhelming'' response to preparations for national elections in February.


'Machinal' Is Canceled
LEAD: The Equity Library Theater's production of Sophie Treadwell's 1928 play ''Machinal,'' which was to have opened Nov. 2, has been canceled because of financial problems.
The company plans to resume the season with Keith Reddin's ''Big Time'' on Nov. 30.
The theater's board will meet in the next two weeks to assess the continuation of the season.

Albans section of Queens, and two suspects were arrested, the police said.

Question Box
LEAD:  The Winning Runs  Q. Three World Series come to mind that ended when the winning run was scored in the bottom of the last inning: 1960, when Bill Mazeroski of Pittsburgh hit a leadoff home run off Ralph Terry that beat the Yankees in Game 7; 1953, when Billy Martin of the Yankees singled home Hank Bauer to beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in six games, and 1935, when Goose Goslin of Detroit singled home Mickey Cochrane in the sixth game against the Chicago Cubs.

LEAD: ''We've been shaken, we've been jolted, but we're saying yes to life.
And it's important for us to be shaken - rich, poor and middle class.
This quake shook us all, and now we have a common problem and need common solutions.''  -the Rev.
Cecil Williams of San Francisco.  [ A1:1. ]

Coal Mine Strike in Siberia
LEAD: As many as 20,000 Siberian coal miners defied an official ban and mounted a protest strike today, raising the prospect of more industrial unrest before of the harsh Russian winter.
Tass said pit workers in the city of Mezhdurechensk, who began a wave of strikes that paralyzed the Soviet coal industry in July, stopped work again for two hours to protest the failure to implement pledges made to them by management.

Chess
LEAD: In the two semifinal world championship candidates matches, which ended Oct. 17 in London, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union defeated his countryman Artur Yusupov and Jan Timman of the Netherlands defeated Jonathan Speelman of Britain.
Karpov and Timman will meet in the final in London in March to determine the next challenger for the titleholder, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union.

Eastern Quakes: Real Risk, Few Precautions
LEAD: AN EARTHQUAKE as powerful as the one that struck northern California last week could occur almost anywhere along the East Coast, experts say.
And if it did, it would probably cause far more destruction than the West Coast quake.


Bickering Splits Westchester's Legislature
LEAD: As Election Day draws near, any vestiges of civility have slipped out under the giant wood panel doors of the chambers here of the Westchester County Legislature, where every seat is up for grabs.


Reagan Given Top Award By Japanese
LEAD: Ronald Reagan was hailed, honored and generally treated like a head of state today while Japanese leaders fondly recalled his Presidency as a time of fewer frictions over trade and other issues.


Judge Hastings, Fairly Judged
LEAD: Impeachments by the House and trials in the Senate are so cumbersome and distasteful that Alcee Hastings of Florida is only the sixth Federal judge to be removed in this manner.
But in convicting and removing Judge Hastings, despite his acquittal of similar charges at a criminal trial, Congress acted responsibly, even judiciously.


Problems Loom in Effort to Control Use of Chemicals for Illicit Drugs
LEAD: FRUSTRATED by the failure to stop the flood of drugs into the country, leaders of America's battle against drugs are seeking to restrict supplies of key ingredients and processing chemicals required to make illegal substances.
But many experts believe the effort is doomed to failure by the seemingly endless alternative methods of synthesizing drugs that technically skilled criminals have devised.

The Welfare War Between the States
LEAD: Much has been written about the wars waged between states to attract new jobs.
A similar war is being waged in welfare reform.
Some states keep welfare benefits low so that some of their residents will move to more socially responsible states.

Israel Crausman, 90, Architect in New York
LEAD: Israel L. Crausman, an architect and engineer, died of heart disease on Sunday at his home in Spring Valley, N.Y.
He was 90 years old.
Mr.
Crausman was born in Bessarabia, now part of the Soviet Union, and came here with his family at the age of 13.
He graduated from Cooper Union six years later with architectural and engineering degrees.

New Indignities for Refugees in Japan
LEAD: Before a small group of Vietnamese were resettled in eastern Tokyo recently, the Japanese authorities had to assure nearby residents that the refugee centers would have showers.
The neighbors were worried that the refugees might mingle with them in the local public baths.

LEAD: Richard J. Condon was sworn in yesterday as New York City's 35th Police Commissioner a few minutes after Mayor Edward I. Koch promised that he would not cut the hiring of police officers to balance the municipal budget.

LEAD: Huge explosions at a petrochemical complex on the Houston Ship Channel today injured more than 100 workers, sent debris flying for miles and started a fire that burned out of control for hours.

Manville's Trust for Asbestos Victims Runs Low
LEAD: The trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos has almost run out of money.
As a result, tens of thousands of people with asbestosis, lung cancer and other often fatal diseases who ask the trust for money this year will have to wait 25 years before being compensated, the trust estimates.

LEAD: Executives of NBC News said yesterday that errors in news judgment, transmission problems and a lack of experienced technical personnel had contributed to the division's failure last week to provide competitive coverage in the first 90 minutes after the earthquake struck San Francisco.

Stocks Drop Broadly; Dow Off 26.23 Points
LEAD: Stocks dropped broadly yesterday, as investors focused on a faltering economy, weakening corporate profits and a stagnant dollar.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 26.23 points, or about 1 percent, to 2,662.91.


Magazine Executives Celebrate Their Industry's Revival
LEAD: The publishers and editors of America's magazines have gathered at this resort community on Florida's southwest coast this week to celebrate their industry's renewed prosperity.
The Annual Magazine Conference comes at a time when circulation is rising, new titles are proliferating and advertising revenue share -coaxed away from television - is increasing.

LEAD: Hungary today marked the 33d anniversary of the violent uprising against Soviet rule in 1956 by peacefully scrapping the ''socialist people's'' label and proclaiming itself a republic.

Savings Outflow In August
LEAD: The savings industry lost billions of dollars in deposits in August as the tough new capital requirements set by the savings and loan rescue forced executives to shrink the size of their institutions, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.

Hong Kong-Beijing Immigrant Rift Ends
LEAD: A diplomatic dispute between Hong Kong and China was resolved today when officials here announced that Beijing had agreed to resume accepting the return of Chinese illegal immigrants who have crossed into the colony.


Santa Fe Talking To Pension Fund
LEAD: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said its Santa Fe Pacific Realty Corporation unit is negotiating with the California Public Employees Retirement System to issue the pension fund stock representing a 20 percent stake in the unit.
Before the transaction is complete, the realty company would issue debt that, when combined with the money it will receive from the pension fund, will enable it to pay back more than $500 million of debt owed to the parent company.

Review/Television; AIDS Quilt and the Stories Behind Its Symbols
LEAD: As of this past summer, the number of deaths among Americans with AIDS rose to more than 59,000, higher than the total fatalities in the Vietnam War.
Yet the vast majority of people with AIDS remain virtually invisible on prime-time television.
There is one obvious reason.
The groups most affected so far, male homosexuals and drug users, are considered by many to be social outsiders.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Salt in the Sea  Q.Why is the ocean salty?
A.Rocks that erode on the continents contain salt, which is brought by the rivers to the ocean, said Harmon Craig, professor of geochemistry and oceanography at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California at San Diego.

Prime Planning 2,500 Layoffs
LEAD: Prime Computer Inc. said today that it would lay off 2,500 employees, or about 20 percent of its employees.


Wall St. Journal To Raise Rates
LEAD: The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that it would raise national advertising rates 4 percent next year.
The increase is smaller than the 6.5 percent of 1989 because the cost of newsprint and postage has not risen this year, said Roger May, a spokesman for The Journal. ''We wanted to share that with our customers,'' he said.

Solidarity Struggles - With Democracy
LEAD: It's a thrill to watch former political prisoners and underground Solidarity activists sitting in the august chamber of Poland's new Parliament, debating budget bills and tax legislation.
This is the Communist world's most dramatic revolution so far.
It is also sobering to see how difficult the construction of a democratic system of government is proving to be, mechanically and psychologically.


New Haven Register Sold
LEAD: Goodson Newspaper Group Inc., headed by the television pioneer Mark Goodson, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell The New Haven Register to the Ingersoll Publications Company for more than $275 million.


Ogilvy Group's Chairman Resigns
LEAD: A little more than a year after becoming chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group, the world's seventh-largest advertising agency, Kenneth Roman resigned yesterday.
His departure after 26 years at the company comes just five months after he lost a takeover battle to the WPP Group, the London-based marketing and communications company that also owns J.


Net Rises 14% At McDonald's
LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation today reported a 14 percent increase in its third-quarter earnings, attributed largely to strong sales overseas and the success of domestic promotional programs.

The California Quake; Bay Area's Commuters Find a New Way to Go: Mass Transit
LEAD: After surprisingly smooth traveling on the first full workday after last week's devastating earthquake, local transit and city officials wondered if the long weeks without the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and one of its key feeder highways, the Nimitz Freeway, would substantially alter the travel habits of local residents.


David Victor Dies; Produced 'Kildare' And Other TV Series
LEAD: David Victor, a producer of numerous television series including ''Dr.
Kildare'' and ''Marcus Welby, M.D.,'' died after a heart attack on Oct. 18 while he and his wife, Florence, were vacationing in Williamsburg, Va.
He was 79 years old and lived in Los Angeles.


British TV on Eve of Competitive Era
LEAD: On the eve of legislation to change the face of British television by 1992, viewers, critics and broadcasters are debating whether more commercial competition will lead to lower standards on the air.


The Chancellor's Handcuffs
LEAD: Even though Joseph Fernandez will not take office formally until January as New York City's schools chancellor, he is off to a promising start.
His initiative deserves more energetic support than it's getting from Albany.

Tapes of School Officials: Ante Becomes 'Little Higher'
LEAD: These are excerpts from conversations taped by Colman Genn, superintendent of School District 27 in Queens, with James C. Sullivan, the school board treasurer, Samuel Granirer, board vice president, and William Sampol, a former Republican state legislative aide seeking a $42,000-a-year district job, and others over a course of seven months.


For Storage, New Disks Gain Ground On Floppies
LEAD: CD-ROM, which stands for Compact Disk Read Only Memory, is the nerdy cousin of the audio compact disk's that are replacing conventional phonograph albums.
While a single five-inch audio CD can hold an hour's worth of Beethoven or The Austin Lounge Lizards, an identical computer CD-ROM disk can hold 550 to 600 megabytes of data, the equivalent storage capacity of hundreds of floppy diskettes.


U.S. Attorney Is Said to Be Investigating Con Edison in Steam Blast
LEAD: Con Edison is under investigation by the United States Attorney's office in connection with the explosion of an asbestos-lined steam pipe in Gramercy Park, a top Federal environmental official told a Congressional hearing in Manhattan yesterday.


2 Forms of Skin Cancer Increase
LEAD: Two deadly forms of skin cancer are increasing at alarming rates in the United States, apparently because people are spending more time in the sun, researchers have found.


Net Off at Exxon and Phillips; Occidental and ARCO Gain
LEAD: Big oil companies reported mixed third-quarter earnings yesterday, with the Exxon Corporation and the Phillips Petroleum Company down, while the Occidental Petroleum Company, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Amerada Hess Corporation reported gains.
Ashland Oil Inc. reported a loss for the quarter.


British Aerospace Strike
LEAD: Britain's main engineering unions said today that they would ask 7,000 workers to go on strike next week at two British Aerospace plants and a Rolls-Royce factory to support a shorter workweek.
The Confederation of Engineering and Shipbuilding Unions had conducted a poll of workers in seven factories to measure support for a strike on the issue of cutting the workweek to 35 hours, from 39.

Gasoline Prices Drop
LEAD: The average price of gasoline nationwide dipped about a half-cent a gallon at the pumps in the last two weeks.
The Lundberg Survey of 12,000 gas stations showed the average retail price of all grades of gasoline, including taxes, at 109.12 cents a gallon on Friday, down 0.53 cent from Oct. 6, Trilby Lundberg said Sunday.

2 Norway Banks Agree to Merger
LEAD: Two of Norway's biggest banks, Den Norske Creditbank and Bergen Bank A.S., agreed to merge effective Jan. 1.
In the merger, two D.N.C. shares will be worth one Bergen Bank share.
Trading in the stock of both banks was suspended before the terms were announced, with D.N.C. shares quoted at 99.5 kroner, about $14.4, and Bergen


Gilbert J. Sinnott, 82, Insurance Executive
LEAD: Gilbert J. Sinnott, a retired insurance executive, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla.
He was 82 years old.

LEAD: *
Bowne &amp; Co., a communications company, named Catherine Godbille vice president of its Bowne International unit and director of Bowne Translation Services.


Corrections
LEAD: A caption on Sunday with an article about fashion industry reaction to the book ''Chic Savages'' misidentified the woman in the lower picture.
She was the designer Mary McFadden, not Anna Wintour, who was pictured above.

Market Place; Behind the Surge In Rally's Stock
LEAD: RALLY'S Inc. has a goal of providing fast food faster than McDonald's.
But its new speed record has nothing to do with hamburgers.


Paribas Makes Offer For Navigation Mixte
LEAD: Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, the French investment banking group, said today that it would try to acquire two-thirds of Navigation Mixte, a holding company with interests in insurance and banking.


Tony Manero, Golf Champion, 84
LEAD: Tony Manero, the 1936 United States Open golf champion and a member of the 1937 United States Ryder Cup team, died of heart failure Sunday at Greenwich Hospital.
He was 84 years old.

FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: San Antonio's $575 million tax-exempt bond issue to refinance debt previously sold when interest rates were higher was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The maximum yield on the electric and gas system revenue refunding bonds is 7.30 percent for bonds due in 2009.


West German Rightist Party Does Well in Municipal Vote
LEAD: Candidates of the far right won six Stuttgart city council seats and received more than 10 percent of the vote in several other municipal elections in the southern state of Baden-Wurttemberg, officials said today.


Giuliani Calls for Road and Bridge Repairs
LEAD: Standing in front of the Williamsburg Bridge, which had to be closed for about two weeks last year because of poor maintainance, Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday announced his plans for improving the city's infrastructure if he is elected mayor.


School Superintendent in Queens Tells of Costly Patronage Scheme
LEAD: A Queens schools superintendent who secretly tape-recorded conversations with school board members testified yesterday that dozens of unnecessary jobs in his district were awarded to friends and supporters of those board members at an annual cost of almost $1 million.


Teamster Leader Found Slain In Local Office in New Jersey
LEAD: An official of teamsters Local 478 was found shot to death today at the local headquarters in Union, officials said.
A co-worker found the official, Harry Serio, 68 years old, was found at 8 A.M., an assistant Union County prosecutor, David J. Hancock, said.


SEARCH IS STOPPED FOR PARTS OF JET
LEAD: After failing to find a part crucial to investigators, searchers have stopped looking for engine pieces from a jetliner that crashed in July, Some 90 volunteers with metal detectors turned up engine fragments over the weekend when they examined stubble from corn and soybean, but a flange from the engine remained missing.

Reputed Organized-Crime Figure Agrees to Fine in Teamsters Case
LEAD: A reputed organized-crime figure who had high-level ties to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is to pay the Government $250,000 in a civil settlement that will also permanently bar him from all labor union activities, the United States Attorney's office in New York announced yesterday.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Oct. 12 about Tass's reaction to the world attention given its report of extraterrestrial creatures in a Soviet city misidentified the chairman of the astronomy department at Cornell University.
He is Yervant Terzian.


Big Board's Trading Data
LEAD: Computer-driven program trading accounted for 13.8 percent of the average daily New York Stock Exchange trading volume in September, the exchange said yesterday.
The percentage is sharply higher that the 10.3 percent of average trading in August by the exchange's member firms.

Race Is Getting Closer, Mayoral Candidates Agree
LEAD: David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani remained apart yesterday on holding debates, but agreed that the New York City mayoral race had grown considerably closer.


Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs
LEAD: Federal efforts to seize the property of a Vermont man who was caught growing marijuana in his vegetable garden have aroused the ire of neighbors here.


Giants' Clark Rated Best Big-League Player
LEAD: Will Clark, the San Francisco Giants' first baseman, who was named the best player in the National League playoff earlier this month, gained the No. 1 ranking among all major league players today.


Lebanese Militia Leaders Fault Proposed Charter
LEAD: Lebanon's Muslim and Christian militia commanders today sharply criticized a new national charter for governing the country, a day after it was adopted by 62 Lebanese legislators in Saudi Arabia.


A 6-Foot-3, Blue-Eyed Taiwanese-American Is China's Top Rocker
LEAD: Dressed in a sequined jacket and white slacks, a slender blue-eyed, black-haired singer swivels his hips around the stage under the light of a flickering strobe as a crowd of 15,000 Chinese youngsters, officials and even grandparents watch the spectacle in fascination.

Children Still Being Sold Vehicles
LEAD: Dealers are still selling all-terrain vehicles for use by children despite an agreement between the Federal Government and the manufacturers to curtail such sales, a consumer group charged today.


Japan's Maneuvering For a Big Global Voice
LEAD: Japan, the world's biggest creditor and provider of financial assistance, is quietly building its influence in global finance institutions long dominated by the United States and Western Europe.
Having gained the appointment of a Japanese official to the top ranks of the World Bank, Japan is moving to promote a candidate to run the International Monetary Fund when the term of its managing director expires in


By Design; The Little Black Suit
LEAD: The little black suit is this fall's surprise success story.
While all the fashion oracles were predicting a preponderance of brown, the return of gray and camel, or the ascension of red, women were out finding and buying their new fall suits - in solid black.


Ramada Alters Buyout Terms
LEAD: After failing to raise $230 million in ''junk bond'' financing for a plan to divide the company, Ramada Inc. altered the terms of its deal.
Under the new arrangement, Ramada investors will receive up to $1 for each share of stock instead of up to $7.
Investors in the company, which is planning to sell its hotel business to concentrate on gaming, will also receive one share of stock in the new Ramada company, to be called the Aztar Corporation, instead of one-half share for every Ramada share under the original plan.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-17  Moscow admitted violations in Afghanistan.
The invasion broke Soviet law and international norms of behavior, Foreign Minister Shevardnadze told the Soviet legislature.
Page A1


Plans for a Mayoral Debate Finally Appear to Be Firming
LEAD: After three weeks of politicking and posturing, David N. Dinkins and Henry F. Hewes agreed yesterday to three debates.
Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed to three debates, but two of them without Mr.
Hewes and Ronald S. Lauder, who is in Europe and is not sure what he will do.


Review/Dance; Royal Winnipeg's 'Anne of Green Gables'
LEAD: The Royal Winnipeg Ballet is a survivor.
Repeatedly defying adversity, it continues to prosper on the Canadian prairie, and it is now celebrating its 50th anniversary.
It was in a festive mood on Sunday afternoon at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx.
But what made the onstage merriment possible was a tradition of courage and determination.


Fischer-Dieskau Is Ill
LEAD: The baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau has canceled his performances with the New York Philharmonic on Saturday and next Tuesday. saying he is suffering from the flu.
He was to have sung Mahler's ''Songs of a Wayfarer.'' Instead, the orchestra will present an all-Tchaikovsky program, including ''Romeo and Juliet,'' ''Francesca da Rimini'' and the Fourth Symphony, with Leonard Bernstein conducting.

LEAD: REID A. BRYSON and Verner E. Suomi of the University of Wisconsin at Madison started their careers as best friends, colleagues who helped each other build homes on adjacent lots and who together ran the university's meteorology department, making it one of the best in the nation.

Time Warner Reports Loss For Quarter
LEAD: Reflecting the costs of its recent merger, Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had lost $176 million in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, compared with a profit for Time Inc. alone of $81 million, or $1.42 a share, a year earlier.


Baseball Fans Are Mixed on Restart of World Series
LEAD: Baseball fans expressed mixed reactions today on the propriety and practicality of resuming the World Series on Friday.
But they generally seemed to agree that the slogan ''The Battle of the Bay'' had lost its ring of cheer since the earthquake struck northern California six days ago.


Let the Dollar Drift
LEAD: One reason the financial markets are jittery is the increasing tension between the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve over the value of the dollar.
The Treasury wants to push the dollar down and thus push exports up.
The Federal Reserve resists.


The California Quake; Children Live With Fear in Area of Disasters
LEAD: The lights were back on and children returned to class today at Lexington Elementary School near the summit of the Santa Cruz Mountains and just a few miles from the epicenter of the earthquake last Tuesday.
For children who lost their homes, who saw neighbors injured or who have spent nights sleeping in a strange place, today was a day of sharing their own stories.


Chinese Mushrooms Barred
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was blocking indefinitely all shipments of canned and pickled mushrooms from China after a number of food poisonings were associated with earlier shipments.

Ewan MacColl Dies; Folk Singer Was 74
LEAD: Ewan MacColl, who led the folk music revival in Britain and wrote the Grammy Award-winning ballad ''The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face,'' died on Sunday in a London hospital after heart surgery.
He was 74 years old.

Congress Moves on Ethics, but Stalls on Campaign Spending
LEAD: In response to attacks this year on lawmakers' personal and professional behavior, Congress has developed several measures to tighten ethical standards but has made little progress on restricting campaign spending.


Dollar Ends Session Lower As Traders Await U.S. Data
LEAD: The dollar drifted lower in lackluster trading yesterday as currency markets around the world awaited direction from United States economic reports scheduled for release this week.


Rationing 'Dallas' in Europe
LEAD: Western Europe, the font of Western culture, now seeks to protect itself against foreign cultural subversion.
In an absurd effort to regulate public taste, the 12-nation European Community has put restrictions on foreign television shows.
Though the lid may have little practical effect, Washington is filing formal charges under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which sets the global rules for exporting and importing.

LEAD: The board of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, announced yesterday that it would seek to keep the company independent while it examines financial and strategic alternatives.

G.M. and Fuji Out
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation and Fuji Heavy Industries of Japan have decided to withdraw from a planned car-making joint venture with a Chinese company in northern China, officials at both companies said.
Fuji said it had decided to drop the project because of a lack of components and worry about political instability.


Iran Offers Trade on Hostages, but U.S. Is Cautious
LEAD: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran said today that Teheran would help the Bush Administration obtain the freedom of American hostages if Washington helped solve the case of three Iranians kidnapped in Lebanon or returned Iranian assets frozen in the United States since 1979.

LEAD: New details were released yesterday that could support David N. Dinkins's contention that he properly valued stock sold to his son for $58,000 in 1986, even though in 1983 he had put its market value at more than $1 million.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Credit Company yesterday priced the largest issue of any pass-through securities to date, with the sale of $2.575 billion in asset-backed certificates issued through Ford Credit 1989-A Grantor Trust.
The asset-backed securities, which are due in 1994, are secured by automobile loans sold to the trust by Ford Motor

LEAD: Israeli authorities operating in the Gaza Strip say they recently discovered a cache of detailed, secret documents showing that the Palestine Liberation Organization is hiring local killers to assassinate other Palestinians and carry out ''military activity'' against Israelis.

Jefferson Smurfit Offer Price Raised
LEAD: SIBV/MS Holdings Inc. said it had increased the price of its public tender offer for the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation, a maker of paper products, by $1.25 a share, to $43.
The increase of $12.2 million in its offer was made to settle shareholder litigation on the bid.
The company said terms of the settlement - but not the increase in price for the tender offer or the merger that is to follow - was subject to approval by the Delaware Court of Chancery.

Texas Congressman Stricken
LEAD: Representative Jack Brooks, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, underwent hospital tests today after suffering abdominal pains during a flight from Texas to Washington, his office announced.
Mr.
Brooks, a 66-year-old Texas Democrat, was being treated at Bethesda Naval Hospital to determine the cause of the pain, his office said in a brief statement.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about do-it-yourself abortions referred incompletely to the author of the book ''When Birth Control Fails.'' It is by Suzann Gage, who teaches at Holistic Health for Women, a clinic in Los Angeles.

They were the people who stood over a fire turning flora and fauna into dinner.

LEAD: Robert Chambers, who is serving a prison sentence in the slaying of Jennifer Levin, sued state prison officials yesterday, saying they would not allow him to take college courses.
Mr.
Chambers is a 22-year-old former addict serving a 5-to-15-year sentence for manslaughter in the August 1986 killing of Miss Levin.

Stake in Sealed Air
LEAD: A group led by the Fort Hill Investors Management Corporation, a Boston investment firm, has lowered its stake in the Sealed Air Corporation to 1.7 percent from 7.23 percent.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the investment group gave no reason for the sale.
Sealed Air is a packaging materials concern based in East Saddle Brook, N.J.

R. N. Rose Dies at 87; Oil Company Engineer
LEAD: R. Nelson Rose, an engineer whose knowledge of rust inhibitors helped preserve equipment salvaged from the French liner Normandie after she sank in New York Harbor Feb. 9, 1942, died of a pulmonary embolism Sunday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 87 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.


No Way to Meet the Garbage Crisis
LEAD: New Yorkers had every reason to believe that the planned Brooklyn Navy Yard incinerator would proceed on schedule.
But David Dinkins, running for mayor, now asserts that if elected, he would defer building the plant for three years pending study.
The incinerator needs no further study.
To delay its construction would only aggravate the impending garbage crisis.

They begin to nuzzle.
They kiss.
It's a big, wet, messy one.

LEAD: Morehouse College announced Monday that two students have been expelled because of a fraternity hazing that led to a potential member's death last week.
Eight other students were suspended for one year.
The college said all were members of Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity, the nation's oldest black Greek-letter fraternity.

LEAD: Signaling President Bush's unusually strong support for Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaign, three Cabinet secretaries and the President's chief of staff will be the main attractions at Giuliani fund-raisers in the next week.


Clashes in Southern Lebanon
LEAD: Israeli troops shot and killed two guerrillas in the buffer zone in southern Lebanon today, military headquarters reported.
The clash, north of Merj 'Uyun, came hours after the army said Israeli-backed Lebanese militiamen shot and killed two other guerrillas in the zone.
Officials were unable to say if the victims were Palestinian or Lebanese guerrillas.

Breeden sent reassuring signals to the markets today, saying that his agency would not press Congress to grant the commission power to close the nation's securities markets in times of crisis.

LEAD: Shell, Mobil and Chevron reported yesterday that third-quarter profits were down slightly from the year earlier, following a pattern set by Exxon on Monday.

Treasury Issues Continue Up
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities continued to climb and yields decline yesterday as more investors moved from the stock to the fixed-income market.
Dealers attributed the latest ''stocks for bonds'' move to a sharp selloff in equities that pulled the Dow Jones industrial average down at one point by as much as 85 points.

Forest City Jobs
LEAD: The Forest City Ratner Companies has assigned its marketing and communications business to Della Femina McNamee WCRS and two other WCRS companies.

Della Femina will handle the advertising component of the $5 million to $6 million account, while WCRS's Creamer Dickson Basford will handle public relations, and its Cohn &amp; Wells will handle direct response.

Exxon Capital
LEAD: The Exxon Capital Corporation is offering $200 million of notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
Underwriters gave the notes an 8 1/4 percent coupon and priced them at 99.60, to yield 8.31 percent, or about 45 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

Wine Talk
LEAD: AS descriptives go, ''sweet wine'' has some unfortunate connotations for many Americans.
When it comes to food and drink, sweet means fat.
It also means childlike and unsophisticated.
Wine lovers in particular, like arrivistes trying to shed their embarrassing past, point their noses up and wrinkle them at the mention of sweet wine.


Car Sales Are Down 19 Percent
LEAD: Sales of United States-built cars plunged 19 percent in mid-October and sales of domestic light trucks dropped 22.8 percent as auto makers continued to feel the effects of earlier aggressive discounting.


Sheraton Moscow
LEAD: The Sheraton Moscow, the first luxurious American hotel in the Soviet capital, will be built one mile from Red Square, Soviet and United States officials said.
Sheraton officials described the six-floor, 450-room hotel as unprecedented in the Soviet Union.
It will cost $75 million to construct at 26 Gorky Street, one mile from Red Square in the heart of Moscow, and is expected to be complete by 1992.

Amoco Production
LEAD: The Amoco Production Company, a unit of the Amoco Corporation, said it plans to install two platforms and drill as many as 22 wells to develop significant oil reserves it has discovered in the Atlantic Ocean about 25 miles off the coast of Congo.
It said production is expected to be about 40,000 barrels of oil a day.


Nunn Reinstated
LEAD: The Phoenix Cardinals announced yesterday that the defensive end Freddie Joe Nunn has been reinstated by the N.F.L. after serving a 30-day suspension for substance abuse.

LEAD: The Federal guidelines instituted to hit hard at illegal drug users by seizing their cars and boats have been altered, allowing some people to pay fines and go on their way, a Customs Service official said today.

Boeing Jet Order
LEAD: Canadian Airlines International Ltd., a unit of the PWA Corporation, said it would buy 16 more Boeing jets by 1994 and phase out its Airbus Industrie and McDonnell Douglas jets.
In a statement, the company said it would buy six of Boeing's 747-400 aircraft and 10 of its 767-300er jets by 1994.
Canadian Airlines said it would phase out its Airbus A310-300 jets between now and early 1992 and that it plans to sell at least four A310's in 1990.


Olajuwon in Doubt
LEAD: Coach Don Chaney of the Houston Rockets said on Monday that Akeem Olajuwon, his 7-foot center from Nigeria, may not be ready to play at full speed when the Rockets open their National Basketball Association season on Nov. 3 against the Clippers in Los Angeles.
Since preseason practices began, Olajuwon has been restricted to conditioning drills while continuing rehabilitation from a blood clot in his leg.


Debating Face to Face - to Face
LEAD: In 13 days New Yorkers go to the polls to choose their next mayor, yet no televised debate has been scheduled between David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani.
The voters, who for the first time are contributing tax dollars to help finance a mayoral campaign, have every right to feel cheated.
New Yorkers are entitled to see the candidates together on the same platform and, at long last, to hear them ventilate their views of the central problems facing the next mayor.

Revenue rose 12.6 percent, to $61.7 million, from $54.8 million a year earlier.

Too Much Fight In The Irish
LEAD: Take your average, high-powered college football institution.
Feature it in three angry confrontations in the moments before nationally televised games within a period of just over 13 months.
Recall an ugly blemish at the end of what had seemed a perfect season - again, with a coast-to-coast audience - when the coach, in the final two minutes of a bowl-game victory for a national championship, feels compelled to go on the field and into the huddle to determine the reason for the unsportsmanlike conduct penalties against his team.

Bridge
LEAD: Bridge players are generous contributors to worthwhile causes.
In 1988, events around North America raised $425,000 for the Charity Foundation of the American Contract Bridge League, which makes grants to a number of major charities.
And the charity games for specific causes probably raise more than that total.

LEAD: Those who call the 1985 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law a bad law because deficit targets have been missed and accounting gimmicks have been used to avoid tough decisions would probably also suggest that religion is a failure because there are so few saints in the world.

STRINGENT CURBS ON ABORTION GAIN IN PENNSYLVANIA
LEAD: The Pennsylvania House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved stringent new restrictions on abortions, the first such legislative move since the United States Supreme Court's July ruling giving states wider authority to limit abortion.


Market Place Added Volatility Expected in 'Junk'
LEAD: AFTER going their separate ways most of this year, the ''junk bond'' and stock markets now seem to share anxieties.
When the Dow Jones industrial average plunged almost 86 points yesterday morning, prices of some high-risk, high-yield bonds fell sharply as well.
Then when stock prices later recovered, junk bonds rose slightly.

German Return For Rothschilds
LEAD: The Rothschild banking family ended an 88-year absence from Germany this week by opening an office in Frankfurt, the family's historic hometown.
The Rothschilds, who had lived in Frankfurt since the Middle Ages, closed their last German firm in 1901.
By that time, financial activity had shifted elsewhere, and family interests in Paris and London had eclipsed those in Frankfurt.


60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: THE integration of Oriental cooking techniques and Western cuisine is well established by now.
Many concepts that are now part of seafood cooking vernacular are a result of travel by French and American chefs, particularly in Japan.


Dow Ends 3.69 Lower In Wild Day
LEAD: The stock market fluctuated wildly yesterday on heavy volume.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 85 points in the first hour of trading but recovered in the late afternoon to close only 3.69 points lower, at 2,659.22.


Inner City: Estimating The Worth
LEAD: In 1983, David N. Dinkins valued his stock in a privately held communications company at more than $1 million.
In 1986, when he sold the shares to his son, he placed the value at $58,000.


Roland Winters, 84; Played Charlie Chan
LEAD: Roland Winters, an actor whose film portrayals included Charlie Chan and Elvis Presley's father, died of a stroke on Sunday at the Actors' Fund Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J.
He was 84 years old.


Woman Shot in a Robbery Gives Birth and Then Dies
LEAD: A woman who had been robbed and shot along with her husband gave birth by Caesarian section early today and then died of a head wound that she received in the assault.


Seoul Agrees to Buy 120 U.S. Fighters
LEAD: In a long and painstaking negotiation, South Korea has agreed to buy 120 jet fighter planes from the United States but under terms that are a setback for Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and that are likely to cause some criticism in Congress.


Earthquake Cuts Ratings Of Networks
LEAD: The three major television networks held just 64 percent of the prime-time audience last week, in part because of the earthquake.
ABC was hardest hit, with the postponement of the World Series and the loss of its Tuesday night comedy lineup (although reruns of two hit programs - ''Roseanne'' and ''The Wonder Years'' - were shown before earthquake coverage began).

Excerpts From Interview With the President
LEAD: Following are excerpts from an interview today with President Bush in the Oval Office:  On the Crisis in Panama  Q. From here, looking from Washington, what do you think the chances are of another rising in Panama?
A.
I think any time you have somebody that is demonstrably evil as Noriega and who is frustrating the will of the people, as he continues to do, there's bound to be upheaval.

The Cold War Becomes Bad Politics
LEAD: A single day's news brings three striking signs of change toward a less threatening world order: Hungary's Parliament proclaims its nation a republic, dropping the adjectives ''Socialist People's'' and dramatically distancing the country from the Soviet empire.
Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union says the nations of Eastern Europe have ''absolute freedom of choice.

LEAD: Garry Templeton, the 33-year-old shortstop for the San Diego Padres, has signed a two-year contract, according to his agent, Richie Bry.
Templeton will reportedly receive $1.2 million over the life of the contract, which includes playing incentives and award bonuses.
In 142 games last season, Templeton batted .255, with 6 home runs and 40 runs batted in.(

The California Quake; Victims of Quake in Bay Area
LEAD: Following is a list of the dead who have been identified in the Oct. 17 earthquake, reported by the coroner's office in each county or the county's office of emergency services.
The list includes deaths from traumatic injuries only, not from heart attacks, except in the case of Santa Clara County, where the count from the emergency agencies is at odds with that of the coroner.

PGA Policy Board Upholds Limit for Foreign Players
LEAD: The PGA Tour Policy Board on Monday rejected a proposal to cut from 15 to 12 the number of American tour events a foreign player must enter in order to retain membership in the PGA Tour and have freedom to play pro tournaments anywhere he wishes at any time.

Last year, the company earned $7 million, or 2 cents a share, for the corresponding period.

LEAD: The Control Data Corporation said today that an extensive reorganization earlier in the year had enabled it to post a third-quarter profit of $9.8 million.
In the period last year, it recorded a loss of $2.4 million.


Judge Sentences Gabor To Three Days in Jail
LEAD: Saying Zsa Zsa Gabor was ''without a hint of remorse'' for slapping a Beverly Hills police officer who stopped her car last June, a judge today sentenced her to three days in jail.


Times Mirror Earnings Drop 13.4%
LEAD: The Times Mirror Company reported today that its third-quarter earnings dropped 13.4 percent, reflecting a special gain in the 1988 quarter, while two other newspaper companies reported advances for the 1989 quarter.

LEAD: President Bush said today that he did not share the worries of some European leaders about the possibility of German reunification, and he predicted major changes in Germany's status in the next decade.

Preserving the Hues and Aromas of Summer's Array
LEAD: FORGET plastic.
The garden's bounty may fade quickly, but you can fool nature without resorting to artifice.
The secret to continued pleasure from summer's sunny colors and the vibrant hues of fall lies in drying flowers, herbs, weeds, seed pods and branches.
With moisture removed, many plants last for months or even years.

LEAD: A Federal court in Chicago has declined to hear an appeal of its decision that the Securities and Exchange Commission was wrong when it decided that a new type of financial instrument traded on several exchanges was a security and not a futures contract.

LEAD: Stephen Stamas, a former executive of the Exxon Corporation who has been president of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York since 1984, has been named chairman, the New York Philharmonic has announced.

Fischer-Dieskau, Ill, Cancels More Concerts
LEAD: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau has canceled two recitals at Carnegie Hall, Nov. 3 and 5, and an appearance with the Cherubini String Quartet on Nov. 9 at Alice Tully Hall.
The baritone, who had previously canceled concerts with the New York Philharmonic, has a severe case of the flu.

LEAD:  SOCCER  Sweden and Belgium in Finals: Sweden, Belgium and South Korea clinched spots yesterday in the 1990 World Cup finals, bringing to 11 the number of nations that have qualified for the 24-team tournament in Italy.
Sweden and South Korea both scored 2-0 victories away from home.
Belgium clinched a spot by struggling to a 1-1 tie at home against Luxembourg.

Boy Is Saved by Umbilical Blood of Sister
LEAD: Medical researchers in France and the United States have replaced the blood-producing cells of a 5-year-old boy seriously ill with anemia by using frozen blood saved from the umbilical cord of his newborn sister.


Copper's 3-Day Fall Halted; Precious Metals Down a Bit
LEAD: A steadier stock market and Japanese buying allowed copper futures prices to end a three-day decline yesterday.
On other futures markets, precious metals were slightly lower, while oil products, most grains and livestock generally climbed.


League Backs Wolves
LEAD: Gary Bettman, a senior vice president and general counsel of the National Basketball Association, said yesterday the league would assist the Minnesota Timberwolves in any legal action that the expansion team took against Rick Mahorn, a former Detroit Piston.


Tax Break Is Coming For the Self-Employed
LEAD: To the Editor:


Baines Gets New Pact
LEAD: Harold Baines, a .288 career hitter for his 10 seasons, has agreed to a new contract with the Texas Rangers that extends through the 1992 season.
The Rangers acquired Baines, a 30-year-old designated hitter, on July 29 in a five-player deal with the Chicago White Sox.
He had been signed through 1990 with an option for 1991.


Nuclear Reactor in Spain Catches Fire
LEAD: A turbine at Spain's oldest nuclear reactor caught fire last week, increasing concern over the country's nuclear safety standards and giving fresh impetus to what had been a background issue in the campaign for Sunday's general election.

Merieux Bid Gains
LEAD: Institut Merieux S.A. agreed to spend about $42.5 million to pay for biotechnology research in Canada, clearing an obstacle in its friendly bid of $942 million (Canadian) for the vaccine maker Connaught Biosciences Inc.
The agreement was reached with Connaught's founder, the University of Toronto, which had been opposing the bid on the ground that a foreign takeover would mean a loss of research spending and jobs in Canada.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Tuesday about negative political campaigns misidentified a Democratic consultant.
He is Robert Squier.


Beirut Christians Urge 'Flexibility' on Pact
LEAD: The agreement reached last weekend aimed at ending Lebanon's 14-year civil war gained momentum today when a coalition of Christian parties and militias called for ''flexibility'' in dealing with the accord.


Mesa Airlines Rebuffs StatesWest
LEAD: Mesa Airlines Inc. rejected a proposal by StatesWest Airlines Inc. to combine the two companies.
Mesa's board considered the proposal too vague and ill defined to merit further consideration, said Gary Risley, Mesa's vice president for corporate affairs.


Next Step for Ruble
LEAD: Yesterday's dramatic reduction in the exchange value of the ruble for Soviet citizens traveling abroad reflects both the continuing trials of shaking the Soviet economy out of its lethargy and the Soviet leadership's willingness to act boldly in pursuit of the goal of integration into the world economy.

Anheuser Cutting Its Beer Prices
LEAD: In a move that may spark a beer price war, the Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that it would begin cutting prices on all its brands, including Budweiser, the nation's best-selling beer.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section yesterday about Paris fashion shows misidentified a designer who showed a collection on Tuesday evening.
He is Valentino Garavani, known professionally as Valentino; he is not Mario Valentino.

LEAD: ASHER/GOULD, a medium-size Los Angeles ad agency, has had a fair amount of experience with clients whose public image is less than stellar.
Among its biggest accounts is the American Savings and Loan Association; until the completion of a Federal bailout plan at the end of last year, it was the nation's largest insolvent savings institution.

LEAD: THE turn-of-the-century building at Madison Avenue and 92d Street, which began its life as the Hotel Chastaigneray, has been given a major face lift.
The Hotel Wales is the newest of Manhattan's boutique hotels, an Edwardian-flavored companion to the Royalton and Morgan's.

Dinkins began asking why his opponent was not being subjected to the same scrutiny.

LEAD: The Oakland police said today that it was too dangerous to continue the search for bodies amid the wreckage of the Nimitz Freeway until the shaky structure was demolished.


At High Point, Fantasies Old (Mostly) and New
LEAD: Armed with the High Point survival kit - flat shoes and a sense of humor - more than 50,000 decorators, retailers and manufacturers' representatives made their way through some 1,600 showrooms at the semiannual International Home Furnishings Market.
The nine-day event, billed as ''the largest concentration of home furnishings in the world,'' introduces the furniture that consumers will see in retail stores next spring.

LEAD: President Bush is expected to announce proposals on Thursday to allow the Government to remove dangerous agricultural chemicals more quickly from the marketplace.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Cement on Quarry Tile  Q.I cemented down some tiles that had worked loose on the landing outside my front door, but I failed to clean up, and left streaks of cement on the surface of these tiles.
How can I remove these streaks without loosening the tiles, and is there anything I can apply to make them shiny after they are cleaned?


Statement May Cast Doubt On Allegation Against Pierce
LEAD: The Inspector General of the Department of Housing and Urban Development has submitted a statement to lawyers for former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. that could cast doubt on a key accusation of favoritism leveled against Mr.
Pierce.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: SHEET vinyl flooring is popular because of its appearance, relatively easy installation and durability.
But vinyl floors require cleaning and polishing, and precautions must be taken to avoid damage from heavy furniture.
Vinyl flooring can be repaired.
If done skillfully, the repairs are often invisible.


Big Gain Expected By Westinghouse
LEAD: The chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation told securities analysts the company expects to exceed a 10 percent operating margin by the end of 1990 and to have a return on equity in the range of 18 to 21 percent.
John C. Marous also predicted ''double digit'' earnings growth in this year's fourth quarter.


Maxicare Accord
LEAD: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. said it had reached agreement with its court-appointed creditors' committees on terms of the company's restructuring in Federal Bankruptcy Court.
The health maintenance organization company said creditors and shareholders would receive no less than $78.8 million in cash, 10-year 13.5 percent notes with a face value of $67 million, and common stock and warrants.

LEAD: THE working title of Leland and Crystal Payton's book in progress - a look at a wide range of wacky, witty and just plain ugly lamps made in the 1950's - was ''Outrageous Lamps.''

Saab Gets Plane Order
LEAD: Saab-Scania A.B. said this week that the United States carrier Express Airlines 1 had placed an order worth 2 billion crown, about $310 million, for 25 of its commuter aircraft.
The Swedish company said the order was for 15 Saab 340's and 10 Saab 2000's, with an option for 10 additional 340's.
Saab said Express Airlines 1, part of Northwest Airlink, was the first company to place a firm order for its 2000.


Home Resale Rise Is 4.3%
LEAD: Sales of existing homes rose for the second consecutive month in September, climbing 4.3 percent to the highest level this year, a real estate trade group said today.

Rule of Law?
LEAD: The United States Government has just made amends, of a kind, for an act of lawless cruelty.

Review/Jazz; A Pianist Comes Into His Own
LEAD: It is a common experience for those listening to jazz groups led by the saxophonist Lou Donaldson to become suddenly riveted by a pianist who emerges from the ensemble to turn it in volatile, joyful directions.
The pianist is Herman Foster, who spends much of his time in groups led by Mr.
Donaldson and others, and as accompanist to a variety of singers.

He was 73 years old and lived in Bay Head, N.J.

LEAD: IT'S sitting on the sideboard, the pumpkin I bought for Halloween, waiting for a new face.

LEAD: Since he exhibited ''Three Studies for Figures at the Base of the Crucifixion'' at the Lefevre Gallery in London 44 years ago, Francis Bacon has remained master of the macabre.

LEAD:  International


L. J. Hooker Sells Merksamer Stake
LEAD: The L. J. Hooker Corporation said it had sold its 80 percent stake in the 79-store Merksamer Jewelers chain to a group led by Sam Merksamer for an undisclosed amount.
L.
J.
Hooker, the American unit of the Hooker Corporation of Australia, bought its stake in Merksamer in 1986.
Since then, Hooker ran into financial difficulty.


China-South Africa Deal
LEAD: China, which has traditionally shunned ties with the white supremacist Government of South Africa, is buying coal from Pretoria, a private Dutch group said today.
The first of 10 shipments was unloaded in the southern province of Guangdong in June, according to the Shipping Research Bureau, a body that monitors the oil and coal trade.

LEAD: Kemper Financial Services Inc., the Chicago-based investment management firm, will no longer do business with four Wall Street investment firms that do index arbitrage for their own accounts, officials at the company said.

LEAD: S. Clark Beise, retired president and chief executive of the Bank of America, died Saturday at his home in Hillsborough, Calif.

Konrad Wolff, Pianist And Author, Dies at 82
LEAD: Konrad Wolff, a pianist and the author of several books about the piano, died of heart failure Monday in Cologne, West Germany, where he was performing and lecturing.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH modern design has permeated Italian life for decades, it takes a display like the one at the Italian Trade Center (499 Park Avenue, at 59th Street) to really make the point.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Farm Credit System Banks yesterday priced three consolidated systemwide bond issues totaling $2.45 billion.
The bonds are being offered through the FFCB Funding Corporation and various securities dealers and banks.


Ruble Is Devalued in Some Cases; Step to Spur Soviet Economy Seen
LEAD: The Soviet Union today announced a drastic cut in the ruble exchange rate that applies mainly to foreigners in the country and to Soviet citizens traveling abroad.
The move, which puts a more realistic value on its currency, is apparently a step along a difficult path toward making it possible for anyone to exchange rubles for other world currencies.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said this week that it would spend $11 million to be the sole sponsor of several television specials next season.

LEAD: The U.S.
Trust Corporation, a bank company that serves wealthy investors and institutions, yesterday named H. Marshall Schwarz chairman and chief executive, effective Feb. 1.

LEAD: By using a highly specific new test, a New York internist has found that many people believed to be suffering from irritable bowel syndrome actually have the common intestinal parasitic disease giardiasis.

LEAD: Two Connecticut utilities sweetened their offers yesterday for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire in filings with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manchester, N.H.

Chilean Barred for Life
LEAD: Roberto Rojas, the Chilean national team's goalkeeper, was barred for life from international competition yesterday after accusations he faked an injury at a Brazil-Chile World Cup qualifying match on Sept. 3.
The Federation Internationale de Football Association, soccer's governing body, also suspended Rojas for three months from all activity, including domestic games, and fined the Chilean team about $31,000.


Power Plays Work for Winnipeg
LEAD: Three power-play goals, including Dave Ellett's tie-breaker in the third period, eased the Winnepeg Jets to a 6-4 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight.


Gesture to French Muslims
LEAD: Education Minister Lionel Jospin of France, seeking to resolve a national dispute, ruled today that Muslim girls could wear traditional head scarves but could not refuse to attend classes.
The suspension early this month of three students who wore the head scarves had stirred debate over whether their mode of dress violated France's long tradition of secular public schools.


Foster-Home Arson Kills Counselor; Ex-Resident Arrested
LEAD: A 27-year-old counselor died early yesterday in a fire in Brooklyn at a city-run foster-care home.
And the police arrested a 19-year-old former resident, saying they believed he had set the fire because he was expelled from the home two weeks ago.


Former Labor Secretary Is Named As U.S. Mediator in Coal Strike
LEAD: Calling for a ''time of healing now,'' Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole turned today to a predecessor, W. J. Usery Jr., to mediate a violent, six-month-old coal strike in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky.

Corrections
LEAD: An entry in the Company Earnings listing of Business Day on Friday for W. R. Grace &amp; Company misstated its latest third-quarter net income.
It was $97,891,000.
The Profits Scoreboard chart with the listing also misstated the percentage increase in income from the same quarter last year, when the company earned $50,537,000.


Soviet Grain Approved
LEAD: The Soviet Union has been given the go-ahead to buy up to 16 million metric tons of United States grain in the year that began Oct. 1, the Agriculture Department said today.
John B. Campbell, Acting Under Secretary for international affairs and commodity programs, said the clearance to buy more grain resulted from recent communication between the two countries.

Fly-Fishing Connoisseurs to Gather for Seminars
LEAD: As the fly-fishing season for trout draws to a close for most Easterners - there is a small band of fanatics who will be dodging ice floes on the no-kill sections of the Beaverkill in the Catskills all winter - members of the Theodore Gordon Flyfishers of Manhattan have set up the first half of their annual arts of angling seminars.

Mr.
Ngema was called out of town, a library spokesman said.

Bridge
LEAD: An imaginative bid on the diagramed deal helped the winners of the Flight A Regional Swiss Team Championship in Stamford, Conn., Sunday.
Glenn Milgrim of Whitestone, Queens, overcalled one heart with one spade and heard his partner respond two clubs.
This suggested moderate values with at least six clubs and a misfit in spades.

How to House the Mentally Ill
LEAD: Here's a way for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, lately known for scandal, to gain some positive notice and give some real relief to the nation's cities: Create a new housing voucher for the homeless mentally ill.


France Buys U.S. Butter
LEAD: France has bought 5,000 metric tons of United States surplus butter at cut-rate prices, the United States Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
The salted butter was sold to Fromageries Dischamp of Sayat, France, a privately owned dairy products company, for $1,620 a ton, an average of less than 74 cents a pound.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary on Tuesday about Irma A. Bloomingdale listed some of her survivors incorrectly.
Joseph and Lewis Bloomingdale, both of Scarsdale, N.Y., are her sons, not her brothers.
In addition to her daughters Laura Goeldlin and Beatrice Steinhaus, survivors include a third daughter, Elinor B. Preis of Rancho Bernardo, Calif.

Turner to Make Films
LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. says it has formed a unit to make movies and distribute them to theaters.
Gerry Hogan, president of the new division, said this week that the new branch would be called Turner Pictures and would go into operation immediately.
Its first two releases will be ''The Secret Life of Ian Fleming,'' a dramatization about the former British spy who wrote the James Bond novels, and ''Treasure Island,'' starring Charlton Heston.

LEAD: The $5.5 million Nabisco Championship, which concludes the official money competitions on the PGA Tour, has such a big purse that it has drawn criticism from the golfers who have qualified for the tournament, although not one of the 30 competitors has turned his back on it.

LEAD: Jerry J. Jasinowski became president of the National Association of Manufacturers this week, setting a sort of precedent.

LEAD: ''The Remains of the Day'' by Kazuo Ishiguro won the Booker Prize yesterday for the best novel published in Britain this year.

Security Pacific In Deal for La Jolla
LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation signed a letter of intent to acquire the La Jolla Bancorp in a deal worth about $111 million.
Security Pacific said it would pay $15 in Security Pacific stock for each share of La Jolla, whose stock jumped $3 a share, to $13, on the American Stock Exchange.
Its 30 percent gain was the best of the day.

LEAD: The UAL Corporation said yesterday that its revenues in the third quarter rose 7.1 percent from the corresponding period last year, but earnings fell 72.4 percent.
Even excluding a large one-time gain last year, profits dropped 38 percent.

The program will be repeated tomorrow at 2 P.M. and on Sunday at 5 P.M.

10 Get Awards for Writers
LEAD: Ten writers, including established novelists, a playwright and authors who have not yet written a book, have each been named recipients of $25,000 Whiting Writers' Awards.
The awards program, now in its fifth year, is the largest privately financed program offering individual support exclusively for writers.


The E.T. Answer to Doctor Bills
LEAD: Congress is moving to control the relentless escalation of Medicare payments to doctors.
Different versions of the plan, known as expenditure targets, or E.T., have been approved by committees in both the House and Senate.
The Senate version settles for puffery; the House plan merits support.


Charles Pedersen, 85, Nobel Winner in Chemistry
LEAD: Charles J. Pedersen, who shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1987 for wide-ranging research that included the creation of artificial molecules that can mimic vital chemical reactions of the processes of life, died yesterday at his home in Salem, N.J.
He was 85 years old.

LEAD: In the one moving scene in David Hare's new play, ''The Secret Rapture'' - the last - the audience is suddenly overwhelmed by pity for a young woman it has hated all night long.
The woman is Marion French, a Tory junior cabinet minister whose faith in dog-eat-dog capitalism is so unshakable and whose contempt for her adversaries is so patronizing that she makes Margaret Thatcher seem like Mary Poppins.

Medicare and Social Security Aren't Welfare; Add That Up Again
LEAD: To the Editor:


Colombia Police Bus Bombed
LEAD: A bomb today destroyed a bus filled with police officers in Medellin, killing at least 4 policemen and injuring 40, a radio station reported.
The station, RCN, said without identifying the source of its report that 66 pounds of dynamite exploded beneath the bus in Belo Horizonte, a suburb of Medellin, the base for the most powerful drug cartel in Colombia.


Lockheed Division To Reduce Jobs
LEAD: The Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation, will cut several hundred jobs in the next two months as part of the company''s cost control program, a spokesman said.


Quake Behind It, Bay Area Is Ready to Play Ball
LEAD: The Bay Area readied itself today for the resumption of the World Series, hoping that a baseball game at Candlestick Park on Friday would speed the healing of a region rocked to its foundation just 10 days before.

Mr. D'Amato's Idea of Justice
LEAD: Senator Alfonse D'Amato has failed to distinguish between helping his constituents, for which he is widely known, and intervening in justice.
Three times during Rudolph Giuliani's tenure as U.S.
Attorney in Manhattan, the Senator called the prosecutor to express an interest in pending cases.


Man, Woman and Chimp
''Animal Behavior,'' opening today at the Paris theater, has the manner of a proposal for a snappy screwball comedy that has still to be made.
There is Susan Rice's promising screenplay about a music professor and the pretty absent-minded psychology professor with whom he falls in love.
She loves him in return, but she also loves Michael, her chimpanzee, the key to her experiments in interspecies communication.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, the telecommunications company, named C. Hyde Tucker president and chief executive of Bell Atlantic International.


U.S. Checking Reports of Pressure at H.U.D.
LEAD: Federal prosecutors and Congressional staff members are investigating assertions that two former regional administrators in the New York office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development pressured housing workers to approve projects with ties to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.


Goodbye Rubles, Hello Baubles: Russians Rush to Get Rid of Cash
LEAD: The people standing three deep in line today in front of the jewelry store on the Arbat pedestrian mall did not need the official announcement on Wednesday that the exchange rate for the ruble would be slashed to know the waning value of their currency.


An Avenging Convoy Stalks Contractors
LEAD: After massing its forces like a small army going into battle, the New York City Transportation Department made a dramatic foray yesterday morning against construction contractors who were blocking the streets and sidewalks of mid-Manhattan with their building materials and delivery vehicles.

Japan's Output Declines
LEAD: Japan's industrial production in September fell 2 percent from the previous month, but growth should resume in October, the Government said today.
September's fall was the first since July, and despite the drop production was still 3.9 percent higher than a year earlier.
The ministry also said September sales at Japan's leading department stores and supermarkets grew 9.4 percent from a year earlier.

Pop/Jazz; Pakistani Musicians Who Deal in Ecstasy
LEAD: We live in a shrinking auditory world, in which even the most hermetic of musical cultures becomes familiar through recordings and tours.
But Qawwali, Pakistan's music of Sufi Muslim mysticism, has remained relatively exotic, even for our ethnographic musical gourmands.


Baseball Makes a Donation
LEAD: With officials of four affected communities at his side, Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, announced today that major league baseball would contribute a minimum of $1.4 million to the Northern California Earthquake Relief Fund.


Soviet Arctic Miners Return After Just a Day of New Strikes
LEAD: Thousands of striking coal miners in the Arctic city of Vorkuta voted today to return to work at midnight, preventing a confrontation with the authorities over the legality of their one-day work stoppage.


Seles Qualifies
LEAD: Monica Seles, the 15-year-old Yugoslav who went from No. 86 to No. 7 in the world ranking in 1988-89, has qualified for the $1 million Virginia Slims championships Nov. 13-19 at Madison Square Garden.
She brings to nine the number who have qualified for the 16-player field. (AP)


50 Waste Disposal Plans Help and Hinder Project
LEAD: Federal efforts to assure safe disposal of hazardous waste over the next 20 years have yielded a hodgepodge of plans from the 50 states and the District of Columbia that have both reinforced regional cooperation and hardened barriers to it.


3 to Sing
LEAD: Peter Stampfel, Jimmy Dale Gilmore and David Halley, three singers and songwriters, are to perform tonight at 10 at Gonzalez y Gonzalez, 625 Broadway, at Houston Street (473-8787).
There is no cover charge but there is a two-drink minimum.

LEAD: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that design flaws had been discovered in its top-of-the-line microprocessor chip but that the errors would be corrected quickly and would not hurt its ability to ship ''tens of thousands'' of the chip before the end of the year.

LEAD: In the 1930's, New York boasted something very like a European literary subculture.
Its house organ was The Partisan Review; its luminaries included Philip Rahv, Dwight Macdonald and the two Trillings, Lionel and Diana.
But its most vivid presence was Mary McCarthy, who came to be known, half in awe, as the Dark Lady of


Bigger Shortfall Now Faced By Cuomo for Next Budget
LEAD: New York State will enter the next fiscal year with a budget shortfall that could be twice what the Cuomo administration had originally forecast, adminstration officials say.

LEAD: At the end of a pilgrims' hilly path, where temple monkeys sun themselves and peddlers hustle their marigold garlands and gilded images of Hindu gods, the ugly iron bars of a police barricade are rising this week around a shrine that threatens to become a religious battlefield.


Correction
LEAD: The caption of a picture by The Associated Press in SportsMonday this week about preparations for the World Series misidentified a San Francisco Giants pitcher.
He was Jeff Brantley, not Don Robinson.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 476 money market mutual funds increased by $1.26 billion, to $357.49 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 144 institutional funds decreased by $751.40 million, to $84.82 billion.
The assets of the 236 general-purpose funds were up by $300.10 million, to $116.91 billion.

Review/Ballet; Joffrey Revival of the 1932 'Cotillon'
LEAD: The Joffrey Ballet performance of ''Cotillon'' on Wednesday at City Center (131 West 55th Street) did not look much like period descriptions of this 1932 ballet by Balanchine.
Long lost and remembered with great pleasure by those who saw the original, ''Cotillon'' was an instance of Balanchine's gift for using what he had, in this case the technique and poignant sophistication of Tamara Toumanova, who at 13 was one of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo's ''baby ballerinas'' and for whom Balanchine created the role of the Young Girl.


Canada Would Extradite Suspect
LEAD: The Canadian Government said today that it had ordered the extradition of Charles Ng, a 28-year-old former United States marine who could be sentenced to death in California if he is convicted in one of the state's worst mass-murder cases.


Braniff Adviser
LEAD: Braniff Inc. the financially troubled airline, said it had hired Merrill Lynch to explore the possible sale of the airline.
In late September, Braniff filed for protecion from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
It was the airline's second such filing in seven years.

25 Bulgarian Ecologists Detained
LEAD: The Bulgarian police detained at least 25 environmentalists today, beating and kicking them as they campaigned against a hydroelectric project, Westerners in Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, said.


Works and Process
LEAD: The French choreographer Maguy Marin and her company are to perform excerpts from her new work ''Hey, What's All This to Me?'' tonight and tomorrow as part of the Works and Process series at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and 89th Street.
The work includes popular songs inspired by political and social crises from the French Revolution to the Spanish Civil War.

LEAD: What value judgment can you make on playing in the World Series when it's resumed after a major earthquake has changed lives and fortunes?


No to 2 Royals' Options
LEAD: The Kansas City Royals announced yesterday that they would not pick up the options for next year on the contracts of Willie Wilson, their longtime center fielder, and the pitcher Floyd Bannister.
General Manager John Schuerholz, however, said he was interested in negotiating new contracts for both players.


Leo Stillman, 85, Dies; An Art Deco Architect
LEAD: Leo Stillman, a retired architect who was noted for his Art Deco designs in the 1930's and for later innovations in the use of poured concrete in apartment house construction, died of a stroke on Oct. 18 at the Ocala (Fla.) Geriatric Center.
He was 85 years old.

AIDS Led to Dismissal, Choreographer Says
LEAD: Michael Shawn recently left the AIDS unit of Roosevelt Hospital, where he learned that along with everything else, he now had liver cancer.
Still, this visit was easier than his last, 15 months ago.
That time, he lost his dream job as choreographer for a Broadway show called ''Legs Diamond.''
