Review/Art; New From David Reed, A Modern Traditionalist
LEAD: David Reed's latest show at the Max Protetch Gallery includes seven works, all completed during the past year, that recapitulate what have been abiding themes with this painter.
Mr.
Reed prefers long, narrow canvases that look like unfurled scrolls.
These are hung either lengthwise or vertically and they feature abstract images closely resembling enlarged photographs of swirling brushstrokes.

LEAD: Lawyers for Jon Peters and Peter Guber, the production team the Sony Corporation wants to hire to run its newly acquired Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., argued in papers filed in Los Angeles Superior Court yesterday that both their contractual agreement with Warner Communications Inc. and verbal commitments from its top management permit the pair to join Columbia Pictures.


Control Data Set To Sell Division
LEAD: The Control Data Corporation has agreed to sell its 1,000-employee United States computer maintenance business to the Bell Atlantic Corporation of Philadelphia for an undisclosed price.
The business involves maintenance services for computers not made by Control Data, which is retaining service operations for its own products.

Richard K. Parsell, 89, Ex-Patent Attorney
LEAD: Richard Kendrick Parsell, a retired patent attorney, died Oct. 14 at Church Homes, a retirement community in Hartford.
He was 89 years old and until two years ago, lived in Manhasset, L.I., and in Center Harbor, N.H.


New York Post to End Its Sunday Paper
LEAD: After eight months of steady losses, The New York Post plans to stop publishing on Sundays, the newspaper's publisher and owner, Peter S. Kalikow, announced yesterday.
The last Sunday issue will appear on Nov. 26.


Standard Labels for Tampons
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration announced standard labels today for tampons that will permit consumers to compare the absorbency of different brands.

LEAD: Herman Roth, a retired district manager for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the father of Philip Roth, the novelist, died of a brain tumor on Wednesday at St.
Elizabeth Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J.
He was 88 years old and lived in Elizabeth.

MTM Enterprises
LEAD: Arthur L. Price, the president and chief executive of MTM Enterprises Inc., the Hollywood production company, resigned today, 15 months after MTM was acquired for $320 million by Television South P.L.C., a British broadcasting and entertainment company.
MTM, which Mr.
Price co-founded with Mary Tyler Moore and Grant Tinker in 1969, has been one of the most successful independent television production houses in Hollywood.


Ubu Rep's New Play
LEAD: ''Your Handsome Captain,'' a play by the Guadeloupian writer Simone Schwartz-Bart, will open at the Ubu Repertory Theater, 15 West 28th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M.
The play, a love story about a Haitian couple forced by economic necessity to live in different countries, will be performed in English.

McDonald's Plastic Recycling Plan
LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation and eight of the nation's largest plastics producers announced yesterday that they would set up a national program to recycle plastic hamburger containers and other packages.
The $16 million program will begin in New England and will later be extended to four metropolitan areas in other sections of the country, participants said.


Dean Alfange, Liberal Leader, Is Dead at 91
LEAD: Dean Alfange, a lawyer who ran unsuccessfully for governor of New York in 1942 as a candidate of the American Labor Party and who two years later was a leader in forming the Liberal Party, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 91 years old.

It has one street, one church, four restaurants, a handful of shops, lots of open space, magnificent vistas of Manhattan, two chronic-care hospitals, a small lighthouse and eerie, fenced-off ruins dating from the island's

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Blackhawks 5, Canadiens 3: Steve Thomas scored twice last night in Chicago as the Blackhawks defeated Montreal for the first time in 13 games, moving into first place in the Norris Division.
The team last beat Montreal on Jan. 2, 1985, and was 0-7-5 since.
Jacques Cloutier stopped 14 shots before Guy Carbonneau put in a 10-footer with 3:13 remaining in the middle period.

LEAD: Prices of RJR Nabisco's ''junk bonds'' tumbled yesterday on unconfirmed rumors that a proposed deal by the company to sell its Del Monte division was in trouble.
Bonds of distressed companies like Federated Stores and Southland also fell sharply, dealers said.
Some Federated bonds were quoted as low as 12 cents on the dollar.

East Germans Declare Amnesty for Those Who Fled
LEAD: East Germany announced an amnesty today for all citizens who have fled or tried to flee the country, as well as for most of those arrested in the recent wave of anti-Government demonstrations.


Personal Income Up 0.3% in Month
LEAD: Americans' personal income, dealt a blow by Hurricane Hugo, rose a lackluster three-tenths of 1 percent in September as consumer spending posted its weakest advance in a year.

Pierce Balks Again in H.U.D. Inquiry
LEAD: Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. invoked the Fifth Amendment again today in refusing to answer lawmakers' questions about political favoritism in Federal housing programs, prompting new calls for appointment of a special prosecutor.


I.B.M. Strategy On Upgrading
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was offering incentives for some customers to postpone upgrading certain models of mainframe computers from this year until next June.


Bridge
LEAD: Few bridge players ever achieve a 75% score in a duplicate game and fewer still ever celebrate a 65th wedding anniversary.
The parlay, both events on one day, is almost certainly singular.
It occurred October 11 at the Riverdale Yacht Club, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, and the record-setter was Reginald Johnson, 89 years old.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday about the Women in Comedy festival of the Manhattan Punch Line Theater misidentified the performer in the foreground.
She was Patricia Scanlon, not Nancy Mura.

Alfred Wilson, 85, 1924 Olympic Medalist
LEAD: Alfred M. Wilson, a retired executive vice president of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Company, died after a heart attack yesterday at Vineyard Haven Hospital on Martha's Vineyard, Mass.
He was 85 years old and lived on the island.

LEAD: Whenever Kazuo Ishiguro goes on the road to promote his books, he has to spend much of his time explaining himself.

Too Soon Darkness
LEAD: In Australia, with summer coming on, they'll be setting their clocks forward one hour this weekend - the start of daylight time Down Under.
Up here in the Northern Hemisphere, it's back to darkness in the afternoon.
Too soon.

Alfred C. Bruce, 88, An Ex-Civil Engineer
LEAD: Alfred C. Bruce, a retired civil engineer and business executive, died of heart disease Thursday at a nursing home in East Haven, Conn.
He was 88 years old and had lived for many years in Southport, Conn.


U.S. Won't Challenge Los Angeles Hiring Plan
LEAD: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has decided that it will not challenge the efforts of Los Angeles to help coordinate the hiring of day laborers, at least for now.


About New York; On Special Night, Ecstatic Dances Celebrate Torah
LEAD: Every week, Jews read successive passages of the Torah, the Five Books of Moses.
In a year's time, they are finished.
It is time to start over.


Free Soviet Press Depends on Attitude, Not Law
LEAD: To the Editor:


Stocks Close Hectic Week With a Slide
LEAD: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, ending one of Wall Street's most turbulent weeks in recent months.


Review/Recital; The Issue Of Crescendo For a Pianist
LEAD: Peter Orth, who played Hoiby, Chopin, Brahms and Ravel on Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, is a pianist capable of communicating real musical ideas.
This puts him ahead of most young instrumentalists, even if some aspects of his musical and technical approach are not fully persuasive.


Reagan Warns Japanese on Trade
LEAD: In a tougher warning on trade than he issued as President, Ronald Reagan said today that Americans did not think their products had fair access to Japan and that trade barriers must be lowered to avoid rising anger in the United States.


Soon the Republicans Will Choke on Success
LEAD: There has been a lot of talk recently about the seeming free fall of the Democratic Party and despair about whether it will ever again take back the White House from the Republicans.

Crane Gets 8.9% Of Milton Roy
LEAD: The Crane Company, a New York-based engineering products concern, has acquired an 8.9 percent stake in the Milton Roy Company.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Crane said it had acquired the shares to obtain ''a significant equity interest'' in Milton Roy, and left open the possiblility of seeking control of the gas-monitoring equipment concern based in St.


Ciba-Corning Deal
LEAD: Ciba-Geigy A.G. said it had agreed to buy Corning Inc.'s share of the Ciba-Corning Diagnostics Corporation, a joint venture in which each company had owned half.
Terms were not disclosed.
Ciba-Corning, based in Medfield, Mass., provides diagnostic systems and related products.
It has 2,500 employees and had 1988 sales of about $300 million.


DINKINS IS SEEKING TO WIDEN APPEAL
LEAD: In an effort to assure voters that his administration will be broad-based, David N. Dinkins has told associates that he will appoint Victor L. Kovner, a longtime ally and a politically active Manhattan lawyer, as his corporation counsel if he is elected mayor of New York City.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Halloween Safety
LEAD:  Tuesday is Halloween, a time for ghosts and goblins and little children.
With a little planning and some common sense, adults can make Halloween festivities safe.
Here are some tips.
In the Street: Plan trick-or-treat routes in advance, picking well-lit streets.
Choose costumes in light colors so drivers can see them.

Patents; Quigg, Leaving Office, Cites Patent Speed-Up
LEAD: The Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, Donald J. Quigg, who will step down Tuesday, is claiming at least one victory for efficiency: The average time needed to process a patent application is now 18 months, down from almost two years when he took office in 1985.

LEAD: Engineers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee obtained a patent this week on a device that distinguishes African ''killer'' bees from ordinary European bees by measuring the buzzing of their wings.

Soviet Official Explains Ruble Devaluation
LEAD: Slashing the value of the ruble this week was a small step toward making the Soviet currency freely convertible but a big step toward cutting back the country's flourishing black market, a Soviet state bank official said today.


Aquino Ban on Marcos Is Upheld
LEAD: The Supreme Court today narrowly upheld President Corazon C. Aquino's right to ban the return to the Philippines of the body of her predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos.


Henderson Outdoes His Dream
LEAD: On the bus that carried the Oakland Athletics across the bay and into another grand moment in the 86th World Series, Dave Henderson allowed himself a few moments to dream.


Tanker, After Being Barred, Docks in Alaska
LEAD: A tanker that has been anchored in Cook Inlet for lack of a state-approved contingency plan for cleaning up any oil spill began unloading oil Friday night after the ship's owner agreed temporarily to adopt the cleanup plan of another company.

Fallout From Testimony Worries Queens District
LEAD: Like most educators and parents in School District 27 in Queens this week, Toby Sohn, a special-education teacher, was mesmerized by her superintendent's testimony before the Gill Commission - tales of racial and religious bias in hiring, unnecessary jobs and a plot by some school board members to run the schools as patronage mills.


Dataproducts Sought by DPC
LEAD: DPC Acquisition Partners began an unsolicited $10-a-share cash tender offer for all the shares of the Dataproducts Corporation that it does not already control, in a transaction that would value the company at more than $200 million.
DPC Acquisition is controlled by Crescott Inc., a New York investment firm that already controls 7.5 percent of Dataproducts' 21 million shares outstanding.


Eunice Taylor Vanderhoef, Horticulturist, 91
LEAD: Eunice Taylor Vanderhoef, a horticulturist in Connecticut, died Wednesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.
She was 91 years old and lived in Greenwich.

LEAD: Rick Mahorn, who refused to report to the Minnesota Timberwolves this fall after they made him their first selection in the expansion draft last June, was traded to the Philadelphia 76ers yesterday for a first-round pick in the 1990 college draft and second-round choices in 1991 and 1992.
The trade is conditional on Mahorn's reporting to


Unusual Bond Trading Disturbs the Market
LEAD: Unusual and very large trading by a single party, thought to be Japanese, has captivated and disrupted the government bond market, contributing to price swings and setting off fears of a corner in one issue of government bonds.

LEAD: A concert version of Jean Philippe Rameau's opera ''Hippolyte et Aricie'' is to be presented by the Concert Royal Baroque Orchestra on Nov. 29 and 30 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

Tickets are $20.

Mobil Plans to Cut About 400 Jobs
LEAD: The Mobil Corporation said a previously announced reorganization of its American operations would involve eliminating about 400 jobs nationwide.
The company, the nation's second-largest oil concern behind the Exxon Corporation, said the biggest reduction would come in its Denver office, which will be reduced to 105 employees from 430.

The Big Oil Spill From Home Mechanics
LEAD: Only the biggest oil spills get much attention, but the smallest ones add up.
The amount of oil dumped by do-it-yourself auto mechanics every two and a half weeks is roughly equivalent to the amount spilled by the Exxon Valdez, experts say.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Oct. 19 about the rescue of a 6-year-old boy, Julio Berumen, after the California earthquake misstated the circumstances of his removal from a car.
Rescuers were impeded by the body of a family friend, later identified as Yolanda Orozco, not by the body of the boy's mother, Petra Berumen.

LEAD: Where did Congress suddenly find $3.5 billion for earthquake disaster relief?
In a loophole.
If the quake had hit last month, as Hurricane Hugo did, money to aid its victims would have had to come from cutting other programs.
But, as luck would have it, the deadline for trimming this year's budget deficit has passed now, and with it this year's spending ceiling.


POSTINGS: At Home, Off Course; 20 Condos
LEAD: Howard Loewentheil, head of LFM Development Corporation of New Rochelle, N.Y., was so pleased with Fairway Greens - the Mamaroneck condominium project overlooking a golf course that he completed last year, with 50 of 54 units sold - that he decided to do a similar one in his home base.


Off the Record
LEAD: THE STATEMENT was never made on the record, off the record, in any way,'' insisted Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley.
He had been reported by The Washington Times to have told a group of foreign journalists that ''the President is like a mad dog after a bone on this capital gains cut.''


Exchange Program of Jobs Worldwide
LEAD: WHEN 23-year-old Debra Commey of Accra, Ghana, was an accounting student at the University of Ghana, she never dreamed that she would work for the International Business Machines Corporation.
But now she is in the accounting section of I.B.M.'s Latin American division in North Tarrytown.


Numbers, Too, Were Against the Giants
LEAD: If the World Series was supposed to become part of the healing process after the earthquake here, it didn't offer much healing to the San Francisco Giants in the third game.
They knew the numbers all too well: 16 teams in the previous 85 years of the Series had lost the first three games, and none recovered.


Northeast Forests, Too, Get Congress's Interest
LEAD: CONGRESSIONAL debate over the future of American forests has almost always concentrated on the vast timber-growing areas of the Pacific Northwest and Alaska.
But slowly, the future of another heavily forested region, the Northeast, has begun to stir concern on Capitol Hill.

LEAD: Amy Maureen Edelmann and William Paul Donohue Jr. plan to marry in December.
The future bride's parents, Maureen Edelmann of Montville, N.J., and West Tisbury, Mass., and Dr.
Robert B. Edelmann of Mendham, N.J., have made known her engagement to Mr.
Donohue, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Donohue of Manhasset, L.I.


Teamwork
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Heyday of the Three-Martini Lunch
LEAD: WE CALLED THEM SILVER BULLETS - they were six-ounce martinis made up of six ounces of gin, a drop of vermouth and a thin strip of lemon peel floating on the top, surrounded by a handful of silvery slivers of ice. ''Straight up'' was the way most people drank in the 1960's; ordering ''on the rocks'' was seen as a sign of weakness, as was the substitution of vodka.

Browsing Through Columbia's Jazz Reissue Bins
LEAD: When long-playing records came on the market 40 years ago and began supplanting the 78-rpm disks that had been dominant for much of the preceding half-century, a colorful byproduct of the record business disappeared along with the 10- and 12-inch shellac platters.


The Opium War
LEAD: The argument about legalizing drugs has become passionate, for good reason.
There is a certain intellectual appeal to the logic that suppression provokes the enormity of crime, corruption and irresistible riches that make enforcement so ineffective and so costly.

LATE-NIGHT COOL
LEAD: Arsenio Hall should not be angered by Johnny Carson's attempt to control guest appearances (''Late-Night Cool,'' by Michael Norman, Oct. 1).
After Mr.
Hall has ruled the late-night talk circuit for nearly 30 years, he may use the power that comes with that territory to impede rising young competitors.


11th-Hour Syracuse Victory
LEAD: John Biskup, who missed his fourth extra-point attempt of the season, kicked a 24-yard field goal with four seconds left today to lift Syracuse to a comeback triumph over East Carolina, 18-16.


FASHION: On the Street; Bending Tradition Just a Bit
LEAD: After many years atop the illustrious domes of statesmen and politicians, the homburg is becoming a fashionable addition to the downtown look.
So, thanks to brisk business at thrift shops and antique-clothing markets, are vintage snap-brim fedoras and that flat-topped favorite of 50's hipsters, the porkpie.


Rising to the Occasion: Simple Souffles
LEAD: FOR DINING ROOM DRAMA, NOTHING compares with a souffle.
Its golden dome, towering tremulously above the edges of the dish, creates a stunning impression, suggesting that either daredevil or genius has been at work in the kitchen.


A HITTING PITCHER PERSONIFIES OAKLAND'S MASTERY
LEAD: Mike Moore epitomized the lopsided nature of the 1989 World Series tonight.
It was so lopsided that it could have been played on only one side of the San Francisco Bay as an intrasquad game and been at least as interesting.


One Struggle Over, Attention Turns to Guilt
LEAD: One afternoon two years ago, when Richard Wesley was feeling especially frustrated in his effort to write a play about what W. E. B. Du Bois had called ''the talented tenth'' of black America, he drove from his suburban New Jersey home to visit cousins in Harlem.
Heading across 145th Street, he noticed a car wash and decided to pull in.


More Boats Being Kept On Racks
LEAD: MORE Connecticut boats are being kept year round in warehouses instead of on the water, as rack storage buildings, or boat valet operations, are constructed along the coast.


LATE-NIGHT COOL
LEAD: So Paramount believes that Johnny Carson's audience is ''skewed to older men.'' Well, maybe yes, maybe no.
Frankly, this 61-year-old WASP finds Mr.
Carson and his fill-in buddy Jay Leno consummate bores. (Is it foreordained that they do a Dan Quayle or Exxon joke every night?) Arsenio Hall, on the other hand, is alive, upbeat.


An Out-of-the-Way Place in Darien
LEAD: BACKSTREET in Darien couldn't be more appropriately named.
In a modest clapboard shopping complex, facing a municipal parking lot on a short, inconspicuous street off Route 1, just a block from the railroad overpass, the tiny restaurant requires directions to find.
Backstreet has the easygoing atmosphere of a neighborhood drop-in place, with only about 50 seats.

LEAD: The Celia Cruz Celebrates Harlem show at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem on Oct. 21 caught fire during the second half and stayed lighted.

Don't Waste Time Planning - Act
LEAD: American managers should reject the barrage of criticism they receive for focusing so much on short-term results.
Instead, they should concentrate on doing a much better job on those short-term results.
Traditionally, our greatest strength is the ''let's do it,'' ''let's try it'' attitude.
This American penchant for quick successes and quick rewards dovetails with the pressure for results that most American managers face.


Business Lunch: A Personal Approach
LEAD: IN WASHINGTON, GEORGETTE MOSBACHER IS known primarily as the wife of a Cabinet member and as a glamorous addition to the capital's party circuit.


Peace at Last, on Paper at Least, for Lebanon
LEAD: AFTER 14 years of civil war, Muslims and Christians in Lebanon have drawn up a new charter for sharing power that recognizes the dominant weight of the country's Muslim population and the country's Arab identity.
The deal struck last week holds a promise of an end to a murderous conflict, but it is still hard to say that peace in Lebanon is at hand.

Alvin Schwartz of Schenectady, N.Y.

LEAD: Autumn is sweater season.

Soft knits are a nice change from tailored jackets, and will slip comfortably under coats when winter's chilly blasts move in.

A Case for Boys' Manners
LEAD: WE had heard there were more wolves in Russia than any other country, but one afternoon we wondered if they all had gathered in our backyard.
They arrived one by one and immediately canvased the yard for a new toy to attack.
They were not very gracious in delivering their presents to the birthday boy, nor did they remember to wish him a happy birthday.

A Lesson in Pain and Loss Comes at the Death of a Hamster
LEAD: IT was clear and cold, the kind of night that feels right for putting on a mask and going door-to-door to ask for Halloween treats.
Instead, the whole family processed solemnly outside.
I ran ahead to cut a late-blooming rose from the garden.
My daughter Liza came next, holding a tiny white box gingerly in front of her, with her brother shining a flashlight to show the way.


Pastimes; Bridge
LEAD: Tournament bridge players have a major problem that tournament chess players solved more than a century ago: slow play.
The chess clock, with its associated time limits and forfeitures for exceeding them, cannot conveniently be applied in bridge events although there have been attempts.

LEAD: After deciding to free four people who were apparently wrongly convicted of terrorist bombings in 1975, the British Government is under growing pressure to reopen the case of six men who were convicted of murdering 21 people in the bombings of two Birmingham pubs in 1974.

ECONOMICS: READING YOUR WAY OUT OF CHAOS
LEAD: Economics has long accommodated dozens of schools of thought.
But in the last decade or so, it has become more like physics or chemistry, disciplines so broad and so complicated that, within the field, one group of specialists barely speaks the same language as the Ph.D.'s across the hall.
And so much of what is published seems more to proselytize for an ideology than to make sense of the chaotic world inhabited by economists.

Soviet Union
LEAD: To the Editor: Driving in the Soviet Union is indeed the best way to experience the joys and frustrations of that country.
I was sorry to see, however, that there was no mention of the group trips run by Pioneer Travel Service of Cambridge, Mass.
Pioneer has operated camping and driving trips to the Soviet Union for 23 years.

LEAD: Yes, they are ''just'' baseball games.
Yes, death, destruction and despair have tragically gripped the Bay Area.
But invariably the process of life must continue.
The process of healing must begin.
The World Series should not be called off, assuming roads are commutable, sufficient police are available and the edifices holding 60,000 people are certifiably safe.

A Place for Developing Artistry in Glass
LEAD: IN the brilliant light of their red-hot furnaces, silhouetted glassmakers take on a primeval aspect.
Ritual-like blowing and twisting of a long pipe turns the molten glass at the tip into a glowing sphere.
The blowpipe is passed from hand to hand and back to the ''glory hole,'' where the glass is reheated and reworked, again and again.

Unclogging a Pop-Up Drain
LEAD: POP-UP drains, the kind operated by raising a vertical rod in the center of the faucet, are common on bathroom sinks.
Although convenient to use, these drains clog easily because the opening in the bottom of the sink cannot be screened.
Also, the plug mechanism frequently slips out of adjustment.

On the Ancient Nile, a Modern Voyage
LEAD: PERHAPS, when you think of Egypt, you imagine yourself on a boat, gliding smoothly along the wide green Nile as people have done for thousands of years.
Beyond the bulrushes and palm trees that line the shore are small mud-brick villages, each with its own mosque and minaret, flanked by wide fields of black earth being plowed by bullocks.

The N.F.L.'s Painful Profit Crunch
LEAD: It is a curious enterprise: an intercity alliance of 28 monopolies, blessed by Congress and invariably ruled by fabulously rich capitalists, bound up in its own form of socialism.

'Forced March' Sees the Holocaust Through a Victim
LEAD: Amid the growing number of films dealing with the Holocaust, some of the most effective have been those that bracket the horrors of World War II with the flashbacks of a central character.
From ''The Pawnbroker'' to ''Sophie's Choice,'' there seems to be something more ''real'' about avowedly subjective recollections, as opposed to reconstructions that purport to show the past in an objective way.


Why Not an Aperitif
LEAD: AN APERITIF IS BOTH A DRINK and an occasion, a point in time when the day's labors are suspended and the fun part begins.
An aperitif smoothes the rumples, cleanses the palate and wakes up the stomach.
In Europe, its role in the ritual of hospitality is so central that over the years a whole class of specially concocted drinks has evolved based on secret, almost alchemical formulas.

Medicare Fee for Doctor Bills Rising to $29 a Month in '90
LEAD: The insurance premium that the nation's 33 million Medicare beneficiaries pay to cover doctor bills will rise to $29 a month in 1990, the Department of Health and Human Services said this weekend.
The 1989 rate is $27.90 a month.
Congress has decreed that 25 percent of the cost of Medicare's program that pays physician fees be covered by premiums paid by beneficiaries.

Pastimes; Around the Garden Joan Lee Faust
LEAD: For This Week: Leaves are falling; keep after them with rakes or power blowers; add them to compost.
Mow the lawn one more time and set the blade to cut low, about one-inch; this short cut will endure until spring and spur rapid start up of the grass.
Finish bulb and shrub planting; tree planting continues well into early winter.

LEAD: Most of us see Italian landscapes for the first time over somebody else's shoulders - the valley of the Arno, for example, behind Pollaiuolo's martyred St.
Sebastian, or the lakes of Mantua through the back windows in Mantegna's strange ''Death of the Virgin.'' After a time it seems natural to want to move the all-important central figures for a while and to walk into the picture, in particular the part that they necessarily hide from you.

LEAD: Exxon has resigned from the National Wildlife Federation's corporate advisory board and has called the federation unfair in its criticism of the Alaska oil spill last March.

LEAD: A pedestrian bridge with as many as 50 people on it collapsed today, killing at least five people and injuring 18, after the crowd rocked the span back and forth, the authorities said.

LEAD: This city's celebrated passion for skyscrapers has been as evident as ever recently.
First there was the announcement last June by Lee Miglin and J. Paul Beitler, a pair of local developers, that they planned to put up a 125-story, 1,914-foot tower on a tight corner site downtown, a building that would be the tallest skyscraper in the world, eclipsing its neighbor, the Sears Tower, by more than 400 feet.

Hemond Rewarded
LEAD: The Baltimore Orioles yesterday extended the contract of Roland Hemond, the team's general manager, and gave him the added title of executive vice president.
In 1988, Hemond's first season as general manager, the Orioles had a 54-107 record.
Fortunately for Hemond, he had a two-year contract, and this year the team finished at 87-75, coming within a hair of the American League East pennant.

LEAD: They were brought together by chance, by fate, by an act of God, some might say: 23 men, 15 women and a little boy.

Another Quarter Of Economic Growth
LEAD: The economy grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the quarter that ended in September as a surge in consumer spending offset weakness in exports and the industrial sector, the Commerce Department reported.
The overall advance matched that of the April-June period.
Economists found reason to cheer in the report's indication of lower third-quarter inflation, even though that was mostly a reflection of falling energy prices.

LEAD: ONE DAY IN THE middle of the baseball season, nine Houston Astros, in New York for a series against the Mets, spent an afternoon in midtown Manhattan.
For 90 minutes they sat around a conference table on the 26th floor of a Third Avenue office tower, listening to Don Fehr, a man more important to their careers than any manager, umpire or opposing pitcher.

Unclogging a Pop-Up Drain
LEAD: POP-UP drains, the kind operated by raising a vertical rod in the center of the faucet, are common on bathroom sinks.
Although convenient to use, these drains clog easily because the opening in the bottom of the sink cannot be screened.
Also, the plug mechanism frequently slips out of adjustment.

They take risks, accept challenges, try out new behavior.

Ms.
Chinh did not anticipate leaving her native Hanoi when she was 14.

MR. LONELYHEARTS
LEAD: I FIRST MET EPPIE LEDERER (alias Ann Landers) in July 1981.
She had just given a speech at a real estate convention and, as a reporter for The Orlando Sentinel, I approached her for an interview.
I was star-struck and somewhat fawning.
She was 63 years old and a legend; I was 22 and not yet jaded about celebrityhood.

Cooked Anchovies: A Different Taste
LEAD: ANCHOVIES taste quite different when they are cooked.
In the Piedmont region of Italy, raw vegetables are served with a classic hot dip made with anchovies, garlic and olive oil that is called bagna cauda.
It is usually cooked in an earthenware pot brought to the table and kept warm over a spirit lamp.

Boeing and Strikers to Talk
LEAD: The Boeing Company and the machinists' union have agreed to hold contract talks for only the second time since 58,000 workers struck the aircraft manufacturer Oct. 4 over wages and work schedules.
The announcement was made Friday by a Federal mediator, Doug Hammond, who said the two sides would meet separately with mediators Sunday and direct talks would be held Monday.

Robert Halsband, 75, English Scholar, Dies
LEAD: Robert Halsband, an authority on 18th-century English literature and a teacher and writer, died of pneumonia Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 75 years old.
Professor Halsband wrote a dozen books on the literary figures of the 1700's and their works.
Among his books are ''The Life of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu,'' ''The Complete Letters of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu'' and ''The Rape of the Lock and Its Illustrations, 1714-1896.

LEAD: The 19th century brought curious items to numismatics, coins called struck copies.

Say 'Ah'
LEAD: THE ELASMOSAUR WAS A GIANT sea reptile with fierce-looking jaws, flippers and an athletic neck that accounted for more than half its length.
Dating from the Cretaceous Period, some 66 million to 144 million years ago, it belonged to a family of creatures known as plesiosaurs, of which paleontologists say they are often reminded when they hear descriptions from those who claim to have sighted the Loch Ness monster, the possibly apocryphal

LEAD: At St.
Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Ossining, N.Y., Dr.

Doing More With Less: Companies Donate Volunteers
LEAD: After a surge early in the decade, the growth of corporate philanthropy has stalled.
Corporate contributions, adjusted for inflation, have fallen by 7 percent since 1985, to $4.8 billion in 1988.
By comparison, individuals donated $86.7 billion, up 15 percent for the same period.
The most recent culprits for the decline in corporate giving: the rise of cash-draining mergers, the stock market crash in 1987, increased foreign competition and a reduced tax incentive.

Baseball Adds To Quake Aid
LEAD: Baseball's $1.4 million contribution to the Northern California Earthquake Relief Fund breaks down this way: $50,000 from each of 24 clubs and $100,000 each from the two Bay Area teams, the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland Athletics.

By Robert Heller. (Truman Talley/Dutton, $22.50.) One day in 1957, Akio Morita, the co-founder and chairman of the Sony Corporation, turned down a purchase order for 100,000 new transistor radios from the Bulova Corporation because Bulova would sell them only if the radios carried the Bulova brand name.

Unclogging a Pop-Up Drain
LEAD: POP-UP drains, the kind operated by raising a vertical rod in the center of the faucet, are common on bathroom sinks.
Although convenient to use, these drains clog easily because the opening in the bottom of the sink cannot be screened.
Also, the plug mechanism frequently slips out of adjustment.


Spotlight On Artists From Asia
LEAD: FOR several years Asia has been providing an astounding number of remarkable young musicians.
The opening of cultural doors and a strong sense of discipline are often credited, and the number of musicians of Asian heritage in the United States is increasing.

COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Capone Connection; Transforming a Onetime Chicago Mob Headquarters
LEAD: A $2.6 million Federal urban development action grant awarded to this city last month has provided the last link in the financing of a $28.6 million project to transform the historic Lexington Hotel, where Al Capone had his headquarters, and a neighboring building into a 258-suite hotel with 32,000 square feet of retail space.

Individualism That Promises Fun
LEAD: THE Jersey City Museum's ''Two Arks, a Palace, Some Robots and Mr.
Freedom's Fabulous Fifty Acres'' will be fun for most of its viewers.
Dominating the show is a wolf-sized dog made entirely out of automobile engine parts, by William Clark.
Titled ''Junkyard Dog,'' but looking infinitely meaner than the real thing, the creature stands with its jaws ajar to reveal huge white-painted fangs.

Special Today: Entertaining/Section 6


Soviet Union
LEAD: To the Editor: ''Relatively new?'' My wife and I did a month's auto tour of the Soviet Union, camping in our own car, 20 years ago.
Judging from your story of Aug. 27, the only thing that has changed since then is that the gasoline hoses have nozzles.
In 1969, the hoses just ended, and sometimes the fuel was supplied in jerry cans, not pumped.

LEAD: The nation of Zaire went into mourning, by presidential decree, for four days after the death on Oct. 12 of L'Okanga La Ndju Pene Luambo Makiadi, the Zairian bandleader and guitarist more simply known as Franco, who died at the age of 51.
During the mourning period, Franco's music was heard continuously on the radio - probably without much repetition, since he had recorded at least 100 albums since 1956, when he helped to start O.

INSIDE THE INTIFADA
LEAD: AT MIDDAY THE WORD spreads among the young men of Husan: Gather at the usual place just after dark.
And a little before 8 P.M., about 15 youths assemble at the prearranged spot.
Their faces are covered by ski masks or checkered kaffiyehs, and each in turn utters the password, an Arabic letter difficult for Hebrew-speakers to pronounce.


Couple Die in Fall From Train
LEAD: An elderly California couple were killed in a fall from a moving Amtrak train today, the authorities said.
Investigators were trying to determine the events that led to the deaths of Arthur Kohfeld, 87 years old, and his wife, Dorthea, 76, of Reedley, Calif., near Middle Point in northwest Ohio, the Van Wert County Sheriff's Department said.

Pastimes; Stamps
LEAD: A delivery experiment that failed yielded stamps and postal stationery that are inexpensive but hard to find, a combination that attracts hobbyists.

The company's substantial debt has been downgraded, its inventories have increased and it has been reducing staff.

The 'Subway to Nowhere' Now Goes Somewhere
LEAD: Twenty years after its conception, a new subway-line extension - dubbed the subway to nowhere by its critics -made a ceremonial maiden run yesterday, rumbling under the East River from Manhattan to Roosevelt Island and into Queens.
Regular service was to start today on the $868 million line, the first subway to the island.

LEAD: Despite considerable resistance to the concept, a growing number of nonprofit groups are thriving by using marketing research principles to refine their services and target their message.
Those nonprofits that can afford it have begun to rely on M.B.A.'s, consulting firms, advertising agencies, lobbyists and media specialists to guide their leaders, who traditionally have had little business experience.

Ladle Label
LEAD: What's in a nickname?
For Vinnie (Microwave) Johnson, the No. 3 guard on the champion Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association, apparently a lucrative endorsement contract.

LEAD:  FUNNY BUSINESS: An Outsider's Year in Japan.
By Gary J. Katzenstein. (Soho Press, $17.95.) Gary J. Katzenstein went to Japan with his eyes and heart open.
His innocence did not last.
A computer specialist, Mr.
Katzenstein went to work for Sony as part of a yearlong fellowship.
Expecting to bear witness to the dazzling efficiency of a leading Japanese corporation, he instead found an office filled with grim workers whose greatest virtue was endurance.

In Nuclear Cleanup, Costs Grow and Promise Fades
LEAD: Engineers arrived here in 1982 to begin cleaning up a factory that once processed nuclear waste.
Their task was to employ a pioneering technology: remove hundreds of thousands of gallons of radioactive liquids and sludge from an aging storage tank and make the radioactive materials safe from spills or leaks by mixing them with cement or glass.

LEAD: WHEN THE TRUSTEES OF ROCKEFELLER University in New York City appointed Nobel Laureate David Baltimore as president earlier this month, it plunged the school's distinguished scientific faculty into turmoil.

Touch Tones
LEAD: IN THE 18TH CENTURY, VELVET was velvet, silk was silk, lace was lace and men were men - no matter how elaborately they adorned themselves in luxurious trimmings.
A hundred years later, the finery of French court dressing had given way to the simplicity of the English squire, whose coarse tweeds and woolens set the tone for a new definition of masculine attire.

A Large Helping Of Gunter Wand In Four Big Sets
LEAD: Like an errant delivery truck that mistakenly dumps a ton of coal on your lawn, the good people at BMG/RCA Records have seen fit to release 24 compact disks of Germanic music conducted in a Germanic fashion by Gunter Wand.
The disks, assembled in four boxed sets, consist of the complete symphonies of Beethoven (60090-2-RC, 6 disks), Schubert (60096-2-RG, 5 disks), Brahms (60085-2-RG, 3 disks) and Bruckner (60075-2-


Japan Moves Toward Modest Aid for Poland
LEAD: Prodded by the United States and other Western democracies, Japan is moving cautiously toward approving a modest program of aid for Poland.
It would be the first time that Tokyo has provided economic assistance to a nation in the Eastern bloc.


Homeless Projects At the Crossroads
LEAD: Two years ago, Andrew M. Cuomo arrived in the county determined to build transitional housing for the homeless in Mount Vernon, White Plains and Greenburgh.


Miami Undone By Turnovers
LEAD: Undone by six turnovers, two of them coming 1 yard from a touchdown, the University of Miami hopes for a perfect season came apart tonight with a 24-10 loss to Florida State.


For a Bit of a Gamble, Meet Them in St. Louis
LEAD: In South Africa in 1959 one would hardly have expected to find the American musical thriving, much less splashing in the rain that Louis Burke and Joan Brickhill concocted for their revival of Gershwin's ''Lady Be Good'' that year.
Yet musicals and dramas with such special effects as Borzois, chariots, 45-foot sequined cloaks, shipwrecks and flying Ariels became the trademarks of this married couple who eventually mounted more than 80 productions in their native country.


Rhones, California Style
LEAD: YOU DON'T HAVE TO BE A WINE EXPERT to recognize such names as cabernet, chardonnay and pinot noir.
Of course, they're the names of the grapes that go into California's most famous wines.
But don't get too comfortable; things are changing out on the West Coast.
Are you ready for syrah, mourvedre, grenache, cinsault and viognier?


Magazine to Print Lost Stevenson Story
LEAD: An unpublished and nearly forgotten story by Robert Louis Stevenson will appear in the fall issue of the Georgia Review, the University of Georgia's literary magazine announced today.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. A citronella candle dripped melted wax onto the pressure-treated pine on our outside deck.
We have tried removing this stain, but so far nothing has worked.
Any suggestions?


Leading a Path to Nature and Its Restful Ways
LEAD: JEAN VERTEFEUILLE introduces people to the sight of blue herons, the feel of canoe paddles and the sound of silence.


HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
LEAD:  Here are some notable releases of the last few months.
Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.
Classical


Hello, Central. Get Me Stereo
LEAD: A well-appointed home once had its music room, usually containing one or two grand pianos. (A second piano was handy for playing duo-piano arrangements of symphonic scores, which used to be a popular pastime in musical households.) Later, as domestic space got tight, the music room contained a hi-fi system and maybe no piano at all.


23 Yachts Set Sail In Race's 2d Leg
LEAD: Twenty-three sleek monohull yachts from 13 countries set sail today on the rugged second leg of the 33,000-mile Whitbread Round the World Race.


Sound Coalition Filed No Suits
LEAD: As an organization committed to the protection of the Sound, the Long Island Sound Task Force welcomed the article ''The Sea That Unites Also Divides'' (Sept. 24).
We want to clarify a statement in the accompanying article, ''The Watch From the Shore: A Who's Who for Long Island Sound,'' that the Connecticut Coastal Coalition, of which the task force is a member, has taken legal action against municipalities.

Condemned to Poverty
LEAD: To the Editor:


Dancing to a Revolutionary Beat
LEAD: Maguy Marin, considered one of France's most audacious young choreographers, has always gone her own way, and never the same way twice.
In her latest work, ''Hey, What's All This to Me!?'' (''Eh, Qu'est Ce Que Ca M'Fait a Moi!?''), an abrasive rock musical about the French Revolution, Miss Marin shows that the glut of bicentennial reverence has not slowed her down.


Mediation Can Aid Children in Divorce
LEAD: Janice Cohn and Gary Skoloff are certainly on the right track (''Children Can Survive a Divorce,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 24) when they say that non-adversarial settings afford parents an opportunity to constructively consider the needs of their children instead of fighting over them in a courtroom.


The Road From Pulpit to Prison
LEAD: Jim Bakker, the television evangelist, apparently had no intention of waiting for the afterlife to get his taste of the good life.
With his PTL ministry bringing in $100 million a year at its peak, the boyish Mr.
Bakker indulged in expensive homes, cars and companionship, mostly with his ministry's money.


One Goal, Two Styles in New York City: Family Lunch
LEAD: TO INCLUDE THEIR YOUNG SON AS MUCH as possible in their lives, Martine and Jean-Michel Bergougnoux entertain en famille -for lunch usually, and in ways that allow Edouard, now 4, to take a small but active role.
In New York just three years, they like to share the personal, low-key pleasures of French home cooking with new American friends.


CAMPUS LIFE: Michigan; Marshmallows Are Added To List of Missiles
LEAD: The University of Michigan athletics department is taking action against marshmallows and students in wolverine costumes.
After receiving complaints from fans, the school has added marshmallows to the list of items prohibited in the 101,701-seat Michigan Stadium.


Woody as Rabbi
LEAD: To the Editor:


Faulty Metal in a Part Is Blamed for Iowa Jet Crash
LEAD: Government investigators have concluded that a manufacturing flaw caused the crack in an engine fan assembly that brought about the crash of the United Airlines jet over Iowa last July.


Question Of the Week; Should The Series Have Been Called Off?
LEAD: Only if a portion of revenues from the gate, the concessions, the salaries and the media is donated to relief, should the Series go on.
STEPHEN R. TOBER  Portsmouth, N.H.

LEAD: It's been said, by Woody Allen, I think, that if you do comedy, you don't sit at the grown-ups' table.
If you do animals, you may not even get into the house - and with reason.

CRACK AND RACIAL TENSIONS
LEAD: Thank you for showing me just how easy it is to produce and smoke crack.
Your simple, step-by-step instructions make an excellent primer for any first-time crack user.
The ''recipe'' and how-to-smoke instructions were great.
The only thing missing was a map of the neighborhoods where crack is bought most easily.

C.
Frampton Chowenhill of Chappaqua, N.Y.
A December wedding is planned.

LEAD: The tailback J. J. Flannigan and the quarterback Darian Hagan each rushed for more than 100 yards and Colorado's defense stifled Oklahoma today to give the Buffaloes a 20-3 victory, their first over the Sooners in 12 years.

Angolan Resists U.S. Effort on Peace Talks
LEAD: Angola will not soften its attitude to rebels because of pressure from Washington, the Angolan President, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, said today.


The Muted Beauty of November
LEAD: NOVEMBER is a beautiful month.
October gets all the attention because every hill and valley and suburban street is ablaze with autumn color, but November has its own charm.


Reaction Is Mixed On Court Security
LEAD: TOUGH new security measures in use at the Hudson County Administration Building in Jersey City are drawing mixed reactions from county employees, lawyers and visitors to the busy nine-story structure that contains the courtrooms and offices of 21 State Superior Court judges.


Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race
LEAD: THE last two times out, Denis Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, ran for re-election unopposed.
This time, he is being challenged more by his own record as a staunch antiabortionist than anything else.


Further Delay Urged for New Mexico Nuclear Waste Dump
LEAD: An already delayed underground nuclear-waste dump in New Mexico, which the Energy Department now hopes to open by 1992 to end a crisis in plutonium disposal, should be delayed two or three more years to insure proper safety testing, a panel of advisers has told the department.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Whalers 1, Bruins 0: Mike Liut posted his second successive shutout and the 22d of his National Hockey League career last night in Boston as Hartford edged the Bruins on Scott Young's third-period goal.
Liut, first among active goaltenders in shutouts, made 28 saves to win a goaltending duel with Boston's Reggie Lemelin, who had to make only 17.

LEAD: While most nonprofit groups struggle to maintain their services, several liberal advocacy groups have had to deal with a different problem: how to manage phenomenal growth.

LEAD: THE police and citizens here have had many violent clashes over the years, but the city had never held hearings on police brutality until last month, when a group of black politicians asserted that brutality was increasing.


Court Rejects Plea for Abortion Before Jail
LEAD: A county judge has refused a woman's request to postpone her 60-day jail sentence so she can have an abortion first.

LEAD: In less than three months in office, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has performed calisthenics on National Fitness Day, given speeches endorsing the cause of consumers and generally tried to project an image of renewal and stability in the Government.

LEAD: Thursday night at the Knitting Factory, the only palm trees in sight were printed on the singers' shirts.
But the four Jolly Boys, who are graying, brought with them the casual atmosphere of the Jamaican resort beach at Port Antonio, where they serenade tourists and residents under the Caribbean sun.

Martin J. Margolin of Great Neck, was married yesterday to Dr.
Simon Cheirif, a son of Rachel Cheirif-Kuriansky of Mexico City, and the late Benito Cheirif.

LEAD: SOMEBODY somewhere must want to buy a dismantled 18th-century tavern, move an early 19th-century Greek Revival house or help solve the problems of a 1933 International Style prefabricated home.
That is the idea that led the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation to start its Historic Properties Exchange.

Frank F. Blaisdell, Mayor, 76
LEAD: Frank F. Blaisdell, a former mayor of Middletown Township in New Jersey and longtime business and community leader in Red Bank, N.J., died at his home Thursday after a long illness.
He was 76 years old.

LEAD: A Northeast Notebook item on Oct. 15 about redevelopment in Winthrop, Me., misidentified the former variety store that was moved.
It was Wilson's, not Grant's.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

Old and New Guard Aim to Narrow Gap
LEAD: Paul Tagliabue stood at a lectern at a hotel in Cleveland three days ago and was scrutinized from his first answer to his last.
He had just been voted commissioner of the National Football League after a seven-month search.
The league's 28 owners had named a man from within, one they considered their own.


Question Box
LEAD:  Series Surprises  Q. No team has ever reached the World Series with a losing record during the regular season, but has there ever been a Series in which both teams had losing records the year before they won their pennants?
A.
Never before baseball's first expansion in 1961, only once before the league championship series format was set up in 1969 and only once more since then.


Don't Play Games With Water Quality
LEAD: After this year's spring rains, New Yorkers put aside worries about the quantity of their water supply and started debating its quality.
For 150 years, the city's supply has been coming from what was sparsely settled countryside.

Irish 'Peace Trains' Halted by Bomb Threat
LEAD: Two ''peace trains'' that were formed to protest Irish Republican Army bomb attacks on the Dublin-Belfast rail link have been halted by a bomb threat.


Review/Television; 'Barging Through Europe,' a 3-Part Series
LEAD: As a series, WNET's ''Travels'' is based on a promising idea: take trips to places, familiar or a bit exotic, with travelers who will put their own personal spin on the experience.
Travelogues in living color have long been one of television's stronger suits.
But ''Travels'' is not content to let the cameras do most of the work.


Brush Fire Near Los Angeles Blackens Thousands of Acres
LEAD: A wind-whipped blaze roared through brush and canyon country overlooking the Pacific Ocean today, charring 4,000 acres, destroying one home and forcing more than 2,000 campers to flee, officials said.

LEAD: In a pessimistic assessment of trade prospects, the Bush Administration said Friday that it was unclear that the trade deficit could be shrunk further and warned that it might grow next year.

Corrections
LEAD: An article last Monday about plans by the Department of Housing and Urban Development to remove Puerto Rico from the jurisdiction of the department's New York regional office described the 1987 management of the agency's moderate-rehabilitation program incompletely.

LEAD: ''The leading role of the party will remain.

I was portrayed by an actor named Ed Flanders.
My wife fell out of her chair laughing.
I did not think it was particularly funny.

Corrections
LEAD: A chart on the Business Technology page on Oct. 18 about new computer chips referred incorrectly to products of the MIPS Company.
The company's R4000 chip has not yet been announced; MIPS executives said the company had not backed away from a design strategy known as ''superscalar execution,'' which lets a computer execute more than one instruction in a tick of the quartz crystal clock that governs the chip's speed.


Capital Ties Murder Record
LEAD: The District of Columbia matched its year-old record for homicides today with five killings in a seven-hour period that pushed this year's total to 369 killings.
Three of the weekend killings were linked to drugs, as are most of the slayings in the nation's capital.
The police said at the end of 1988 that homicides took 372 lives that year, but three victims of police shootings were subtracted from the total Sunday.

Nuclear Plant Remains Shut
LEAD: A problem with a cooling system at the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear-power plant will keep the plant from reopening on schedule, plant officials said today.
The plant was shut down almost two weeks ago when a malfunction was discovered in its electronic system.
It was being brought back on line late last week when a problem with the cooling system was discovered, said Robert Burtch, a spokesman for Niagara Mohawk, a co-owner of the plant.

LEAD: In a decision that is likely to upset some state and local government officials, the Financial Accounting Foundation voted 12 to 2 yesterday to require government-owned utilities, hospitals, colleges and universities to base their accounting decisions on standards set by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, not its sister organization, the Governmental Accounting Standards Board.


Justice Dept. Approves Timing of Vote on New York Charter
LEAD: The Justice Department yesterday gave its approval to the timing of the referendum next week on the revised New York City Charter.
But the department also said it was unlikely that the agency would complete its review of the substance of the proposal by Election Day.

LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-17  Soviet price increases were called for on cigarettes, beer and food delicacies.
Officials said prices will be set by the market on some other products next year.

Israel Spira, 99, Leader of Bluzhov Hasidim
LEAD: Rabbi Israel Spira, who as the Grand Rabbi of Bluzhov was the spiritual leader of a Hasidic branch in Brooklyn and Israel, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn.
He was 99 years old and lived in Brooklyn's Borough Park section, where his synagogue was situated.


A's Earn Record $117,580.29 Shares
LEAD: None of the eligible members of the champion Oakland Athletics were among the 18 first-day filers for free agency yesterday, but they became wealthier anyway, gaining a record winning share from the World Series.


Sotheby's to Break Up a Robert Sketchbook
LEAD: A decision by Sotheby's in London to break up one of two surviving sketchbooks by Hubert Robert, a leading French artist of the 18th century, has provoked criticism among some historians of French art and has prompted the resignation of a consultant to the auction house.


Creditors and Eastern Seen Near Accord
LEAD: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines are close to backing management's ambitious plan to rebuild the bankrupt carrier, two people involved in the creditors' meetings said yesterday.


John Beckman Is Dead; Designer of Sets Was 91
LEAD: John Beckman, who designed the sets for ''Casablanca'' and other films and for the television series ''Designing Women,'' died in his sleep on Wednesday.
He was 91 years old and lived in Sherman Oaks, Calif.


Tracking a New Drug From the Soil in Japan To Organ Transplants
LEAD: IN the unending quest for new pharmaceuticals, many companies have sent employees to the remotest areas of the globe to collect samples of soil and other natural products.
From these forays have come many drugs now used to treat infections, heart disease, arthritis, cancer and other ailments.


U.S. Birth Level Nears 4 Million Mark
LEAD: The number of babies born in the United States every year is edging toward four million, a level not reached since the baby boom in the 1950's.
Until recently, demographers thought that level would be out of reach until well into the 21st century.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has subjected John S.R.
Shad, its former chairman and now the head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, to tight limits on his dealings with the agency.

LEAD: THERE'S a commotion down in Al Carosi's basement.
It's coming from Derek, who is 13 years old, and Brendan, 9.
As their father, Mr.
Carosi wants them to pipe down.
But as the senior vice president for marketing at Hasbro Inc., the nation's largest toymaker, Mr.
Carosi is glad to hear it.

LEAD: The sandbagged bunkers and lookout towers of this American-built base rise in the heart of a broad valley with the greatest concentration of coca plants in the world, roamed by heavily armed drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas.


2 More Concert Guards Held
LEAD: Two Burns International Security guards at the Meadowlands Sports Complex were arrested today, bringing to nine the number of guards charged with assaulting patrons at a series of Grateful Dead rock concerts Oct. 11, 14 and 15.
Seven guards were arrested Friday night on charges of aggravated assault.


Genetic Links May Help Save Rhinos From Extinction
LEAD: IN a discovery that could be crucial to the survival of the black rhinoceros, scientists have found that different subspecies of the endangered animal are so genetically similar that they can interbreed.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Edberg Advances: Second-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden advanced easily in the first round of the Paris Open yesterday by beating Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 6-3.
Also advancing easily was Aaron Krickstein of the United States, seeded sixth, who beat Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, 6-1, 6-3.


Topics of The Times; Public Service, New and Old
LEAD: Young lawyers and law graduates who choose careers in public service can expect to earn only a fraction of the wages of those who serve private clients.
Some law schools and law firms have begun to recognize the need to address the growing pay gap through such measures as student loan forgiveness programs.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the resignation of Nigel Lawson as Chancellor of the Exchequer in Britain misidentified the editor of the magazine American Economist.
He is Michael Szenberg.


Investor Group Makes Offer To Buy Detroit Free Press
LEAD: A group of Michigan investors yesterday proposed to buy The Detroit Free Press for $68 million, just as the owner of the money-losing daily newspaper, Knight-Ridder Inc., was asking the Supreme Court for permission to merge the newspaper's business operations with those of its rival, The Detroit News.

LEAD: For the final premiere of their season, Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis have jointly choreographed a single work, ''Segue.''


Atoms Bound Together by Light
LEAD: RESEARCHERS at Harvard University and the Rowland Institute, a private research center in Cambridge, Mass., have discovered a way light can bind matter into molecules.
The scientists formed the ''optical molecules'' by using a previously unknown interaction detected accidentally while conducting other experiments.


Pilot of Crashed Jet Was Flying Too Low In Carrier Approach
LEAD: A Navy pilot attempting his first landing at sea was flying too low before his training jet crashed on the aircraft carrier Lexington, killing him and four others, the ship's captain said today.

LEAD: Monticello is one of the great works of American architecture, and one of the nation's most revered historical shrines.
Thomas Jefferson's home in Charlottesville is also a place in which you can buy earrings, glassware, key rings, jigsaw puzzles, T-shirts, plates, pillows, mugs, scarfs, bookends, neckties, cuff links, wastebaskets, candlesticks, silverware, place mats, cassette tapes, tote bags and cookie molds.

LEAD: Wieden &amp; Kennedy, a small agency in Portland, Ore., with a lofty creative reputation, yesterday won the trade advertising account of TV Guide.

LEAD: Louise Schmir Hay, chairman of the mathematics department at the University of Illinois at Chicago, died of cancer Saturday at West Suburban Hospital in Oak Park, Ill.
She was 54 years old and lived in Oak Park.


Quotron Is Set To Lay Off 400
LEAD: Quotron Systems Inc., the nation's leading provider or electronic stock quotes, said it would lay off 400 workers.
The company blamed the continued problems in the securities industry since the October 1987 stock market crash for the cutbacks.


Sonics Release Gaze

Gaze was expected to become the 12th man on the Sonics' roster, but a 6-10 center-forward, Scott Meents, who played at Illinois in 1986, got the roster spot.(

Drillers Seek Rich Energy Source At Site of Ancient Volcanic Blast
LEAD: IN the hope of verifying the existence of a vast reservoir of useful, nonpolluting energy, scientists are drilling into a dome of California rock where one of the most violent volcanic explosions in earth's history occurred.


Review/Television; America's 'Great Adventure,' World War I
LEAD: ''The Great War: 1918,'' tonight's episode of the estimable history series ''The American Experience,'' at 9 o'clock on Channel 49 and at 10 on Channel 13, gets its power from the newsreels of trench fighting in the last grim year of World War I. The straightforward if undistinguished narration, written by the producer Tom Weidlinger and read by Eric Sevareid, tells how the ebullience of the ill-trained young Americans marching to join the Allies in 1917 was transformed by the shock of combat.

Gateway to Volumes
LEAD: THOUSANDS of software titles are available for Compact Disk Read Only Memory, or CD-ROM.
Most of them are notable primarily for cramming vast amounts of arcane material onto a single 4.7-inch platter.
Although most CD-ROM applications are specialized, there are an increasing number of general interest CD-ROM titles that, for the right users, might justify the purchase of CD-ROM paraphernalia..


Pedro Vargas, a Mexican Singer And Film Performer, Is Dead at 85
LEAD: Pedro Vargas, who was known as ''the tenor of the Americas'' during a career that lasted more than 60 years, died of heart failure today at his home here.
He was 85 years old.
His eldest son, Pedro Jr., said he died in his sleep, and that he had been suffering for several years from diabetes and heart problems.

LEAD: Federal prison officials have agreed to accept as many as 800 state prison inmates in Pennsylvania to relieve crowding caused by the destruction of cellblocks in rioting last week at the Camp Hill prison, state and Federal officials said today.

LEAD: Quebecor Inc. of Montreal and the Maxwell Communication Corporation of Britain said today that they would merge their printing businesses in Canada and the United States to form North America's second-largest printer.

LEAD: The smell of suntan lotion sweetens the salt air in the ocean breezes.
Hot and blinding sunlight bounces from the blue water to the shell-pink stucco of the beachfront hotels.
The breaking waves muffle the rustle of swaying palm fronds.
Just like the travel brochures promise.

LEAD: Gerald Arpino's ''Viva Vivaldi'' sailed back into the Joffrey Ballet repertory over the weekend.
And the company's performance of the ballet on Sunday afternoon at City Center (131 West 55th Street) suggested why this has become a signature work for the Joffrey and for Mr.
Arpino.
Although ''Viva Vivaldi'' ends curiously, with a section led by two male soloists instead of the grand summary one might expect of a festive pure-dance piece of this sort, the ballet has moments in the spotlight for nearly everyone in the cast.

LEAD: Scarcely skipping a beat, the spring and summer fashion openings picked up yesterday in New York, just a few days after the Paris shows faded into memory.
Many audience members, as well as the trends, were the same on both sides of the Atlantic as the week opened: the jacket continues as key to spring dressing, fringe appears everywhere, bright colors are set off by neutral black, navy, white and beige, and hemlines frequently dip.

Giants Toughen Up in 2d Half and Jolt Vikings
LEAD: For almost the first 34 minutes of the game tonight, the Minnesota Vikings outclassed the Giants in every department.
Then, in the third quarter, the Giants' defense and kickoff team exploded with three big plays, and the Giants rolled to a 24-14 victory.
It did not come cheaply.
Phil Simms, the Giants' starting quarterback, lasted only six plays before he was sacked by Al Noga and knocked out of the game with a sprained right ankle.

LEAD: Another marathon came and went over the weekend, this one in Chicago, and it has still been more than five years since an American has finished a race of that distance under 2 hours 10 minutes.


Weisfield's Is Sold
LEAD: Ratners Group P.L.C. agreed to acquire the American specialty jewelry retailer Weisfield's Inc. for $50 a share, or $55 million.
Weisfield's operates 87 stores in nine states.
Weisfield's stock jumped $14, to $53, in over-the-counter trading.
Its 35.9 percent increase was the best of the day.

Her little brother, who likes bows and arrows, will be Robin Hood.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Poland Devalues Zloty
LEAD: Poland devalued the zloty today by 12.6 percent, continuing its drive to narrow a huge gap between the free-market and official rates for the currency.
The central bank set the new rate at 2,400 zloties to the United States dollar, compared with 2,098 on Friday, according to figures published by the Government newspaper Rzeczpospolita.


Margaret L. Alsina
LEAD: Margaret Lowenthal Alsina, a retired language teacher at the Allendale Columbia School in Rochester, died of a heart attack on Oct. 21 at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester.
She was 66 years old and lived in Rochester.


Supreme Court Roundup; Product-Liability Ruling Left Standing by Justices
LEAD: The Supreme Court today let stand one of the most far-reaching product-liability rulings ever issued by an American court.


ANOTHER BIG RALLY IN EAST GERMANY
LEAD: Chanting demands for everything from free elections to the ouster of the secret police, more than 300,000 East Germans marched around Leipzig's old center in what has become the major weekly ritual of the growing popular movement for change.


Corrections
LEAD: A music review on Wednesday about a piano recital by Norman Krieger at Alice Tully Hall misidentified a composer on the program.
He is Lowell Liebermann.


Ex-Head of MCA Unit Talks to Time Warner
LEAD: Irving Azoff, the former chairman of the MCA Music Entertainment Group, is expected to join Time Warner Inc. as head of his own record label in a joint venture arrangement, several industry executives said yesterday. which is the umbrella company for the record label, music publishing and amphi theatre operation.


TV Networks May Approve A Pool for Election Exit Polls
LEAD: The three major broadcast networks and the Cable News Network are expected to approve this week a plan to conduct joint exit polls and pool the information during national elections, beginning next year.
ABC News and CBS News, both of which want to control the pool, have offered competing plans, network news executives said yesterday.


The Spanish Victory: A Mandate for the Socialists
LEAD: After a tightly fought election in which business executives and bankers sided openly with the governing Socialist Party, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has won a mandate to continue modernizing Spain's economy in preparation for the creation of a single European market after 1992.


Father Thomas Oddo, Catholic Educator, 45
LEAD: The Rev.
Thomas Oddo, president of the University of Portland and a trustee at three other Roman Catholic institutions, was killed Sunday in an auto accident.
He was 45 years old.


One Top Soviet Editor Backs Another's Ouster
LEAD: The new editor of Pravda today defended President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's effort to oust the editor of Argumenty i Fakty, the country's most popular paper, saying that any editor who is a Communist must answer to the party even if his publication is ostensibly independent.


Suwalki Journal; In Poland's Hopeless Hog Picture, a Hopeful Spot
LEAD: In this land of limited meat and scarce though cherished kielbasa, few things would seem to offer a better growth opportunity than pigs.
And yet in the last three years stocks of hogs, Poland's principal livestock, fell from 22 million to fewer than 14 million.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''There is no business address in the world that has the same cachet as Rockefeller Center.


PATTERNS
LEAD:  The Tired Look


Rosario P. San Filippo, 90, Retired Surgeon
LEAD: Dr.
Rosario P. San Filippo, the retired director of surgery at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Friday at the medical center.
He was 90 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

Friend Turned Foe of Gandhi Is Gaining in Self-Assurance
LEAD: Vishwanath Pratap Singh stood on the veranda of his home here and described the disenchantment that he felt for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, whom he had served as Finance and Defense Minister and whom he hopes to unseat in national elections three weeks away.


Doctors Are Baffled By Rates For Cancer
LEAD: In the United States, the death rate from colon and rectal cancer is highest along an arc from Maine to Iowa, say Government researchers, who are puzzled by the finding.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Dun &amp; Bradstreet Corp. said its Erisco unit had bought data bases and other assets of Managed Health Care Services.
Terms were not disclosed.


Three for the City Council
LEAD: Only 3 of the New York City Council's 35 members face more than token opposition in the election next Tuesday.
That's what often happens in heavily Democratic New York; winning the primary is almost always tantamount to election.
The proposed revision of the City Charter, which would expand the Council and give it some real power, might change that.


Review/Opera; Handel's 'Caesar,' Updated Into Musical Comedy
LEAD: Because Handel's Italian operas were written in a Baroque form that was already outmoded in his lifetime, companies feel justified in bending them into shapes that the modern-day operagoer may easily recognize.
Typically, the scores are drastically cut and/or their numbers shifted around in hopes of sharpening dramatic points.

Dodge City Journal; Soviets Find Friendship In a Historic Cow Town
LEAD: When a Soviet delegation led by a top adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union expressed the desire to meet ''real Americans,'' Senator Bob Dole arranged to give them a taste of the Old West mixed with some Western-style democracy.


Foolish, and Thuggish, in Nicaragua
LEAD: The only positive thing to be said about the assault on peace by Nicaragua's President, Daniel Ortega, is the universal storm of outrage it instantly provoked.
That storm may, as soon as today, force him to back down from his re-declaration of war against the contras.
But even if he does, his bellicosity threatens the Nicaraguan election campaign just under way.


COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: Revco D.S.
Inc., the bankrupt pharmacy chain, received a $925 million buyout offer 10 days ago from the Robert M. Bass Group and Acadia Partners.


Two Plead Not Guilty In Shooting of Officers
LEAD: Two brothers pleaded not guilty today to the attempted murder of two Essex County police officers who wandered into what authorities said was a drug-related shootout.

Dangerous Delusions: When Fans Are a Threat
LEAD: INTENSE public attention on the lives of the famous is leading an increasing number of mentally disordered people to place celebrities at the center of delusions that can lead to harassment and occasionally to violence, psychiatrists say.


Spinal Surgery
LEAD: A University of Mississippi player remained in critical condition in Memphis after five hours of spinal surgery yesterday, and doctors said it was unlikely he would regain the use of his arms and his legs.


Kean's Popularity Is Little Help to Courter
LEAD: The popularity of New Jersey's best-known Republican, Gov.
Thomas H. Kean, has been of little help this fall to his own party and its candidate for governor, Representative Jim Courter.


Shuttle Crew Completes a Practice Launching
LEAD: A team of five astronauts successfully concluded a practice countdown today for a November launching of the space shuttle Discovery on a secret military mission.


DEALS

Joseph Beruh, 65, Dies; A Theatrical Producer
LEAD: Joseph Beruh, a theatrical producer whose shows included ''Godspell,'' ''The Magic Show'' and ''American Buffalo,'' died in his sleep on Monday, apparently of a heart attack.
He was 65 years old.


U.N. Funds Sought by President Again Facing Cuts in Congress
LEAD: Against President Bush's wishes, Congress is planning to withhold money owed the United Nations this year for the fifth year running.


Rediscovering the Lost Crops of the Incas
LEAD: HALF a millennium ago in the Andes, on the eve of the Spanish conquest, the Incas created an agricultural wonderland.
On irrigated mountainside terraces along the spine of South America, they cultivated an estimated 70 species of crops, almost as many as the farmers of Europe and Asia combined.


53d St. Group Tries to Help Homeless Closest to Home
LEAD: Many civic associations take on projects that produce quick, visible results, like increased police protection, cleaner streets or new trees.

New York to Drop Ban On Private AIDS Tests
LEAD: New York, the only state to prohibit testing for the AIDS virus by commercial laboratories, said today that it would lift the ban.


Court Review Set in LTV Pension Case
LEAD: The Supreme Court today agreed to review a case that could affect the solvency of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the troubled Federal agency that Congress set up 15 years ago to guarantee the security of employee pensions.


Nynex's Debt Under Review
LEAD: The debt rating of the Nynex Corporation and related entities has been placed under review for possible downgrading, the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation said yesterday.
The review affects about $7.7 billion in outstanding debt.


Reports of Needle Attacks on West Side Rise to 23
LEAD: Sixteen additional women have reported that a group of teen-age girls struck them from behind with a needle or pin on walks last week on the Upper West Side, the police said yesterday.


Rangers Have Depth Misperception
LEAD: The notion had surfaced even before the season began: The Rangers, decent but not deep in talent, were a couple of critical injuries away from serious trouble.


Dollar Takes Its Cue From Stocks
LEAD: Something different is happening in the foreign exchange market.
In a reversal of the recent pattern, the dollar is being led around by the stock market.


Miller to Market Non-Alcohol Beer
LEAD: In another sign of sluggish sales for the beer industry, the Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee said it plans to sell a beer-flavored alcohol-free beverage.
The nation's No. 2 brewer, after the Anheuser-Busch Companies, said it would begin selling the drink, Miller Sharp's, on Jan. 1.


Bridge
LEAD: The members of Congress who played last Thursday in the first match between the Senate and the House of Representatives are now looking forward to their next match.
They are to play Feb. 23 in London against the British Parliament, and will be seeking to avenge two previous defeats.

Thomas Noyes, 67, Broadway Producer and Newspaperman
LEAD: Thomas Ewing Noyes, a Broadway producer who later became a reporter and an editorial writer and a radio commentator, died of heart disease on Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington.
He was 67 years old.


Hercules Analyzes Unit
LEAD: Hercules Inc. said today that it was assessing the future of the Aircraft and Electronic Products part of its Hercules Aerospace Company as part of its shift in strategic direction.
Hercules said it engaged the First Boston Corporation to analyze the business and help determine the best course of action.


Bush's Acid Test
LEAD: President Bush's much-ballyhooed clean air proposals took a beating in a House committee but he still can push his innovative acid-rain program through Congress - if he throws the full weight of his Administration and his own prestige behind it.


Gag That Man!
LEAD: Some of those people in Washington really have their nerve.


Beathard Is the Man Jets Need
LEAD: If the Jets lose in New England next Sunday for a 1-8 record, they will have sunk to the depths of the worst start in their 30-year history.
But even if they somehow were to avert that embarrassment, it's time for the Jets' owner, Leon Hess, to acknowledge that three heads are not better than one.


Bush Asked to Oust Wall
LEAD: The chairman of the House Banking Committee has asked President Bush to dismiss M. Danny Wall, the nation's top Federal regulator of savings and loan associations, because of Mr.
Wall's handling of the failure of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.
