NEW EVIDENCE SEEN IN PAN AM ATTACK
LEAD: Investigators in Europe have uncovered evidence and testimony linking a radical Palestinian faction to the December 1988 bombing of a Pan Am flight over Lockerbie, Scotland, United States Government officials said today.


Piniella and Quinn Meet About Reds Job
LEAD: Lou Piniella, the former Yankee outfielder and manager, said last night that he had met earlier in the day in Ohio with Bob Quinn, the Cincinnati general manager, about the Reds' managerial vacancy. ''The Reds have permission to talk to me, and I met with Quinn today,'' Piniella said after returing to his Allendale, N.J.


6 Detained Americans Freed by Mozambique
LEAD: Six American members of a missionary medical team seized by soldiers last week were released today, United States officials said.


Japanese Buy New York Cachet With Deal for Rockefeller Center
LEAD: The Rockefeller Group, the owner of Rockefeller Center, Radio City Music Hall and other mid-Manhattan office buildings, said yesterday that it had sold control of the company to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo, one of the world's biggest real estate developers.


On TV, Fiction Blurs Fact
LEAD: The urge to dramatize news events is leading television down two dangerous paths.
One is the familiar docudrama, a blend of drama and documentary like ABC's ''The Final Days,'' shown Sunday.
The other is the re-enactment or simulation of news events on news programs.
The minimum remedy - a foghorn-blast warning to viewers that fact and fiction are being blended - may make docudramas palatable.


Kateb Yacine, Novelist And Poet, Is Dead at 60
LEAD: Kateb Yacine, a leading Algerian novelist, poet and playwright, died of leukemia on Saturday in Grenoble, France.
He was 60 years old.


Copper Prices Off Sharply On Fears of Larger Supply
LEAD: Copper futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange, extending the market's two-week-old slide amid new selling prompted by a continued easing of supply fears.

Bellevue Jury Rejects Plea Of Insanity
LEAD: A Manhattan jury, rejecting the insanity defense of Steven Smith, convicted the 24-year-old homeless man yesterday of robbing, raping and murdering Dr.
Kathryn Hinnant in her office in Bellevue Hospital on Jan. 7.


White House to Limit Job Screening
LEAD: The Bush Administration will not use anti-abortion views as a test for screening job candidates except for people being considered for the Government's top health policy jobs, the White House said today.


The Trident Boondoggle
LEAD: A common-sense pillar of U.S. strategic policy over the years has been that our nuclear weapons planning and arms control goals should be consistent.
In that respect, the Trident submarine program is a bafflement.
By pursuing it full bore, we are ignoring our goals for a strategic arms agreement and committing to buying billion-dollar submarines that we may be forced to dismantle in a few years.


Traffic Alert
LEAD: Because of the Village Halloween Parade, Broadway between 14th and 23d Streets will be closed tonight from 6 to 11, as will Fifth Avenue between 14th and 23d Streets.
The Avenue of the Americas will be closed between Houston and 14th Streets from 5 P.M. to 11 P.M.


Hundreds of Demonstrators Encircle K.G.B. Headquarters in Moscow


Gilbert in Masters
LEAD: Brad Gilbert, ranked fifth in the world and the winner of five tournaments in 1989, is the fourth player to qualify for the eight-player Masters Championships, Nov. 28-Dec. 3 at the Garden.
Gilbert, who is in fourth place in the Nabisco Grand Prix standing, joins Ivan Lendl, Boris Becker, and Stefan Edberg.


Chinese Seeking to Avoid Reduction of Debt Rating
LEAD: Chinese state bankers said today that there was no reason for China's international credit rating to be diminished and expressed confidence over the country's ability to repay its mounting debts.
According to the latest official figures, China's debts totaled $40 billion at the end of 1988.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Oct. 14 about the nation's 10 largest guard companies misidentified the fifth-largest.
It is American Protective Services Inc.

Neil H. G. Green, 66, An Executive of Nestle
LEAD: Neil Harold George Green, senior vice president of finance and treasurer of Nestle Holdings Inc., died on Sunday at his home in Jackson, Miss.
The cause of death was not released.
He was 66 years old.


Pactel's Damage Is Over $40 Million
LEAD: Pacific Telesis Group, one of the nation's seven regional telephone companies, said that the Oct. 17 earthquake in nothern California had caused $40 million to $50 million in damage to its buildings and network facilities.
Pactel, based in San Francisco, said most of the damage would be covered by a $150 million earthquake insurance policy that it carries.


Communication Center Names New Chairman
LEAD: Burton B. Staniar, chairman and chief executive officer of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company (Group W), has been named chairman of the Center for Communication.


Fire Kills 60-Year-Old Woman
LEAD: A 60-year-old woman who apparently had been smoking in bed was killed today when her bedroom became engulfed in flames, the authorities said.
The woman, Nancy Sterback, was dead when firefighters arrived to put out the 4:30 A.M. fire.
About 20 years ago, another person died in a fire in the same room, Chief David Russell said.


Shun 'Backwater of Oppression,' Nixon Tells China
LEAD: Former President Richard M. Nixon urged China today not to sink into a ''backwater of oppression and stagnation'' and called on both the United States and China to strive for cooperation to overcome the present bitterness in their relationship.


Merrill Ends Index Arbitrage
LEAD: Merrill Lynch &amp; Company, the nation's largest retail brokerage, said yesterday that it would abandon its business in index arbitrage, the best-known form of program trading.


As Oratory Fades, Obstacles to Chemical Arms Pact Multiply
LEAD: One month after President Bush proposed from a United Nations podium that the United States and Soviet Union begin to slash their stockpiles of poison gas, his initiative has run into political and technological obstacles.


Give Us Biomedical Research, Not Bombs
LEAD: To the Editor:


Market Place; Individuals Stay Unafraid of Stocks
LEAD: SMALL investors, far from being scared by market volatility, seem to see it as an opportunity this year.
Some mutual fund managers said yesterday that there was a net flow of cash into funds in October, when the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 190 points in a single day.

LEAD: Murray Levy, a clothing manufacturer and philanthropist, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Rye, N.Y.
He was 77 years old.


Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker
LEAD: The long history of migrant labor in America's orchards and fields has been a chronicle of debt, dependency and fear.
Now the discovery of a written record of degradation and servitude among sweet potato pickers at a farm near here has demonstrated anew how little the lives of migrant workers have changed.

LEAD: Nora Levin, founder of the Holocaust Oral History Archive at Gratz College and author of ''The Holocaust: The Destruction of European Jewry, 1933-1945,'' died of cancer on Thursday at American Oncological Hospital in Philadelphia.
She was 73 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

LEAD: A harsh retribution has been visited upon the people of Nkqokqweni.
They have been beaten, detained, deported and have seen their homes bulldozed to rubble, all because they believe that they belong to South Africa.

Fatal Car Accident Shuts Bridge in Queens
LEAD: The North Channel Bridge, which connects the Rockaways peninsula with the mainland of Queens, was closed for five hours yesterday morning after a fatal car accident left oil contaminated with a toxic chemical on the road, the police said.


U.S.-Soviet Citizen Forum: Fewer Rifts Now
LEAD: Soviet and American citizens celebrated the improvement in relations between their two nations today as they met here for their fifth annual exercise in people-to-people diplomacy.
But the occasion was marred by American concern about a Soviet editor who was not allowed to attend.


Nearly Complete Tyrannosaur Skeleton Found
LEAD: THE most complete skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex ever found has been uncovered in the badlands of eastern Montana.
Paleontologists expect the fossilized bones to give them a much clearer picture of the anatomy of the fierce-looking carnivore that, in the popular imagination at least, epitomizes the great dinosaurs.

Despite Scorn, Team in Utah Still Seeks Cold-Fusion Clues
LEAD: THE euphoria and wild claims about a ''cold fusion'' power source are long gone.
So is the gold-rush fever over the hope of turning a table-top apparatus into a font of nearly limitless energy and profit.
It's even hard to find the T-shirts and bumper stickers that entrepreneurs once peddled around town to celebrate the finding.
